translation: The wise one, unmoved by the celestial beings such as gods, seers, and ancestors, should abandon sharp and cruel substances for themselves; they should employ mild medicines found in ghee, butter, and similar substances. They must conduct rituals like worship, offerings, application of mantras and other religious practices as prescribed by the Vedas. Furthermore, they should follow rules, regulations, and expiatory actions as stated in the Vedas for the purposes of peace, propitiation, and fire sacrifices; also included are recitation, well-being, and other observances.

sloka: bhūtānāmadhipaṃ devamīśvaraṃ jagataḥ prabhum|  pūjayan prayato nityaṃ jayatyunmādajaṃ bhayam||91||
translation: Worshiping daily with devotion the lord of all beings, the god of the gods, the ruler of the universe, the imperishable one, one conquers the delusion and fear that arises from intoxication.

sloka: rudrasya pramathā nāma gaṇā loke caranti ye|  teṣāṃ pūjāṃ ca kurvāṇa unmādebhyaḥ pramucyate||92||
translation: Those who in the world wandering are known as Rudra's attendants, by performing their worship, one is freed from delusion.

sloka: balibhirmaṅgalairhomairoṣadhyagadadhāraṇaiḥ|  satyācāratapojñānapradānaniyamavrataiḥ||93||  devagobrahmaṇānāṃ ca gurūṇāṃ pūjanena ca|  āgantuḥ praśamaṃ yāti siddhairmantrauṣadhaistathā||94||
translation:
With auspicious offerings, medicines, and the careful handling of holy plants,
And through truthfulness, right conduct, austerity, knowledge, and the giving of alms,
As well as through self-control and vows, one can appease uninvited guests
With the help of powerful mantras and healing herbs. (93-94)

sloka: yaccopadekṣyate kiñcidapasmāracikitsite|  unmāde tacca kartavyaṃ sāmānyāddhetudūṣyayoḥ||95||
translation: That which is indicated as a treatment for epilepsy should certainly be done, having understood the cause; this is the general rule for remedy and deterrent.

sloka: nivṛttāmiṣamadyo yo hitāśī prayataḥ śuciḥ|  nijāgantubhirunmādaiḥ sattvavān na sa yujyate||96||
translation: One who has abandoned meat and alcohol, is benevolent, diligent, and pure; who is free from hypocrisy and guided by truthfulness; such a self-controlled person of noble character is not fit to be associated with.

sloka: prasādaścendriyārthanāṃ buddhyātmamanasāṃ tathā|  dhātūnāṃ prakṛtisthatvaṃ vigatonmādalakṣaṇam||97||
translation: The grace of sense objects is due to the discriminative power of the intellect and the mind; similarly, the inherent nature of the elements is devoid of delusion.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  unmādānāṃ samutthānaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ sacikitsitam|  nijāgantunimittānāmuktavān bhiṣaguttamaḥ||98||
translation: In that regard, the characteristic of intoxication's emergence is skillfully diagnosed by the best physician through its external causes, having been released from their own.

sloka: athātaḥ pramehacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1|| iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now, we shall explain the science of determining the self (pramā). Thus spoke the revered Ātreyah.

sloka: nirmohamānānuśayo nirāśaḥ punarvasurjñānatapoviśālaḥ|  kāle'gniveśāya sahetuliṅgānuvāca mehāñśamanaṃ ca teṣām||3||
translation: Free from delusion and infatuation, devoid of attachment, dispassionate, and with vast knowledge and austerities, Vasu addressed me, seeking self-control and tranquility for them.

sloka: āsyāsukhaṃ svapnasukhaṃ dadhīni grāmyaudakānūparasāḥ payāṃsi|  navānnapānaṃ guḍavaikṛtaṃ ca pramehahetuḥ kaphakṛcca sarvam||4||
translation: The transient joy of eating food and the pleasure of sleep are originated from the combination of water from outside and liquids within the body; new digestion caused by eating and drinking, as well as the accumulation of kapha (phlegm), are all causes of diabetes.

sloka: medaśca māṃsaṃ ca śarīrajaṃ ca kledaṃ kapho bastigataṃ pradūṣya| karoti mehān samudīrṇamuṣṇaistāneva pittaṃ paridūṣya cāpi||5|| kṣīṇeṣu doṣeṣvavakṛṣya bastau dhātūn pramehānanilaḥ karoti|  doṣo hi bastiṃ samupetya mūtraṃ sandūṣya mehāñjanayedyathāsvam||6||
translation: The bile, mixed with fat and flesh in the body, produces inflammation when it vitiates them. Likewise, when the same is removed from the excreta after being located in the weakened bodily humors, it causes urine to flow and produce pus, as it naturally does.

sloka: sādhyāḥ kaphotthā daśa pittajāḥ ṣaṭ yāpyā na sādhyaḥ pavanāccatuṣkaḥ||  samakriyatvādviṣamakriyatvānmahātyayatvācca yathākramaṃ  te||7||
translation: The ten [daśa] Kapha-related [kapha utthāḥ sādhyāḥ] and six [ṣaṭ] Pitta-related [pitta jāḥ yāpyāḥ] disorders, which are curable [sādhyaḥ], as well as the four [catuṣkaḥ] related to Vata, which are not curable [na sādhyaḥ], should be treated in order [yathā kramam], according to their severity [samakriyatvāt viṣamakriyatvāt mahātyayatvāt ccā].

sloka: kaphaḥ sapittaḥ pavanaśca doṣā medo'sraśukrāmbuvasālasīkāḥ|  majjā rasaujaḥ piśitaṃ ca dūṣyāḥ[1] pramehiṇāṃ viṃśatireva mehāḥ||8||
translation: Of the twenty types of impurities, those that are salty, windy, bile-related, phlegm-related, sweat-related, urine-related, and excrement-related are the ones that taint [the bodies of] living beings.

sloka: jalopamaṃ cekṣurasopamaṃ vā ghanaṃ ghanaṃ copari viprasannam|  śuklaṃ saśukraṃ śiśiraṃ śanairvā lāleva vā vālukayā yutaṃ vā||9||  vidyāt pramehān  kaphajān daśaitān
translation: Like water or as clear as sugarcane juice, dense like a cloud, located above the priest, pure, seminal, and cool; gradually approaching like a crawling insect, combined with grains of pollen – learn of the ten qualities that pertain to kapha.

sloka: kṣāropamaṃ kālamathāpi nīlam|  hāridramāñjiṣṭhamathāpi raktametān pramehān ṣaḍuśanti pittāt||10||
translation: Like alkali, even in the present moment, time wears down; similarly, bile neutralizes the six causes of impure thoughts that are colored blue, yellow, or red.

sloka: majjaujasā vā vasayā'nvitaṃ vā lasīkayā vā satataṃ vibaddham|  caturvidhaṃ mūtrayatīha[1] vātāccheṣeṣu dhātuṣvapakarṣiteṣu||11||
translation:
Bound constantly, either by the power of lust, or by habit, or by irresponsible actions, a person releases four types of impurities into the elements of air, etc., that are in a state of withdrawal.

word level split: majja, ujasā, vā, vasayā, annvitaṃ, vā, lasīkayā, vā, satataṃ, vibaddham, caturvidhaṃ, mūtraya, iha, vāta, accheṣeṣu, dhātuṣu, apakarṣiteṣu.

sloka: varṇaṃ rasaṃ sparśamathāpi gandhaṃ yathāsvadoṣaṃ bhajate pramehaḥ|  śyāvāruṇo vātakṛtaḥ saśūlo majjādisādguṇyamupaityasādhyaḥ||12||
translation: Even the colorblind person enjoys taste, touch, and scent, just like a normal person; similarly, this incurable disease called "prameha" (possibly diabetes) affects a person with the combination of black and tawny colors, produced by wind, and endowed with the quality of marrow, etc.

sloka: svedo'ṅgagandhaḥ śithilāṅgatā ca śayyāsanasvapnasukhe ratiśca|  hṛnnetrajihvāśravaṇopadeho ghanāṅgatā keśanakhātivṛddhiḥ||13|| śītapriyatvaṃ galatāluśoṣo mādhuryamāsye karapādadāhaḥ|  bhaviṣyato mehagadasya rūpaṃ mūtre'bhidhāvanti pipīlikāśca||14||
translation: Perspiration, originating from the body, with its pleasant smell; relaxation of the limbs; lying down, sitting, sleeping in pleasure and delight; attraction to the sense objects of sight, taste, hearing; firmness of the body; growth of hair, nails, and complexion; coolness and lightness; bitterness, astringency, and dryness; sweetness on the tongue; burning sensation in the hands and feet; this is my future form as described in the Vedic hymns. Insects rush towards the sound of its utterance.

sloka: sthūlaḥ pramehī balavānihaikaḥ kṛśastathaikaḥ paridurbalaśca|  sambṛṃhaṇaṃ tatra kṛśasya kāryaṃ saṃśodhanaṃ doṣabalādhikasya||15||  snigdhasya yogā vividhāḥ prayojyāḥ kalpopadiṣṭā malaśodhanāya[1] | ūrdhvaṃ tathā'dhaśca male'panīte meheṣu santarpaṇameva kāryam||16||
translation: The gross element should be excited there (in the body), while the lean one should be cleansed; for the one with more impurities than strength, various yogic practices should be applied; and scraping should be done for the weak one. In the case of the lean one, activation is to be done. Additionally, in the upward and downward flow of impurities in the channels, retention alone is to be practiced.[1]

sloka: gulmaḥ kṣayo mehanabastiśūlaṃ mūtragrahaścāpyapatarpaṇena|  pramehiṇaḥ syuḥ paritarpaṇāni[2] kāryāṇi tasya[3] prasamīkṣya vahnim||17||
translation: For me, the digestive disorders such as bloating, indigestion, and constipation, as well as the urge to urinate, are all symptoms that need to be alleviated. By carefully considering this person's condition, one should determine and carry out the appropriate treatments for curing them, while observing the digestive fire (i.e., the bodily process of digestion).

sloka: saṃśodhanaṃ nārhati yaḥ pramehī tasya kriyā saṃśamanī prayojyā|
translation: One who is not fit for purification cannot have their actions subdued.

sloka: manthāḥ kaṣāyā yavacūrṇalehāḥ pramehaśāntyai laghavaśca bhakṣyāḥ||18|| ye viṣkirā ye pratudā vihaṅgāsteṣāṃ rasairjāṅgalajairmanojñaiḥ|  yavaudanaṃ rūkṣamathāpi vāṭyamadyāt[1] sasaktūnapi cāpyapūpān||19||  mudgādiyūṣairatha tiktaśākaiḥ purāṇaśālyodanamādadīta|  dantīṅgudītailayutaṃ pramehī tathā'tasīsarṣapatailayuktam||20||  saṣaṣṭikaṃ syāttṛṇadhānyamannaṃ yavapradhānastu bhavet pramehī|  yavasya bhakṣyān vividhāṃstathā'dyāt kaphapramehī madhusamprayuktān||21||
translation: "Barley grains, ground and processed into powder, mixed with liquids, promote urination and are light to digest. Similarly, the ancient dish made from rice, seasoned with various spices such as pepper and salt, or lentils, or a mix of bitter, astringent and pungent flavors, or a preparation of sesame seeds and jaggery, or a drink prepared from crushed licorice, or a porridge made from roasted barley flour, all help eliminate Kapha-related impurities. Additionally, various other dishes derived from barley can also be consumed."

sloka: niśisthitānāṃ triphalākaṣāye syustarpaṇāḥ kṣaudrayutā yavānām|  tān sīdhuyuktān prapibet pramehī prāyogikānmehavadhārthameva||22||
translation: Of the mature three-fruited tree (Pipal) that is steadfast, offering the twigs yoked with grains, one should drink those that are processed and infused with medicinal decoction, for the sole purpose of maintaining good health.

sloka: ye śleṣmamehe vihitāḥ kaṣāyāstairbhāvitānāṃ ca pṛthagyavānām|  saktūnapūpān saguḍān sadhānān bhakṣyāṃstathā'nyān vividhāṃśca khādet||23||
translation: Who, for those imbued with impurities, are prescribed to consume (by the scriptures) specific foods such as pungent, bitter, astringent tastes, grains, legumes, fruits and vegetables, as well as other varieties (not specified here).

sloka: kharāśvagohaṃsapṛṣadbhṛtānāṃ tathā yavānāṃ vividhāśca bhakṣyāḥ|  deyāstathā veṇuyavā yavānāṃ kalpena godhūmamayāśca bhakṣyāḥ||24||
translation: Of kharas, horses, and geese, that are fed, as well as various bhaksyas of barley, similarly of yavas; also, venus and barley given through the custom of godhuma.

sloka: saṃśodhanollekhanalaṅghanāni kāle prayuktāni kaphapramehān|  jayanti pittaprabhavān virekaḥ santarpaṇaḥ saṃśamano vidhiśca||25||
translation: In due course, the practices of purgation, emesis, and enema, which are properly used, give rise to the aggravation of bile, while alleviating phlegm-related ailments; this is the established method.

sloka: dārvīṃ surāhvāṃ triphalāṃ samustāṃ kaṣāyamutkvāthya pibet pramehī| kṣaudreṇa yuktāmathavā haridrāṃ pibedrasenāmalakīphalānām||26||
translation: One should drink the powder of triphala in a cup made from dārvī, mixed with kvāthya water, to eliminate sluggishness. Alternatively, one can also consume haridrā mixed with water or the juice of āmalakī fruits.

sloka: harītakīkaṭphalamustalodhraṃ pāṭhāviḍaṅgārjunadhanvanāśca| ubhe haridre tagaraṃ viḍaṅgaṃ kadambaśālārjunadīpyakāśca||27|| dārvī viḍaṅgaṃ khadiro dhavaśca surāhvakuṣṭhāgurucandanāni|  dārvyagnimanthau triphalā sapāṭhā pāṭhā ca mūrvā ca tathā śvadaṃṣṭrā||28|| yavānyuśīrāṇyabhayāguḍūcīcavyābhayācitrakasaptaparṇāḥ|  pādaiḥ kaṣāyāḥ kaphamehināṃ te daśopadiṣṭā madhusamprayuktāḥ||29||

uśīralodhrāñjanacandanānāmuśīramustā malakābhayānām|  paṭolanimbāmalakāmṛtānāṃ mustābhayāpadmakavṛkṣakāṇām||30|| lodhrāmbukālīyakadhātakīnāṃ nimbārjunāmrātaniśotpalānām| śirīṣasarjārjunakeśarāṇāṃ priyaṅgupadmotpalakiṃśukānām||31|| aśvatthapāṭhāsanavetasānāṃ kaṭaṅkaṭeryutpalamustakānām|  paitteṣu meheṣu daśa pradiṣṭāḥ pādaiḥ kaṣāyā madhusamprayuktāḥ||32||
sarveṣu meheṣu matau tu pūrvau kaṣāyayogau vihitāstu sarve|  manthasya pāne yavabhāvanāyāṃ syurbhojane pānavidhau pṛthak ca||33||
translation: In all my habits, the two earlier-prescribed austerities are established; in the contemplation of milk-consumption, there should be distinct rules for eating and drinking.

sloka: siddhāni tailāni ghṛtāni caiva deyāni meheṣvanilātmakeṣu|  medaḥ kaphaścaiva kaṣāyayogaiḥ snehaiśca vāyuḥ śamameti teṣām||34||
translation: To those who are capable, ghee and oil, too, should be given, derived from sesame and cow milk, for through the anointment with these, the bodily humors of phlegm and fat become balanced, and the wind is pacified.

sloka: kampillasaptacchadaśālajāni  baibhītarauhītakakauṭajāni|  kapitthapuṣpāṇi ca cūrṇitāni kṣaudreṇa lihyāt kaphapittamehī||35||  pibedrasenāmalakasya cāpi kalkīkṛtānyakṣasamāni kāle|  jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta purāṇamannaṃ mehī rasairjāṅgalajairmanojñaiḥ||36||
translation: Consume at an appropriate time fruits of the Kapitha tree, shaken from their stalks and split, cleaned with a small amount of water; also, bitter and astringent fruits that alleviate kapha and pitta imbalances. When they have aged, consume ancient grains, relishing their flavors and finding satisfaction in them.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā'nubandhaṃ pavanāt kaphasya pittasya vā snehavidhirvikalpyaḥ|  tailaṃ kaphe syāt svakaṣāyasiddhaṃ pitte ghṛtaṃ pittaharaiḥ kaṣāyaiḥ||37||
translation: Having seen the bondage of phlegm by air or the elimination of excess phlegm and pitta, oil should be used in cases of phlegm; when there is a need to pacify kapha dosha, clarified butter (ghrita) should be used in cases of pitta dosha.

sloka: trikaṇṭakāśmantakasomavalkairbhallātakaiḥ sātiviṣaiḥ salodhraiḥ|  vacāpaṭolārjunanimbamustairharidrayā[1] padmakadīpyakaiśca||38|| mañjiṣṭhayā cāgurucandanaiśca sarvaiḥ samastaiḥ kaphavātajeṣu|  meheṣu  tailaṃ vipaced ghṛtaṃ tu paitteṣu miśraṃ triṣu lakṣaṇeṣu||39||
translation: With licorice, aguru, and candana, along with all other remedies for phlegm and wind disorders, the oil is extracted in the first of the three descriptions. The ghee is churned separately in the other two.

sloka: phalatrikaṃ dāruniśāṃ viśālāṃ mustāṃ ca niḥkvāthya niśāṃ sakalkām|  pibet kaṣāyaṃ madhusamprayuktaṃ sarvaprameheṣu samuddhateṣu||40||
translation: Having extracted the ripe fruits from the trees and the large mustard seeds at night, one should drink the concoction made of kaṣāya herbs and honey in all ailments that manifest.

sloka: lodhraṃ śaṭīṃ puṣkaramūlamelāṃ mūrvāṃ  viḍaṅgaṃ triphalāṃ yamānīm|  cavyaṃ priyaṅguṃ kramukaṃ viśālāṃ kirātatiktaṃ kaṭurohiṇīṃ ca||41||  bhārṅgīṃ nataṃ citrakapippalīnāṃ mūlaṃ sakuṣṭhātiviṣaṃ sapāṭham|  kaliṅgakan keśaramindrasāhvāṃ nakhaṃ sapatraṃ maricaṃ plavaṃ ca||42||  droṇe'mbhasaḥ karṣasamāni paktvā pūte caturbhāgajalāvaśeṣe| rase'rdhabhāgaṃ madhunaḥ pradāya pakṣaṃ nidheyo ghṛtabhājanasthaḥ||43||
translation: The root of puṣkara, lodhrā, śaṭī, mūrvā, viḍaṅga, triphalā, yamānī, cavya, priyaṅgu, kramuka, and viśālā; the kirāta kind of kaṭurohṇī, bhārṅgī, natā, citraka, pippalīna's root, sakuṣṭha+tiṣa, pāṭha, kaliṅga keśara, indrasāhvā, nakha, marica, and plava; after cooking in four parts of pure water, drained of its water content, mixed with the top portion of honey, placed in a ghṛta bhājana - this is the method for preparing the medicinal paste.

sloka: madhvāsavo'yaṃ[1] kaphapittamehān kṣipraṃ nihanyāddvipalaprayogāt|  pāṇḍvāmayārśāṃsyaruciṃ grahaṇyā doṣaṃ kilāsaṃ vividhaṃ ca kuṣṭham||44||  iti madhvāsavaḥ|
translation:
This is Madhvasa's teaching: "Quickly destroy this Kaphapittameha[2] by using Dvipala's remedy. Also, eliminate the various disorders like Pandu, Arshas, and Kushta, as well as the Grahana Dosha."

[1] Madhvasa + asavaH: Here, 'asavaH' generally means 'disease' or 'intoxication', while 'Madhvasa' is a name of a teacher. The verse seems to be using 'Madhvasa' as an adjective (possessive) to specify that this teaching/opinion belongs to Madhvasa, the teacher.
[2] Kaphapittameha: A medical term referring to a disorder caused by the imbalance of Kapha and Pitta doshas in the body.

sloka: kvāthaḥ sa evāṣṭapalaṃ ca dantyā bhallātakānāṃ ca catuṣpalaṃ syāt|  sitopalā tvaṣṭapalā viśeṣaḥ kṣaudraṃ ca tāvat pṛthagāsavau tau||45||
translation: Where, indeed, can there be found both the eight-palamedean one and the four-ballistic one, when there are separate cups of sugar and ghee, and a small amount of ordinary liquid?

sloka: sārodakaṃ vā'tha kuśodakaṃ vā  madhūdakaṃ vā triphalārasaṃ vā|  sīdhuṃ pibedvā nigadaṃ pramehī mādhvīkamagryaṃ cirasaṃsthitaṃ vā||46||
translation: One may sip either pure water, or water mixed with kusha grass, or honey, or the extract of three fruits. This, indeed, leads to steadiness, quells excessive thirst and eliminates impurities.

sloka: māṃsāni śūlyāni mṛgadvijānāṃ khādedyavānāṃ vividhāṃśca bhakṣyān|  saṃśodhanāriṣṭakaṣāyalehaiḥ santarpaṇotthāñ śamayet pramehān||47||
translation: One who consumes the flesh of animals and birds, whether occasionally or regularly, should mitigate the resulting disturbance of the bodily humors with purifying and soothing substances.

sloka: bhṛṣṭān yavān bhakṣayataḥ prayogācchuṣkāṃśca saktūnna bhavanti mehāḥ|  śvitraṃ ca kṛcchraṃ kaphajaṃ ca kuṣṭhaṃ tathaiva mudgāmalakaprayogān||48||
translation: The consumption of insufficiently threshed barley makes one's urine thin, becomes rough and also causes rough husks to appear. Similarly, the use of mudga and āmalaka (types of pulses) can lead to conditions like skin disorders such as leprosy and other ailments associated with an imbalance of kapha (phlegm).

sloka: santarpaṇottheṣu gadeṣu yogā medasvināṃ ye ca mayopadiṣṭāḥ|  virūkṣaṇārthaṃ kaphapittajeṣu siddhāḥ prameheṣvapi te prayojyāḥ||49||
translation: In cases of inflammation, those yoga practices taught by me and suitable for the obese should be applied even in conditions related to phlegm and bile; they are accomplished and can be used in ailments.

sloka: vyāyāmayogairvividhaiḥ pragāḍhairudvartanaiḥ snānajalāvasekaiḥ| sevyatvagelāgurucandanādyairvilepanaiścāśu[1] na santi mehāḥ||50||
translation: With various advanced yoga practices, deep bows, and ablution with water, I am not easily angered when served regularly with sandalwood paste, etc., and the respectful attention of a teacher or guru.

sloka: kledaśca medaśca kaphaśca vṛddhaḥ pramehahetuḥ prasamīkṣya tasmāt|  vaidyena pūrvaṃ kaphapittajeṣu meheṣu kāryāṇyapatarpaṇāni||51||
translation: Perceiving that old age, exudation, and phlegm are its causes, the wise physician should first attend to eliminating the root of phlegm and bile-related ailments.

sloka: yā vātamehān prati pūrvamuktā vātolbaṇānāṃ vihitā kriyā sā|  vāyurhi meheṣvatikarśitānāṃ kupyatyasādhyān prati nāsti cintā||52||
translation: The wind that was previously ordained as the foremost action of the fierce ones, agitates those who are extremely weakened in their vital energies , [and] for that reason , there is no anxiety about the unattainable .

sloka: yairhetubhirye prabhavanti mehāsteṣu prameheṣu na te niṣevyāḥ|  hetorasevā vihitā yathaiva jātasya rogasya bhaveccikitsā||53||
translation: By what causes are these manifestations of mine present in the living beings, (but) not to be served; just as serving a doctor is prescribed for an already born disease.

sloka: hāridravarṇaṃ rudhiraṃ ca mūtraṃ vinā pramehasya hi pūrvarūpaiḥ|  yo mūtrayettaṃ na vadet pramehaṃ raktasya pittasya hi sa prakopaḥ||54||
translation: One who does not speak of pus/fluid resembling blood and urine, instead of the initial secretion (prior to ejaculation), brings on rage in semen, redness in eyes, and bile.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā pramehaṃ madhuraṃ sapicchaṃ madhūpamaṃ syāddvividho vicāraḥ|  kṣīṇeṣu doṣeṣvanilātmakaḥ syāt  santarpaṇādvā kaphasambhavaḥ syāt||55||
translation: Upon seeing a sweet and prized madhu-like diabetes mellitus, two considerations arise: when the wind-like symptoms weaken , it could indicate a reduction in dosha; alternatively, it may signify the emergence of kapha due to heightened feelings of attachment .

sloka: sapūrvarūpāḥ kaphapittamehāḥ krameṇa ye vātakṛtāśca mehāḥ| sādhyā na te pittakṛtāstu yāpyāḥ sādhyāstu medo  yadi na praduṣṭam||56||
translation: Those who are naturally constituted with a balanced constitution of phlegm and bile, and later influenced by wind-related disorders - their bile-related ailments can be treated, but not those caused by an increase in fat tissue, if it's not corrupted.

sloka: jātaḥ pramehī madhumehino vā na sādhya uktaḥ sa  hi  bījadoṣāt|  ye  cāpi  kecit  kulajā  vikārā  bhavanti  tāṃśca pravadantyasādhyān||57||
translation: Born or arising from a hereditary defect, whether as a minor or major issue, is declared unsolvable . Moreover, certain inheritable anomalies , if they manifest , are also classified as insoluble .

sloka: pramehiṇāṃ yāḥ piḍakā mayoktā rogādhikāre pṛthageva sapta|  tāḥ śalyavidbhiḥ kuśalaiścikitsyāḥ  śastreṇa saṃśodhanaropaṇaiśca||58||
translation: The seven diseases, pointed out by the expert [Pramehahara], as being particularly associated with an enlarged spleen and excess fluid, are to be skillfully treated with surgical methods such as excision and evacuation.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  heturdoṣo dūṣyaṃ mehānāṃ sādhyatānurūpaśca|  mehī dvividhastrividhaṃ[1] bhiṣagjitamatikṣapaṇadoṣaḥ||59|| ādyā yavānnavikṛtirmanthā mehāpahāḥ kaṣāyāśca|  tailaghṛtalehayogā bhakṣyāḥ pravarāsavāḥ siddhāḥ||60||  vyāyāmavidhirvividhaḥ snānānyudvartanāni gandhāśca|  mehānāṃ praśamārthaṃ cikitsite diṣṭametāvat||61||
translation: The first among the treatments for disorders of fluids is the appropriate use of foods and drinks, such as properly prepared barley and wheat, which eliminate impurities and excess water. Additionally, oils, ghee, soups, wholesome beverages, condiments, and spices are recommended for alleviating issues related to fluids.

sloka: athāto grahaṇīdoṣacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now, we shall explain the remedy for the faults of grasping ; grahani dosa cikitsitam ; we say this ; by the revered Atreya .

sloka: āyurvarṇo balaṃ svāsthyamutsāhopacayau prabhā|  ojastejo'gnayaḥ prāṇāścoktā dehāgnihetukāḥ||3||
translation: Longevity, complexion, strength, and health, as well as the digestive fire, are all mentioned as effects of the bodily agents.

sloka: śānte'gnau mriyate yukte ciraṃ jīvatyanāmayaḥ|  rogī syādvikṛte mūlamagnistasmānnirucyate||4||
translation: In a state of tranquility, one who is constantly united with the sacred fire meets an death free from disease; hence, they identify the root cause as the agni (fire) within.

sloka: yadannaṃ dehadhātvojobalavarṇādipoṣakam|  tatrāgnirheturāhārānna hyapakvādrasādayaḥ||5||
translation: When food is the nourisher of the physical constituents of the body, then fire is its cause, and the unripe or matured forms of food are its sustenance.

sloka: annamādānakarmā tu prāṇaḥ koṣṭhaṃ prakarṣati|  taddravairbhinnasaṅghātaṃ snehena mṛdutāṃ gatam||6||  samānenāvadhūto'gnirudaryaḥ pavanodvahaḥ|  kāle bhuktaṃ samaṃ samyak pacatyāyurvivṛddhaye||7||  evaṃ rasamalāyānnamāśayasthamadhaḥ sthitaḥ|  pacatyagniryathā sthālyāmodanāyāmbutaṇḍulam||8||
translation: The force of life expands the stomach by drawing in food that has been processed into a liquid form with a gentle motion . Similarly, the agent of digestion , situated in the stomach along with the water , digests food at the proper time to promote health and longevity . In the same way, the digestive fire cooks the grains that have been soaked in water , causing them to swell , within the container of the stomach . The taste and other qualities of food are also processed in this way for the nourishment of the body.

sloka: annasya bhuktamātrasya ṣaḍrasasya prapākataḥ|  madhurādyāt kapho bhāvāt phenabhūta  udīryate||9||
translation: The six tastes, once consumed and digested, produce phlegm due to the inherent quality of sweetness.

sloka: paraṃ tu pacyamānasya vidagdhasyāmlabhāvataḥ|  āśayāccyavamānasya pittamacchamudīryate||10||
translation: Indeed, for the discerning person who is tasting (examining) with a calm mind, the true nature of the bitter (harsh) behavior of another becomes apparent, revealing their hidden inner qualities.

sloka: pakvāśayaṃ tu prāptasya śoṣyamāṇasya vahninā|  paripiṇḍitapakvasya vāyuḥ syāt kaṭubhāvataḥ||11||
translation: For the cooked food that has become ready and is being dried by the heat of a fire, the air, becoming sharp like a knife, causes it to spoil.

sloka: annamiṣṭaṃ hyupahitamiṣṭairgandhādibhiḥ pṛthak|  dehe prīṇāti gandhādīn ghrāṇādīnīndriyāṇi ca||12||
translation: Food that is properly prepared and offered with fragrances and other enhancements pleases the senses through the respective organs in the body.

sloka: bhaumāpyāgneyavāyavyāḥ pañcoṣmāṇaḥ sanābhasāḥ|  pañcāhāraguṇānsvānsvānpārthivādīnpacanti hi||13||
translation: The five fires, namely the fire of the earth, water, Agni (digestive fire), Vayu (wind), and the sun, each with their own qualities, consume the offerings made to them; this is true for the fires starting from Pṛthvī (earth) to Indra.

sloka: yathāsvaṃ svaṃ ca puṣṇanti dehe dravyaguṇāḥ pṛthak|  pārthivāḥ pārthivāneva śeṣāḥ śeṣāṃśca kṛtsnaśaḥ||14||
translation: Just as distinct material elements and qualities within the body nourish their respective selves, similarly, some elements nourish other parts of the body in their entirety.

sloka: saptabhirdehadhātāro dhātavo dvividhaṃ punaḥ|  yathāsvamagnibhiḥ pākaṃ yānti kiṭṭaprasādavat ||15||
translation: The seven dhātāras (constituent principles of the body) are of two kinds, just as cooking ingredients combine, similarly, they too merge into the body like kiṭṭaprasāda (a type of cooked rice).

sloka: rasādraktaṃ tato māṃsaṃ māṃsānmedastato'sthi ca|  asthno majjā tataḥ śukraṃ śukrādgarbhaḥ prasādajaḥ||16||
translation: Derived from blood is the flesh, then follows fat; from fat comes bone, and from bones comes the marrow; from marrow, finally, arises the embryo, born of sustenance.

sloka: rasāt stanyaṃ tato raktamasṛjaḥ kaṇḍarāḥ sirāḥ|  māṃsādvasā tvacaḥ ṣaṭ ca medasaḥ snāyusambhavaḥ||17||
translation: Emerging from the fluid, next comes red blood; from flesh come muscles, tendons, and skin; six organs develop from fat.

sloka: kiṭṭamannasya viṇmūtraṃ rasasya tu kapho'sṛjaḥ|  pittaṃ māṃsasya khamalā malaḥ svedastu medasaḥ||18||  syātkiṭṭaṃ keśalomāsthno majjñaḥ sneho'kṣiviṭtvacām|  prasādakiṭṭe dhātūnāṃ pākādevaṃvidharcchataḥ ||19||  parasparopasaṃstabdhā dhātusnehaparamparā |
translation: Of the body, what are the byproducts of phlegm, mucus, bile, and flesh? What arises from the hair, skin, and bones, as well as the fluids within the joints and marrow? When they are properly combined, these constituents form a harmonious bond in the body, nourished by the internal fire that promotes their transformation. This is the natural process of bodily functions.

sloka: vṛṣyādīnāṃ prabhāvastu puṣṇāti balamāśu hi||20||
translation: Invigorates the strength of the herd animals in no time.

sloka: ṣaḍbhiḥ kecidahorātrairicchanti parivartanam|  santatyā bhojyadhātūnāṃ parivṛttistu cakravat||21||
translation: Some choose to undergo nourishment cycles in six days, while the cycle of consumption of nutrients for all occurs continuously, like a wheel.

sloka: (ityuktavantamācāryaṃ śiṣyastvidamacodayat|  rasādraktaṃ visadṛśāt kathaṃ dehe'bhijāyate||22||  rasasya ca na rāgo'sti sa kathaṃ yāti raktatām|  dravādraktātsthiraṃ māṃsaṃ kathaṃ tajjāyate nṛṇām||23||  dravadhātoḥ sthirānmāṃsānmedasaḥ sambhavaḥ katham|  ślakṣṇābhyāṃ māṃsamedobhyāṃ kharatvaṃ kathamasthiṣu||24||  khareṣvasthiṣu majjā ca kena snigdho mṛdustathā|  majjñaśca pariṇāmena yadi śukraṃ pravartate||25||  sarvadehagataṃ śukraṃ pravadanti manīṣiṇaḥ|  tathā'sthimadhyamajjñaśca śukraṃ bhavati dehinām||26||  chidraṃ na dṛśyate'sthnāṃ ca tanniḥsarati vā katham|
translation: "How does the fluid appear red in the body?" "In what way does semen originate from solid flesh in humans?" "How do soft flesh and fat turn into hard bones?" "Under what circumstances do bones become the dwelling of marrow and fat?" "When the fat and semen are transformed, how is it that hardness appears in them?" "How can there be oiliness and softness in bones?" "Furthermore, when the semen undergoes transformation, how does it produce marrow?" "All scholars say that semen exists throughout the body." "How does it exist in the middle of the bones?" "If there is no visible opening, then how does it leave the solid parts?"

sloka: evamuktastu śiṣyeṇa guruḥ prāhedamuttaram||27||  tejo rasānāṃ sarveṣāṃ manujānāṃ yaducyate|  pittoṣmaṇaḥ sa rāgeṇa raso raktatvamṛcchati||28||
translation: In this way, spoken to by the disciple, the teacher revealed the supreme truth: the vital essence of all human beings is referred to as "pitta" ; it becomes colored with redness due to heat in the body .

sloka: vāyvambutejasā raktamūṣmaṇā cābhisaṃyutam|  sthiratāṃ prāpya māṃsaṃ syāt svoṣmaṇā pakvameva tat ||29||
translation: Becoming firmly established with the vital air, heat, and the redness derived from water and fire, that fleshy substance becomes fully cooked by its own nature.

sloka: svatejo'mbuguṇasnigdhodriktaṃ medo'bhijāyate|
translation: From its own radiance and the water, endowed with favorable qualities, fat is produced.

sloka: pṛthivyagnyanilādīnāṃ saṅghātaḥ svoṣmaṇā kṛtaḥ||30||  kharatvaṃ prakarotyasya jāyate'sthi tato nṛṇām|
translation: The assembly of earth, fire, and wind, created by its own heat, brings about the quality of mobility in humans.

sloka: karoti tatra sauṣiryamasthnāṃ madhye samīraṇaḥ||31||  medasastāni pūryante sneho majjā tataḥ smṛtaḥ|
translation: There, the cool breeze becomes active in the middle of beauty , filling the fatty tissue with affection . This is remembered as occurring within.

sloka: tasmānmajjñastu yaḥ snehaḥ śukraṃ sañjāyate tataḥ||32||  vāyvākāśādibhirbhāvaiḥ sauṣiryaṃ jāyate'sthiṣu|  tena sravati tacchukraṃ navāt kumbhādivodakam||33||  srotobhiḥ syandate dehāt samantācchukravāhibhiḥ |  harṣeṇodīritaṃ vegāt saṅkalpācca manobhavāt||34||  vilīnaṃ ghṛtavadvyāyāmoṣmaṇā sthānavicyutam|  bastau sambhṛtya niryāti sthalānnimnādivodakam)||35||
translation: Therefore, one who is knowledgeable, from affection is born semen; through the vital airs and other existences, sexual desire is produced in the bodies. Through that, the semen flows, becoming new at times, in pots and the like. It bubbles up through the veins, arising from the body all around, mixed with the fluid of sexual arousal, due to the mind's resolve and thought. When it is diminished, churned by the movements of sexual desire, it becomes solidified into an embryo, drawn into the womb, along with the menstrual fluid.

sloka: vyānena rasadhāturhi vikṣepocitakarmaṇā|  yugapat sarvato'jasraṃ dehe vikṣipyate sadā||36||
translation: By the action instigated by the bodily constituents and the vital air (vyana), all the senses are constantly agitated in all directions at once.

sloka: kṣipyamāṇaḥ khavaiguṇyādrasaḥ sajjati yatra saḥ|  karoti vikṛtiṃ tatra khe varṣamiva toyadaḥ||37||
translation: When forcibly thrown, just like a rain cloud in the sky, it unites with the place where it is devoid of its own qualities; such is the nature of wind.

sloka: doṣāṇāmapi caivaṃ syādekadeśaprakopaṇam |
translation: Even a single region can become prone to the outbreak of faults, albeit.

sloka: iti bhautikadhātvannapaktṝṇāṃ karma bhāṣitam||38||
translation: Thus, the element of material nature is spoken as the action of transforming food.

sloka: annasya paktā sarveṣāṃ paktṝṇāmadhipo mataḥ|  tanmūlāste hi tadvṛddhikṣayavṛddhikṣayātmakāḥ||39||
translation: The chef is considered the master of all cooking preparations; indeed, their root cause for growth or decline lies in the ingredients used.

sloka: tasmāttaṃ vidhivadyuktairannapānendhanairhitaiḥ|  pālayet prayatastasya sthitau hyayurbalasthitiḥ||40||
translation: Therefore, one should carefully maintain the nourishment, hydration, and fuel of the body, for the sustenance and strength of life depend on it.

sloka: yo hi bhuṅkte vidhiṃ tyāktvā grahaṇīdoṣajān gadān|  sa laulyāllabhate śīghraṃ vakṣyante'taḥ paraṃ tu te||41||
translation: One who quickly becomes greedy and acts without following the proper procedures, consuming what is given (in charity) and tainted by faults of accepting gifts - such a person will be spoken of disparagingly.

sloka: abhojanādajīrṇātibhojanādviṣamāśanāt| asātmyaguruśītātirūkṣasanduṣṭabhojanāt||42||  virekavamanasnehavibhramādvyādhikarṣaṇāt|  deśakālartuvaiṣamyādvegānāṃ ca vidhāraṇāt||43||  duṣyatyagniḥ sa duṣṭo'nnaṃ na tat pacati laghvapi|  apacyamānaṃ śuktatvaṃ yātyannaṃ viṣarūpatām  ||44||
translation: Neglecting proper food and eating overly spoiled or unwholesome food, consuming food that is too hot or too cold, or eating at the wrong time or in irregular intervals can lead to a weakened digestive fire (agni), improper digestion, and the accumulation of waste products, which can ultimately result in disease.

sloka: tasya liṅgamajīrṇasya viṣṭambhaḥ sadanaṃ tathā|  śiraso ruk ca mūrcchā ca bhramaḥ pṛṣṭhakaṭigrahaḥ||45||  jṛmbhā'ṅgamardastṛṣṇā ca jvaraśchardiḥ pravāhaṇam|  arocako'vipākaśca ghoramannaviṣaṃ ca tat||46||
translation: For the one in decay, constipation is a symptom, as well as stiffness of the head, fainting, and vertigo. Additionally, there are gripping pains in the back and sides, yawning, tremors, thirst, fever, vomiting, and the excretion of undigested food. Indeed, all of these are terrible signs of afflicted digestion.

sloka: saṃsṛjyamānaṃ pittena dāhaṃ tṛṣṇāṃ mukhāmayān|  janayatyamlapittaṃ ca pittajāṃścāparān gadān||47||  yakṣmapīnasamehādīn kaphajān kaphasaṅgatam|  karoti vātasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ vātajāṃśca gadān bahūn||48||  mūtrarogāṃśca mūtrasthaṃ kukṣirogān śakṛdgatam|  rasādibhiśca saṃsṛṣṭaṃ kuryādrogān rasādijān||49||
translation: Being born, the sperm of the father becomes a flame that consumes thirst with a mouth-like appearance. It also generates sour and pitta-related afflictions and various weapons of pitta. Similarly, phlegm-related afflictions are produced when influenced by kapha, and many weapons of vata arise from the air. Diseases related to urine and those located in the abdomen are caused by urine and feces respectively. By means of fluids like rasa, diseases caused by them are generated.

sloka: viṣamo dhātuvaiṣamyaṃ karoti viṣamaṃ pacan|  tīkṣṇo mandendhano dhātūn viśoṣayati pāvakaḥ||50||
translation: An uneven chef makes an uneven digestion
column4: a sharp and mild fuel ignites and refines the elements.

sloka: yuktaṃ bhuktavato yukto dhātusāmyaṃ samaṃ pacan|
translation: Having consumed food, one should be equally yoked, that is, maintain a balanced state with regard to the bodily constituents (dhatus) and the digestive process (pacan).

sloka: durbalo vidahatyannaṃ tadyātyūrdhvamadho'pi vā||51||
translation: Even the weak one can consume food, whether it is upwards, downwards, or to the side.

sloka: adhastu pakvamāmaṃ vā pravṛttaṃ grahaṇīgadaḥ|  ucyate sarvamevānnaṃ prāyo hyasya vidahyate||52||  atisṛṣṭaṃ vibaddhaṃ vā dravaṃ tadupadiśyate|  tṛṣṇārocakavairasyaprasekatamakānvitaḥ||53||  śūnapādakaraḥ sāsthiparvaruk chardanaṃ jvaraḥ|  lohāmagandhistiktāmla [17] udgāraścāsya jāyate||54||
translation: That which is overripe or recently cooked, when consumed, is declared as food in the primary sense. That which is spilled or scattered is called food in the secondary sense. From it arises, due to thirst, a fluid that is fragrant, rejuvenating, and cooling; as well as fevers, diarrhea, and symptoms of poisoning such as a metallic taste, bad smell, or bitterness.

sloka: pūrvarūpaṃ tu tasyedaṃ tṛṣṇā''lasyaṃ balakṣayaḥ|  vidāho'nnasya pākaśca cirāt kāyasya gauravam||55||
translation: Indeed, this was its previous form, the depletion of strength and thirst, and later on, after a long time, the heaviness of the body; the cooking of food for it.

sloka: agnyadhiṣṭhānamannasya grahaṇādgrahaṇī matā|  nābheruparyahyagnibalenopaṣṭabdhopabṛṃhitā [18] ||56||  apakvaṃ dhāratyannaṃ pakvaṃ sṛjati pārśvataḥ|  durbalāgnibalā duṣṭā [19] tvāmameva vimuñcati||57||
translation: The one overseeing the agnihotra ritual, considered as the one who grasps and releases, is not weak or unskilled in the agnihotra rites. They neither release an unripe offering nor hold onto a ripe one; they release what is foul-smelling and strong-smelling only for you (the fire).

sloka: vātāt pittāt kaphācca syāttadrogastribhya eva ca|  hetuṃ liṅgaṃ rūpabhedāñ śṛṇu tasya pṛthak pṛthak||58||
translation: Learn the individual causes, symptoms, and distinct manifestations of diseases arising from imbalances of wind, bile, and phlegm.

sloka: kaṭutiktakaṣāyātirūkṣaśītalabhojanaiḥ|  pramitānaśanātyadhvaveganigrahamaithunaiḥ||59||  karoti kupito mandamagniṃ sañchādya mārutaḥ [22] |
translation: Angered, a person with a strong digestive fire performs excessive austerities, controlling hunger, thirst, movement, and sexual desires, reducing food intake to only bitter, pungent, and astringent items.

sloka: tasyānnaṃ pacyate duḥkhaṃ śuktapākaṃ kharāṅgatā||60|| kaṇṭhāsyaśoṣaḥ kṣuttṛṣṇā timiraṃ karṇayoḥ svanaḥ|  pārśvoruvaṅkṣaṇagrīvārujo'bhīkṣṇaṃ visūcikā||61||  hṛtpīḍā kārśyadaurbalyaṃ vairasyaṃ parikartikā|  gṛddhiḥ sarvarasānāṃ ca manasaḥ sadanaṃ tathā||62||  jīrṇe jīryati cādhmānaṃ bhukte svāsthyamupaiti ca|  sa vātagulmahṛdrogaplīhāśaṅkī ca mānavaḥ||63||  cirāduḥkhaṃ dravaṃ śuṣkaṃ tanvāmaṃ śabdaphenavat|  punaḥ punaḥ sṛjedvarcaḥ kāsaśvāsārdito'nilāt||64||
translation: His food is not cooked by the pains of the edema that has afflicted the body; The drying up of his throat, hunger, thirst, and the dimness of his ears; The wasting away of the sides, back, neck, and head; The excessive hiccups, distress, emaciation, and exhaustion; The increase of all tastes and the establishment in the mind; The weakening and wasting away of life force, the attainment of health when eating; He is a human being, subject to diseases like wind disorder, abdominal lump, and spleen disease, fearing consumption of old age, dryness, emaciation; The repeated emergence of bile, phlegm, and wind, and the aggravation caused by Vayu.

sloka: kaṭvajīrṇavidāhyamlakṣārādyaiḥ pittamulbaṇam|  agnimāplāvayaddhanti [23] jalaṃ taptamivānalam||65||
translation: With a mixture of cow dung, urine, clarified butter, and other substances, they churn the oblation, making the water boil like fire.

sloka: so'jīrṇaṃ nīlapītābhaṃ pītābhaḥ sāryate dravam|  pūtyamlodgārahṛtkaṇṭhadāhārucitṛḍarditaḥ||66||
translation: He turns the aged blue-black colored gold into shining yellow; extracting the impurities, he refines it by fire.

sloka: gurvatisnigdhaśītādibhojanādatibhojanāt|  bhuktamātrasya ca svapnāddhantyagniṃ kupitaḥ kaphaḥ||67||
translation: Consuming food abnormally beyond the moderate, nourishing, and agreeable meal recommended by the guru, the angered kapha (one of the three bodily humor) destroys the digestive fire even in dreams.

sloka: tasyānnaṃ pacyate duḥkhaṃ hṛllāsacchardyarocakāḥ|  āsyopadehamādhuryakāsaṣṭhīvanapīnasāḥ||68||  hṛdayaṃ manyate styānamudaraṃ stimitaṃ guru|  duṣṭo madhura udgāraḥ sadanaṃ strīṣvaharṣaṇam||69||  bhinnāmaśleṣmasaṃsṛṣṭaguruvarcaḥpravartanam|  akṛśasyāpi daurbalyamālasyaṃ ca kaphātmake||70||
translation: His food is not digested, the one whose heart thinks of something other than eating as sweet; the complexion becomes sallow, and there is a decrease in strength and an increase in phlegm in the body. The emission becomes foul, and the body becomes unattractive. The vigor and enthusiasm for work are diminished. All these symptoms appear in one who has phlegmatic constitution (kapha prakriti) and is also lazy (alasya).

sloka: yaścāgniḥ pūrvamuddiṣṭo rogānīke caturvidhaḥ|  taṃ cāpi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ samavarjaṃ pracakṣmahe||71||
translation: We also declare as something to be avoided the grahaṇī dosha of that agni, which was indicated earlier and is fourfold in types, and which manifests in the form of various diseases in the army.

sloka: pṛthagvātādinirdiṣṭahetuliṅgasamāgame|  tridoṣaṃ nirdiśetteṣāṃ bheṣajaṃ [24] śṛṇvataḥ param||72||
translation: For those who listen, the supreme teaching is as follows: in the assembly of unique and distinguished physical components, the three doshas' remedy should be pointed out.

sloka: grahaṇīmāśritaṃ doṣaṃ vidagdhāhāramūrcchitam|  saviṣṭambhaprasekārtividāhārucigauravaiḥ||73|| āmaliṅgānvitaṃ dṛṣṭvā sukhoṣṇenāmbunoddharet|  phalānāṃ vā kaṣāyeṇa pippalīsarṣapaistathā||74||
translation: Upon seeing a person afflicted by the seizure-like motion caused by the flaw that resides in the one who has taken refuge in grahaṇīm, one should raise them up with the help of water, either warm or cooled with kaṣāya, and also with pippalī and sarṣapa.

sloka: līnaṃ pakvāśayasthaṃ vā''pyāmaṃ srāvyaṃ sadīpanaiḥ|  śarīrānugate sāme rase laṅghanapācanam||75||
translation: Even a ripe fruit that is lying down or being eaten can be illuminated with the aid of lamps; similarly, food that is ingested or digested should serve to nourish and support the body.

sloka: viśuddhāmāśayāyāsmai pañcakolādibhiḥ śṛtam|  dadyāt peyādi laghvannaṃ punaryogāṃśca dīpanān||76||
translation: To him with purified inner self, offer with the five types of oblations starting from "kola" and also additional mild food; re-kindle the sacrificial fires.

sloka: jñātvā tu paripakvāmaṃ mārutagrahaṇīgadam|  dīpanīyayutaṃ sarpiḥ pāyayetālpaśo bhiṣak||77||
translation: Having understood the fully matured meaning of "mārutagrahaṇīgadam" (something that attracts or grasps the wind), the physician should feed the patient a small amount of clarified butter that has been kindled.

sloka: kiñcitsandhukṣite tvagnau saktaviṇmūtramārutam|  dvyahaṃ tryahaṃ vā saṃsnehya svinnābhyaktaṃ nirūhayet||78||
translation: Only after properly preparing the fuel in the fire, should one carefully ignite it, either with a small amount or a large amount of air and firewood.

sloka: tata eraṇḍatailena sarpiṣā tailvakena vā|  sakṣāreṇānile śānte srastadoṣaṃ virecayet||79||
translation: With sesame oil from that eranda plant, or with clarified butter, and even with oil from the tail of a cow, one should cleanse oneself in stillness; thus, one can remove the impurities generated by past actions.

sloka: śuddhaṃ rūkṣāśayaṃ baddhavarcasaṃ cānuvāsayet|  dīpanīyāmlavātaghnasiddhātailena mātrayā||80||
translation: Purify the hardened heart by filling it with the single measure of sesame oil that is capable of enkindling digestive fire and destroying any bitterness or harshness present therein.

sloka: nirūḍhaṃ ca viriktaṃ ca samyak caivānuvāsitam|  laghvannaṃ pratisambhuktaṃ sarpirabhyāsayet punaḥ||81||
translation: Having restrained and abandoned in the right manner , one should again eat light food , consumed just enough after a fast .

sloka: dve pañcamūle saralaṃ devadāru sanāgaram|  pippalīṃ pippalīmūlaṃ citrakaṃ hastipippalīm||82||  śaṇabījaṃ yavān kolan kulatthān suṣavīṃ tathā [27] | pācayedāranālena dadhnā sauvīrakeṇa vā||83||  caturbhāgāvaśeṣeṇa pacettena ghṛtāḍhakam|  svarjikāyāvaśūkākhyau kṣārau dattvā ca yuktitaḥ||84||  saindhavaudbhidasāmudrabiḍānāṃ romakasya ca|  sasauvarcalapākyānāṃ bhāgāndvipalikān pṛthak||85||  vinīya cūrṇitān tasmāt pāyayet prasṛtaṃ budhaḥ|  karotyagniṃ balaṃ varṇaṃ vātaghnaṃ bhuktapācanam||86||  iti daśamūlādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: With five primary ingredients, namely pure devadaru, pippalii, citraka, and hastipippali, along with shana seed, rice grains, kolan, kulatha that are cleaned and soaked; after adding salt, ghee should be cooked to completeness with a quarter of the remaining portion in a controlled fire. Then, mixing in separately prepared ingredients such as samudra-bida (sea salts), romakasha (black salt), sauvarcala paka (lime juice), bhaga-andvipalika (spices), these should be added one at a time to the ghee. The intelligent person should then filter and heat it, preparing agni (digestive fire), strength, complexion, wind control, and digestion in this decimation of the ten roots known as ghrita.

sloka: tryūṣaṇatriphalākalke bilvamātre guḍāt pale|  sarpiṣo'ṣṭapalaṃ paktvā mātrāṃ mandānalaḥ pibet||87||  iti tryūṣaṇādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Having cooked [paktvā] ghee [ghṛtam] with eight [aṣṭa] palas of milk [sarpiṣaḥ], one should cause the fire [manda-analaḥ] to drink (i.e., bring it to a boil) [pibet] after adding only a small amount [mātrām] of jaggery [guḍāt] and a bilva leaf [bilva, mātre], which have been mixed with three triphala fruits [tryūṣaṇatriphalākalke]. This is known as the initial process (tryūṣaṇādyam) in making ghee.

sloka: pañcamūlābhayāvyoṣapippalīmūlasaindhavaiḥ|  rāsnākṣāradvayājājīviḍaṅgaśaṭibhirghṛtam||88||  śuktena mātuluṅgasya svarasenārdrakasya ca|  śuṣkamūlakakolāmbucukrikādāḍimasya ca||89||  takramastusurāmaṇḍasauvīrakatuṣodakaiḥ|  kāñjikena ca tat pakvamagnidīptikaraṃ param||90||  śūlagulmodaraśvāsakāsānilakaphāpaham|  sabījapūrakarasaṃ siddhaṃ vā pāyayedghṛtam||91||  siddhamabhyañjanārthaṃ ca tailametaiḥ prayojayet|  eteṣāmauṣadhānāṃ vā pibeccūrṇaṃ sukhāmbunā||92||  vāte śleṣmāvṛte sāme kaphe vā vāyunoddhate|  dadyāccūrṇaṃ pācanārthamagnisandīpanaṃ param||93||  iti pañcamūlādyaṃ ghṛtaṃ cūrṇaṃ ca
translation: Prepare a decoction of five ingredients:

sloka: majjatyāmā gurutvādviṭ pakvā tūtplavate jale|  vinā'tidravasaṅghātaśaityaśleṣmapradūṣaṇāt||94||
translation: Becoming fully mature, these beans start to sink in water due to their heaviness . But if they are overripe , they float on the surface of water, due to the loss of their natural adhesion and getting polluted .

sloka: parīkṣyaivaṃ purā sāmaṃ nirāmaṃ cāmadoṣiṇam|  vidhinopācaret samyak pācanenetareṇa vā||95||
translation: Having examined this previously silent Sama (a type of Vedic hymn) free from defects, one should properly perform its maintenance either with ritual offering or in some other way.

sloka: citrakaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ dvau kṣārau lavaṇāni ca|  vyoṣaṃ hiṅgvajamodāṃ ca cavyaṃ caikatra cūrṇayet||96||  guṭikā mātuluṅgasya dāḍimasya rasena vā|  kṛtā vipācayatyāmaṃ dīpayatyāśu cānalam||97||  iti citrakādyā guṭikā
translation: Prepare the following at once: Citraka and Pippali root, two alkalis, salts, Vyosa, Hingu, Modaka, Cavya, a powdered mass of Takra or buttermilk or by extract of Dadima with its juice; this is called "Citraka-adiyah Guptika" (a type of Ayurvedic medicine).

sloka: nāgarātiviṣāmustakvāthaḥ syādāmapācanaḥ|  mustāntakalkaḥ pathyā vā nāgaraṃ coṣṇavāriṇā||98||
translation: A city should never have a water supply tainted with snake venom, nor should it be contaminated with alkalies or salts, not even by the end of summer or due to hot weather.

sloka: devadāruvacāmustanāgarātiviṣābhayāḥ|  vāruṇyāmāsutāstoye koṣṇe vā'lavaṇāḥ pibet||99|| varcasyāme saśūle ca pibedvā dāḍimāmbunā|
translation: In the sacred grove, a serpent-free talker of the divine tree, in the cool and warm water of the river born of the rains, should one drink or not? One should drink the nectar-like water from the Bilva fruit.

sloka: viḍena [29] lavaṇaṃ piṣṭaṃ bilvaṃ citrakanāgaram||100||  sāme vā sakaphe vāte koṣṭhaśūlakare pibet|
translation: Either in the juice of citron or in a vessel with a hole and made from a bamboo stick, one may drink (liquid).

sloka: kaliṅgahiṅgvativiṣāvacāsauvarcalābhayāḥ||101||  chardyarśogranthiśūleṣu pibeduṣṇena vāriṇā|  pathyāsauvarcalājājīcūrṇaṃ maricasaṃyutam||102||
translation: In the Kalinga region, let them drink, with hot water, from the tip of a sharpened arrowhead, the mixture of turmeric and lime, which is recommended for use as an antiseptic.

sloka: abhayāṃ pippalīmūlaṃ vacāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm|  pāṭhāṃ vatsakabījāni citrakaṃ viśvabheṣajam||103||  pibenniṣkvāthya cūrṇaṃ vā kṛtvā koṣṇena vāriṇā|  pittaśleṣmābhibhṛtāyāṃ grahaṇyāṃ śūlanuddhitam||104||
translation: Drink, when afflicted by an excess of bile and phlegm, the decoction of

sloka: sāme sātiviṣaṃ vyoṣaṃ lavaṇakṣārahiṅgu ca|  niḥkvāthya pāyayeccūrṇaṃ kṛtvā vā koṣṇavāriṇā||105||
translation: Mixing equally, in a proper manner, the curry made from the finest herbs and salty water, having drained it (of impurities), and then adding hot water to it – who would do this?

sloka: pippalīṃ nāgaraṃ pāṭhāṃ sārivāṃ bṛhatīdvayam|  citrakaṃ kauṭajaṃ bījaṃ lavaṇānyatha pañca ca||106||  taccūrṇaṃ sayavakṣāraṃ dadhyuṣṇāmbusurādibhiḥ|  pibedagnivivṛddhyarthaṃ koṣṭhavātaharaṃ naraḥ||107||
translation: To increase the digestive fire, a man should drink a mixture prepared by grinding together equal parts of nagaram (black gram), pippali (long pepper), sari (white rice), vatam (barley), bhrngarajam ( Indian aloe), citrakam (plumbago zeylanica), kutajam (holarrhena antidysentrica), and five lavana (salts) with curd, warm water, and sura (fermented liquor).

sloka: maricaṃ kuñcikāmbaṣṭhāvṛkṣāmlāḥ kuḍavāḥ pṛthak|  palāni [30] daśa cāmlasya vetasasya palārdhikam||108||  sauvarcalaṃ biḍaṃ pākyaṃ yavakṣāraḥ sasaindhavaḥ|  śaṭīpuṣkaramūlāni hiṅgu hiṅguśivāṭikā||109||  tat sarvamekataḥ sūkṣmaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā prayojayet|  hitaṃ vātābhibhūtāyāṃ grahaṇyāmarucau tathā||110||  iti maricādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: Ground and dry thoroughly the following: sauvarcala salt, black gram, pākya ingredient, barley, sasaindhava salt, śaṭīpuṣkaramūlāni plants, asafoetida, and āṭikā. Once everything is finely ground into a powder, it should be used during the time of being affected by vāta imbalance, for the purpose of alleviating it, as well as during meals and while undergoing emesis therapy. This is known as marica and similar substances in their powdered form.

sloka: caturṇāṃ prasthamamlānāṃ tryūṣaṇasya palatrayam|  lavaṇānāṃ ca catvāri śarkarāyāḥ palāṣṭakam|  sañcūrṇya śākasūpānnarāgādiṣvavacārayet||111||  kāsājīrṇāruciśvāsāhṛtpāṇḍvāmayaśūlanut|
translation: Having mixed together the four kinds of grains and tryushana (a type of powdered condiment), as well as four types of salts and eight varieties of sugar, one should prepare dishes with vegetables, soups, and other ingredients. Similarly, one should prepare various foods for those afflicted by jirna (old age), rucisha (lack of appetite), shvasa (breathing difficulty), hridaya (heart disease), pandu (anemia), and amaya (disease due to imbalance of bodily humors) with sharp, flat, and blunt implements.

sloka: cavyatvakpippalīmūladhātakīvyoṣacitrakān||112||  kapitthaṃ bilvamambaṣṭhāṃ śālmalaṃ hastipippalīm|  śilodbhedaṃ tathā'jājīṃ piṣṭvā badarasammitam||113||  paribharjya ghṛte dadhnā yavāgūṃ sādhayedbhiṣak| rasaiḥ kapitthacukrīkāvṛkṣāmlairdāḍimasya ca||114||  sarvātisāragrahaṇīgulmārśaḥplīhanāśinī|
translation: Grinding together the bark of Cavya and the roots of Pippali, Citraka, Dhataki, and Vyosa, along with the fruits of Kapittha, Bilva, Amla, Shalmali, Hastipippali, and the stone Silaudbhedam; mixing it all with ghee and milk, a physician should prepare and administer this to the patient, using decoctions made from the bark and leaves of Kapitthacukri, Vrksamla, and Dadi. This remedy destroys all symptoms of disease that arise due to excesses in diet and behavior.

sloka: pañcakolakayūṣaśca mūlakānāṃ ca soṣaṇaḥ||115||  snigdho dāḍimatakrāmlo jāṅgalaḥ saṃskṛto rasaḥ|  kravyādasvarasaḥ śasto bhojanārthe sadīpanaḥ||116||  takrāranālamadyāni pānāyāriṣṭa eva ca|
translation: The churning of five substances is the extraction of sap from their roots; it is unctuous, astringent, and sour. Cultivated in wilderness, it has a pleasant taste and is used as seasoning in food and drink. It is also known as the essence of flesh-eating animals and is illuminating in the form of alcoholic beverages.

sloka: takraṃ tu grahaṇīdoṣe dīpanagrāhilāghavāt||117||  śreṣṭhaṃ madhurapākitvānna ca pittaṃ prakopayet|  kaṣāyoṣṇavikāśitvādraukṣyāccaiva kaphe hitam||118||  vāte svādvamlasāndratvāt sadyaskamavidāhi tat|  tasmāt takraprayogā ye jaṭharāṇāṃ tathā'rśasām||119||  vihitā grahaṇīdoṣe sarvaśastān prayojayet|
translation: In the case of grahaṇī dosha (a type of indigestion), one should administer takra (buttermilk) that is light to digest, and is superior in sweet taste. Pittam (bile) is aggravated by it, but it is beneficial for kapha (phlegm) due to its hot and thin qualities. It is recommended for vata (wind) due to its unctuousness, sourness, and cold potency. Hence, in the case of grahaṇī dosha, one should administer takra to all patients, considering it as a prescribed remedy.

sloka: yavānyāmalake pathyā maricaṃ tripalaṃśikam||120||  lavaṇāni palāṃśāni pañca caikatra cūrṇayet|  takre tadāsutaṃ [31] jātaṃ takrāriṣṭaṃ pibennaraḥ|  dīpanaṃ śothagulmārśaḥkrimimehodarāpaham||121||  iti takrāriṣṭaḥ
translation: With āmalaka fruit, one should consume powders of marica and triputaga; then, drink buttermilk mixed with salts and powdered hingu; this churned buttermilk removes Kapha-Pitta doshas.

sloka: svasthānagatamutkliṣṭamagninirvāpakaṃ bhiṣak|  pittaṃ jñātvā virekeṇa nirharedvamanena vā||122||
translation: Knowing the aggravated Pitta (bile) that has accumulated in its natural location, the physician should remove it completely, either through evacuation or emesis.

sloka: avidāhibhirannaiśca laghubhistiktasaṃyutaiḥ|  jāṅgalānāṃ rasairyūṣairmudgādīnāṃ khaḍairapi||123||  dāḍimāmlaiḥ sasarpiṣkairdīpanagrāhisaṃyutaiḥ|  tasyāgniṃ dīpayeccūrṇaiḥ sarpirbhiścāpi tiktakaiḥ||124||
translation: With a small amount of alkali-like substances mixed in by the uneducated , the juices of the jāṅgalānām and grains like mudga and others , along with lime and sour substances , and also with fuel for lamps, the fire is kindled by grinding and adding pungent substances.

sloka: candanaṃ padmakośīraṃ pāṭhāṃ mūrvāṃ kuṭannaṭam|  ṣaḍgranthāsārivāsphotāsaptaparṇāṭarūṣakān||125||  paṭolodumbarāśvatthavaṭaplakṣakapītanān|  kaṭukāṃ rohiṇīṃ mustaṃ nimbaṃ ca dvipalāṃśikam||126||  droṇe'pāṃ sādhayet pādaśeṣe prasthaṃ ghṛtāt pacet|  kirātatiktendrayavavīrāmāgadhikotpalaiḥ||127||  kalkairakṣasamaiḥ peyaṃ tat pittagrahaṇīgade|  iti candanādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Prepare sandalwood, padma-kosha, patha, mura, kuta, nata, and shade-granthi-asri plants, as well as patala, udumbara, ashvattha, vata, plaksha, peeta, nimba, and dvipalaashika. In the remaining portion of a vessel, cook ghee with kirata, tikta, indra, yava, vira, ama, agadhi, kaa, utpala, kalki, aksha samas. This sandalwood-based ghee is suitable for consumption and beneficial in treating pitta-agrahani diseases.

sloka: tiktakaṃ yadghṛtaṃ coktaṃ kauṣṭhike tacca dāpayet||128||
translation: When butter has been churned and becomes sour, then it should be offered in the Kaushtiki fire.

sloka: nāgarātiviṣe mustaṃ dhātakīṃ ca rasāñjanam|  vatsakatvakphalaṃ bilvaṃ pāṭhāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm||129||  pibet samāṃśaṃ taccūrṇaṃ sakṣaudraṃ taṇḍulāmbunā|  paittike grahaṇīdoṣe raktaṃ yaccopaveśyate||130||  arśāṃsi ca gude śūlaṃ jayeccaiva pravāhikām|  nāgarādyamidaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛṣṇātreyeṇa pūjitam||131||  iti nāgarādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: Drink the powdered

sloka: bhūnimbakaṭukāvyoṣamustakendrayavān samān|  dvau citrakādvatsakatvagbhāgān ṣoḍaśa cūrṇayet||132||  guḍaśītāmbunā pītaṃ grahaṇīdoṣagulmanut|  kāmalājvarapāṇḍutvamehārucyatisāranut||133||  iti bhūnimbādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: Consisting of sixteen parts, the mixture is made with two citraka seeds and a portion equal to indra's share, along with nimba, bitter katuka, ōṣa, and mustaka. Additionally, it includes pīta, formed from guḍa, śīta, ambu, and eliminates the impurities of grahaṇī, dosas, and gulma. This mixture, starting with bhū, is also known to counter kāma, lājvara, pāṇḍutva, meha, aruci, and atisāra.

sloka: vacāmativiṣāṃ pāṭhāṃ saptaparṇaṃ rasāñjanam|  syonākodīcyakaṭvaṅgavatsakatvagdurālabhāḥ||134||  dārvīṃ parpaṭakaṃ pāṭhāṃ yavānīṃ madhuśigrukam|  paṭolapatraṃ siddhārthān yūthikāṃ jātipallavān||135||  jambvāmrabilvamadhyāni nimbaśākaphalāni ca|  tadrogaśamamanvicchan bhūnimbādyena yojayet||136||
translation:
Consider the path of words as the foremost among the various paths of speech. Gathering the seven-leaved one (Saptaparṇa), color it with the juices of Syonāka, Dīcyaka, Kaṭu, Vatsaka, and Durālabha.

Prepare the Darvi and Parpaṭaka paths, as well as Yavānī mixed with Madhu and Śigru. Make use of Patola leaves, Tram leaves, and Siddhārtha fruits in order to alleviate diseases and calm the mind.

Gather the freshly bloomed Jambu, Āmra, Bilva, Nimba, and Śāka fruits for this purpose. Apply these individually or together as needed to pacify disorders and bring about tranquility.

sloka: kirātatiktaḥ ṣaḍgranthā trāyamāṇā kaṭutrikam|  candanaṃ padmakośīraṃ dārvītvak kaṭurohiṇī||137||  kuṭajatvakphalaṃ mustaṃ yavānī devadāru ca|  paṭolanimbapatrailāsaurāṣṭrayativiṣātvacaḥ||138||  madhuśigrośca bījāni mūrvā parpaṭakastathā|  taccūrṇaṃ madhunā lehyaṃ peyaṃ madyairjalena vā||139||  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīrogagulmaśūlārucijvarān|  kāmalāṃ sannipātaṃ ca mukharogāṃśca nāśayet||140||  iti kirātādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: The

sloka: grahaṇyāṃ śleṣmaduṣṭāyāṃ vamitasya yathāvidhi|  kaṭvamlalavaṇakṣāraistiktaiścāgniṃ vivardhayet||141||
translation: In the proper manner, one should increase the fire using Kaṭu, Amla, Lavana, and Tikta constituents of Vamitasya (something that is to be evacuated) when it is afflicted with excessive phlegm.

sloka: palāśaṃ citrakaṃ cavyaṃ mātuluṅgaṃ harītakīm|  pippalīṃ pippalīmūlaṃ pāṭhāṃ nāgaradhānyakam||142||  kārṣikāṇyudakaprasthe paktvā pādāvaśeṣitam|  pānīyārthaṃ prayuñjīta yavāgūṃ taiśca sādhayet||143||
translation: With ingredients such as palasha, citraka, cavya, matalunga, haritaki, pippalii, pippalii root, and patha, as well as grains like nagara-dhanyaka, first cook the karsika grains near water. Then, use this to prepare a drink and mix in barley, with which one should perform proper sips and accomplishment.

sloka: śuṣkamūlakayūṣeṇa kaulatthenāthavā punaḥ|  kaṭvamlakṣārapaṭunā laghūnyannāni bhojayet||144||  amlaṃ cānu pibettakraṃ takrāriṣṭamathāpi vā|  madirāṃ madhvariṣṭaṃ vā nigadaṃ sīdhumeva vā||145||
translation: Should one nourish oneself with light foods such as dried roots, or again with bitter, astringent, and pungent flavors, consuming them in small quantities? Or should one sip wine, superior quality wine, strong drink, or even an alcoholic beverage that is aged and refined?

sloka: droṇaṃ madhūkapuṣpāṇāṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ tato'rdhataḥ|  citrakasya tato'rdhaṃ syāttathā bhallātakāḍhakam||146||  mañjiṣṭhāṣṭapalaṃ [32] caiva tridroṇe'pāṃ vipācayet|  droṇaśeṣaṃ tu tacchītaṃ madhvardhāḍhakasaṃyutam||147||  elāmṛṇālāgurubhiścandanena ca rūṣite|  kumbhe māsasthitaṃ jātamāsavaṃ taṃ prayojayet||148|| grahaṇīṃ dīpayatyeva bṛṃhaṇaḥ [33] kaphapittajit|  śothaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ kilāsaṃ ca pramehāṃśca praṇāśayet||149||  iti madhūkāsavaḥ
translation: Prepare the following in a three-fourths portion of a drona measure each of madhūka and citraka flowers, and a half of bhallātakāḍhaka, along with a quarter of mṛṇāla and aguru each. Mix these in a pot, adding thereto a measure of āsava that has been kept for a month. Apply this to the affected area, which will help reduce kapha, pitta, and disorders such as grahaṇī, shotha, kuṣṭha, kilāsa, and pramehā. This is the recipe for madhūkāsava.

sloka: madhūkapuṣpasvarasaṃ śṛtamardhakṣayīkṛtam|  kṣaudrapādayutaṃ śītaṃ pūrvavat sannidhāpayet||150||  taṃ piban grahaṇīdoṣāñjayet sarvān hitāśanaḥ|  tadvaddrākṣekṣukharjūrasvarasānāsutān [34] pibet||151||
translation: Having collected the nectar from Madhūka flowers, one should prepare a cool mixture with an equal quantity of water. A selfless person should make others consume this, freeing them from all digestive impurities. They too should drink it, along with their children, after extracting the juice from sugarcane.

sloka: prasthau durālabhāyā dvau pasthamāmalakasya ca|  dantīcitrakamuṣṭī [35] dve pratyagraṃ cābhayāśatam||152||  caturdroṇe'mbhasaḥ paktvā śītaṃ droṇāvaśeṣitam|  saguḍadviśataṃ pūtaṃ madhunaḥ kuḍavāyutam||153||  tadvat priyaṅgoḥ pippalyā viḍaṅgānāṃ ca cūrṇitaiḥ|  kuḍavairghṛtakumbhasthaṃ pakṣājjātaṃ tataḥ pibet||154||  grahaṇīpāṇḍurogārśaḥkuṣṭhavīsarpamehanut|  svaravarṇakaraścaiṣa raktapittakaphāpahaḥ||155||  iti durālabhāsavaḥ
translation: Having cooked four handfuls of rice in a pot with water and strained off the excess, mixed with one hundred and twenty grains of sugar and ghee from a pot, this drink is to be consumed. It is made of pippali and dried ginger processed together, alleviates disorders such as grahaṇī, pāṇḍu, roga, arśa, kuṣṭha, vīsarpa, meha, and eliminates rakta, pitta, and kapha doshas. This is the hard-to-find elixir.

sloka: haridrā pañcamūle dve vīrarṣabhakajīvakam|  eṣāṃ [36] pañcapalān bhāgāṃścaturdroṇe'mbhasaḥ pacet||156||  droṇaśeṣe rase pūte guḍasya dviśataṃ bhiṣak|  cūrṇitān kuḍavārdhāṃśān prakṣipecca samākṣikān||157||  priyaṅgumustamañjiṣṭhāviḍaṅgamadhukaplavān|  lodhraṃ śābarakaṃ caiva māsārdhasthaṃ pibettu tam||158||  eṣa mūlāsavaḥ siddho dīpano raktapittajit|  ānāhakaphahṛdrogapāṇḍurogāṅgasādanut||159||  iti mūlāsavaḥ
translation: With the remainder of the dough ball, the physician should cook the portions of five ingredients in four droṇas of clarified butter. Once the mixture is pure and strained, he should add a mixture of priyangu, musta, mañjiṣṭha, viḍaṅga, madhuka, lodhram, and śābala. This mūlāsava, powerful and radiant, eliminates impurities related to blood, phlegm, bile, heart, and skin diseases. Thus is the preparation of mūlāsava.

sloka: prāsthikaṃ [37] pippalīṃ piṣṭvā guḍaṃ madhyaṃ bibhītakāt|  udakaprasthasaṃyuktaṃ yavapalle nidhāpayet||160||  tasmāt palaṃ sujātāttu salilāñjalisaṃyutam|  pibetpiṇḍāsavo hyeṣa rogānīkavināśanaḥ||161||  svastho'pyenaṃ pibenmāsaṃ naraḥ snigdharasāśanaḥ [38] |  icchaṃsteṣāmanutpattiṃ rogāṇāṃ ye'tra kīrtitāḥ||162|| iti piṇḍāsavaḥ
translation: Therefore, one should drink this rice-water, which is mixed with well-prepared sugar and jujube paste, is combined with water in the palms joined together, and is a drink that destroys diseases. Even a healthy person who regularly consumes unctuous foods should drink it once a month to prevent the occurrence of diseases as mentioned before. This is called rice-water.

sloka: nave pippalimadhvākte kalase'gurudhūpite|  madhvāḍhakaṃ jalasamaṃ cūrṇānīmāni dāpayet||163||  kuḍavārdhaṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ pippalyāḥ kuḍavaṃ tathā|  caturthikāṃśāṃ tvakkṣīrīṃ keśaraṃ maricāni ca||164||  tvagelāpatrakaśaṭīkramukātiviṣāghanān|  hareṇvelvālutejohvāpippalīmūlacitrakān||165||  kārṣikāṃstat sthitaṃ māsamata ūrdhvaṃ prayojayet|  mandaṃ sandapayatyagniṃ karoti viṣamaṃ samam||166||  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīrogakuṣṭhārśaḥśvayathujvarān|  vātaśleṣmāmayāṃścānyānmadhvariṣṭo vyapohati||167||  iti madhvariṣṭaḥ
translation: Using fresh pippali (long pepper) and madhva (honey), one should offer a mixture of crushed samit (water-soaked unbroken rice grains), cūrṇāni (powders) made from kuḍava (black pepper), viḍaṅgānām (cloves), pippalyāḥ (long pepper), kuḍavam (black pepper), tvakkṣīrīm (cinnamon), keśaram (cardamom), and maricāni (dry ginger) in a pot containing water infused with aguru (agalloch). The mixture should also include hareṇvelvālu (saffron strands), tejohvāpippalīmūlacitraka (roots of pippalī, tejohva and citraka plants), tvagelāpatra (tree barks), kaśaṭī (costus), kramuka (herbs that promote digestion) and other such herbs. This mixture, known as madhvariṣṭaḥ, is used to treat ailments such as heart diseases, cough, fever, indigestion, and those caused by vāta (wind), śleṣma (phlegm) and āma (toxins).

sloka: samūlāṃ pippalīṃ kṣārau dvau pañca lavaṇāni ca|  mātuluṅgābhayārāsnāśaṭīmaricanāgaram||168||  kṛtvā samāṃśaṃ taccūrṇaṃ pibet prātaḥ sukhāmbunā|  śleṣmike grahaṇīdoṣe balavarṇāgnivardhanam||169||  etairevauṣadhaiḥ siddhaṃ sarpiḥ peyaṃ samārute|
translation: Having crushed together the dried root of pippalí, two types of kshára, five salty substances, mātuluṅga, abhayārāsnāśaṭīmari, and nāgaram, one should drink it in the morning as a pleasant beverage, mixed with water. This mixture is beneficial in treating imbalances of kapha and agni. With these medicinal ingredients, clarified butter is considered to have been effectively prepared.

sloka: gaulmike ṣaṭpalaṃ proktaṃ bhallātakaghṛtaṃ ca yat||170||
translation: In the Gaumika (probably a particular text or tradition), six palm-lengths are mentioned as the measurement for Bhallaataka poison.

sloka: biḍaṃ kālotthalavaṇaṃ sarjikāyavaśūkajam|  saptalāṃ kaṇṭakārīṃ ca citrakaṃ ceti dāhayet||171||  saptakṛtvaḥ srutasyāsya kṣārasya [39] dvyāḍhakena tu|  āḍhakaṃ sarpiṣaḥ paktvā pibedagnivivardhanam||172||  iti kṣāraghṛta
translation: The one who knows (vidam) should ignite and burn with a fire fueled by the clarified butter of this dissolved salt (ksharaghrita), which is made from the churning of seven measures (saptalam) of water (kala) with the addition of lavaṇa, sarjikaya, vasuka, and jama substances, along with the citraka plant; this process should be repeated seven times (saptakritva); drinking the ghee that remains after boiling the curdled milk (sarpisha) aids in the strengthening of the digestive fire (agni).

sloka: samūlāṃ pippalīṃ pāṭhāṃ cavyendrayavanāgaram|  citrakātiviṣe hiṅgu śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||173||  vacāṃ ca kārṣikaṃ pañcalavaṇānāṃ palāni ca|  dadhnaḥ prasthadvaye tailasarpiṣoḥ kuḍavadvaye||174||  khaṇḍīkṛtāni niṣkvāthya śanairantargate rase|  antardhūmaṃ tato dagdhavā cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā ghṛtāplutam||175||  pibet pāṇitalaṃ tasmiñjīrṇe syānmadhurāśanaḥ|  vātaśleṣmāmayānsarvānhanyādviṣagarāṃśca saḥ||176||
translation: Consuming the powdered dry Pippalii fruit and Samula fruit, along with a mixture of

sloka: bhallātakaṃ trikaṭukaṃ triphalāṃ lavaṇatrayam|
translation: antardhūmaṃ dvipalikaṃ gopurīṣāgninā dahet||177||  sa kṣāraḥ sarpiṣā pīto bhojye vā'pyavacūrṇitaḥ|  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīdoṣagulmodāvartaśūlanut||178||
column4: The pungent poison, the three-pointed and bitter-tasting fruit, the group of three salts; the internal smoke, the cow dung, consumed by fire; the alkali, mixed with ghee or eaten in food, that which causes burning in the heart, removal of phlegm, bile, and intestinal worms – all these completely destroy.

sloka: durālabhāṃ karañjau dvau saptaparṇaṃ savatsakam|  ṣaḍgranthāṃ madanaṃ mūrvāṃ pāṭhāmāragvadhaṃ tathā||179||  gomūtreṇa samāṃśāni kṛtvā cūrṇāni dāhayet|  dagdhvā ca taṃ pibet kṣāraṃ grahaṇībalavardhanam||180||
translation: Obtain with difficulty these two karanj flowers and the seven-leaved plant with the name savatsaka, along with the six-bundled madana herb and the murcha plant. After grinding them together with cow's urine and reducing them to ashes, consume those ashes, which enhance digestive power.

sloka: bhūnimbaṃ rohiṇīṃ tiktāṃ paṭolaṃ nimbaparpaṭam|  dahenmāhiṣamūtreṇa kṣāra eṣo'gnivardhanaḥ||181||
translation: This alkaline bhūṇimba, bitter rohiṇī, paṭola, and sour nimba-parpaṭa, when combined with the emission of a male animal's "dahenmāhiṣa" and kṣāra, increase agni's strength.

sloka: dve haridre vacā kuṣṭhaṃ citrakaḥ kaṭurohiṇī|  mustaṃ ca bastamūtreṇa dahet kṣāro'gnivardhanaḥ||182||
translation: With two [dve] ingredients, namely turmeric (haridre) and black cumin seeds (kustham), as well as citraka, kaṭu, rohiṇī, musta; when cooked with bastamootra, it eliminates kshara and increases the heat of agni.

sloka: catuṣpalaṃ sudhākāṇḍāttripalaṃ lavaṇatrayāt|  vārtākīkuḍavaṃ cārkādaṣṭau dve citrakāt pale||183||  dagdhāni vārtākurase guṭikā bhojanottarāḥ|  bhuktaṃ bhuktaṃ pacantyāśu kāsaśvāsārśasāṃ hitāḥ||184||  visūcikāpratiśyāyahṛdrogaśamanāśca tāḥ|  ityeṣā kṣāraguṭikā kṛṣṇātreyeṇa kīrtitā||185||  iti kṣāraguḍikā
translation: The pill-like preparation made of four ingredients including sugar and three types of salt is called vārtākīkuḍava. It is advised to consume it quickly after mixing with water, as it alleviates Kapha-related ailments such as diarrhea, cough, and dyspnea. This has been described as kṣāraguṭikā in the Ātreya text.

sloka: vatsakātiviṣe pāṭhāṃ duḥsparśāṃ hiṅgu citrakam|  cūrṇīkṛtya palāśāgrakṣāre mūtrasrute pacet||186||  āyase bhājane sāndrāttasmāt [40] kolaṃ sukhāmbunā|  madyairvā grahaṇīdoṣaśothārśaḥpāṇḍumān pibet||187||  iti caturthakṣāraḥ
translation: After milking the calf, one should churn curd with a pestle made of citraka wood, and having finely crushed palasha tree bark in water mixed with urine, cook it. Then, on the fourth day of this process, strain the liquid through a filter made from kola plant and made smooth with sukhambu juice, and let an alcohol-free person drink it to remove any impurities caused by alcohol. (186-187)

sloka: triphalāṃ kaṭabhīṃ cavyaṃ bilvamadhyamayorajaḥ|  rohiṇīṃ kaṭukāṃ mustaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ pāṭhāṃ ca hiṅgu ca||188||  madhukaṃ muṣkakayavakṣārau trikaṭukaṃ vacām|  viḍaṅgaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ svarjikāṃ nimbacitrakau||189||  mūrvājamodendrayavān guḍūcīṃ devadāru ca|  kārṣikaṃ lavaṇānāṃ ca pañcānāṃ palikānpṛthak||190||  bhāgān dadhni trikuḍave ghṛtatailena mūrcchitam|  antardhūmaṃ śanairdagdhvā tasmāt pāṇitalaṃ pibet||191||  sarpiṣā kaphavātārśograhaṇīpāṇḍurogavān|  plīhamūtragrahaśvāsahikkākāsakrimijvarān||192||  śoṣātisārau śvayathuṃ pramehānāhahṛdgrahān|  hanyāt sarvaviṣaṃ [41] caiva kṣāro'gnijanano varaḥ||193||  jīrṇe rasairvā madhurairaśnīyāt payasā'pi vāiti pañcamakṣāraḥ
translation: Consuming a mixture of the three fruits, kaṭabhī, cavya, and bilva, along with the juices of madhyamaya, rohiṇī, musta, kuṣṭha, pāṭhā, hiṅgu, madhuka, muṣkakayavakṣarau, trikaṭukam, vacam, viḍaṅga, pippalīmūla, nimba and citraka, combined with the powders of mūrvā, indra, guḍūcī, devadāru, kārṣika, and lavaṇānām, each in equal parts, taken with ghee and milk when digestive fires are subdued, purifies the body by eliminating all impurities, phlegm, wind, bile, piles, urinary disorders, cough, hiccoughs, and fevers. It destroys all toxins and cures old age and diseases caused by the imbalance of the three doshas, viz., kapha, vāta, and pitta. The fifth kṣāra, prepared from the juices of madhura fruits, is beneficial when consumed along with payasā.

sloka: tridoṣe vidhividvaidyaḥ pañca karmāṇi kārayet||194||  ghṛtakṣārāsavāriṣṭān dadyāccāgnivivardhanān|  kriyā yā cānilādīnāṃ nirdiṣṭā grahaṇīṃ prati||195||  vyatyāsāttāṃ samastāṃ vā kuryāddoṣaviśeṣavit|
translation: In the case of the three doshas, the specialist should perform the five treatments: ghee, kshara, asava, and arishta should be administered; additionally, those that are suitable for vata and similar ailments should be prescribed; one who is knowledgeable about the specifics of dosha should implement all of them or only the appropriate ones.

sloka: snehanaṃ svedanaṃ śuddhirlaṅghanaṃ dīpanaṃ ca yat||196||  cūrṇāni lavaṇakṣāramadhvariṣṭasurāsavāḥ|  vividhāstakrayogāśca dīpanānāṃ ca sarpiṣām||197||  grahaṇīrogibhiḥ sevyāḥ
translation: The rejuvenative measures consist of sweat-inducing and oleation , as well as purification , ingestion , and stimulation . These can be achieved through various combinations of powders , salts , alkalis , fermented liquors , and other substances . Additionally, ghee can be used in various ways for stimulation. These treatments should be administered by those skilled in managing the relevant orifices and their functions.

sloka: kriyāṃ cāvasthikīṃ śṛṇu|  ṣṭhīvanaṃ ślaiṣmike rūkṣaṃ dīpanaṃ tiktasaṃyutam||198||
translation: Listen about the persistent action, characterized by stiffening in the cold and pungent region.

sloka: sakṛdrūkṣaṃ sakṛtsnigdhaṃ kṛśe bahukaphe hitam|  parīkṣyāmaṃ śarīrasya dīpanaṃ snehasaṃyutam||199||
translation: We shall examine closely whether the body's illumination has occurred due to being once touched by dryness, moistness, emaciation, or abundance of phlegm, and its union with affection.

sloka: dīpanaṃ bahupittasya tiktaṃ madhurasaṃyutam| bahuvātasya tu snehalavaṇāmlayutaṃ hitam||200||
translation: The illuminator of many substances, pungent yet sweet-tasting, beneficial for those with an excess of wind humor and mixed with tastes such as sour, salty, and bitter.

sloka: sandhukṣati tathā vahnireṣāṃ vidhivadindhanaiḥ| snehameva paraṃ vidyāddurbalānaladīpanam||201||
translation: "The fire, like this, kindles appropriately with fuel , for which the ultimate knowledge is to be compassionate even towards the weak flame ."

sloka: nālaṃ snehasamiddhasya śamāyānnaṃ sugurvapi|  mandāgniravipakvaṃ tu purīṣaṃ yo'tisāryate||202||  dīpanīyauṣadhairyuktāṃ ghṛtamātrāṃ pibettu saḥ| tayā samānaḥ pavanaḥ prasanno [42] mārgamāsthitaḥ||203|| agneḥ samīpacāritvādāśu prakurute balam|
translation: For one who is not capable of controlling their emotions, even a small amount of well-cooked food is difficult to digest. If they drink ghee (clarified butter) mixed with medicinal herbs, equal in quantity to their own strength, their bodily purification will be enhanced and they will become stronger more quickly by staying close to the fire of Agni.

sloka: kāṭhinyādyaḥ purīṣaṃ tu kṛcchrānmuñcati mānavaḥ||204||  saghṛtaṃ lavaṇairyuktaṃ naro'nnāvagrahaṃ pibet|
translation: A man should relieve himself with difficulty of hard excrement
column4: a softened and salt-mixture should be eaten by a person without initial aversion.

sloka: raukṣyānmande pibetsarpistailaṃ vā dīpanairyutam||205||
translation: In the dim lamp's light, one should sip sesame oil as a drink.

sloka: atisnehāttu mande'gnau cūrṇāriṣṭāsavā hitāḥ|  bhinne gudopalepāttu male tailasurāsavāḥ||206||
translation: Even a small amount of fuel, when handled with great care in a damp fire, can produce a potent brew; similarly, even a broken pot filled with ghee, oil, and sura, if neglected, can cause harm.

sloka: udāvartāttu mande'gnau nirūhāḥ snehabastayaḥ|  doṣavṛddhyā tu mande'gnau śuddho doṣavidhiṃ caret||207||
translation: In a weakened fire, one should initially hold back affectionate fuel; when the faults increase, one should carefully follow the proper method for purification.

sloka: vyādhiyuktasya mande tu sarpirevāgnidīpanam|  upavāsācca mande'gnau yavāgūbhiḥ pibedghṛtam||208||  annāvapīḍitaṃ balyaṃ dīpanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ ca tat|
translation: For the weak, affected by disease, just as offering fuel to a weakened snake, so too should they sip ghee in fire made from barley grains; for that restricted diet nourishes and increases the strength of the weakened.

sloka: dīrghakālaprasaṅgāttu kṣāmakṣīṇakṛśānnarān||209||  prasahānāṃ rasaiḥ sāmlairbhojayet piśitāśinām|  laghu tīkṣṇoṣṇaśodhitvāddīpayantyāśu te'nalam||210||  māṃsopacitamāṃsatvāttathā''śutarabṛṃhaṇāḥ|
translation: Due to prolonged association, one becomes tolerant towards the harsh bitterness of the unrefined; one should feed such rough-mannered individuals with well-prepared meats, as this quickly enhances their nourishment and increases their sharpness and warmth.

sloka: nābhojanena kāyāgnirdīpyate nātibhojanāt||211||  yathā nirindhano vahniralpo vā'tīndhanāvṛtaḥ|
translation: Not by scanty eating does the body of a person get ignited, nor by overeating. Like a poorly fed or a well-fed fire enveloped by its fuel, so is the case with the body.

sloka: snehānnavidhibhiścitraiścūrṇāriṣṭasurāsavaiḥ  ||212||  samyakprayuktairbhiṣajā balamagneḥ pravardhate|  yathā hi sāradārvagniḥ sthiraḥ santiṣṭhate ciram||213||
translation: The strength of a person is augmented by physicians who skillfully and appropriately use medicines made from pure ingredients, just as the fire of the autumn season remains steady for a long time.

sloka: snehānnavidhibhistadvadantaragnirbhavet sthiraḥ|  hitaṃ jīrṇe mitaṃ cāśnaṃściramārogyamaśnute||214||  avaiṣamyeṇa dhātūnāmagnivṛddhau yateta nā|  samairdoṣaiḥ samo madhye dehasyoṣmā'gnisaṃsthitaḥ||215||  pacatyannaṃ tadārogyapuṣṭyāyurbalavṛddhaye|  doṣairmando'tivṛddho vā viṣamairjanayedgadān||216||  vācyaṃ mandasya tatroktamativṛddhasya vakṣyate|
translation: With a steady mind similar to the fire enveloped by control through affection for the proper foods, one obtains long-term health as time passes. When the digestive fire is balanced in the middle of the body, it digests food properly, promoting health, strength, and growth. If the fire becomes excessive or deficient due to imbalanced factors, it may produce harmful effects on the body. This has been stated for the case of a weakened person, and will be discussed further in regards to an excessively heated condition.

sloka: nare kṣīṇakaphe pittaṃ kupitaṃ mārutānugam||217||  svoṣmaṇā pāvakasthāne balamagneḥ prayacchati|  tadā labdhabalo dehe virūkṣe sānilo'nalaḥ||218||  paribhūya pacatyannaṃ taikṣṇyādāśu muhurmuhuḥ|  paktvā'nnaṃ sa tato dhātūñchoṇitādīn pacatyapi||219||
translation: In the presence of a person whose bile has decreased in the damaged stomach, the wind follows. Then, having gained strength in the body, just as fire placed in its proper fuel, it consumes the food thoroughly and quickly. Afterwards, it digests even the humors such as blood and others.

sloka: tato daurbalyamātaṅkānmṛtyuṃ copanayennaram|  bhukte'nne labhate śāntiṃ jīrṇamātre pratāmyati||220||  tṛṭśvāsadāhamūrcchādyā vyādhayo'tyagnisambhavāḥ|  tamatyagniṃ gurusnigdhaśītairmadhuravijjalaiḥ||221||  annapānairnayecchāntiṃ dīptamagnimivāmbubhiḥ|  muhurmuhurajīrṇe'pi bhojyānyasyopahārayet||222||  nirindhano'ntaraṃ labdhvā yathainaṃ na vipādayet|
translation: From that point, one should lead a weakened person (towards strength), and also guide them away from fear of death. By eating moderately, they will achieve peace. With cool and soothing actions of gurus, one can counter diseases such as hiccups, fainting, etc., which arise from an imbalance of bodily fire. Just as rain extinguishes a blazing fire, one should consume foods and drinks in small quantities, even if hungry, to prevent aggravating the disease. Having fully recovered, one should cautiously return to their regular diet.

sloka: pāyasaṃ kṛśarāṃ snigdhaṃ paiṣṭikaṃ guḍavaikṛtam||223||  adyāttathaudakānūpapiśitāni bhṛtāni ca|  matsyānviśeṣataḥ ślakṣṇānsthiratoyacarāṃstathā||224||  āvikaṃ ca bhṛtaṃ māṃsamadyādatyagnināśanam [46] |
translation: Today, prepare a thin and smooth rice pudding, made with easily digestible ingredients. Also, cook fish that is tender, does not swim in water, and is served as an offering to the fire.

sloka: yavāgūṃ samadhūcchiṣṭāṃ ghṛtaṃ vā kṣudhitaḥ pibet||225||  godhūmacūrṇamanthaṃ vā vyadhayitvā sirāṃ pibet|  payo vā śarkarāsarpirjīvanīyauṣadhaiḥ śṛtam||226||
translation: Even if hungry, one should sip either leftover sacrificial gruel or ghee; or after churning and straining, the water from boiled barley; or from milk, sugar, clarified butter, or medicinal herbs.

sloka: phalānāṃ tailayonīnāmutkruñcāśca [47] saśarkarāḥ|  mārdavaṃ janayantyagneḥ snigdhā māṃsarasāstathā||227||
translation: The churning of milk produces cream and butter; similarly, the agni (fire) brings about mellowness and softness in meat.

sloka: pibecchītāmbunā sarpirmadhūcchiṣṭena saṃyutam|  godhūmacūrṇaṃ payasā sasarpiṣkaṃ pibennaraḥ||228||  ānūparasasiddhān vā trīn snehāṃstailavarjitān|  payasā sammitaṃ [48] cāpi ghanaṃ trisnehasaṃyutam||229||  nāristanyena saṃyuktāṃ pibedaudumbarīṃ tvacam|  tābhyāṃ vā pāyasaṃ siddhamadyādatyagniśāntaye||230||
translation: One may drink milk, mixed with honey and madhuka (a type of plant), which is uncontaminated and increased three times with the addition of snehana (an ointment or a medicinal product), as well as clarified butter, for soothing the stomach. Alternatively, one may drink rice washed in water, mixed with milk, or payasam (a sweet dish made of milk and sugar) for appeasing the fire within.
