sloka: raktaśālirmahāśāliḥ kalamo lāṅgalaḥ sitaḥ| śāradaḥ ṣaṣṭikaścaiva syādannavidhirarśasām||95|| ityukto bhinnaśakṛtāmarśasāṃ ca kriyākramaḥ|96|
translation: Designated as the sequence of actions for those with controlled excitement and excitement, it is said: "There will be a red-eyed maize of great size, a black antelope, a white one, an autumn season, and also a sixty-year period."

sloka: ye'tyarthaṃ gāḍhaśakṛtasteṣāṃ vakṣyāmi bheṣajam||96||sasnehaiḥ śaktubhiryuktāṃ prasannāṃ lavaṇī kṛtām| dadyānmatsyaṇḍikāṃ pūrvaṃ bhakṣayitvā sanāgarām||97||
translation: I will speak the remedy for those who are deeply troubled; made tranquil with ointments and fortified with strength, (they) should first consume a fish's liver.

sloka: guḍaṃ sanāgaraṃ pāṭhāṃ phalāmlaṃ pāyayecca tam| guḍaṃ ghṛta yava kṣāra yuktaṃ vā'pi prayojayet||98||
translation: Offer to that person either jaggery mixed with ghee, puffed rice, a sour fruit, or a drink; or alternatively, jaggery combined with rice, salt, and ghee.

sloka: yavānīṃ nāgaraṃ pāṭhāṃ dāḍimasya rasaṃ guḍam| satakra lavaṇaṃ dadyādvātavarco'nulomanam||99||
translation: Offer to a learned person a measure of molasses, the taste of pomegranate, mixed with a hundred parts of salt and sprinkled with a gentle breeze.

sloka: duḥsparśakena bilvena yavānyā nāgareṇa vā| ekaikenāpi saṃyuktā pāṭhā hantyarśasāṃ rujam||100||
translation: With a single neem leaf or even a small portion of it, capable of crushing the harm caused by unwholesome touch.

sloka: prāgbhaktaṃ yamake bhṛṣṭān saktubhiścāvacūrṇitān| karañja pallavān dadyādvātarco'nulomanān||101||
translation: Offer to Yamake the untasted, previously enjoyed rice, crushed with pestle and mixed with broken Karnañja leaves, before it is offered to the fire altar. (101)

sloka: madirāṃ vā salavaṇāṃ sīdhuṃ sauvīrakaṃ tathā| guḍa nāgarasaṃyuktaṃ pibedvā paurvabhaktikam||102||
translation: Choose to sip either salavaṇā or madirā, or sauvīraka, which is mixed with nāgarasa and guda, as an expression of your former devotion.

sloka: pippalī nāgara kṣāra kāravī dhānya jīrakaiḥ| phāṇitena ca saṃyojya phalāmlaṃ dāpayedghṛtam||103||
translation: Mix together in ghee the following: Pippalí fruits, nāgara salt, kṣāra, ka+ravi whole spices, dhānya, and jīraka; add this to phala āmlam.

sloka: pippalī pippalīmūlaṃ citrako hastipippalī| śṛṅgaverayavakṣārau taiḥ siddhaṃ vā pibedghṛtam||104||
translation: One should drink clarified butter mixed with the root of pippalī and citraka plants, as well as the bark of a elephant's trunk and the kṣāra of barley, for it brings about success.

sloka: cavya citraka siddhaṃ vā guḍa kṣāra samanvitam| pippalīmūla siddhaṃ vā saguḍakṣāra nāgaram ||105||
translation: Prepared from either cavya and citraka, or siddha with the addition of guda and ksara, or made from pippalimula and sagudaksara, such is the description of nagaram.

sloka: pippalī pippalīmūla dadhi dāḍima dhānyakaiḥ | siddhaṃ sarpi rvidhātavyaṃ vāta varco vibandhanut||106||
translation: Ripen the sesame seeds and mix them with curd, roots of pippal tree, and grains; Prepare ghee as it is mandatory, channeling air and energy for perfection.

sloka: cavyaṃ trikaṭukaṃ pāṭhāṃ kṣāraṃ kustumburūṇi ca| yavānīṃ pippalīmūlamubhe ca viḍasaindhave||107|| citrakaṃ bilvamabhayāṃ piṣṭvā sarpirvipācayet| śakṛdvātānulomyārthaṃ jāte dadhni caturguṇe||108||
translation: Grind together cavya, trikatukam, patha, ksharah, kustumburu, yavani, pippalimula, and ubhe viḍa. Then, with citraka and bilva, mixed with abhayam, cause the serpent to vomit by administering this concoction when the wind moves in a downward direction; this will have fourfold effectiveness.

sloka: pravāhikāṃ gudabhraṃśaṃ mūtrakṛcchraṃ parisravam| gudavaṅkṣaṇaśūlaṃ ca ghṛtametadvyapohati||109||
translation: The flowing feces and urine discharge, along with the intestinal worms and mucus, are expelled by this ghee.

sloka: nāgaraṃ pippalīmūlaṃ citrako hastipippalī| śvadaṃṣṭrā pippalī dhānyaṃ bilvaṃ pāṭhā yavānikā||110|| cāṅgerīsvarase sarpiḥ kalkairetairvipācayet| caturguṇena dadhnā ca tadghṛtaṃ kaphavātanut||111||
translation: Citraka should anoint the city park's pipal tree, and a elephant's pipal tree with sap; he should also eat the bitter bel fruit. He should prepare the rice-water with buttermilk, using four measures of it along with ghee that reduces kapha and vata doshas.

sloka: arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ mūtrakṛcchraṃ pravāhikām| gudabhraṃśārtimānāhaṃ ghṛtametadvyapohati||112||
translation: I, who am afflicted with the grahaṇī disorder, expel this liquid feces along with its accompanying discomforts and the downward movement of gases from the lower abdomen.

sloka: pippalīṃ nāgaraṃ pāṭhāṃ śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ ca pṛthak pṛthak| bhāgāṃstripalikān kṛtvā kaṣāyamupakalpayet||113|| gaṇḍīraṃ pippalīmūlaṃ vyoṣaṃ cavyaṃ ca citrakam| piṣṭvā kaṣāye vinayet pūte dvipalikaṃ bhiṣak||114|| palāni sarpiṣastasmiṃścatvāriṃśat pradāpayet| cāṅgerīsvarasaṃ tulyaṃ sarpiṣā dadhi ṣaḍguṇam||115|| mṛdvagninā tataḥ sādhyaṃ siddhaṃ sarpirnidhāpayet|
translation: Take separately the fibers of the pippalī, the peg of the city, the śvadaṃṣṭrā, and also the bhāgāṃstripalikān. Having made separate piles, one should prepare a kaṣāya. Grind together gaṇḍī, the root of pippalī, vyoṣa, cavya, citrakam, and add kaṣāya; mix well to make a paste. Add to this the equivalent of cāṅgerīsvarasa in sarpiṣa, making it six times as thick as dadhi. With mild heat, cook the sarpir, considering it done when ready.

sloka: tadāhāre vidhātavyaṃ pāne prāyogike vidhau||116|| grahaṇyarśovikāraghnaṃ gulmahṛdroganāśanam| śothaplīhodarānāhamūtrakṛcchrajvarāpaham||117||
translation: At that time, food should be prepared and offered in the prescribed manner during ablutions, capable of destroying phlegm, bile, wind-related ailments, and eliminating symptoms like diarrhea, bloating, indigestion, and fever.

sloka: kāsahikkāruciśvāsasūdanaṃ pārśvaśūlanut| balapuṣṭikaraṃ varṇyamagnisandīpanaṃ param||118||
translation: Who is there to alleviate a fit of cough and increase strength and complexion, fanning on one side with a fan and kindling the fire?

sloka: saguḍāṃ pippalī yuktāṃ ghṛtabhṛṣṭāṃ harītakīm| trivṛddantīyutāṃ vā'pi bhakṣayedānulomikīm||119|| viḍvāta kapha pittānāmānulomye'tha nirvṛte| gude'rśāṃsi praśāmyanti pāvakaścābhivardhate||120||
translation: Consuming a mixture of dried guava, Indian berries, clarified butter, and haritaki in a proper sequence can pacify vata, kapha, and pitta doshas in the body. This results in the soothing of hemorrhoids and the strengthening of the digestive fire.

sloka: barhi tittiri lāvānāṃ rasānamlān susaṃskṛtān| dakṣāṇāṃ vartakānāṃ ca dadyādviḍvātasaṅgrahe||121||
translation: In the consecration of the fire altar, one should offer refined and pure liquids such as barley and sesame to the skilled performers, who are like the chirping tittiri birds, eagerly waiting in anticipation.

sloka: trivṛddantīpalāśānāṃ cāṅgeryāścitrakasya ca| yamake bharjitaṃ dadyācchākaṃ dadhi samanvitam||122||
translation: Of the three-leaved Ashwattha tree and Citraka's branch, a ripe fruit or shoot should be given, filled with curd, to an Angirasa named Yamak.

sloka: upodikāṃ taṇḍulīyaṃ vīrāṃ vāstuka pallavān| suvarcalāṃ saloṇīkāṃ yava śākamavalgujam||123|| kākamācīṃ ruhāpatraṃ mahāpatraṃ tathā'mlikām| jīvantīṃ śaṭiśākaṃ ca śākaṃ gṛñjanakasya ca||124|| dadhi dāḍima siddhāni yamake bharjitāni ca| dhānya nāgara yuktāni śākānyetāni dāpayet||125||
translation: Offer first cooked rice, then freshly sprouted grains such as barley and wheat, along with vegetables like ash gourd, pointed gourd, and bitter gourd. Also include fruits such as crows' delights (a type of wild berry), mangoes, ripe bananas, and those that are well-developed and free from blemishes. Provide these to the teacher, along with yogurt, citron, and other prepared foods.

sloka: godhālopāka mārjāra śvāviduṣṭragavāmapi| kūrma śallakayoścaiva sādhayecchākavadrasān||126|| rakta śālyodanaṃ dadyādrasaistairvāta śāntaye|127|
translation: Even the washerman, along with the mongoose, camel, and cowherd, should strive to prepare a broth. And for soothing the wind, one should give red rice cooked in milk mixed with these juices.

sloka: jñātvā vātolbaṇaṃ rūkṣaṃ mandāgniṃ gudajāturam||127|| madirāṃ śārkaraṃ jātaṃ sīdhuṃ takraṃ tuṣodakam| ariṣṭaṃ dadhimaṇḍaṃ vā śṛtaṃ vā śiśiraṃ jalam||128|| kaṇṭakāryā śṛtaṃ vā'pi śṛtaṃ nāgaradhānyakaiḥ| anupānaṃ bhiṣagdadyādvātavarco'nulomanam||129||
translation: Having known the swift wind, the insipid and weak digestive fire born from cow dung, as well as the intoxicating alcohol produced from sugarcane or grains; the cool and solidified liquid, refrigerated or not, or even the iced water; the beverages such as milk, buttermilk, beer, or toddy, and the exhilarating drink prepared by physicians; one should consume [them] in moderation.

sloka: udāvarta parītā ye ye cātyarthaṃ virūkṣitāḥ| vilomavātāḥ śūlārtāsteṣviṣṭamanuvāsanam||130||
translation: Those who, seeking their own advantage, have turned away from the ultimate goal and are tossed about by contrary winds, such as arrogance and desire – they follow a harmful doctrine.

sloka: pippalīṃ madanaṃ bilvaṃ śatāhvāṃ madhukaṃ vacām| kuṣṭhaṃ śaṭīṃ puṣkarākhyaṃ citrakaṃ devadāru ca||131|| piṣṭvā tailaṃ vipaktavyaṃ payasā dviguṇena ca| arśasāṃ mūḍhavātānāṃ tacchreṣṭhamanuvāsanam||132||
translation: Grinding together bilva, pippalii, madhuka, and kushtha fruits, along with shatavari, citraka, devadaru, and the one known as puṣkara; mixed with twice the amount of milk and ghee, and then given to those suffering from arsha afflictions – this is the most excellent treatment for the foolish.

sloka: gudaniḥsaraṇaṃ śūlaṃ mūtrakṛcchraṃ pravāhikām| kaṭyūrupṛṣṭhadaurbalyamānāhaṃ vaṅkṣaṇāśrayam||133|| picchāsrāvaṃ gude śophaṃ vātavarcovinigraham| utthānaṃ bahuśo yacca jayettaccānuvāsanāt||134||
translation: The anus's natural evacuation is a piercing weapon; the flow of urine is its stream. The area between the hips and thighs is its weakness. I take hold of the folds of the stomach. From the anus comes forth wind and feces, which I contain. I can also raise up many things; victory is indeed mine through my constant support.

sloka: ānuvāsanikaiḥ piṣṭaiḥ sukhoṣṇaiḥ snehasaṃyutaiḥ| dārvantaiḥ stabdha śūlāni gudajāni pralepayet||135|| digdhāstaiḥ prasravantyāśu śleṣma picchāṃ saśoṇitām| kaṇḍūḥ stambhaḥ saruk śophaḥ srutānāṃ vinivartate||136||
translation: With well-ground and warmly mixed grains, combined with sneha, joined with dāru-ants, firmly planted; when applied, they quickly melt the hardened kapha, along with its piccha, sa-sonita, and become discharged. The growths such as kaṇḍū, stambha, ruk, śopha in the ears are halted by this application.

sloka: nirūhaṃ vā prayuñjīta sakṣīraṃ dāśamūlikam| samūtra sneha lavaṇaṃ kalkairyuktaṃ phalādibhiḥ||137||
translation: Should one join (prayujyeta) the unbaked clay (niruham) or not (vā), as a witness (saksiram) to the earthen vessel (dasa mulikam), mixed (yuktam) with sand (samutra), affection (sneha), and salt (lavaṇa), along with fruits (phala) and other (adibhih) materials?

sloka: harītakīnāṃ prasthārdhaṃ prasthamāmalakasya ca| syāt kapitthāddaśapalaṃ tato'rdhā cendravāruṇī||138|| viḍaṅgaṃ pippalī lodhraṃ maricaṃ sailavālukam| dvipalāṃśaṃ jalasyaitaccaturdroṇe vipācayet||139|| droṇaśeṣe rase tasmin pūte śīte samāvapet| guḍasya dviśataṃ tiṣṭhettat pakṣaṃ ghṛtabhājane||140||
pakṣādūrdhvaṃ bhavet peyā tato mātrā yathābalam| asyābhyāsādariṣṭasya gudajā yānti saṅkṣayam||141||
translation: Upon ascending to the side of the scale, the weight becomes greater according to its own strength; through repeated practice of this method, even poison is destroyed.

sloka: grahaṇī pāṇḍu hṛdroga plīha gulmodarāpahaḥ| kuṣṭha śophāruciharo balavarṇāgnivardhanaḥ||142|| siddho'yamabhayāriṣṭaḥ kāmalāśvitranāśanaḥ| kṛmigranthyarbuda vyaṅga rājayakṣma jvarāntakṛt||143|| ityabhayāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: This is the remedy for emaciation, heart disease, enlarged spleen, edema, abscess, leprosy, and debilitating fever, increasing strength and complexion. It is fearless, eliminating diseases such as consumptive illnesses, intestinal parasites, tumors, skin diseases, royal consumption, and fever. Thus, it is called "fearless."

sloka: dantī citraka mūlānāmubhayoḥ pañcamūlayoḥ| bhāgān palāṃśānāpothya jaladroṇe vipācayet||144|| tripalaṃ triphalāyāśca dalānāṃ tatra dāpayet| rase caturtha śeṣe tu pūte śīte samāvapet||145|| tulāṃ guḍasya tattiṣṭhenmāsārdhaṃ ghṛtabhājane| tanmātrayā pibannityamarśobhyo vipramucyate||146||
translation: One should cook the fifth part of the roots of both Citraka and Dantī in twice the quantity of water, discarding the excess water. Of the pulp that remains, one should give three parts to Triphala and mix the fourth part with clarified butter that has been previously strained. By drinking this every day, one is freed from the impurities caused by the ingestion of incompatible foods.

sloka: grahaṇī pāṇḍu rogaghnaṃ vātavarco'nulomanam| dīpanaṃ cārucighnaṃ ca dantyariṣṭamimaṃ viduḥ||147|| iti dantyariṣṭaḥ|
translation: They know this as "dantyariṣṭa," the one that stops the roga (disease) called pāṇḍu, caused by vāta; and also, the one that enhances complexion and brightness.

sloka: harītakī phalaprasthaṃ prasthamāmalakasya ca| viśālāyā dadhitthasya pāṭhācitrakamūlayoḥ||148|| dve dve pale samāpothya dvidroṇe sādhayedapām| pādāvaśeṣe pūte ca rase tasmin pradāpayet||149|| guḍasyaikāṃ tulāṃ vaidyastat sthāpyaṃ ghṛtabhājane| pakṣasthitaṃ pibedenaṃ grahaṇyarśovikāravān||150||
translation: Taking equal measures of haritaki fruit powder and dried Indian berry, one should consume this mixture after appropriately cleaning and filtering it. The physician should weigh out an equal measure of jaggery and mix it into a pot of clarified butter. One should drink this concoction while seated firmly, being careful to avoid spilling.

sloka: hṛtpāṇḍurogaṃ plīhānaṃ kāmalāṃ viṣamajvaram| varcomūtrānilakṛtān vibandhānagnimārdavam||151|| kāsaṃ gulmamudāvartaṃ phalāriṣṭo vyapohati| agnisandīpano hyeṣa kṛṣṇātreyeṇa bhāṣitaḥ||152|| iti phalāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: The affliction of the pale-skin disease, accompanied by enlarged lymph nodes and irregular fever, is eliminated by the windy evacuation medicine. This is declared by Krsna Dvaipayana in the phrase 'Phalaarishta'.

sloka: durālabhāyāḥ prasthaḥ syāccitrakasya vṛṣasya ca| pathyāmalakayoścaiva pāṭhāyā nāgarasya ca||153|| dantyāśca dvipalān bhāgāñjaladroṇe vipācayet| pādāvaśeṣe pūte ca suśīte śarkarāśatam||154|| prakṣipya sthāpayet kumbhe māsārdhaṃ ghṛtabhāvite| pralipte pippalī cavya priyaṅgu kṣaudra sarpiṣā||155||
translation: Obtaining the fine powder of citraka and vṛṣa, one should prepare a pathyā dosage. Of the āmalaka fruits, only the soft and ripe ones are to be chosen, along with an equal measure of jala droṇa. All these ingredients, except for a quarter of the śarkarā, are to be well-mixed in a clean and pure vessel. After adding pippalī, cavya, priyaṅgu, and kṣaudra sarpiṣā, it should then be placed in a pot and allowed to rest for half a month.

sloka: tasya mātrāṃ pibet kāle śārkarasya yathābalam| arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣamudāvartamarocakam||156|| śakṛnmūtrānilodgāravibandhānagnimārdavam| hṛdrogaṃ pāṇḍurogaṃ ca sarvametena sādhayet||157|| iti dvitīyaphalāriṣṭaḥ |
translation: One should drink the due measure of sugar at the appropriate time, according to one's strength; remove the impurities of grapefruit-sized intestines and the softness of digestive fire; cure all heart and whites of the eye diseases with this as the means. This is the second beneficial result.

sloka: navasyāmalakasyaikāṃ kuryājjarjaritāṃ tulām| kuḍavāṃśāśca pippalyo viḍaṅgaṃ maricaṃ tathā||158|| pāṭhāṃ ca pippalī mūlaṃ kramukaṃ cavya citrakau| mañjiṣṭhailvālukaṃ lodhraṃ palikānupakalpayet||159|| kuṣṭhaṃ dāruharidrāṃ ca surāhvaṃ sārivādvayam| indrāhvaṃ bhadramustaṃ ca kuryādardhapalonmitam||160|| catvāri nāgapuṣpasya palānyabhinavasya ca| droṇābhyāmambhaso dvābhyāṃ sādhayitvā'vatārayet||161|| pādāvaśeṣe pūte ca śīte tasmin pradāpayet| mṛdvīkādvyāḍhakarasaṃ śītaṃ niryūhasammitam||162|| śarkarāyāśca bhinnāyā dadyāddviguṇitāṃ tulām| kusumasya rasasyaikamardhaprasthaṃ navasya ca||163|| tvagelāplavapatrāmbusevyakramukakeśarān| cūrṇayitvā tu matimān kārṣikānatra dāpayet||164|| tat sarvaṃ sthāpayet pakṣaṃ sucaukṣe ghṛtabhājane| pralipte sarpiṣā kiñciccharkarāgurudhūpite||165|| pakṣādūrdhvamariṣṭo'yaṃ kanako nāma viśrutaḥ| peyaḥ svāduraso hṛdyaḥ prayogādbhaktarocanaḥ||166||
translation: Of the new mango tree, one should prepare a smooth mortar with the named ingredients: kuḍavāṃśā, pippalya, viḍaṅga, marica, pāṭhā, pippalī, mūla, kramukam, cavya, citrakau, mañjiṣṭhailvāluka, lodhram. Add palikānu and make it according to measurements: kuṣṭha, dāruharidrā, surāhva, sāriva, indraahva, bhadramusta. From the new nāga flowers and its buds, prepare two parts using droṇas and water. In a clean vessel, mix all of these with ghee, adding a little curdled milk and sugar when it starts to solidify. This preparation, named kanaka, is pleasant for the heart, increases taste and is loved by devotees.

sloka: arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣamānāhamudaraṃ jvaram| hṛdrogaṃ pāṇḍutāṃ śothaṃ gulmaṃ varcovinigraham||167|| kāsaṃ śleṣmāmayāṃścogrān sarvānevāpakarṣati| valīpalitakhālityaṃ doṣajaṃ ca vyapohati||168|| iti kanakāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: I, who am free from the flaw of seizure of vital breaths, identify the symptoms of arśas. I expel the diseases of the heart such as jvara, hṛtroga, pāṇḍutā, śotha, and gulma. I stimulate the digestive fire and remove all impurities . I also draw out the heavier constituents like urine and feces , and eliminate any excess mucus with even the most severe cases . Thus says Kanakaariṣṭa.

sloka: patrabhaṅgodakaiḥ śaucaṃ kuryāduṣṇena vā'mbhasā|  iti śuṣkārśasāṃ siddhamuktametaccikitsitam||169||
translation: Achieving cleanliness with fresh water using broken vessel pieces is recommended
column4: this has been declared as effective for those suffering from dry skin.

sloka: cikitsitamidaṃ siddhaṃ srāviṇāṃ śṛṇvataḥ param | tatrānubandho dvividhaḥ śleṣmaṇo mārutasya ca||170||
translation: This treatment, when heard by those who can deliver (sravinam), is indeed successful. In it, there are two binding elements: phlegm and the wind.

sloka: viṭ śyāvaṃ kaṭhinaṃ rūkṣaṃ cādho vāyurna vartate| tanu cāruṇavarṇaṃ ca phenilaṃ cāsṛgarśasām||171|| kaṭyūrugudaśūlaṃ ca daurbalyaṃ yadi cādhikam| tatrānubandho vātasya heturyadi ca rūkṣaṇam||172||
translation: If a body, lacking in vitality and possessing a dark, hard, and rough exterior, does not maintain its slender form with a golden hue; then, when excessive weakness is present, it becomes bound by the force of wind, causing further roughening.

sloka: śithilaṃ śvetapītaṃ ca viṭ snigdhaṃ guru śītalam| yadyarśasāṃ ghanaṃ cāsṛk tantumat pāṇḍu picchilam||173|| gudaṃ sapicchaṃ stimitaṃ guru snigdhaṃ ca kāraṇam| śleṣmānubandho vijñeyastatra raktārśasāṃ budhaiḥ||174||
translation: The soft while and yellow one, having a slimy and heavy quality, cool and smooth; if appearing dense, fine and reddish-brown in color, slippery, light and compact; understanding it to be the cause, the wise recognize there the presence of phlegm and blood.

sloka: snigdhaśītaṃ hitaṃ vāte rūkṣaśītaṃ kaphānuge| cikitsitamidaṃ tasmāt sampradhārya prayojayet||175||
translation: This treatment, being cool and unctuous, and alleviating kapha when the weather is cold and dry, should be remembered and applied accordingly. (175)

sloka: pittaśleṣmādhikaṃ matvā śodhanenopapādayet| sravaṇaṃ cāpyupekṣeta laṅghanairvā samācaret||176||
translation: Perceiving an excess of bile and phlegm, one should eliminate it through proper purgation; one should also ignore the discharge and perform evacuation carefully.

sloka: pravṛttamādāvarśobhyo yo nigṛhṇātyabuddhimān| śoṇitaṃ doṣamanilaṃ tadrogāñjanayedbahūn||177|| raktapittaṃ jvaraṃ tṛṣṇāmagnisādamarocakam| kāmalāṃ śvayathuṃ śūlaṃ guda vaṅkṣaṇa saṃśrayam||178|| kaṇḍvaruḥkoṭhapiḍakāḥ kuṣṭhaṃ pāṇḍvāhvayaṃ gadam| vāta mūtra purīṣāṇāṃ vibandhaṃ śiraso rujam||179|| staimityaṃ gurugātratvaṃ tathā'nyān raktajān gadān|
translation: The one who, being ignorant, restrains the one addicted to the vice of gambling, will produce many diseases such as blood impurities, poison, and bile-related afflictions like jaundice, inflammation, and indigestion. Additionally, he will cause harm to the body in the form of fissures, itching, leprosy, skin disorders, anemia, and other iron-deficiency ailments. Furthermore, he will also aggravate problems related to wind, urine, feces, and stiffness or heaviness in the head and other red-colored bodily substances. Similarly, he will worsen other conditions caused by imbalanced rakta (blood), including various kinds of wounds, cuts, and bruises.

sloka: tasmāt srute duṣṭarakte raktasaṅgrahaṇaṃ hitam||180|| hetu lakṣaṇa kālajño bala śoṇita varṇavit| kālaṃ tāvadupekṣeta yāvannātyayamāpnuyāt||181||
translation: Therefore, one who knows the signs of the impure blood should postpone its collection until the appropriate time. One should be attentive to this until an unchanging (desired) state is achieved.

sloka: agni sandīpanārthaṃ ca rakta saṅgrahaṇāya ca| doṣāṇāṃ pācanārthaṃ ca paraṃ tiktairupācaret||182||
translation: For kindling the fire, for gathering red sandalwood, and also for purifying away faults, one should treat (it) with increasing levels of bitterness.

sloka: yattu prakṣīṇadoṣasya raktaṃ vātolbaṇasya ca| vartate snehasādhyaṃ tat pānābhyaṅgānuvāsanaiḥ||183||
translation: That which is the curable flaw of the inflated one, and is like blood, can be attained through practices like washing, massaging, and following dietary restrictions.

sloka: yattu pittolbaṇaṃ raktaṃ gharmakāle pravartate| stambhanīyaṃ tadekāntānna cedvātakaphānugam||184||
translation: That which is excessively yellowish-red and manifests in hot weather, if it is not a grain dish, it increases vata and kapha dosas.

sloka: kuṭaja tvaṅniryūhaḥ sanāgaraḥ snigdha rakta saṅgrahaṇaḥ| tvagdāḍimasya tadvat sanāgaraścandanarasaśca||185|| candana kirātatiktaka dhanvayavāsāḥ sanāgarāḥ kvathitāḥ| raktārśasāṃ praśamanā dārvītvaguśīra nimbāśca||186|| sātiviṣā kuṭaja tvak phalaṃ ca sarasāñjanaṃ madhuyutāni| raktāpahāni dadyāt pipāsave taṇḍulajalena||187||
translation: A kuṭaja tree, its shoots, resembling a sanāgara (mass of froth), with smooth red bark, capable of collecting rainwater, along with the juice of candana, and other aromatic substances like kirāta, tiktaka, dhanva, yava, ushira, nimbā, etc., when cooked and combined with madhu (honey) and sarasa (juice of pomegranate), can be used to prepare a medicine that helps in reducing bleeding and inflammation. (185-187)

sloka: kuṭaja tvaco vipācyaṃ palaśatamārdraṃ mahendrasalilena| yāvatsyādgatarasaṃ taddravyaṃ pūto rasastato grāhyaḥ||188|| mocarasaḥ sasamaṅgaḥ phalinī ca samāṃśikaistribhistaiśca | vatsakabījaṃ tulyaṃ cūrṇitamatra pradātavyam||189|| pūtotkvathitaḥ sāndraḥ sa raso darvīpralepano grāhyaḥ| mātrākālopahitā rasakriyaiṣā jayatyasṛksrāvam||190||
translation: The powder of bark from the kuṭaja tree, having been heated and made smooth with water from the Mahendra mountain, should be accepted until it loses its original taste. The equalized vatsaka seed, along with the three samāṃśikās, after being crushed and made into a paste, should be given. Once cooked and made thick, the sap that has been smeared on the darvī is to be consumed for the success of the rite.

sloka: chagalī payasā pītā peyāmaṇḍena vā yathāgnibalam| jīrṇauṣadhaśca śālīn payasā chāgena bhuñjīta||191||
translation: Just as a thirsty person should drink milk, or alternatively buttermilk, according to their strength; in the same way, one should consume grains and aged medicines with water, according to their capacity.

sloka: raktārśāṃsyatisāraṃ raktaṃ sāsṛgrujo nihantyāśu| balavacca raktapittaṃ rasakriyaiṣā jayatyubhayabhāgam ||192|| iti kuṭajādirasakriyā|
translation: The one who is afflicted with bloody dysentery quickly eliminates the red-colored contents from the body. This twofold effect is brought about by this medical treatment . Thus, declares the author of the work on simple remedies .

sloka: nīlotpalaṃ samaṅgā mocarasaścandanaṃ tilā lodhram| pītvā cchagalīpayasā bhojyaṃ payasaiva śālyannam||193||
translation: Drinking the cool water mixed with candana powder, extracted from blue lotus, tilaha and lodhraka, one can enjoy a meal as satisfying as consuming rice pudding.

sloka: chāgali payaḥ prayuktaṃ nihanti raktaṃ savāstukarasaṃ ca| dhanva vihaṅga mṛgāṇāṃ raso niramlaḥ kadamlo vā||194||
translation: The milky preparation, mixed with the red juice of a tree, when offered to jackals, birds, and deer, becomes pure and free from any foul taste.

sloka: pāṭhā vatsakabījaṃ rasāñjanaṃ nāgaraṃ yavānyaśca| bilvamiti cārśasaiścūrṇitāni peyāni śūleṣu||195||
translation: Mix into the milk for infants a paste made of barley, beans, and Bilva fruits, along with collyrium and Rasaa; this is to be given through a pipe.

sloka: dārvī kirātatiktaṃ mustaṃ duḥsparśakaśca rudhiraghnam|
translation: A deer-skin, bitter to the touch, unpleasant, and capable of destroying bloodied wounds.

sloka: rakte'tivartamāne śūle ca ghṛtaṃ vidhātavyam||196|| kuṭajaphala valka keśara nīlotpala lodhra dhātakī kalkaiḥ| siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ vidheyaṃ śūle raktārśasāṃ bhiṣajā||197||
translation: In the case of a bleeding wound, clarified butter should be applied; it is to be prepared with the drugs such as Kuṭaja fruit, Valka, Keśara, blue lotus, Lodhra, and Dhātakī. The treatment with clarified butter that has been properly prepared with these drugs is beneficial for patients suffering from bleeding wounds.

sloka: sarpiḥ sadāḍimarasaṃ sayāvaśūkaṃ śṛtaṃ jayatyāśu| raktaṃ saśūlamathavā nidigdhikādugdhikāsiddham||198||
translation: Ghee, always mixed with sugar and salt, becomes popular as āśu, whether thickened or not, and turns into something established, either reddish or having pieces of wood (in it).

sloka: lājāpeyā pītā sacukrikā keśarotpalaiḥ siddhā| hantyāśvasrasrāvaṃ tathā balā pṛśniparṇībhyām||199||
translation: The sacrificial post, adorned with white turmeric and kesara flowers, is capable of stopping the swift flow of blood from a horse; similarly, the pṛshniparni plants also serve this purpose.

sloka: hrīvera bilva nāgara niryūhe sādhitāṃ sanavanītām| vṛkṣāmla dāḍimāmlāmamlīkāmlāṃ sakolāmlām||200||
translation: The bilva tree in the city, obtained without causing harm, along with the three types of āmla and dāḍima fruits, is fit to be used in the rite of hrī.

sloka: gṛñjanakasurāsiddhāṃ dadyādyamakena bharjitāṃ peyām| raktātisāra śūla pravāhikā śotha nigrahaṇīm||201||
translation: Who can offer a potion, ignited by the power of mantras, that neutralizes the deadly poisonous flow of red boils?

sloka: kāśmaryāmalakānāṃ sakarbudārān phalāmlāṃśca| gṛñjanaka śālmalīnāṃ kṣīriṇyāścukrikāyāśca||202|| nyagrodha śuṅgakānāṃ khaṇḍāṃstathā kovidāra puṣpāṇām| dadhnaḥ sareṇa siddhān dadyādrakte pravṛtte'ti||203||
translation: Of the ashmaris and amlakas, which are ripened and emit a sweet scent, and of the gṛñjanaka śālmalīnām, kṣīriṇyāścukrikāyāśca, as well as the ripe fruit of nyagrodha and shungaka trees, what is obtained by the wise, and what is given by the milky sap flowing from them when they bloom?

sloka: siddhaṃ palāṇḍuśākaṃ takreṇopodikāṃ sabadarāmlām| rudhirasrave pradadyānmasūrasūpaṃ ca takrāmlam||204||
translation: The perfect Palanda shaka, mixed with takra, offered into the conch filled with savory fluid and tamarind; and the soured balls of masura are presented.

sloka: payasā śṛtena yūṣai rmasūra mudgāḍhakīmakuṣṭhānām | bhojanamadyādamlaiḥ śāli śyāmāka kodravajam||205||
translation: Made with curd and butter, the gruel of śāli, śyāmāka, and kodrava grains is the first course of eating for those afflicted with mouth ulcers.

sloka: śaśa hariṇa lāva māṃsaiḥ kapiñjalaiṇeyakaiḥ susiddhaiśca| bhojanamadyādamlairmadhurairīṣat samaricairvā||206||
translation: Consuming the flesh of hares, deer, and birds, along with properly ripened ones, is a meal made sweet with various delicious liquors – this is what I partake of only slightly.

sloka: dakṣa śikhi tittiri rasairdvikakudalo pākajaiśca madhurāmlaiḥ| adyādrasairativaheṣvarśaḥsvanilolbaṇaśarīraḥ||207||
translation:
Skilled Daksha, with a splendid peacock feather,
With the taste of sweet Rasi and Paka,
Today becomes the irresistible lord of the senses,
Adorned with the powerful form of wind.

sloka: rasa khaḍa yūṣa yavāgū saṃyogataḥ kevalo'thavā jayati| raktamativartamānaṃ vātaṃ ca palāṇḍurupayuktaḥ||208||
translation: Born victorious is the mixture of yava (barley) and usira (calamus), when combined with rasa khanda (juice or essence extractor), solely because it successfully holds back the rushing wind that scatters red sandalwood powder.

sloka: chāgāntarādhi taruṇaṃ sarudhiramupasādhitaṃ bahu palāṇḍu| vyatyāsānmadhurāmlaṃ viṭśoṇitasaṅkṣaye deyam||209||
translation: A young shoot, nourished from within by the nectar of sap, should be offered after removing the bark and impurities; such is the rule.

sloka: navanīta tilābhyāsāt keśara navanīta śarkarābhyāsāt| dadhi sara mathitābhyāsādarśāṃsyapayānti raktāni||210||
translation: From sesame seeds consumed with fresh butter and sugar mixed with milk, one gets complexion similar to that of pomegranate.

sloka: navanītaghṛtaṃ chāgaṃ māṃsaṃ ca saṣaṣṭikaḥ śāliḥ| taruṇaśca surā maṇḍastaruṇī ca surā nihantyasram||211||
translation: Newly acquired ghee, a goat, six months old paddy, a young shoot of barley, and two types of alcoholic beverages - all these together consume the strength (of a person).

sloka: prāyeṇa vāta bahulānyarśāṃsi bhavantyatisrute rakte| duṣṭe'pi ca kapha pitte tasmādanilo'dhiko jñeyaḥ||212||
translation: Generally, in most cases, the air element becomes more prominent during the predominance of phlegm and bile. Therefore, it should be known as superior in that context.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā tu raktapittaṃ prabalaṃ kapha vāta liṅgamalpaṃ ca| śītā kriyā prayojyā yatheritā vakṣyate cānyā ||213||
translation: Having seen a powerful rakta Pitta condition, indicative of an imbalance of Kapha and Vata, and minimal in nature, one should apply cooling measures, as will be described; other [measures] will be spoken of.

sloka: madhukaṃ sapañcavalkaṃ badarītvagudumbaraṃ dhavapaṭolam| pariṣecane vidadhyādvṛṣakakuma yavāsa nimbāṃśca||214||
translation: In the rite of ablution, one should apply the exudation of Madhuka, the milky latex of Sapam and Valka, the bark of Badari, the resin of Dhavapaṭala, together with the powder of Vṛṣakakuma and the seeds of Yava and the fruit of Nimbā.

sloka: rakte'tivartamāne dāhe klede'vagāhayeccāpi| madhuka mṛṇāla padmaka candana kuśa kāśa niṣkvāthe||215||
translation: In the spreading fire and quenching floods, as also in streams, Madhuka and other similar plants like Mritnala, Padmaka, Chandana, Kusa and Kasha release their scents.

sloka: ikṣurasa madhuka vetasa niryūhe śītale payasi vā tam| avagāhayet pradigdhaṃ pūrvaṃ śiśireṇa tailena||216||
translation: Should one first immerse in the coolness of rainwater or of the snow-capped peaks, that previous impurity, the honey-like sap of the Madhuka and Vetasa trees, mixed with the juice of sugarcane?

sloka: dattvā ghṛtaṃ saśarkaramupasthadeśe gude trikadeśe ca| śiśira jala sparśa sukhā dhārā prastambhanī yojyā||217||
translation: Having offered the ghee and sugar at the upasthadesha (base) of the trikadesha (three-petaled) guda (pericarp), one should fix a pleasing cool jala sparshah (touch of water) as a dhara (flow) prastambhanii (inhibitor) in shrishira (the body).

sloka: kadalīdalairabhinavaiḥ puṣkarapatraiśca śītajalasiktaiḥ|  pracchādanaṃ muhurmuhuriṣṭaṃ padmotpaladalaiśca||218||
translation: Shielded again and again with new, cool, and fresh kadalikada leaves and lotus petals.

sloka: durvāghṛtapradehaḥ śatadhautasahasradhautamapi sarpiḥ|  vyajanapavanaḥ suśīto raktasrāvaṃ jayatyāśu||219||
translation: Even a ghee that has been washed a hundred times , if offered with ill intent , becomes as offensive as pus; swiftly it conquers . The pure act of fanning is always virtuous.

sloka: samaṅgā madhukābhyāṃ tila madhukābhyāṃ rasāñjanavṛtābhyām| sarjarasa ghṛtābhyāṃ vā nimbaghṛtābhyāṃ madhughṛtābhyāṃ vā||220|| dārvītvaksarpirbhyāṃ sacandanābhyāmathotpalaghṛtābhyām| dāhe klede ca gudabhraṃśe gudajāḥ pratisāraṇīyāḥ syuḥ||221||
translation: With sesame seeds and honey, or with sugar mixed, or with clarified butter from cows' milk, or with that of neem and madhuka; when subjected to fire, heat, or a fall, the excrements of these cows become remedies for diarrhea.

sloka: ābhiḥ kriyābhirathavā śītābhiryasya tiṣṭhati na raktam| taṃ kāle snigdhoṣṇairmāṃsarasaistarpayenmatimān||222||
translation: With cooling actions or with heating ones, the wise should maintain the balance of someone's bodily fluids, nourishing them with oils and spices at the appropriate time.

sloka: avapīḍaka sarpirbhiḥ koṣṇai rghṛta tailikaistathā'bhyaṅgaiḥ| kṣīra ghṛta taila sekaiḥ koṣṇaistamupācaredāśu||223||
translation: With finely powdered pieces of snake-venom antidote, equal parts of ghee and butter mixed with water, should be quickly applied.

sloka: koṣṇena vātaprabale ghṛtamaṇḍenānuvāsayecchīghram| picchābastiṃ dadyāt kāle tasyāthavā siddham||224||
translation: Should one efficiently cause a ghee vessel to be heated by the power of the wind and fire, or should one wait for the proper time? It is accomplished either way.

sloka: yavāsa kuśa kāśānaṃ mūlaṃ puṣpaṃ ca śālmalam| nyagrodhodumbarāśvattha śuṅgāśca dvipalonmitāḥ||225|| triprasthaṃ salilasyaitat kṣīraprasthaṃ ca sādhayet| kṣīraśeṣaṃ kaṣāyaṃ ca pūtaṃ kalkairvimiśrayet||226|| kalkāḥ śālmali niryāsa samaṅgā candanotpalam| vatsakasya ca bījāni priyaṅguḥ padmakeśaram||227|| picchābastirayaṃ siddhaḥ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaraḥ| pravāhikā gudabhraṃśa raktasrāva jvarāpahaḥ||228||
translation: Growing in the Kusha grassland is a Kasha plant, its root and flower are from a Salmali tree. The roots of Nyagrodha, Udumbara, Ashwattha, and Shunga trees also; these, when combined with three Prasthas of water and milk, make for Ksheera siddha. After boiling and straining it through śālmalī niryāsa, candana, utpala, the seeds of vatsaka, priyangu, and keśara, it becomes pure. When further processed with picchabasti, saghritaksha-sharkara, pravahika, gudabhramsha, raktasrava, and jvarapaha, it becomes a medicinal concoction.

sloka: prapauṇḍarīkaṃ madhukaṃ picchābastau yatheritān| piṣṭvā'nuvāsanaṃ snehaṃ kṣīradviguṇitaṃ pacet||229|| iti picchābastiḥ|`
translation: Having prepared the "picchabastau" (a type of flour) mixed with honey and the powder of the Pundarika tree, one should cook it with milk doubled in quantity, added with snow-like freshness.

sloka: hrīveramutpalaṃ lodhraṃ samaṅgā cavya candanam| pāṭhā sātiviṣā bilvaṃ dhātakī devadāru ca||230|| dārvī tvaṅ nāgaraṃ māṃsī mustaṃ kṣāro yavāgrajaḥ| citrakaśceti peṣyāṇi cāṅgerīsvarase ghṛtam||231|| aikadhyaṃ sādhayet sarvaṃ tat sarpiḥ paramauṣadham|
translation: Prepare with great care a single unguent by combining the following: Hrī , Utпала , Lodhrа , Samaṅgā , Cavya , Candana , Pāṭhā , Śāti-viṣā Bilva , Dhātakī , Devadāru , Dārvī , Tvaṅ , Nāgaram , Māṃsī , Musta , Kṣāra , Yava-agrajaḥ , Citraka , Peśyāṇi , Cāṅgerīsvaram , and Ghṛtam . This unguent, Sarpiḥ, becomes the ultimate medicine.

sloka: arśotisāra grahaṇī pāṇḍuroge jvare'rucau||232|| mūtrakṛcchre gudabhraṃśe bastyānāhe pravāhaṇe| picchāsrāve'rśasāṃ śūle yojyametattridoṣanut||233|| iti hrīverādighṛtam|
translation: The one who restrains vomiting and diarrhea in a feverish patient with fair complexion, who is afflicted by inflammation of the urinary system and rupture of the anus; who skillfully uses suction and leech application; such a person has neutralized three types of impurities. This is declared as the initial level of shameful conduct (related to bodily processes).

sloka: avākpuṣpī balā dārvī pṛśniparṇī trikaṇṭakaḥ| nyagrodhodumbarāśvatthaśuṅgāśca dvipalonmitāḥ||234|| kaṣāya eṣāṃ peṣyāstu jīvantī kaṭurohiṇī| pippalī pippalīmūlaṃ nāgaraṃ suradāru ca||235|| kaliṅgāḥ śālmalaṃ puṣpaṃ vīrā candanamutpalam | kaṭphalaṃ citrako mustaṃ priyaṅgvativiṣāsthirāḥ||236|| padmotpalānāṃ kiñjalkaḥ samaṅgā sanidigdhikā| bilvaṃ mocarasaḥ pāṭhā bhāgāḥ karṣasamanvitāḥ||237|| catuṣprasthe śṛtaṃ prasthaṃ kaṣāyamavatārayet| triṃśatpalāni prastho'tra vijñeyo dvipalādhikaḥ||238|| suniṣaṇṇakacāṅgeryoḥ prasthau dvau svarasasya ca| sarvairetairyathoddiṣṭairghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||239||
translation: The following are the individual descriptions of various trees and plants: a type of creeper , strong like a bamboo , with spear-like leaves , trikaṇṭaka , nyagrodha , udumbara , aśvattha , śuṅgā , growing in pairs , pala , surrounded by : kaṣāya eṣām is to be removed; peṣyāstu jīvantī kaṭuruhṇī should not be cut; pippalī , its bark and mūlam ; nāgaram , sura dāru ; kaliṅgāḥ , śālmalam , puṣpam and vīrā candanam , utpalam , kaṭphala , citraka , musta , priyaṅgvatī , ati viṣa asthirāḥ ; padma , utpalānām kiñjalkaḥ , samaṅgā , sanidigdhikā bilvam ; mā ūca rasaḥ of pāṭhāḥ , bhāgāḥ karṣa samanvitāḥ ; catuṣprasthe śṛtam prastham should be kept clean; the quantity of thirty palāni is to be considered as an adhikaḥ in dvip

sloka: etadarśaḥsvatīsāre raktasrāve tridoṣaje| pravāhaṇe gudabhraṃśe picchāsu vividhāsu ca||240|| utthāne cātibahuśaḥ śothaśūle gudāśraye| mūtragrahe mūḍhavāte mande'gnāvarucāvapi||241|| prayojyaṃ vidhivat sarpirbalavarṇāgnivardhanam| vividheṣvannapāneṣu kevalaṃ vā niratyayam||242|| iti suniṣaṇṇakacāṅgerīghṛtam|
translation: This is to be applied as per rules: the red-eyed one in the current cycle, with three doshas and a bright red appearance; when there is flow interruption in the lower abdomen, in various types of faeces, and also during flatulence; at the time of lifting heavy objects, in hemorrhoids, in wounds, in mucus discharges, in the case of a foolish person, in the air passing from the mouth, in weak digestion, in a feeble agni , and also when not eating anything; the serpent-like one, with great strength, increasing agni, in various types of food and drink; thus it is described in Sunishannakacangerighrita.

sloka: bhavanti cātra vyatyāsānmadhurāmlāni śītoṣṇāni ca yojayet| nityamagnibalāpekṣī jayatyarśaḥkṛtān gadān||243||
translation: Here arise both sweet and pungent sensations, cold and hot , which must be constantly balanced with fire . The one who masters the mace becomes victorious .

sloka: trayo vikārāḥ prāyeṇa ye parasparahetavaḥ| arśāṃsi cātisāraśca grahaṇīdoṣa eva ca||244|| eṣāmagnibale hīne vṛddhirvṛddhe parikṣayaḥ| tasmādagnibalaṃ rakṣyameṣu triṣu viśeṣataḥ||245||
translation: The three transformations, generally arising from mutual causes, namely, exertion, perspiration, and discharge, as well as grasping faults – when the agni's strength is diminished, there is growth (of these) and when it increases, there is decay. Therefore, the strength of agni should be protected in these three aspects in particular.

sloka: bhṛṣṭaiḥ śākai ryavāgūbhiryūṣairmāṃsarasaiḥ khaḍaiḥ| kṣīra takra prayogaiśca vividhairgudajāñjayet||246||
translation: He fattens himself with choice herbs and plants, meat soups, and broths; and also with milk and buttermilk, through the use of various methods.

sloka: yadvāyorānulomyāya yadagnibalavṛddhaye| annapānauṣadhadravyaṃ tat sevyaṃ nityamarśasaiḥ||247|| yadato viparītaṃ syānnidāne yacca darśitam| gudajābhiparītena tat sevyaṃ na kadācana||248||
translation: That which is in line with the natural order, increasing the digestive fire and promoting the intake of food, medicines, and other substances should be consumed regularly. However, that which goes against this principle or is hidden, as well as what is shown during inappropriate times, should never be consumed.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  arśasāṃ dvividhaṃ janma pṛthagāyatanāni ca| sthāna saṃsthānaliṅgāni sādhyāsādhyaviniścayaḥ||249||
translation: In that regard, there are two types of manifestations of the seers' hymns and separate places for their origin; (there are) specific indicators of location and establishment, as well as ascertainment of what is to be achieved and not.

sloka: abhyaṅgāḥ svedanaṃ dhūmāḥ sāvagāhāḥ pralepanāḥ| śoṇitasyāvasekaśca yogā dīpanapācanāḥ||250||
translation: Massages, sweating, fumigation, rinsing, anointing; application of oil, pouring of liquid substances like blood, and consumption of Yogic practices, illuminating and digestive substances.

sloka: pānānna vidhiragryaśca vātavarco'nulomanaḥ| yogāḥ saṃśamanīyāśca sarpīṃṣi vividhāni ca||251|| bastayastakrayogāśca varāriṣṭāḥ saśarkarāḥ| śuṣkāṇāmarśasāṃ śastāḥ srāviṇāṃ lakṣaṇāni ca||252|| dvividhaṃ sānubandhānāṃ teṣāṃ ceṣṭaṃ yadauṣadham| rakta saṅgrahaṇāḥ kvāthāḥ peṣyāśca vividhātmakāḥ||253|| snehāhāra vidhiścāgryo yogāśca pratisāraṇāḥ| prakṣālanāvagāhāśca pradehāḥ secanāni ca||254|| ativṛttasya raktasya vidhātavyaṃ yadauṣadham| tatsarvamiha nirdiṣṭaṃ gudajānāṃ cikitsite||255||
translation: The foremost rule regarding intake is to consume food and drink; the wind's force should be regulated through exhalation and inhalation. Yogic practices should also be adopted, as well as methods for calming down the various types of serpents. The ways to prepare diverse kinds of rice-gruels, sweets, and sour foods have been discussed. Two categories of substances bound together require specific actions: restraining blood flow through cauterization, using various methods; inducing bleeding in certain conditions; or applying various other treatments. The primary rule regarding oleation is to apply oil, while emesis is recommended for eliminating excessive phlegm and mucus. Different parts of the body should be bathed, and laxatives administered as required. When there is an excess of blood, it is advised to reduce it through medical treatment. All these methods are detailed in the treatment of piles.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte  cikitsāsthāne'rśaścikitsitaṃ nāma caturdaśo'dhyāyaḥ||14||
translation: Named "Fourteen Chapters," this is the treatment, thoroughly revised by Caraka, described in the scripture regarding the fire offerings and consecrations, relating to the place of medical treatment.

sloka: athātaḥ kāsacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ ||2||
translation: Then we shall explain what is to be understood. Thus spoke the Lord Atreya.

sloka: tapasā yaśasā dhṛtyā dhiyā ca parayā'nvitaḥ |  ātreyaḥ kāsaśāntyarthaṃ prāha siddhaṃ cikitsitam ||3|| vātādijāstrayo ye ca kṣatajaḥ kṣayajastathā |  pañcaite syurnṛṇāṃ kāsā vardhamānāḥ kṣayapradāḥ ||4||
translation: Endowed with austerity, reputation, and steadfastness of the highest order, Atreya spoke what is established as the proven treatment for achieving peace. The three born from the wind and such, as well as the five formed among humans, all growing and leading to decay, are eight in total.

sloka: pūrvarūpaṃ bhavetteṣāṃ śūkapūrṇagalāsyatā |  kaṇṭhe kaṇḍūśca bhojyānāmavarodhaśca jāyate ||5||
translation: The original form of the eatables (such as fruits) becomes manifest as early as in their buds, in the form of downward pointing hairs, swelling, and the beginning of taste.

sloka: adhaḥpratihato vāyurūrdhvasrotaḥsamāśritaḥ |  udānabhāvamāpannaḥ kaṇṭhe saktastathorasi ||6||
translation: The wind, originally settled above, but now directed downward and resting at the chest and throat, has taken on the form of udāna.

sloka: āviśya śirasaḥ khāni sarvāṇi pratipūrayan |  ābhañjannākṣipan dehaṃ hanumanye tathā'kṣiṇī ||7||
translation: Entering the caves of all the senses in the head, completely filling them, tearing apart and casting down the body, I know him to be Hanuman.

sloka: netre pṛṣṭhamuraḥpārśve nirbhujya stambhayaṃstataḥ |  śuṣko vā sakapho vā'pi kasanātkāsa ucyate ||8||
translation: Deprived of nourishment from the eyes and back, whether dry or fleshy, it is called "kasanaatkasa" (a withered or emaciated thing).

sloka: pratighātaviśeṣeṇa tasya vāyoḥ saraṃhasaḥ |  vedanāśabdavaiśiṣṭyaṃ kāsānāmupajāyate ||9||
translation: The distinctive quality of the breath of one who opposes is reborn as a specific sensation of pain for some.

sloka: rūkṣaśītakaṣāyālpapramitānaśanaṃ striyaḥ |  vegadhāraṇamāyāso vātakāsapravartakāḥ ||10||  hṛtpārśvoraḥśiraḥśūlasvarabhedakaro bhṛśam |  śuṣkoraḥkaṇṭhavakrasya hṛṣṭalomnaḥ pratāmyataḥ ||11||  nirghoṣadainyastananadaurbalyakṣobhamohakṛt |  śuṣkakāsaḥ kaphaṃ śuṣkaṃ kṛcchrānmuktvā'lpatāṃ vrajet ||12||  snigdhāmlalavaṇoṣṇaiśca bhuktapītaiḥ praśāmyati |  ūrdhvavātasya jīrṇe'nne vegavānmāruto bhavet ||13||
translation:
(10) Striyaḥ, those who are weak due to lack of proper nutrition and wearing rough, simple clothing, can barely sustain themselves. They are afflicted with Vāta Kāsa, caused by the aggravation of Vāyu in their bodies.

(11) Their hṛt-pārśva (chest and sides), uraḥ (abdomen), śiraḥ (head), and śūla (spine) become painful and inflamed, causing great distress. Despite being thin and weak, they still manage to maintain a joyful demeanor.

(12) Their Kapha becomes aggravated due to the lack of proper nutrition, leading to Śuṣka Kāsa and other related ailments. After enduring much hardship, they are eventually relieved from their discomforts and find peace.

(13) When they consume wholesome food that is sweet, sour, salty, and warm in nature, their bodies become pacified and the wind within them becomes still, leading to a state of equilibrium.

sloka: kaṭukoṣṇavidāhyamlakṣārāṇāmatisevanam |  pittakāsakaraṃ krodhaḥ santāpaścāgnisūryajaḥ ||14||  pītaniṣṭhīvanākṣitvaṃ tiktāsyatvaṃ svarāmayaḥ |  urodhūmāyanaṃ tṛṣṇā dāho moho'rucirbhramaḥ ||15||  pratataṃ kāsamānaśca jyotīṃṣīva ca paśyati |  śleṣmāṇaṃ pittasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ niṣṭhīvati ca paittike ||16||
translation: The lack of astringent, sour, salty, and warm food causes the bodily humors to become imbalanced: roughness originating from Vata, intense heat from fire, mucus from Kapha, and bile from Pitta. These manifest as harsh speech, anger causing pain, phlegm, and imbalance in the body. When one abstains from sweet, sour, and salty foods and instead consumes astringent, bitter, and pungent food, the bodily humors return to their natural state. Excessive consumption of light and dry food leads to a Vata imbalance, while an abundance of heavy and oily food results in Kapha dominance. An overindulgence in hot, spicy, and sour foods disrupts Pitta. As the humors become balanced, the body becomes healthy, the senses become clear, and the mind finds peace.

sloka: gurvabhiṣyandimadhurasnigdhasvapnāviceṣṭanaiḥ |  vṛddhaḥ śleṣmā'nilaṃ ruddhvā kaphakāsaṃ karoti hi ||17||  mandāgnitvārucicchardipīnasotkleśagauravaiḥ |  lomaharṣāsyamādhuryakledasaṃsadanairyutam ||18||  bahulaṃ madhuraṃ snigdhaṃ niṣṭhīvati ghanaṃ kapham |  kāsamāno hyarug vakṣaḥ sampūrṇamiva manyate ||19||
translation:
Consuming excessively pungent, hot, sharp, sour, and salty substances causes an increase in bile, which leads to cough, anger, and inflammation. A person with weak digestive fire, poor complexion, and excessive thirst, sweating, and burning sensation also suffers from similar symptoms. When phlegm is increased due to the consumption of unctuous, sweet, and salty foods or when it is naturally secreted, a person may feel heavy in the chest, as if it is full, and experience confusion and dizziness. The stars seem to twinkle before the eyes, and phlegm is expelled from the nose and mouth. (17-19)

The translation is based on the given word split and the general meanings of the words. However, the verse seems to be a part of a larger medical text that describes the symptoms of an imbalance in the bodily humors (doshas). The identification of specific substances or foods mentioned in the verse would require additional context or information.

sloka: ativyavāyabhārādhvayuddhāśvagajavigrahaiḥ |  rūkṣasyoraḥ kṣataṃ vāyurgṛhītvā kāsamāvahet ||20||
translation: Becoming afflicted with the excessive indulgence in sexual activity, horse and elephant fights, the old and overweight one, who is blocked by phlegm, causes vomiting, thirst, nasal discharge, and physical impurity, generates an abundance of thick phlegm, resembling a swollen chest.

sloka: sa pūrvaṃ kāsate śuṣkaṃ tataḥ ṣṭhīvet saśoṇitam |  kaṇṭhena rujatā'tyarthaṃ virugṇeneva corasā ||21||  sūcībhiriva tīkṣṇābhistudyamānena śūlinā |  duḥkhasparśena śūlena bhedapīḍābhitāpinā ||22||
translation:
Exceeding the bounds of propriety, a burden to himself and others, like a dry tree that stands in the path, such is the one who is afflicted by unrighteous desires. With sharp instruments, like a butcher who pierces the vital organs of an elephant or a bull, so does he torment himself through his own wicked actions. (21-22)

Note: The word "ati" means "exceeding" and "vyavaya" means "sexual intercourse". This combined meaning has been used in the translation. Similarly, "bhara" means "burden", "adhva" means "path", "yut" means "standing", "dhah" means "like", "gaja" means "elephant", "vigrahaih" means "organs", "rukshasya" means "dry", "urasah" means "chest", "ksatam" means "wounded", "vayuh" means "air", "grihitva" means "held", "kamsam" means "meat", "avahet" means "takes". These meanings have been used in the translation. The words "dhah", "gaja", and "vigrahaih" are not translated as they do not add any further meaning to the translation.

sloka: parvabhedajvaraśvāsatṛṣṇāvaisvaryapīḍitaḥ |  pārāvata ivākūjan kāsavegātkṣatodbhavāt ||23||
translation: Previously dry, now pierced by a sharp weapon at his throat, blood gushes and flows; resembling a cloud, he is tormented by the burning sensation caused by the separating of the mountain's parts.

sloka: viṣamāsātmyabhojyātivyavāyādveganigrahāt |  ghṛṇināṃ śocatāṃ nṝṇāṃ vyāpanne'gnau trayo malāḥ ||24||
translation: The three impurities of fever, dyspnea, and thirst, caused by a separation from the appropriate time for eating, overindulgence, suppression of natural urges, and exertion, trouble those who are compassionate.

sloka: kupitāḥ kṣayajaṃ kāsaṃ kuryurdehakṣayapradam |  durgandhaṃ haritaṃ raktaṃ ṣṭhīvet pūyopamaṃ kapham ||25||  sthānādutkāsamānaśca hṛdayaṃ manyate cyutam |  akasmāduṣṇaśītārto bahvāśī durbalaḥ kṛśaḥ ||26||  snigdhācchamukhavarṇatvak śrīmaddarśanalocanaḥ |  pāṇipādatalaiḥ ślakṣṇaiḥ satatāsūyako ghṛṇī ||27||  jvaro miśrākṛtistasya pārśvaruk pīnaso'ruciḥ |  bhinnasaṃhatavarcastvaṃ svarabhedo'nimittataḥ ||28||
translation: Due to uneven digestion caused by improper eating habits , excessive indulgence in sexual activities , and suppression of natural urges , some people may experience disgust and sorrow among the masses . This is due to the accumulation of undigested food in the digestive system, which can lead to various symptoms such as foul-smelling stools , loose stools , bloody stools , and mucus in the stools . Other symptoms may include feeling heavy in the stomach , thinking that the heart is sinking , feeling thirsty even after drinking water , emaciation , and oily or sticky stools . Additionally, symptoms such as fever , foul odor , and irregular breathing sounds may also be present.

sloka: ityeṣa kṣayajaḥ kāsaḥ kṣīṇānāṃ dehanāśanaḥ |  sādhyo balavatāṃ vā syādyāpyastvevaṃ kṣatotthitaḥ ||29||  navau kadācit sidhyetāmetau pādaguṇānvitau |  sthavirāṇāṃ jarākāsaḥ sarvo yāpyaḥ prakīrtitaḥ ||30||
translation: The angry one who causes decay, what is this Kasa (a type of cough) that brings forth a foul smell, turns the color of the face yellowish-green, and dries up the body? It is said to be a natural affliction for the old, affecting their vision, complexion, strength, and balance. Its various forms, mixed with jvara (fever), are often found in weak and emaciated persons, causing distress with its unsteady and changing appearance, affecting the luster of the body, the clarity of the eyes, and the color of the sides, face, and complexion. What is this, O Tamasa (darkness), that arises from the distinction of your vocal vibrations?

sloka: trīnsādhyānsādhayetpūrvān pathyairyāpyāṃśca yāpayet |  cikitsāmata ūrdhvaṃ tu śṛṇu kāsanibarhiṇīm ||31||
translation: "Having accomplished the three main duties prior, let one also perform the remaining ones. Now listen, I will tell you about medicine that uplifts and eliminates the decay of the body in the elderly. The one who is powerful can achieve this."

sloka: rūkṣasyānilajaṃ kāsamādau snehairupācaret |  sarpirbhirbastibhiḥ peyāyūṣakṣīrarasādibhiḥ ||32||  vātaghnasiddhaiḥ snehādyairdhūmairlehaiśca yuktitaḥ |  abhyaṅgaiḥ pariṣekaiśca snigdhaiḥ svedaiśca buddhimān ||33||  bastibhirbaddhaviḍvātaṃ śuṣkordhvaṃ cordhvabhaktikaiḥ |  ghṛtaiḥ sapittaṃ sakaphaṃ jayet snehavirecanaiḥ ||34||
translation: One should properly care for the dry earth's crevices using moisturizing agents such as sweat, oils, and appropriate liquids; this is considered therapeutic. Furthermore, listen carefully to my advice on how to treat the fissures of the earth that extend upward.

sloka: kaṇṭakārīguḍūcībhyāṃ pṛthak triṃśatpalādrase |  prasthaḥ siddho ghṛtādvātakāsanudvahnidīpanaḥ ||35||  iti kaṇṭakārīghṛtam |
translation: A wise person should apply separately, using thirty palmfuls of oil, a mixture of oils that counteracts the drying wind, with herbs, fats, and the residue of ghee, along with smoke and heat, for anointing, bathing, and sweating, in order to conquer phlegm and bile, and to alleviate vata with warm, unctuous ointments.

sloka: pippalīpippalīmūlacavyacitrakanāgaraiḥ |  dhānyapāṭhāvacārāsnāyaṣṭyāhvakṣārahiṅgubhiḥ ||36||  kolamātrairghṛtaprasthāddaśamūlīrasāḍhake |  siddhāccaturthikāṃ pītvā peyāmaṇḍaṃ pibedanu ||37||  tacchvāsakāsahṛtpārśvagrahaṇīdoṣagulmanut |  pippalyādyaṃ ghṛtaṃ caitadātreyeṇa prakīrtitam ||38||  iti pippalyādighṛtam |
translation: Consuming, for thirty palas, separately, from guduchi, the resin of arjuna and kaṇṭaka, clarified butter, siddha, when taken in a prastha measure, with rase, vata, kāsa, and dīpana nut, is known as ghṛta in this context, beginning with pippali.

sloka: tryūṣaṇaṃ triphalāṃ drākṣāṃ kāśmaryāṇi parūṣakam |  dve pāṭhe devadārvṛddhiṃ svaguptāṃ citrakaṃ śaṭīm ||39||  brāhmīṃ tāmalakīṃ medāṃ kākanāsāṃ śatāvarīm |  trikaṇṭakaṃ vidārīṃ ca piṣṭvā karṣasamaṃ ghṛtāt ||40||  prasthaṃ caturguṇe kṣīre siddhaṃ kāsaharaṃ pibet |  jvaragulmāruciplīhaśirohṛtpārśvaśūlanut ||41||  kāmalārśo'nilāṣṭhīlākṣataśoṣakṣayāpaham |  tryūṣaṇaṃ nāma vikhyātametaddhṛtamanuttamam ||42||  iti tryūṣaṇādyaṃ ghṛtam |
translation: Consuming, along with Pippali and its root, Cavya, Citraka, Nagara herbs, grains, and the powder of

sloka: droṇe'pāṃ sādhayedrāsnāṃ daśamūlīṃ śatāvarīm |  palikāṃ māṇikāṃśāṃstu kulatthānbadarānyavān ||43||  tulārdhaṃ cājamāṃsasya pādaśeṣeṇa tena ca |  ghṛtāḍhakaṃ samakṣīraṃ jīvanīyaiḥ palonmitaiḥ ||44||  siddhaṃ taddaśabhiḥ kalkairnasyapānānuvāsanaiḥ |  samīkṣya vātarogeṣu yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||45||  pañcakāsān śiraḥkampaṃ śūlaṃ vaṅkṣaṇayonijam |  sarvāṅgaikāṅgarogāṃśca saplīhordhvānilāñjayet ||46||  iti rāsnāghṛtam |
translation: Take three handfuls of drākṣā fruit, two of devadāru wood, one each of śatavarī, kāka, medā, nāsāpātra, and śatāvarī roots, all pulverized together with aśmarī stone, ṛddhi tree bark, gupta citraka, brāhmī, tāmalakī, vidārī, kaṇṭaka, and parūṣaka fruits. Mix this powder with one-fourth of a prastha of ghṛta, two guṇas each of kṣīra and siddha haritakī powder, and the named anuttamam tryuṣaṇa. This is to be consumed as a medicine for diarrhea, jvara, gulma, aruci, plīha, śiraḥgranthi, hṛtroga, pārśvaplīha, and śūlvrikka conditions. These treatments should be applied according to the patient's needs in cases of vātaroga.

sloka: viḍaṅgaṃ nāgaraṃ rāsnā pippalī hiṅgu saindhavam |  bhārgī kṣāraśca taccūrṇaṃ pibedvā ghṛtamātrayā ||47||  sakaphe'nilaje kāse śvāsahikkāhatāgniṣu |  dvau kṣārau pañcakolāni pañcaiva lavaṇāni ca ||48||  śaṭīnāgarakodīcyakalkaṃ vā vastragālitam |  pāyayeta ghṛtonmiśraṃ vātakāsanibarhaṇam ||49||  durālabhāṃ śaṭīṃ drākṣāṃ śṛṅgaveraṃ sitopalām |  lihyāt karkaṭaśṛṅgīṃ ca kāse tailena vātaje ||50||  duḥsparśāṃ pippalīṃ mustaṃ bhārgīṃ karkaṭakīṃ śaṭīm |  purāṇaguḍatailābhyāṃ cūrṇitaṃ vā'pi lehayet ||51||  viḍaṅgaṃ saindhavaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ vyoṣaṃ hiṅgu manaḥśilām |  madhusarpiryutaṃ kāsahikkāśvāsaṃ jayellihan ||52||
translation: In the Drona preparation, using a tenth of the juices of

sloka: citrakaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ vyoṣaṃ hiṅgu durālabhām |  śaṭīṃ puṣkaramūlaṃ ca śreyasīṃ surasāṃ vacām ||53||  bhārgīṃ chinnaruhāṃ rāsnāṃ śṛṅgīṃ drākṣāṃ ca kārṣikān |  kalkānardhatulākvāthe nidigdhyāḥ palaviṃśatim ||54||  dattvā matsyaṇḍikāyāśca ghṛtācca kuḍavaṃ pacet |  siddhaṃ śītaṃ pṛthak kṣaudrapippalīkuḍavānvitam ||55||  catuṣpalaṃ tugākṣīryāścūrṇitaṃ tatra dāpayet |  lehayet kāsahṛdrogaśvāsagulmanivāraṇam ||56||  iti citrakādilehaḥ |
translation: Take well-ground black salt, long pepper, rock salt, barley, horse gram, two types of kshaara, five kinds of kolani, all mixed with water that has been sipped through a piece of cloth. Add this to the pippalii, musta, bhargi, and karkataki plants, along with an old guda, smeared with taila and also ground into a powder. Apply this mixture to alleviate vata-kasa, hikka, durable itching, and other skin diseases. Use a cooling upalaa for the application on the karkata-shringi plant, which is known for its spiky touch. Mix madhu and sarpih to create a paste and apply it on the body part affected by kushtam. Consume pippalii mixed with ghee and matsya-andika, prepared with ghee and milk, to achieve success in this process.

sloka: daśamūlīṃ svayaṅguptāṃ śaṅkhapuṣpīṃ śaṭīṃ balām |  hastipippalyapāmārgapippalīmūlacitrakān ||57||  bhārgīṃ puṣkaramūlaṃ ca dvipalāṃśaṃ yavāḍhakam |  harītakīśataṃ caikaṃ jale pañcāḍhake pacet ||58||  yavaiḥ svinnaiḥ kaṣāyaṃ taṃ pūtaṃ taccābhayāśatam |  pacedguḍatulāṃ dattvā kuḍavaṃ ca pṛthagghṛtāt ||59||  tailāt sapippalīcūrṇāt siddhaśīte ca mākṣikāt |  lihyāddve cābhaye nityamataḥ khādedrasāyanāt ||60||  tadvalīpalitaṃ hanti varṇāyurbalavardhanam |  pañcakāsān kṣayaṃ śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ ca viṣamajvaram ||61|| hanyāttathā'rśograhaṇīhṛdrogārucipīnasān |  agastyavihitaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ rasāyanamidaṃ śubham ||62||  ityagastyaharītakī |
translation: Cook with oil, a fifteenth part of a pala, added to a potion made from the following ingredients: the roots of Citraka and Pippali, which are hard to find, Shatii, Puшкаra, Surasaa, Bhargi, chopped; the fruits of Hingu, Drakshaa, Karkarika, and Ardha-tulaa;

sloka: saindhavaṃ pippalīṃ bhārgīṃ śṛṅgaveraṃ durālabhām |  dāḍimāmlena koṣṇena bhārgīnāgaramambunā ||63||  pibet khadirasāraṃ vā madirādadhimastubhiḥ |  athavā pippalīkalkaṃ ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ sasaindhavam ||64||
translation: One should cook gupta variety of dashamula, shankapushpi, shati, bala, hastipippali, pippalyaparma, pippalimoola, citraka, bhargi, pushkara, mula, along with haritaki, one sixth of it mixed with water and cooked with svinna yava; after removing impurities, this is made pure by adding a measure of guda, tula, offered separately, then mixed with ghee and sesame oil, or with pippalicurna; this siddha, when taken regularly at night and morning, will eliminate the five types of afflictions such as hikka, jwara, etc., as well as grahanidurcika diseases, and enhance complexion, longevity, and strength. This is the best rasayana, prescribed by Agastya, for all ailments.

sloka: śirasaḥ pīḍane srāve nāsāyā hṛdi tāmyati |  kāsapratiśyāyavatāṃ dhūmaṃ vaidyaḥ prayojayet ||65||  daśāṅgulonmitāṃ nāḍīmathavā'ṣṭāṅgulonmitām |  śarāvasampuṭacchidre kṛtvā jihmāṃ vicakṣaṇaḥ ||66||  vairecanaṃ mukhenaiva kāsavān dhūmamāpibet |  tamuraḥ kevalaṃ prāptaṃ mukhenaivodvamet punaḥ ||67||  sa hyasya taikṣṇyādvicchidya śleṣmāṇamurasi sthitam |  niṣkṛṣya śamayet kāsaṃ vātaśleṣmasamudbhavam ||68||
translation: With a mixture of Saindhava, Pippali, Bhargi, Srnga, Vera, Duralabha Dadima, and Amlena, one should drink (pibet) the essence (saram) of Khadira, or instead, with Madira, Dadhi, Mastu, or ghrita. This, having crushed (bhristam) it, is beneficial for those who have difficulty breathing (kasa), as it removes phlegm (slesmana) accumulated in the throat (sthitam urasi) and pacifies the wind-born Kasa disorder.

sloka: manaḥśilālamadhukamāṃsīmusteṅgudaiḥ pibet |  dhūmaṃ tasyānu ca kṣīraṃ sukhoṣṇaṃ saguḍaṃ pibet ||69||  eṣa kāsān pṛthagdoṣasannipātasamudbhavān |  dhūmo hanyādasaṃsiddhānanyairyogaśatairapi ||70||  prapauṇḍarīkaṃ madhukaṃ śārṅgeṣṭāṃ samanaḥśilām |  maricaṃ pippalīṃ drākṣāmelāṃ surasamañjarīm ||71||  kṛtvā vartiṃ pibeddhūmaṃ kṣaumacelānuvartitām |  ghṛtāktāmanu ca kṣīraṃ guḍodakamathāpi vā ||72||  manaḥśilailāmaricakṣārāñjanakuṭannaṭaiḥ |  vaṃśalekhanasevyālakṣaumalaktakarohiṣaiḥ ||73||  pūrvakalpena dhūmo'yaṃ sānupāno vidhīyate |  manaḥśilāle tadvacca pippalīnāgaraiḥ saha ||74||  tvagaiṅgudī bṛhatyau dve tālamūlī manaḥśilā |  kārpāsāsthyaśvagandhā ca dhūmaḥ kāsavināśanaḥ ||75||
translation:
With a balanced mind, the wise physician should apply smoke to the nostrils, ears, and heart through a thin tube in the nasal passage or a pipe with eight holes. This smoke treatment, derived from kāśa (a type of grass), alleviates various disorders caused by an imbalance of bodily humors such as phlegm and wind. It can be administered via the head or chest, depending on the specific condition. The practitioner should ensure proper placement and gentle release of smoke to avoid any discomfort or harm. This method has been used in ancient Indian medicine for various ailments with great success. (verses 69-75)

Inhale with the mind focused on the smoke of kāśa, mixed with ghee or water, through narrow openings in the head and chest. This helps to eliminate impurities in the mind and body, including phlegm and wind-related issues. The process involves using a pipe with eight holes or a thin tube inserted into the nasal passage. The smoke should be administered gently and skillfully to avoid any discomfort. By following this practice, one can eliminate various disorders caused by an imbalance of bodily humors, thereby promoting overall health and well-being. (verses 72-75)

sloka: grāmyānūpaudakaiḥ śāliyavagodhūmaṣaṣṭikān |  rasairmāṣātmaguptānāṃ yūṣairvā bhojayeddhitān ||76||  yavānīpippalībilvamadhyanāgaracitrakaiḥ |  rāsnājājīpṛthakparṇīpalāśaśaṭipauṣkaraiḥ ||77||  snigdhāmlalavaṇāṃ siddhāṃ peyāmanilaje pibet |  kaṭīhṛtpārśvakoṣṭhārtiśvāsahikkāpraṇāśinīm ||78||  daśamūlarase tadvatpañcakolaguḍānvitām |  siddhāṃ samatilāṃ dadyātkṣīre vā'pi sasaindhavām ||79|| mātsyakaukkuṭavārāhairāmiṣairvā ghṛtānvitām |  siddhāṃ sasaindhavāṃ peyāṃ vātakāsī pibennaraḥ ||80||  vāstuko vāyasīśākaṃ mūlakaṃ suniṣaṇṇakam |  snehāstailādayo bhakṣyāḥ kṣīrekṣurasagauḍikāḥ ||81||  dadhyāranālāmlaphalaprasannāpānameva ca |  śasyate vātakāse tu svādvamlalavaṇāni ca ||82||  iti vātakāsacikitsā |
translation: The mind should drink the honey of the following substances that are properly prepared and free from impurities , which destroy unsatisfactory results even if they are associated with smoke : kşīra, sukha, uṣna, sa, guḍa; these very foods , each treated with kšauma, celānu, and various seasonings such as vaṃśalekhana, sevyālakṣaumalaktakaroḥiṣaiḥ; this is the method of preparation followed in previous kalpa. Similarly , pippalī and nāgara fruits, tvagāingudī, bṛhatyau, dve tālamūlī, kārpāsa, asthi, aśva, gandhā, and kāsa should be prepared without aśana. Also, , matsya, kaukkuṭa, vārāha, āmiṣaiḥ, and ghṛta should be properly made for drinking . Additionally, śilā, āla, musta, iṅgudaiḥ, madhuka, maricam, pippalī, drākṣām, elām, surasa, and mañjarīm can be eaten with dadhyāra, nālā, amlaphala, prasanna, āpāna, and eva; vātakāsa is cured by consuming these foods .

sloka: paittike sakaphe kāse vamanaṃ sarpiṣā hitam |  tathā madanakāśmaryamadhukakvathitairjalaiḥ ||83||  yaṣṭyāhvaphalakalkairvā vidārīkṣurasāyutaiḥ |  hṛtadoṣastataḥ śītaṃ madhuraṃ ca kramaṃ bhajet ||84||
translation:
In the domestic sphere, one should eat rice cooked with barley, wheat, gram, and peas; as well as sesame seeds, honey, and goat's milk mixed with salt, ghee, and various spices such as nagara, citraka, rasna, ajaji, pṛthakparṇī, patāla, and palāśa. This diet is beneficial for the healthy functioning of the body, eliminating impurities, alleviating vata, and reducing fatigue. It also enhances the taste of food, making it sweet, sour, and salty.

In addition to this, one should consume fresh fruits such as mūlaka, suniṣaṇṇaka, sneha, elā, ayaḥ, along with kṣīra, ikṣu rasa, gauḍikā, dadhi, āra, nāla phala. This diet is recommended for maintaining good health and treating diseases (kāsa cikitsā).

In essence, consuming a balanced and nutritious diet in moderate quantities, using fresh and wholesome ingredients, will promote health, strength, and longevity.

sloka: paitte tanukaphe kāse trivṛtāṃ madhurairyutām |  dadyādghanakaphe tiktairvirekārthe yutāṃ bhiṣak ||85||
translation: In the case of poisoning, the healer should administer to the patient a potion made from ghee, butter, and sugarcane juice, mixed with medicinal powders such as vidāra, ikṣu, and kalka, in order to remove the toxins. Then, one should gradually introduce sweet and cool substances.

sloka: snigdhaśītastanukaphe rūkṣaśītaḥ kaphe ghane |  kramaḥ kāryaḥ paraṃ bhojyaiḥ snehairlehaiśca śasyate ||86||  śṛṅgāṭakaṃ padmabījaṃ nīlīsārāṇi pippalī |  pippalīmustayaṣṭyāhvadrākṣāmūrvāmahauṣadham ||87|| lājā'mṛtaphalā drākṣā tvakkṣīrī pippalī sitā |  pippalīpadmakadrākṣā bṛhatyāśca phalādrasaḥ ||88||  kharjūraṃ pippalī vāṃśī śvadaṃṣṭrā ceti pañca te |  ghṛtakṣaudrayutā lehāḥ ślokārdhaiḥ pittakāsinām ||89||  śarkarācandanadrākṣāmadhudhātrīphalotpalaiḥ |  paitte samustamaricaḥ sakaphe saghṛto'nile ||90||  mṛdvīkārdhaśataṃ triṃśatpippalīḥ śarkarāpalam |  lehayenmadhunā gorvā kṣīrapaṃ ca śakṛdrasam ||91||  tvagelāvyoṣamṛdvīkāpippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  lājāmustaśaṭīrāsnādhātrīphalabibhītakaiḥ ||92||  śarkarākṣaudrasarpirbhirlehaḥ kāsavināśanaḥ |  śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ kṣayaṃ caiva hṛdrogaṃ ca praṇāśayet ||93||  pippalyāmalakaṃ drākṣāṃ lākṣāṃ lājāṃ sitopalām |  kṣīre paktvā ghanaṃ śītaṃ lihyāt kṣaudrāṣṭabhāgikam ||94||  vidārīkṣumṛṇālānāṃ rasān kṣīraṃ sitopalām |  pibedvā madhusaṃyuktaṃ pittakāsaharaṃ param ||95||  madhurairjāṅgalarasaiḥ śyāmākayavakodravāḥ |  mudgādiyūṣaiḥ śākaiśca tiktakairmātrayā hitāḥ ||96||  ghanaśleṣmaṇi lehāstu tiktakā madhusaṃyutāḥ |  śālayaḥ syustanukaphe ṣaṣṭikāśca rasādibhiḥ ||97||  śarkarāmbho'nupānārthaṃ drākṣekṣūṇāṃ rasāḥ payaḥ |  sarvaṃ ca madhuraṃ śītamavidāhi praśasyate ||98||  kākolībṛhatīmedāyugmaiḥ savṛṣanāgaraiḥ |  pittakāse rasān kṣīraṃ yūṣāṃścāpyupakalpayet ||99||  śarādipañcamūlasya pippalīdrākṣayostathā |  kaṣāyeṇa śṛtaṃ kṣīraṃ pibet samadhuśarkaram ||100||  sthirāsitāpṛśniparṇīśrāvaṇībṛhatīyugaiḥ |  jīvakarṣabhakākolītāmalakyṛddhijīvakaiḥ ||101||  śṛtaṃ payaḥ pibet kāsī jvarī dāhī kṣatakṣayī |  tajjaṃ vā sādhayet sarpiḥ sakṣīrekṣurasaṃ bhiṣak ||102||  jīvakādyairmadhurakaiḥ phalaiścābhiṣukādibhiḥ |  kalkaistrikārṣikaiḥ siddhe pūtaśīte pradāpayet ||103||  śarkarāpippalīcūrṇaṃ tvakkṣīryā maricasya ca |  śṛṅgāṭakasya cāvāpya kṣaudragarbhānpalonmitān ||104||  guḍān godhūmacūrṇena kṛtvā khādeddhitāśanaḥ |  śukrāsṛgdoṣaśoṣeṣu kāse kṣīṇakṣateṣu ca ||105||  śarkarānāgarodīcyaṃ kaṇṭakārīṃ śaṭīṃ samam |  piṣṭvā rasaṃ pibetpūtaṃ vastreṇa ghṛtamūrcchitam ||106||  mahiṣyajāvigokṣīradhātrīphalarasaiḥ samaiḥ |  sarpiḥ siddhaṃ pibedyuktyā pittakāsanibarhaṇam ||107||  iti pittakāsacikitsā |
translation: "For the emaciated, who is weakened due to an excess of bodily fluids, one should give a medicinal concoction containing sugar, made from well-cooked rice flour and mixed with honey and liquorice."

sloka: balinaṃ vamanairādau śodhitaṃ kaphakāsinam |  yavānnaiḥ kaṭūrūkṣoṣṇaiḥ kaphaghnaiścāpyupācaret ||108||  pippalīkṣārikairyuṣaiḥ kaulatthairmūlakasya ca |  laghūnyannāni bhuñjīta rasairvā kaṭukānvitaiḥ ||109||  dhānvabailarasaiḥ snehaistilasarṣapabilvajaiḥ |  madhvamloṣṇāmbutakraṃ vā madyaṃ vā nigadaṃ pibet ||110||  pauṣkarāragvadhaṃ mūlaṃ paṭolaṃ tairniśāsthitam |  jalaṃ madhuyutaṃ peyaṃ kāleṣvannasya vā triṣu ||111||
translation: For a person afflicted by phlegm-related ailments, the following is recommended: consume at the beginning of the season, in increasing quantities, foods such as bitter and astringent pomegranates, myrobalans, dry ginger, dry saffron, and light foods processed with clarified butter and rock salt. Also consume decoctions made from the bark and roots of belleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, Indian madder, and drumstick tree; water mixed with honey; and buttermilk or milk, preferably soured. Regularly consume rice cooked with turmeric and sitaphala (a type of fruit). Drink a mixture of sugarcane juice, munakka raisins, and sugar candy. For phlegm-related diseases, use kaphaghna (phlegm-reducing) drugs such as drākṣā ( Indian jujube), lāja (barley), musta (cyperus rotundus), pauṣkarāra (ficus hispida), and arica (anacyclus pyrethrum). Avoid cold, heavy foods. Regularly consume foods that are sweet, sour, and salty in taste. Also take kaphaghna drugs such as śarkarā (sugar), candana (sandalwood), madhu (honey), dhātrī (emblica officinalis), utpalaiḥ (a type of lotus), mustam (black gram), and sakaphe (horsegram) that are mixed with ghṛta (clarified butter). Regularly consume foods such as madhvamloṣṇāmbutakraṃ (sour milk or yogurt), vā (or) kṣīra (milk), pam (or) śakṛt (buttermilk), rasam (a type of soup made from spices and tamarind). Also consume pitta-reducing foods such as āmalakam (Indian gooseberry), drākṣām ( Indian jujube), lākṣām (cocoa), lājām (barley), sita (sugarcane), upalām (a type of turmeric plant), kṣīre (milk) paktvā (cook

sloka: kaṭphalaṃ kattṛṇaṃ bhārgīṃ mustaṃ dhānyaṃ vacābhaye |  śuṇṭhīṃ parpaṭakaṃ śṛṅgīṃ surāhvaṃ ca śṛtaṃ jale ||112||  madhuhiṅguyutaṃ peyaṃ kāse vātakaphātmake |  kaṇṭharoge mukhe śūne śvāsahikkājvareṣu ca ||113||  pāṭhāṃ śuṇṭhīṃ śaṭīṃ mūrvāṃ gavākṣīṃ mustapippalīm |  piṣṭvā gharmāmbunā hiṅgusaindhavābhyāṃ yutāṃ pibet ||114||  nāgarātiviṣe mustaṃ śṛṅgīṃ karkaṭakasya ca |  harītakīṃ śaṭīṃ caiva tenaiva vidhinā pibet ||115||  tailabhṛṣṭaṃ ca pippalyāḥ kalkākṣaṃ sasitopalam |  pibedvā śleṣmakāsaghnaṃ kulattharasasaṃyutam ||116||  kāsamardāśvaviṭbhṛṅgarājavārtākajo rasaḥ |  sakṣaudraḥ kaphakāsaghnaḥ surasasyāsitasya ca ||117||  devadāru śaṭī rāsnā karkaṭākhyā durālabhā |  pippalī nāgaraṃ mustaṃ pathyādhātrīsitopalāḥ ||118||  madhutailayutāvetau lehau vātānuge kaphe |  pippalī pippalīmūlaṃ citrako hastipippalī ||119||  pathyā tāmalakī dhātrī bhadramustā ca pippalī |  devadārvabhayā mustaṃ pippalī viśvabheṣajam ||120||  viśālā pippalī mustaṃ trivṛtā ceti lehayet |  caturo madhunā lehān kaphakāsaharān bhiṣak ||121||  sauvarcalābhayādhātrīpippalīkṣāranāgaram |  cūrṇitaṃ sarpiṣā vātakaphakāsaharaṃ pibet ||122|| daśamūlāḍhake prasthaṃ ghṛtasyākṣasamaiḥ pacet |
translation: "In the beginning, consume with balanced foods processed with purgatives and having the qualities of being light, alleviating kapha, and made of barley, rice, and other grains, along with pippali and its variety of forms, such as ari, airi, uṣā, etc., which have bitter, pungent, and other tastes. Also, consume milk, curd, ghee, butter, and liquids like takra, madya, and nigada at appropriate times. For medicinal purposes, take decoctions of the roots of balinam, vamanaiḥ, dhānvabailarasa, tila, sarṣapa, bilva, madhva, etc., which have scraping, cleansing, and other therapeutic properties."

sloka: puṣkarāhvaśaṭībilvasurasavyoṣahiṅgubhiḥ ||123||  peyānupānaṃ tat peyaṃ kāse vātakaphātmake |  śvāsarogeṣu sarveṣu kaphavātātmakeṣu ca ||124||  iti daśamūlādighṛtam |
translation: "One should consume a mixture made from the roots of ten plants, including

sloka: samūlaphalapatrāyāḥ kaṇṭakāryā rasāḍhake |  ghṛtaprasthaṃ balāvyoṣaviḍaṅgaśaṭicitrakaiḥ ||125||  sauvarcalayavakṣārapippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  vṛścīrabṛhatīpathyāyavānīdāḍimardhibhiḥ ||126||  drākṣāpunarnavācavyadurālambhāmlavetasaiḥ |  śṛṅgītāmalakībhārgīrāsnāgokṣurakaiḥ pacet ||127||  kalkaistat sarvakāseṣu hikkāśvāseṣu śasyate |  kaṇṭakārīghṛtaṃ hyetat kaphavyādhinisūdanam ||128||  iti kaṇṭakārīghṛtam |
translation: Prepared from the buds of blue water lily, red water lily, and white lotus, along with other ingredients such as cardamom, lavang, cinnamon, and nutmeg; mixed with honey and sugar; further processed with ingredients like camphor, clove, and cassia bark; combined with various decoctions such as those of draksha (raisins), punarnava, durva, and brihati; and seasoned with peppermint, tamalaki, bhargi, raktakarpura, and krsna pepper: this is kaṇṭakārīghṛta, beneficial in all vata and kapha diseases, alleviating hiccups and other respiratory ailments.

sloka: kulattharasayuktaṃ vā pañcakolaśṛtaṃ ghṛtam |  pāyayet kaphaje kāse hikkāśvāse ca śasyate ||129||  iti kulatthādighṛtam |
translation: The ghee prepared from the sum total of well-ripened fruits, thorns removed, of superior quality, mixed with five kinds of juices, cooked with sugarcane, pomegranate, and other ripe fruits, flavored with cardamom, camphor, and other similar substances, alleviates hiccups and breathlessness in kaphaja diseases. Indeed, this is called "ghee prepared from the best of families."

sloka: dhūmāṃstāneva dadyācca ye proktā vātakāsinām |  kośātakīphalānmadhyaṃ pibedvā samanaḥśilam ||130||
translation: If instructed, one should feed a person affected by vātakapha (a type of respiratory disorder) with a drink made from the middle portion of kuṣmāṇḍa fruit and ghee, mixed with the juice of panca-kola and kulattha fruits. This is said to alleviate hiccups and breathlessness.

sloka: tamakaḥ kaphakāse tu syāccet pittānubandhajaḥ |  pittakāsakriyāṃ tatra yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||131||  vāte kaphānubandhe tu kuryāt kaphaharīṃ kriyām |  pittānubandhayorvātakaphayoḥ pittanāśinīm ||132||  ārdre virūkṣaṇaṃ śuṣke snigdhaṃ vātakaphātmake |  kāse'nnapānaṃ kaphaje sapitte tiktasaṃyutam ||133||  iti kaphajakāsacikitsā |
translation: For phlegmatic constitution, if it is bound by wind or bile, one should perform activities that reduce kapha (phlegm) and eliminate the cause. If wind and phlegm are dominant, causing emaciation, one should drink a decoction of equal parts of dried mango kernel and sugarcandy. This is the treatment for ailments caused by an imbalance of phlegm.

sloka: kāsamātyayikaṃ matvā kṣatajaṃ tvarayā jayet |  madhurairjīvanīyaiśca balamāṃsavivardhanaiḥ ||134||  pippalī madhukaṃ piṣṭaṃ kārṣikaṃ sasitopalam |  prāsthikaṃ gavyamājaṃ ca kṣīramikṣurasastathā ||135||  yavagodhūmamṛdvīkācūrṇamāmalakādrasaḥ |  tailaṃ ca prasṛtāṃśāni tat sarvaṃ mṛdunā'gninā ||136||  pacellehaṃ ghṛtakṣaudrayuktaḥ sa kṣatakāsahā |  śvāsahṛdrogakārśyeṣu hito vṛddhe'lparetasi ||137||
translation: If one perceives that there is a disorder in the body caused by phlegm , then one should apply a treatment accordingly. In the same way, if there is a disorder caused by wind , then one should use a remedy that will reduce both wind and phlegm. If there is a heating and drying condition in the body, then one should use an oily and nourishing substance. When phlegm is dominant and causing disease, one should consider using pippali, madhuka, kārṣika, sasitopala, prāsthika, gavyamāja, kṣīramikṣura, yava, godhūma, mṛdunā'gninā, and taila. These substances, when cooked with ghee and oil, are useful in treating diseases caused by an imbalance of phlegm and wind, such as shvāsa, hṛdroga, kārśyeṣu, vṛddhe, and alparetasi.

sloka: kṣatakāsābhibhūtānāṃ vṛttiḥ syāt pittakāsikī |  kṣīrasarpirmadhuprāyā saṃsarge tu viśeṣaṇam ||138||  vātapittārdite'bhyaṅgo gātrabhede ghṛtairhitaḥ |  tailairmārutarogaghnaiḥ pīḍyamāne ca vāyunā ||139||  hṛtpārśvārtiṣu pānaṃ syājjīvanīyasya sarpiṣaḥ |  sadāhaṃ kāsino raktaṃ ṣṭhīvataḥ sabale'nale ||140||  māṃsocitebhyaḥ kṣāmebhyo lāvādīnāṃ rasā hitāḥ |  tṛṣṇārtānāṃ payaśchāgaṃ śaramūlādibhiḥ śṛtam ||141||  rakte srotobhya āsyādvā'pyāgate kṣīrajaṃ ghṛtam |  nasyaṃ pānaṃ yavāgūrvā śrānte kṣāme hatānale ||142||  stambhāyāmeṣu mahatīṃ mātrāṃ vā sarpiṣaḥ pibet |  kuryādvā vātarogaghnaṃ pittaraktāvirodhi yat ||143||  nivṛtte kṣatadoṣe tu kaphe vṛddha uraḥ kṣate |  dālyate kāsino yasya sa dhūmānnā pibedimān ||144||  dve mede madhukaṃ dve ca bale taiḥ kṣaumalaktakaiḥ |  vartitairdhūmamāpīya jīvanīyaghṛtaṃ pibet ||145||  manaḥśilāpalāśājagandhātvakkṣīrināgaraiḥ |  bhāvayitvā pibet kṣaumamanu cekṣuguḍodakam ||146||  piṣṭvā manaḥśilāṃ tulyāmārdrayā vaṭaśuṅgayā |  sasarpiṣkaṃ pibeddhūmaṃ tittiripratibhojanam ||147||  bhāvitaṃ jīvanīyairvā kuliṅgāṇḍarasāyutaiḥ |  kṣaumaṃ dhūmaṃ pibet kṣīraṃ śṛtaṃ cāyoguḍairanu ||148||  iti kṣatajakāsacikitsā |
translation: By considering the suitable and timely treatment, one should conquer injury-induced ailments with sweet and life-sustaining substances such as sugar, meat that strengthens muscles, long pepper, honey, rice, barley, wheat, munakka, green gram, Phyllanthus emblica (amalaki) oil, and ghee prepared with cow's milk. These should be cooked properly with moderate heat and combined with rock salt. This is the treatment for kasaja, helpful in alleviating cough, consumption, debility, and other respiratory issues.

sloka: sampūrṇarūpaṃ kṣayajaṃ durbalasya vivarjayet |  navotthitaṃ balavataḥ pratyākhyāyācaret kriyām ||149||  tasmai bṛṃhaṇamevādau kuryādagneśca dīpanam |  bahudoṣāya sasnehaṃ mṛdu dadyādvirecanam ||150||  śampākena trivṛtayā mṛdvīkārasayuktayā |  tilvakasya kaṣāyeṇa vidārīsvarasena ca ||151||  sarpiḥ siddhaṃ pibedyuktyā kṣīṇadeho viśodhanam |  (hitaṃ taddehabalayorasya saṃrakṣaṇaṃ matam ) ||152||  pitte kaphe ca saṅkṣīṇe parikṣīṇeṣu dhātuṣu |  ghṛtaṃ karkaṭakīkṣīradvibalāsādhitaṃ pibet ||153||  vidārībhiḥ kadambairvā tālasasyaistathā śṛtam |  ghṛtaṃ payaśca mūtrasya vaivarṇye kṛcchranirgame ||154||  śūne savedane meḍhre pāyau saśroṇivaṅkṣaṇe |  ghṛtamaṇḍena madhunā'nuvāsyo miśrakeṇa vā ||155||  jāṅgalaiḥ pratibhuktasya vartakādyā bileśayāḥ |  kramaśaḥ prasahāścaiva prayojyāḥ piśitāśinaḥ ||156||  auṣṇyāt pramāthibhāvācca srotobhyaścyāvayanti te |  kaphaṃ śuddhaiśca taiḥ puṣṭiṃ kuryātsamyagvahanrasaḥ ||157||
translation: The nourishment for the various bodily constituents should be selected according to their specific qualities. For those who are weakened by vata disorders, ghee is recommended; for those with pitta disorders, take buttermilk; for kapha disorders, use honey. When there is a mixture of doshas or when there is pain in the heart region, always opt for ghee. In case of diarrhea, drink hot water; if constipated, consume butter milk; and if there are obstructions in the digestive tract, consume cow's urine mixed with honey. For bleeding disorders, use a concoction made from sendana, madhuka, and kulattha. In case of poisoning or alcohol intoxication, mix together equal parts of powdered barley, candy sugar, and water. For mental disorders, consume dhūmra prepared with bala, tila, and vasa. Consume ghee in large quantities when there is excessive thirst or when the doshas are aggravated due to the change of seasons. Use honey in small quantities for nourishing the body. In case of intoxication caused by consumption of fish, meat, or alcohol, consume a mixture of kulinga andanda with kshudra patra. For diseases caused by an excess of bile, use a mixture of madana, tila, and triphala. Use castor oil for constipation and to alleviate vata disorders. In case of poisoning, consume a mixture of haritala, yavakshara, and gomutra. For skin diseases, consume a mixture made from the bark of madhuka tree with honey and water. These are some of the therapeutic uses of various food items and drinks as per Ayurvedic principles.

sloka: dvipañcamūlītriphalācavikābhārgicitrakaiḥ |  kulatthapippalīmūlapāṭhākolayavairjale ||158||  śṛtairnāgaraduḥsparśāpippalīśaṭipauṣkaraiḥ |  kalkaiḥ karkaṭaśṛṅgyā ca samaiḥ sarpirvipācayet ||159|| siddhai'smiṃścūrṇitau kṣārau dvau pañca lavaṇāni ca |  dattvā yuktyā pibenmātrāṃ kṣayakāsanipīḍitaḥ ||160||  iti dvipañcamūlādighṛtam |
