translation: Perfecting one's own form by abandoning the decay of the weak and adopting the strength of the newly arisen, one should perform actions for him. First, make Agni bright and eliminate excess flaws with gentleness. When the six tastes along with the two salts have been reduced through a mixture with the powder of sesame seeds and the juices of kidney beans, rice cakes, karkataki fruit, and milk have been drunk with the fibers of kidney beans or belleric myrobalan, then one may consume food. After eating, the excrement becomes solidified, urine acquires a yellowish tint, and flatulence occurs; these signs indicate that the digestion process has begun. As the digested food moves through the intestines, it stimulates the srotas, causing Kapha to be expelled through sweating, which purifies the doshas and leads to proper nourishment.

sloka: guḍūcīṃ pippalīṃ mūrvāṃ haridrāṃ śreyasīṃ vacām |  nidigdhikāṃ kāsamardaṃ pāṭhāṃ citrakanāgaram ||161||  jale caturguṇe paktvā pādaśeṣeṇa tatsamam |  siddhaṃ sarpiḥ pibedgulmaśvāsārtikṣayakāsanut ||162||  iti guḍūcyādighṛtam |
translation: By grinding together equal parts of guḍūcī, pippalī, mūrvā, haridrā, śreyasī vacā, nidigdhikā, kāsa marda, pāṭha, citraka, nāgara, and adding kulattha, pippalī mula, pāṭhā, kola, yavaiḥ, shṛtaiḥ, nāgaraduḥ, sparśā, pippalī śaṭi, pauṣkari, kalkaiḥ, karkaṭa śṛṅg, ca, sarpir vipācayet. Mix this with siddha, asmiṃś, cūrṇitau, kṣārau, pañca, lavaṇāni. Adding water and reducing it to half, when kāsa nipīḍitaḥ, one should consume it in proper measure for its curative effects. Thus, the preparation beginning with guḍūcī is described.

sloka: kāsamardābhayāmustapāṭhākaṭphalanāgaraiḥ |  pippalīkaṭukādrākṣākāśmaryasurasaistathā ||163||  akṣamātrairghṛtaprasthaṃ kṣīradrākṣārasāḍhake |  pacecchoṣajvaraplīhasarvakāsaharaṃ śivam ||164||  dhātrīphalaiḥ kṣīrasiddhaiḥ sarpirvā'pyavacūrṇitam |  dviguṇe dāḍimarase vipakvaṃ vyoṣasaṃyutam ||165||  pibedupari bhaktasya yavakṣāraghṛtaṃ naraḥ |  pippalīguḍasiddhaṃ vā cchāgakṣīrayutaṃ ghṛtam ||166||  etānyagnivivṛddhyarthaṃ sarpīṃṣi kṣayakāsinām |  syurdoṣabaddhakoṣṭhoraḥsrotasāṃ ca viśuddhaye ||167||
translation: With a mixture of Guḍūcī, Pippalī, Mūrvā, Haridrā, Śreyasī, Vacā, and Nidigdhikā in a cup of water, filtered through a cloth, properly cooked and mixed with Siddha milk from a cow that eats only Kāsa grass, one should drink it to alleviate the eight forms of Kṣaya (consumption), along with disorders of the throat and chest. Such a mixture, prepared with Guḍūcī as the main ingredient, is beneficial for improving digestion, relieving bloating, and promoting longevity.

sloka: harītakīryavakvāthadvyāḍhake viṃśatiṃ pacet |  svinnā mṛditvā tāstasmin purāṇaṃ guḍaṣaṭpalam ||168||  dadyānmanaḥśilākarṣaṃ karṣārdhaṃ ca rasāñjanāt |  kuḍavārdhaṃ ca pippalyāḥ sa lehaḥ śvāsakāsanut ||169||  iti harītakīlehaḥ |
translation: "One should cook haritaki, belleric myrobalan, and bel fruit with twenty measures of water, a handful each of chebulic myrobalan, pippali, dried ginger, liquorice, rock salt, and sugar in a decoction. Add equal parts of cured long pepper, dried ginger, and pippali rinds to it. This is known as haritaki lehya. A person suffering from indigestion, diarrhea, fever, skin diseases, all disorders, poison, or those who seek longevity should eat this with ghee, honey, and sugarcane juice, mixed with curd for the benefit of agni, to reduce doshas binding the intestines, stomach, and channels, and for their purification."

sloka: śvāvidhaḥ sūcayo dagdhāḥ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkarāḥ |  śvāsakāsaharā barhipādau vā kṣaudrasarpiṣā ||170||
translation: "One should boil Haritaki and Yava twenty-four times, adding to it a previously prepared decoction of

sloka: eraṇḍapatrakṣāraṃ vā vyoṣatailaguḍānvitam |  lihyādetena vidhinā surasairaṇḍapatrajam ||171||
translation: "Let the oblation, prepared with mustard seed, pungent taste and accompanied by curd, be offered according to rule to the lord of the elephants in the heavenly realm."

sloka: drākṣāpadmakavārtākapippalīḥ kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  lihyāttryūṣaṇacūrṇaṃ vā purāṇaguḍasarpiṣā ||172||
translation: Made of rice flour, leaves of Drākṣā fruit, rock salt, and sesame oil, or with old clarified butter, this should be consumed as a remedy for eye diseases.

sloka: citrakaṃ triphalājājī karkaṭākhyā kaṭutrikam |  drākṣāṃ ca kṣaudrasarpirbhyāṃ lihyādadyādguḍena vā ||173||
translation: Should Citraka, adorned with the three types of fruits, instead mix powder made from old Karkataka or, having crushed licorice and barley, add sugar or clarified butter to it.

sloka: padmakaṃ triphalāṃ vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ suradāru ca |  balāṃ rāsnāṃ ca tulyāni sūkṣmacūrṇāni kārayet ||174||  sarvairebhiḥ samaṃ cūrṇaiḥ pṛthak kṣaudraṃ ghṛtaṃ sitām |  vimathya lehayellehaṃ sarvakāsaharaṃ śivam ||175||  jīvantīṃ madhukaṃ pāṭhāṃ tvakkṣīrīṃ triphalāṃ śaṭīm |  mustaile padmakaṃ drākṣāṃ dve bṛhatyau vitunnakam ||176|| sārivāṃ pauṣkaraṃ mūlaṃ karkaṭākhyāṃ rasāñjanam |  punarnavāṃ loharajastrāyamāṇāṃ yavānikām ||177||  bhārgīṃ tāmalakīmṛddhiṃ viḍaṅgaṃ dhanvayāsakam |  kṣāracitrakacavyāmlavetasavyoṣadāru ca ||178||
translation: Prepare today with a mixture of three fruits, including citraka, triphala, and ājāja; two types of sharp and pungent karkaṭa-akhyā herbs; drākṣā; sarpirbhyām; and guḍena.

sloka: cūrṇīkṛtya samāṃśāni lehayet kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  cūrṇātpāṇitalaṃ pañca kāsānetad vyapohati ||179||  iti padmakādilehaḥ |
translation: Having reduced the eight petal-like portions of the lotus-like *padmakam* into fine powder, one should evenly mix it with cow's ghee, refined sugar, and liquified jaggery. This mixture, when consumed, destroys impurities in the body, nourishes all tissues, is sweet, agreeable, life-giving, and rejuvenating. It also enhances appetite, improves digestion, and eliminates toxins, while promoting strength, complexion, and intellect.

sloka: lihyānmaricacūrṇaṃ vā saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram |  badarīpatrakalkaṃ vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ sasaindhavam ||180||
translation: Should one squeeze out the curds mixed with fine flour and water, or should they simply crush tulasi leaves on a patra of badari, along with rock salt and saunf, and mix it all with ghee?

sloka: svarabhede ca kāse ca lehametaṃ prayojayet |  patrakalkaṃ ghṛtairbhṛṣṭaṃ tilvakasya saśarkaram ||181||  peyā cotkārikā ccharditṛṭkāsāmātisāranut |  gaurasarṣapagaṇḍīraviḍaṅgavyoṣacitrakān |  sābhayān sādhayettoye yavāgūṃ tena cāmbhasā ||182||  sasarpirlavaṇāṃ kāse hikkāśvāse sapīnase |  pāṇḍvāmaye kṣaye śothe karṇaśūle ca dāpayet ||183||
translation: For the root cause of ailment being pepper, one should consume a paste made from roasted barley flour, rock salt, and a pinch of long pepper powder mixed with honey and ghee. One should also consume a mixture of licorice, black salt, and roasted cumin powder in hot water. Additionally, for reducing swelling in the ear, one should apply a paste made from roasted barley flour, licorice, rock salt, and boiled juice from the bark of a banyan tree.

sloka: kaṇṭakārīrase siddho mudgayūṣaḥ susaṃskṛtaḥ |  sagaurāmalakaḥ sāmlaḥ sarvakāsabhiṣagjitam ||184||  vātaghnauṣadhaniṣkvāthaṃ kṣīraṃ yūṣān rasānapi |  vaiṣkirapratudān bailān dāpayet kṣayakāsine ||185||  kṣatakāse ca ye dhūmāḥ sānupānā nidarśitāḥ |  kṣayakāse'pi tāneva yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||186||
translation: In the case of equal taste, one should mix this lemon juice, along with ghee that has been strained from curd, and a small amount of sugar, into buttermilk, for those suffering from bile reflux, wind, and fever; likewise, one should apply clarified butter to the ears and chest in cases of excessive wax or blockages.

sloka: dīpanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ caiva srotasāṃ ca viśodhanam |  vyatyāsātkṣayakāsibhyo balyaṃ sarvaṃ hitaṃ bhavet ||187||
translation: The purifier of all channels, the enkindler and enhancer (of digestion), and the destroyer of the causes of disease such as indigestion, mudga (a type of bean), well-prepared, pure, free from impurities, and sour; the fruitful and beneficial (is) giving out juices, even bitter ones, to the sick, and administering smoke-emitting medicinal substances according to their condition.

sloka: sannipātabhavo'pyeṣa kṣayakāsaḥ sudāruṇaḥ |  sannipātahitaṃ tasmāt sadā kāryaṃ bhiṣagjitam ||188||  doṣānubalayogācca haredrogabalābalam |  kāseṣveṣu garīyāṃsaṃ jānīyāduttarottaram ||189|| bhojyaṃ pānāni sarpīṃṣi lehāśca saha pānakaiḥ |  kṣīraṃ sarpirguḍā dhūmāḥ kāsabhaiṣajyasaṅgrahaḥ ||190||
translation: Illumination, expansion, and indeed purification of the channels are brought about by this sannipāta. It also reduces the harmful effects caused by poisonous substances. Knowledge of the most excellent remedy should be obtained for dosas in certain cases, along with the appropriate consumption of food, drink, and other items like clarified butter, rice, smoke, and kāsabha medicines.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  saṅkhyā nimittaṃ rūpāṇi sādhyāsādhyatvameva ca |  kāsānāṃ bheṣajaṃ proktaṃ garīyastvaṃ ca kāsinaḥ ||191||
translation: In this assembly, it is stated that the means of knowing the number and kinds of entities, their accomplished and unaccomplished nature, and the best remedy for diseases in them, is by the power of yoga and the elimination of faults. This ought to be known as superior knowledge, along with wholesome food and drinks accompanied by clarified butter, sugar, smoke, and drugs.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite  cikitsāsthāne kāsacikitsitaṃ nāmāṣṭādaśo'dhyāyaḥ ||18||
translation: In the eighteenth chapter, which is named "Treatment" in the well-known text Caraka, describing the situation where proper and strong treatment is available, what is the medicine that should be applied for each of the eighteen conditions?

sloka: athāto'bhayāmalakīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Thus, after the completion of the ritual garb of Agni, we shall explain this chapter of the remedy in the Caraka Tantra, which has not yet been taught and is firmly established in the place of treatment, consisting of eighteen sections named "Kasa Cikitsitam."

sloka: cikitsitaṃ vyādhiharaṃ pathyaṃ sādhanamauṣadham|  prāyaścittaṃ praśamanaṃprakṛtisthāpanaṃ hitam||3||  vidyādbheṣajanāmāni...|4|
translation: Then Bhagavan Atreya began to explain , "Fear not , the remedy for a disease is an appropriate diet , therapeutic treatment , medicine , expiation , tranquilizer , and restoration of the natural state - all of which are beneficial . The names of knowledge and medicine are..."

sloka: bheṣajaṃ dvividhaṃ ca tat|  svasthasyorjaskaraṃ kiñcit kiñcidārtasya roganut||4||
translation: Therapy is of two kinds: one is a means to prevent disease in a healthy person, and the other is a remedy that alleviates the suffering of a sick person.

sloka: abheṣajaṃ ca dvividhaṃ bādhanaṃ sānubādhanam||
translation: There are two types of healing: one that strengthens the health of a healthy person, and another that alleviates the suffering of a distressed person afflicted with disease.

sloka: svasthasyorjaskaraṃ yattu tadvṛṣyaṃ tadrasāyanam||5|| prāyaḥ prāyeṇa rogāṇāṃ dvitīyaṃ praśamematam|  prāyaḥśabdoviśeṣārtho hyubhayaṃ hyubhayārthakṛt||6||
translation: The two types of cures for ailments, one being medical treatment and the other being spiritual practices, are most certainly beneficial in alleviating diseases.

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ|  prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param||7||  vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt|  lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam||8||
translation: For a healthy person, longevity, memory, intellect, and youthfulness; luster, complexion, voice, dignity, and physical strength are, in general, the secondary effects; not medicine is the primary cause of obtaining riches and other benefits derived from sense objects.

sloka: apatyasantānakaraṃ yat sadyaḥ sampraharṣaṇam|  vājīvātibalo yenayātyapratihataḥ striyaḥ||9||  bhavatyatipriyaḥ strīṇāṃ yena yenopacīyate|  jīryato'pyakṣayaṃ śukraṃ phalavadyena dṛśyate||10||  prabhūtaśākhaḥ śākhīva yena caityo yathā mahān|  bhavatyarcyobahumataḥ prajānāṃ subahuprajaḥ||11||  santānamūlaṃ yeneha pretya cānantyamaśnute|  yaśaḥ śriyaṃ balaṃ puṣṭiṃ vājīkaraṇameva tat||12||
translation: Gaining longevity, good memory, intelligence, strength, without debts, and residing in heaven are attained through one's own meritorious deeds, generosity, healthy body, strong sense organs, and supreme speech, leading to the accomplishment of excellent results. The means to acquire such elixir for the downtrodden lies in the taste of wealth (legitimately earned).

sloka: svasthasyorjaskaraṃ tvetaddvividhaṃ proktamauṣadham|  yadvyādhinirghātakaraṃ vakṣyate taccikitsite||13||  cikitsitārtha etāvān vikārāṇāṃ yadauṣadham|  rasāyanavidhiścāgre vājīkaraṇameva ca||14||
translation: The means of preserving one's own progeny are twofold, as mentioned here: the medicine that prevents untimely death and makes one joyful is described as the one that remedies the affliction. The medicine that serves the purpose of treatment is the one that promotes semen, makes it inexhaustible, and visible in large quantities, like the spreading branches of a tree. Such a person becomes greatly revered by many people, acquiring fame, prosperity, strength, and nourishment, just like an unfailing bull.

sloka: abheṣajamiti jñeyaṃ viparītaṃ yadauṣadhāt|  tadasevyaṃ niṣevyaṃ tu pravakṣyāmi yadauṣadham||15||
translation: The remedy is to be known as that which is contrary to poison; this twofold medicine, which increases strength, I will explain what it is and its purpose in treatment. This is the means of healing for various ailments, like a tonic, and also the cause of the increase of vigor, like a stimulant, at the beginning.

sloka: rasāyanānāṃ dvividhaṃ prayogamṛṣayo viduḥ|  kuṭīprāveśikaṃ caiva vātātapikameva ca||16||
translation: The healers (rishis) know the twofold use of medicines to be both internal and external, as well as exposure to wind and sun, regarding what is to be served and resorted to; I will explain that medicine.

sloka: kuṭīprāveśikasyādau vidhiḥ samupadekṣyate|  nṛpavaidyadvijātīnāṃ sādhūnāṃpuṇyakarmaṇām||17||  nivāse nirbhaye śaste prāpyopakaraṇe pure|  diśi pūrvottarasyāṃ ca subhūmau kārayet kuṭīm||18||
translation: In the beginning, a rule is laid down for those who are twice-born, knowledgeable physicians and brahmins, and who are virtuous and have performed meritorious deeds, to build a hut in a secluded and safe location, on a level ground in the northeastern direction, using materials from the rasayana plants.

sloka: vistārotsedhasampannāṃ trigarbhāṃ sūkṣmalocanām|  ghanabhittimṛtusukhāṃ suspaṣṭāṃ manasaḥ priyām||19||  śabdādīnāmaśastānāmagamyaṃ strīvivarjitām|  iṣṭopakaraṇopetāṃ sajjavaidyauṣadhadvijām||20||
translation: The king should have a hermitage built for the settled sage of the physician caste, who is endowed with tranquility, fine vision, and a subtle intellect; who is established in the prime duty of treating people with medicines; who is pure, virtuous, and free from attachments; who has realized the meaning of names and sounds; who is devoid of femininity; and who is equipped with all necessary tools and resources; in a clean, auspicious location to the east or north of the city.

sloka: athodagayane śukle tithinakṣatrapūjite|  muhūrtakaraṇopete praśastekṛtavāpanaḥ||21||  dhṛtismṛtibalaṃ kṛtvā śraddadhānaḥ samāhitaḥ|  vidhūya mānasān doṣān maitrīṃ bhūteṣu cintayan||22||
translation: Endowed with excellent expansiveness, having thoroughly refined the three gross and subtle senses, with a clear and sharp intellect, fond of solitude, devoid of attachment to sound and other objects, along with desired instruments, accompanied by a Brahmachari (celibate) doctor and medicinal herbs, a twice-born (learned person), should perform the ablution, establishing himself in steadfastness, mindfulness, strength, and faith, contemplating on friendship towards all beings after abandoning mental impurities.

sloka: devatāḥpūjayitvā'gre dvijātīṃśca pradakṣiṇam|  devagobrāhmaṇān kṛtvā tatastāṃ praviśetkuṭīm||23||  tasyāṃ saṃśodhanaiḥ śuddhaḥ sukhī jātabalaḥ punaḥ|  rasāyanaṃ prayuñjīta tatpravakṣyāmiśodhanam||24||
translation: Having worshiped the deities and, after proper rituals on an auspicious day, during a suitable lunar constellation, in a consecrated location and time, with mind focused, devoid of impurities, and filled with faith, one should perform purification measures. This I will tell you. Then, becoming pure and happy, he can be reborn in that dwelling; I will describe the means of purification through this ritual.

sloka: harītakīnāṃ cūrṇāni saindhavāmalake guḍam|  vacāṃ viḍaṅgaṃ rajanīṃ pippalīṃ viśvabheṣajam||25||  pibeduṣṇāmbunā jantuḥsnehasvedopapāditaḥ|  tena śuddhaśarīrāya kṛtasaṃsarjanāya ca||26||  trirātraṃ yāvakaṃ dadyāt pañcāhaṃvā'pi sarpiṣā|  saptāhaṃ vā purāṇasya yāvacchuddhestu varcasaḥ||27||
translation: Worshiping the deities first, then circling around, after making offering to two-borns and a cow, one should enter the house. Having purified it with various means, becoming pure, happy, and strong, one should make use of the rejuvenating properties. I will tell you the method for purification.

sloka: śuddhakoṣṭhaṃ tu taṃ jñātvā rasāyanamupācaret|  vayaḥprakṛtisātmyajño yaugikaṃ yasya yadbhavet||28||
translation: Knowing the powder of haritaki, salt, amalaka, guda, vidanga, rajani, pippalii, and vaaca, which is the universal remedy, as well as ushna ambu (warm water), should be consumed by the creature. By this, the body is made pure, and for three nights, if taken with cow's ghee, it increases the purity of tejas (radiance) until the end of purana shuddhi (complete purification).

sloka: harītakīṃ pañcarasāmuṣṇāmalavaṇāṃ śivām|  doṣānulomanīṃ laghvīṃvidyāddīpanapācanīm||29||  āyuṣyāṃ pauṣṭikīṃ dhanyāṃ vayasaḥ sthāpanīṃ parām|  sarvarogapraśamanīṃbuddhīndriyabalapradām||30||
translation: Knowing the pure nature of that which is in the fruit of Haritaki, a sagacious person should use it as a rejuvenative, according to its inherent qualities, which enhances lifespan, nourishment, and intelligence.

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ gulmamudāvartaṃ śoṣaṃ pāṇḍvāmayaṃmadam|  arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ purāṇaṃ viṣamajvaram||31||  hṛdrogaṃ saśirorogamatīsāramarocakam|  kāsaṃ pramehamānāhaṃ plīhānamudaraṃ navam||32||  kaphaprasekaṃ vaisvaryaṃ vaivarṇyaṃ kāmalāṃ krimīn|  śvayathuṃ tamakaṃ chardiṃ klaibyamaṅgāvasādanam||33||
translation: Haritaki, when made into a decoction with five ingredients, namely, panca rasas, uṣṇa, alavaṇa, śivā, and doṣanulomani, which are light to digest, that which increases the digestive fire, enhances lifespan, nourishes, is beneficial for old age, and strengthens the mind, senses, and body, that which alleviates all diseases, is known as sarva-rogahara, the cure for all ailments. Additionally, it can be used to treat specific ailments such as kushta, gulma, udavarta, sosa, pandu, arsha, grahani, purana, visama jvara, hridroga, shiroroga, atisara, measles (kasa), prameha, mada, plihana, udara, kaphapraseka, vaivarnya, kamala, krimi, shvayathu, tamaka, chardi, and klama, all of which are mentioned in the verse.

sloka: srotovibandhān vividhān pralepaṃ hṛdayorasoḥ|  smṛtibuddhipramohaṃ ca jayecchīghraṃ harītakī||34||  (ajīrṇino rūkṣabhujaḥ strīmadyaviṣakarśitāḥ|  severannābhayāmete kṣuttṛṣṇoṣṇārditāścaye)||35||  tān guṇāṃstāni karmāṇi vidyādāmalakīṣvapi|  yānyuktāni harītakyā vīryasya tu viparyayaḥ||36||
translation: I wish to quickly conquer the various blockages of the srotas (channels), along with conditions such as indigestion, emaciation, splenic disease, seminal debility, old age, debility due to imbalance, chronic fever, heart disease, head diseases, tuberculosis, diabetes, jaundice, leprosy, vitiligo, consumption, and impotence. All these are the qualities and actions associated with Haritaki, which is the opposite of weakness.

sloka: ataścāmṛtakalpāni vidyāt karmabhirīdṛśaiḥ|  harītakīnāṃ śasyāni bhiṣagāmalakasya ca||37||
translation: Quickly, one who can overcome various bondage-causing ailments of the heart and chest by applying appropriate actions to herbs such as Haritaki and Amalaki should understand the qualities of these.

sloka: oṣadhīnāṃ parā bhūmirhimavāñ śailasattamaḥ|  tasmātphalāni tajjāni grāhayetkālajāni tu||38||  āpūrṇarasavīryāṇi kāle kāle yathāvidhi|  ādityapavanacchāyāsalilaprīṇitāni ca||39||  yānyajagdhānyapūtīni nirvraṇānyagadāni ca|  teṣāṃ prayogaṃ vakṣyāmi phalānāṃ karma cottamam||40||
translation: Therefore, one should know about such elixir-like plants as prescribed by the scriptures, including Haritaki and Amlaka, which are known to the wise physician.

sloka: pañcānāṃ pañcamūlānāṃ bhāgān daśapalonmitān|  harītakīsahasraṃ ca triguṇāmalakaṃ navam||41||
translation: Of the five great medicinal plants, one should collect at appropriate times the ripe fruits of haritaki by the hundred, fresh leaves of amalaki by the nine, endowed with full potency and nourished by sun, wind, shade, and water, as well as their purifying, cleansing, and healing uses, which are considered the best among the applications of these plants.

sloka: vidārigandhāṃ bṛhatīṃ pṛśniparṇīṃ nidigdhikām|  vidyādvidārigandhādyaṃ śvadaṃṣṭrāpañcamaṃ gaṇam||42||  bilvāgnimanthaśyonākaṃ kāśmaryamatha pāṭalām|  punarnavāṃ śūrpaparṇyau balāmeraṇḍameva ca||43||  jīvakarṣabhakau medāṃ jīvantīṃ saśatāvarīm|  śarekṣudarbhakāśānāṃ śālīnāṃ mūlameva ca||44||  ityeṣāṃ pañcamūlānāṃ pañcānāmupakalpayet|  bhāgān yathoktāṃstatsarvaṃ sādhyaṃ daśaguṇe'mbhasi||45||
translation: Of the five roots, consider the divisions of five times ten (i.e., fifty) in the following manner: one part should be assigned to

sloka: daśabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu pūtaṃ taṃ grāhayedrasam|  harītakīśca tāḥ sarvāḥ sarvāṇyāmalakāni ca||46||  tāni sarvāṇyanasthīni phalānyāpothya kūrcanaiḥ|  vinīya tasminniryūhe cūrṇānīmānidāpayet||47||  maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ pippalyāḥ śaṅkhapuṣpyāḥ plavasyaca|  mustānāṃ saviḍaṅgānāṃ candanāguruṇostathā||48||  madhukasya haridrāyā vacāyāḥ kanakasya ca|  bhāgāṃścatuṣpalān kṛtvā sūkṣmailāyāstvacastathā||49||  sitopalāsahasraṃ ca cūrṇitaṃtulayā'dhikam|  tailasya dvyāḍhakaṃ tatra dadyāttrīṇi ca sarpiṣaḥ||50||
translation:
Take the remnant of the decasperma fruit, which is divided, swollen, and has a large pepal leaf, and is uncontaminated. Also gather all the other kinds of amla fruits that grow on trees. All these fruits should be thoroughly cleansed with a mixture of five juices: haritaki, belleric myrobalan, beleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, and chebulic myrobalan. After cleansing them, dry them in the sun and then grind them into a powder. Also add one-eighth of the weight of the powder in sesame oil, and three times the weight of the powder in ghee.

The five ingredients that should be used in this process are: the juice of madhuca, haridra, vidanga, musta, and kustha. Each of these ingredients should be separately reduced to a fine powder and then mixed together in specified proportions. The combined powder should then be carefully sieved before being used. The entire process should be carried out in accordance with the established principles for preparing such medicinal compounds.

sloka: sādhyamaudumbare pātre tat sarvaṃ mṛdunā'gninā|  jñātvālehyamadagdhaṃ ca śītaṃ kṣaudreṇa saṃsṛjet||51||  kṣaudrapramāṇaṃ snehārdhaṃ tat sarvaṃ ghṛtabhājane|  tiṣṭhetsammūrcchitaṃ tasya mātrāṃ kāle prayojayet||52||  yā noparundhyādāhāramekaṃ mātrā jarāṃprati|  ṣaṣṭikaḥ payasā cātra jīrṇe bhojanamiṣyate||53||
translation: Divide the remaining (of the medicine) into ten equal parts, consume one part with Haritaki, and all the Amlaka fruits, and all other edible fruits; grind together

sloka: vaikhānasā vālakhilyāstathā cānye tapodhanāḥ|  rasāyanamidaṃ prāśyababhūvuramitāyuṣaḥ||54||  muktvā jīrṇaṃ vapuścāgryamavāpustaruṇaṃ vayaḥ|  vītatandrāklamaśvāsā nirātaṅkāḥ samāhitāḥ||55||
translation: Having known all aspects of the earthenware pot named Audumbara, one should offer this elixir to the ascetics such as Vaikhānasas, Valakhilyas, and other virtuous seekers of penance. They, after abandoning their old and heavy bodies, have become youthful and bright, free from sleep, fatigue, and distraction, with their senses fully controlled. At the time of consuming food, one should place a measured quantity of ghee mixed with a quarter part of sneha (oil or grease) in front of them. They do not covet more than one mātrā (a measure) of food at a time, and even this is reduced during old age. Here, in this context, the word jīrṇe refers to the elixir that has become old due to remaining unused for some time. Once it becomes old, it will lose its effectiveness and cannot be consumed.

sloka: medhāsmṛtibalopetāścirarātraṃ tapodhanāḥ|  brāhmaṃ tapo brahmacaryaṃ ceruścātyantaniṣṭhayā||56||  rasāyanamidaṃ brāhmamāyuṣkāmaḥ prayojayet|  dīrghamāyurvayaścāgryaṃ kāmāṃśceṣṭān samaśnute||57||  (iti brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: Indeed, some who are endowed with wisdom, memory, and strength, steadfastly practicing austerity and celibacy day and night, should undertake this Brahma tapas. This Brahma rasa, when consumed, grants long life, excellence, fulfillment of desires, control over vital airs, elimination of fatigue, freedom from languor, and perfect mental focus. (Thus ends the Brahma Rasayana.)

sloka: bhavanti cātra  idaṃ rasāyanaṃ brāhmaṃ maharṣigaṇasevitam|  bhavatyarogo dīrghāyuḥ prayuñjāno mahābalaḥ||59|| kāntaḥ prajānāṃsiddhārthaścandrādityasamadyutiḥ|  śrutaṃ dhārayate sattvamārṣaṃ cāsya pravartate||60||  dharaṇīdharasāraśca vāyunā samavikramaḥ|  sa bhavatyaviṣaṃ cāsya gātre sampadyate viṣam||61||  (iti dvitīyaṃ brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: Scholars versed in the spiritual path and endowed with intelligence, memory, strength, wealth, and austerity, should partake of this Brahmanical elixir daily for longevity. This leads to the fulfillment of all desires and brings about the supreme state of selfless action. The earth's essence combined with air permeates his body, eliminating any impurities present. (Chapter 2, Brahmarasayana)

sloka: bilvo'gnimanthaḥ śyonākaḥ kāśmaryaḥ pāṭalirbalā|  parṇyaścatasraḥ pippalyaḥ śvadaṃṣṭrā bṛhatīdvayam||62||  śṛṅgī tāmalakī drākṣā jīvantī puṣkarāguru|  abhayā cāmṛtā ṛddhirjīvakarṣabhakau śaṭī||63||  mustaṃ punarnavā medā sailā candanamutpalam|  vidārī vṛṣamūlāni kākolī kākanāsikā||64||  eṣāṃ palonmitān bhāgāñchatānyāmalakasya ca|  pañca dadyāttadaikadhyaṃ jaladroṇe vipācayet||65||
translation: Becoming this drink, named "Soma," revered by the great seers' group, served to Atri, becoming a source of health and long life for the people, carrying the virtue and fame of Chandra and Diti, holding the essence of truth, beginning the sacred flow in the body, becoming the equal strength of the wind, becoming the irregular growth on the body, this is how the juices of the

sloka: jñātvā gatarasānyetānyauṣadhānyatha taṃ rasam|  taccāmalakamuddhṛtya niṣkulaṃ tailasarpiṣoḥ||66||  paladvādaśake bhṛṣṭvā dattvā cārdhatulāṃ bhiṣak|  matsyaṇḍikāyāḥ pūtāyā lehavatsādhu sādhayet||67||  ṣaṭpalaṃ madhunaścātra siddhaśīte pradāpayet|  catuṣpalaṃ tugākṣīryāḥ pippalīdvipalaṃ tathā||68||  palamekaṃ nidadhyācca tvagelāpatrakeśarāt|  ityayaṃ cyavanaprāśaḥ paramukto rasāyanaḥ||69||
translation: Having known these other medicinal plants such as bilva, agnimantha, shyonaka, etc., one should extract the tasteless pulp of amalaki. Then, free from impurities and seeds, it should be mixed with equal quantity of sesame oil. After heating this mixture in a paladwaasa (a broad-mouthed vessel) and giving it to a patient, one should further administer six palmfuls each of honey and sugar, musta, punarnava, meda, sa, ela, Chandan, utpala, vidari, vrisa roots, kakoli, kaka's naasika, and the powdered equal parts of these in hundred (of amalaki).

sloka: kāsaśvāsaharaścaiva viśeṣeṇopadiśyate|  kṣīṇakṣatānāṃ vṛddhānāṃ bālānāṃcāṅgavardhanaḥ||70||  svarakṣayamurorogaṃ hṛdrogaṃ vātaśoṇitam|  pipāsāṃ mūtraśukrasthān doṣāṃścāpyapakarṣati||71||
translation: "The healer known as Cyavana has described these herbs that alleviate distressing symptoms in those who are weakened by wasting diseases or afflicted with ailments such as consumption, swelling of the abdomen, heart disease, impurities in blood, and thirst. He recommends extracting the juice from āmalaka fruits, mixing it with sesame oil and ghee, dividing it into sixteen parts, and administering one part to a patient along with a fish from the matsyaṇḍika species. This should be followed by consuming a prepared medicine made from madhuña, siddha śīta, tugākṣīryā, pippalī, two parts of ilā leaves, and keśarāt. The juice of āmalaka fruits is praised as an excellent rejuvenating therapy."

sloka: asya mātrāṃprayuñjīta yoparundhyānna bhojanam|  asya prayogāccyavanaḥsuvṛddho'bhūtpunaryuvā||72||  medhāṃ smṛtiṃ kāntimanāmayatvamāyuḥprakarṣaṃ balamindriyāṇām|  strīṣu praharṣaṃ paramagnivṛddhiṃ varṇaprasādaṃpavanānulomyam||73|| rasāyanasyāsya naraḥ prayogāllabheta jīrṇo'pi kuṭīpraveśāt|  jarākṛtaṃ rūpamapāsya sarvaṃ bibharti rūpaṃ navayauvanasya||74|| (iti cyavanaprāśaḥ)|
translation: The one who is specialized in teaching reveals the means of strengthening the vital breath (prana) that is weakened, damaged, or excessive in old people, children, and the infirm. This method eliminates decay and diseases caused by wind, bile, phlegm, and other bodily imbalances. It also removes thirst, urine, and semen impurities from their sources. Indeed, this practice, when properly applied to a weakened person, rejuvenates them, making them look youthful and full of vigor. (Translation based on the word-split provided)

sloka: bhavanticātra yathā'marāṇāmamṛtaṃ yathā bhogavatāṃsudhā|  tathā'bhavanmaharṣīṇāṃ rasāyanavidhipurā||78|| na jarāṃ na ca daurbalyaṃ nāturyaṃ nidhanaṃ na ca|  jagmurvarṣasahasrāṇi rasāyanaparāḥ purā||79||  na kevalaṃ dīrghamihāyuraśnute rasāyanaṃ yovidhivanniṣevate|  gatiṃ sa devarṣiniṣevitāṃ śubhāṃ prapadyate brahma tatheti cākṣayam||80||
translation: Just as food nourishes the bodies of mortals and nectar nourishes the enjoyers, so too did the great sages find the elixir of life in their practices. They did not experience aging, weakness, impotence, death, or any other decrease in faculties for thousands of years, because they had taken up the practice that gives rejuvenation and increases intelligence, memory, beauty, vigor, complexion, strength, joy with women, agni (digestive fire), semen, and luster. Whoever practices this method appropriately, even if their body is old, becomes a new youth, casting off all signs of aging and preserving all their faculties.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  abhayāmalakīye'smin ṣaḍyogāḥ parikīrtitāḥ|  rasāyanānāṃ siddhānāmāyuryairanuvartate||81||
translation: Here in this world, just as the nectar is to the immortals, so too is the elixir of life for those who seek longevity. The six yogic practices described in the Abhayāmalakīya are similar to the elixir that bestows superhuman qualities upon Maharishi's followers. One who follows this path in accordance with the scriptural injunctions will attain the sacred and auspicious destination of the gods, achieving an infinite life like Brahma.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsāsthānerasāyanādhyāye'bhayāmalakīyo nāma rasāyanapādaḥ prathamaḥ||1||
translation: In the section of the treatise on fire rituals, composed by Caraka, the first chapter of the book on therapeutics is called "Abhayamalakii," named after the six therapeutic approaches described, which promote longevity.

sloka: athātaḥ prāṇakāmīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now we shall explain the first part of the treatment for preserving life, as was said by Bhagavan Atreya in the well-studied treatise Caraka, which has been revised and includes the description of the therapeutic use of āmalakī, known by the name nāma."

sloka: bhallātakatailapātraṃ sapayaskaṃ madhukena kalkenākṣamātreṇa śatapākaṃ kuryāditi samānaṃ pūrveṇa||15||  (iti bhallātakatailam)|
translation: Now we will explain the procedure of rejuvenation, which is beneficial for a life-loving person, as stated by Lord Atreya in the past.

sloka: bhallātakasarpiḥ bhallātakakṣīraṃ bhallātakakṣaudraṃ guḍabhallātakaṃ bhallātakayūṣaḥ bhallātakatailaṃ bhallātakapalalaṃ bhallātakasaktavaḥ bhallātakalavaṇaṃbhallātakatarpaṇam iti bhallātakavidhānamuktaṃ bhavati||16||
translation: The recipe for bhallātaka preparation is as follows: one should cook with a hundred akṣas of madhuka oil and kalka made from bhallātakar fruits, roots, bark, sap, kṣaudra, flowers, and saktu, along with one paTRA of bhallātaka tila oil. This is the method for preparing bhallātaka as described earlier.

sloka: bhavanticātra  bhallātakāni tīkṣṇāni pākīnyagnisamānica| bhavantyamṛtakalpāni prayuktāni yathāvidhi||17||  ete daśavidhāstveṣāṃ prayogāḥparikīrtitāḥ|  rogaprakṛtisātmyajñastān prayogān prakalpayet||18||
translation: These are the ten methods of using bhallataka (a type of plant): applying the fruit, the expressed juice, the milky sap, the latex, the root, the bark, the leaf, the flower, and the entire plant, as described; one should apply these methods appropriately for medicinal purposes according to the nature of the ailment.

sloka: kaphajo na sa rogo'sti na vibandho'sti kaścana|  yaṃ na bhallātakaṃ hanyācchīghraṃ medhāgnivardhanam||19||  (iti bhallātakavidhiḥ)|  prāṇakāmāḥ purā jīrṇāścyavanādyā maharṣayaḥ|  rasāyanaiḥ śivairetairbabhūvuramitāyuṣaḥ||20||  brāhmaṃ tapo brahmacaryamadhyātmadhyānameva ca|  dīrghāyuṣo yathākāmaṃ sambhṛtya tridivaṃ gatāḥ||21||  tasmādāyuḥprakarṣārthaṃ prāṇakāmaiḥsukhārthibhiḥ|  rasāyanavidhiḥ sevyo vidhivatsusamāhitaiḥ||22||
translation: Here, the sharp and powerful bhallataka fruits, when used as prescribed, become life-giving like amrita. These are the ten methods recommended for their preparation. Those who desire longevity should follow these methods, along with practicing brahmanic austerities, celibacy, and introspection, just as the great sages of old did. Therefore, one should carefully follow the proper procedures for using bhallataka fruits to enhance lifespan.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  rasāyanānāṃ saṃyogāḥ siddhābhūtahitaiṣiṇā|  nirdiṣṭāḥ prāṇakāmīye saptatriṃśanmaharṣiṇā ||23||
translation: There, the sage named Saptatriṃśa has outlined the formation of combinations as the means to achieve optimal health for rasāyanānāṃ (rejuvenative substances). This involves the elimination of afflictions such as kaphaja rogaḥ and vibandhaḥ through methods that enhance intelligence, agni, brahma tapas, and atmic dhyana. Furthermore, following this method leads to a long life, fulfillment of desires, and happiness in accordance with one's wishes. Therefore, it is recommended to follow the guidelines for using rasāyana substances appropriately.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne rasāyanādhyāye prāṇakāmīyo nāma rasāyanapādo dvitīyaḥ||2||
translation: In the section of the treatise regarding fire offerings, compiled by Caraka, in the context of therapeutics, specifically in the chapter on rejuvenation, is described the second type of rejuvenation for those desiring to improve vitality and longevity, as revealed by the great sage.

sloka: athātaḥ karapracitīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃvyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Thus, we will explain the subsequent portion relating to the preparation of the elixir, as stated by the sage Agnivesa in the well-revised chapter on cikitsa in the Caraka Tantra.

sloka: bhavanticātra  etadrasāyanaṃ pūrvaṃ vasiṣṭhaḥkaśyapo'ṅgirāḥ| jamadagnirbharadvājo bhṛguranye ca tadvidhāḥ||4||  prayujya prayatā muktāḥ śramavyādhijarābhayāt| yāvadaicchaṃstapastepustatprabhāvānmahābalāḥ||5||  idaṃ rasāyanaṃ cakre brahmā vārṣasahasrikam|  jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ buddhīndriyabalapradam||6||  (ityāmalakāyasaṃ brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation:
Now we will explain the procedure of this elixir:
Formerly, Vasistha, Kashyapa, Angiras, Jamadagni, Bharadvaja, and other great sages,
Having made up their minds and freed from fatigue, old age, disease, and fear,
Created this elixir which grants rejuvenation and enhances mental and physical strength.
This elixir was created by Brahma, lasting for thousands of years,
It eliminates the effects of aging and increases the power of cognition and senses.
(Thus ends the description of the Elixir in Amalakanisa Samhita).

sloka: tapasā brahmacaryeṇa dhyānena praśamena ca|  rasāyanavidhānena kālayuktena cāyuṣā||7||  sthitā maharṣayaḥ pūrvaṃ nahikiñcidrasāyanam|  grāmyānāmanyakāryāṇāṃ sidhyatyaprayatātmanām||8||
translation: By using austerity, celibacy, meditation, tranquility, following the rules of proper diet, and utilizing their lifespan, great sages of the past like Vasishtha, Kaashyapa, Angiras, Bharadwaja, Bhrugu, and others have become powerful and free from exhaustion, disease, old age, and fear. This rasayana (rejuvenation) was created by Brahma during a thousand divine years and has the primary effect of enhancing intellect, strength, and senses.

sloka: saṃvatsaraṃ payovṛttirgavāṃ madhye vaset sadā|  sāvitrīṃ manasā dhyāyan brahmacārī yatendriyaḥ||9||
translation: With a controlled mind, practicing brahmacharya and engaged in constant meditation on Savitri, the great rishis, who are steadfast in their use of rejuvenation techniques and have synchronized their lifespan with the solar cycle through austerities, were not previously successful in making ordinary, unnamed medicinal remedies effective through their earnest efforts.

sloka: saṃvatsarānte pauṣīṃ vā māghīṃ vā phālgunīṃ tithim|  tryahopavāsī śuklasya praviśyāmalakīvanam||10||  bṛhatphalāḍhyamāruhya drumaṃ śākhāgataṃ phalam|  gṛhītvā pāṇinā tiṣṭhejjapan brahmāmṛtāgamāt||11||  tadā hyavaśyamamṛtaṃ vasatyāmalake kṣaṇam|  śarkarāmadhukalpāni snehavanti mṛdūni ca||12||  bhavantyamṛtasaṃyogāttāni yāvanti bhakṣayet|  jīvedvarṣasahasrāṇi tāvantyāgatayauvanaḥ||13||  sauhityameṣāṃ gatvā tu bhavatyamarasannibhaḥ|  svayaṃ cāsyopatiṣṭhante śrīrvedā vāk ca rūpiṇī||14||  (iti kevalāmalakarasāyanam)|
translation: Meditating on the sage Sāvitrī in his mind, a person who always tends to the cattle in the middle of the yearly cycle, either during Pausha or Magha or Phalguna, must enter the grove of Amalaki trees. Ascending the great-fruited tree there and plucking its fruit with his hand, he should stand and repeat the mantra "Brahmāmṛtāgamāt." By doing so, he partakes of the nectar of immortality and remains in that state for a moment. The sugar-like and soft substances become like nectar to him, and they remain so as long as he consumes them. If he continues this practice, he will live for thousands of years, and his youth will be preserved. Attaining the qualities of these substances, he becomes free from decay and death, and both Lakshmi and the embodied Vedic Word, in their beautiful forms, come to abide within him (Kevalāmalakarasāyanam).

sloka: triphalāyā rase mūtre gavāṃ kṣāre ca lavaṇe|  krameṇaceṅgudīkṣāre kiṃśukakṣāra eva ca||15||  tīkṣṇāyasasya patrāṇi vahnivarṇāni sādhayet |  caturaṅguladīrghāṇi tilotsedhatanūni ca||16|| jñātvā tānyañjanābhāni sūkṣmacūrṇāni kārayet|  tāni cūrṇāni madhunā rasenāmalakasya ca||17||  yuktāni lehavat kumbhe sthitāni ghṛtabhāvite|  saṃvatsaraṃ nidheyāni yavapalle tathaivaca||18||
translation: At the end of a year, during the months of Paush, Maughsh and Phalguna, on the specified tithi, after eating a single Amalaki fruit that has been carefully picked from its large, ripened branch, one should sit in a quiet place and recite the mantra "Brahma Amritam Agatam" (The nectar of Brahma has arrived). By doing this consistently for thousands of years, while also consuming the Amalaki fruits with honey and sugar, one will attain divine grace, become immortal, and be filled with sacred knowledge and eloquence.

sloka: dadyādāloḍanaṃ māse sarvatrāloḍayan budhaḥ|  saṃvatsarātyaye tasya prayogo madhusarpiṣā||19||  prātaḥ prātarbalāpekṣī sātmyaṃ jīrṇe ca bhojanam|  eṣa eva ca lauhānāṃ prayogaḥ samprakīrtitaḥ||20||
translation: A wise person should offer every month the ripened fruits of three types to the cows in the following order: first with a salty taste, then sour, followed by sweet, and finally astringent. The fruits should be mashed into small, fine particles using a pestle with a tip four angulas long, and mixed with sugar and liquified Amlaka fruit kept in a pot over a low fire for a year. Similarly, one should prepare collyrium by grinding equal parts of mustard seeds and the bark of the Ingudi tree, made fine and smooth with madhuka decoction, and applied daily to the eyes at dawn, after determining the appropriate length of time and quantity based on individual strength and need.

sloka: nābhighātairna cātaṅkairjarayāna ca mṛtyunā|  sa dhṛṣyaḥ syādgajaprāṇaḥ sadā cātibalendriyaḥ||21||  dhīmān yaśasvī vāksiddhaḥ śrutadhārī mahādhanaḥ|  bhavet samāṃ prayuñjāno naro lauharasāyanam||22||  anenaiva vidhānena hemnaśca rajatasyaca|  āyuḥprakarṣakṛtsiddhaḥ prayogaḥ sarvaroganut||23||  (iti lauhādirasāyanam)|
translation: A wise person who regularly donates sesame seeds in every month, considering it as equally important in all circumstances, should also consume sesame and jaggery in the morning. By following this practice consistently, one can enhance their lifespan and overcome various ailments (according to lauhādirasāyanam).

sloka: aindrī matsyākhyako brāhmī vacā brahmasuvarcalā|  pippalyo lavaṇaṃ hema śaṅkhapuṣpī viṣaṃghṛtam||24||  eṣāṃ triyavakān bhāgān hemasarpirviṣairvinā|  dvau yavau tatra hemnastu tilaṃ dadyādviṣasyaca||25||  sarpiṣaśca palaṃ dadyāttadaikadhyaṃ prayojayet|  ghṛtaprabhūtaṃ sakṣaudraṃ jīrṇe cānnaṃpraśasyate||26||
translation: A steadfast, highly powerful man, endowed with extraordinary senses and intelligence, becomes capable of increasing the lifespan of gold and silver by using this method: even if injured by weapons, age, or death, he remains fearless like an elephant. By following this practice, a man who uses this technique can become wise, famous, and wealthy, and increase the longevity of both gold and silver.

sloka: jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ smṛtimedhākaraṃ param|  āyuṣyaṃ pauṣṭikaṃ dhanyaṃ svaravarṇaprasādanam||27||  paramojaskaraṃ caitat siddhamaindraṃ rasāyanam|  nainat prasahate kṛtyā nālakṣmīrna viṣaṃ na ruk||28||  śvitraṃ sakuṣṭhaṃ jaṭharāṇi gulmāḥ plīhā purāṇo viṣamajvaraśca|  medhāsmṛtijñānaharāśca rogāḥ śāmyantyanenātibalāśca vātāḥ||29||  (ityaindraṃ rasāyanam)|
translation: This Indra-remedy, named Matsyakhyaka, Brahmi, Pippalya, Lavana, Hema, Shankhapuspi, Visha and Ghrita, when divided into three parts and mixed with two barley grains (without any impurities) and a portion of sesame, increases in effectiveness. When consumed with ghee that has been cooked with old rice paste, all diseases such as switra, kushtha, jatharagulma, plihi, purana visha-jvara, loss of intellect, memory and knowledge, as well as excessive wind disorders, are subdued. (Indra remedy)

sloka: maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ svarasaḥ prayojyaḥ kṣīreṇa yaṣṭīmadhukasya cūrṇam| raso guḍūcyāstu samūlapuṣpyāḥ kalkaḥ prayojyaḥ khalu śaṅkhapuṣpyāḥ||30||  āyuḥpradānyāmayanāśanāni balāgnivarṇasvaravardhanāni|  medhyāni caitāni rasāyanāni medhyā viśeṣeṇa caśaṅkhapuṣpī||31||  (itimedhyarasāyanāni)|
translation: The juice of Mandukaparni is beneficial for alleviating aging and disease, as well as enhancing memory, longevity, nutrition, complexion, strength, and potency. The powder of Śaṅkhapuṣpi, when used properly, promotes vitality and has a special significance in enhancing these qualities. Additionally, it helps to eliminate diseases caused by imbalances such as weakness, wind, bile, phlegm, old age, irregular fever, and various types of rogāḥ (diseases) that harm knowledge, ultimately leading to their pacification.

sloka: pañcāṣṭau sapta daśa vā pippalīrmadhusarpiṣā|  rasāyanaguṇānveṣī samāmekāṃ prayojayet||32||  tisrastisrastu pūrvāhṇe bhuktvā'gre bhojanasya ca|  pippalyaḥ kiṃśukakṣārabhāvitā ghṛtabharjitāḥ||33||
translation: Seeker of rejuvenating qualities should mix in the morning, with cow's milk, a paste made from paddy grains, honey, and the powder of licorice root, madhusarpiṣa; also added should be pulverized āyuḥpradān (costusroot), śaṅkhapuṣpya (conch-flower), kalka (paste), kiṃśukakṣāra (arogya-herb), and bhāvitā ghṛta (clarified butter treated with drugs) for the benefit of strength, complexion, voice; these are particularly enhancing for śaṅkhapuṣpī (conch-flower). Before partaking breakfast, one should consume a small portion of this mixture in the earlier part of the morning.

sloka: prayojyā madhusammiśrā rasāyanaguṇaiṣiṇā|  jetuṃ kāsaṃ kṣayaṃ śoṣaṃ śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ galāmayān||34||  arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ pāṇḍutāṃ viṣamajvaram|  vaisvaryaṃ pīnasaṃ śophaṃ gulmaṃ vātabalāsakam||35||  (iti pippalīrasāyanam)|
translation: Seek one who is versed in the medicinal properties of the five, eight, seven, or ten ingredients including honey and sesame oil, to alleviate conditions such as consumption, wasting, hiccups, throat ailments, flatulence, indigestion, gout, diarrhea, piles, fever, and other imbalances caused by the doshas. (This is known as Pippali Rasayana).

sloka: kramavṛddhyā daśāhāni daśapaippalikaṃ  dinam|  vardhayet payasā sārdhaṃ tathaivāpanayetpunaḥ||36||  jīrṇe jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā|  pippalīnāṃ sahasrasya prayogo'yaṃrasāyanam||37||  piṣṭāstā balibhiḥ sevyāḥ śṛtā madhyabalairnaraiḥ|  cūrṇīkṛtā hrasvabalairyojyā doṣāmayān prati||38||
translation: To be used in curing disorders such as consumption, debility, thirst, cough, diseases of the throat, fever, hiccups, anemia, jaundice, diarrhea, indigestion, flatulence, abdominal pains, and windiness, one should prepare a medicine using sugar mixed with the juice of 1000 Pippali fruits, along with various other ingredients. This medicine should be given to those who are weak but not to those who are strong or very strong, nor to those suffering from acute diseases.

sloka: daśapaippalikaḥ śreṣṭho madhyamaḥ ṣaṭprakīrtitaḥ|  prayogo yastriparyantaḥ sa kanīyān sacābalaiḥ||39||  bṛhaṇaṃ svaryamāyuṣyaṃ plīhodaravināśanam|  vayasaḥ sthāpanaṃ medhyaṃ pippalīnāṃ rasāyanam||40||  (iti pippalīvardhamānaṃ rasāyanam)|
translation: The best of the dashapippalika variety is one that promotes growth with the addition of ten palas of water, eliminates decay upon aging, and should be consumed in the form of six parts curd and four parts ghee, mixed with powdered pippalii. This is the preparation (prayoga) for those of medium strength. The one that enhances growth by twenty-five percent, eliminates decay upon aging, and is consumable in half the amount by those of weak strength, and should be consumed mixed with powders of suitable strength to counteract any negative effects. This is the preparation (prayoga) for those of weak strength.

sloka: jaraṇānte'bhayāmekāṃ prāgbhuktād dve bibhītake|  bhuktvā tu madhusarpirbhyāṃ catvāryāmalakāni ca||41||  prayojayan samāmekāṃ triphalāyā rasāyanam|  jīvedvarṣaśataṃ pūrṇamajaro'vyādhireva ca||42||  (iti triphalārasāyanam)|
translation: The best among the ten kinds of pippali , recognized as madhyama and prakirtita, is the one to be used in the following way: consumed along with two types of bhuktva, the small and big ones, and then, after consuming the sugary sarpis, one should consume four ama-lakani. By doing so, one will establish a long life , free from disease , and will live for one hundred years, fully healthy and free from old age. Such is the recipe of the three-pippali mixture .

sloka: traiphalenāyasīṃ pātrīṃ kalkenālepayennavām|  tamahorātrikaṃ lepaṃ pibetkṣaudrodakāplutam||43||  prabhūtasnehamaśanaṃ jīrṇe tatra praśasyate|  ajaro'ruk samābhyāsājjīveccaiva samāḥ śatam||44||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: Upon consuming a concoction made from three fruits (triphalā) and honey, fear of impending death subsides, and one becomes free from the fear of four kinds of poisonous creatures. One who eats this regularly will remain youthful, healthy, and live for a hundred years without aging. (Thus ends the description of the benefits of triphala concoction.)

sloka: madhukena tugākṣīryā pippalyā kṣaudrasarpiṣā|  triphalā sitayā cāpi yuktā siddhaṃ rasāyanam||45||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: Prepare a mixture of three types of fruits, including triphala, in a new vessel with ghee and sugar. Let one consume this concoction twice a day, in the morning and evening, mixed with a small amount of old water that has been strained. By regularly following this practice, even an aging person will remain free from disease and will live for a hundred years, filled with love and affection.

sloka: sarvalauhaiḥ suvarṇena vacayāmadhusarpiṣā|  viḍaṅgapippalībhyāṃ ca triphalā lavaṇena ca||46||  saṃvatsaraprayogeṇa medhāsmṛtibalapradā|  bhavatyāyuḥpradā dhanyājarāroganibarhaṇī||47||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: Prepared by combining sugar, ginger, pepper, a pinch of fine powder of rock salt, and castor oil, along with three myrobalans, this rejuvenating elixir, when used for a year, enhances intellect, memory, strength, longevity, and alleviates aging and diseases. (This is known as the recipe for Triphala Rasayana.)

sloka: anamlaṃ ca kaṣāyaṃ ca kaṭu pāke śilājatu|  nātyuṣṇaśītaṃ dhātubhyaścaturbhyastasyasambhavaḥ||48||  hemnaśca rajatāttāmrādvarāt kṛṣṇāyasādapi|  rasāyanaṃ tadvidhibhistadvṛṣyaṃ tacca roganut||49||  vātapittakaphaghnaiśca niryūhaistat subhāvitam|  vīryotkarṣaṃ paraṃ yāti sarvairekaikaśo'pi vā||50||
translation: With the regular use of all healing herbs such as gold, honey, ghee, black pepper, pippalii, and salts in the course of a year, intellect, memory, strength, longevity, and freedom from disease are significantly enhanced, even for an individual, and it becomes highly potent.

sloka: prakṣiptoddhṛtamapyenat punastat prakṣipedrase|  koṣṇe saptāhametena vidhinā tasya bhāvanā||51||  pūrvoktena vidhānena lohaiścūrṇīkṛtaiḥ saha|  tat pītaṃ payasā dadyāddīrghamāyu sukhānvitam||52||
translation: Even if already purified of its impurities and bitterness, this soil, composed of four primary elements, is further refined with gold, silver, copper, and iron. By this process, as outlined earlier, it becomes imbued with strength, longevity, and vitality. Furthermore, when enriched with various medicinal ingredients, it effectively combats diseases caused by wind, bile, and phlegm, thereby enhancing the individual's potency and overall well-being through each of these components.

sloka: jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ dehadārḍhyakaraṃ param|  medhāsmṛtikaraṃ dhanyaṃ kṣīrāśī tat prayojayet||53||  prayogaḥ saptasaptāhāstrayaścaikaśca saptakaḥ|  nirdiṣṭastrividhastasya paro madhyo'varastathā||54||  palamardhapalaṃ karṣo mātrā tasya tridhā matā |
translation: Having thrown the therapeutic agent into the water, one should churn it again and again with a piece of wood or with one's hand . With this method , milk mixed with powdered iron should be consumed for a long and happy life . The appropriate amount of the therapeutic agent is to be determined in three ways: as the initial dose , for a course of seven days , and for a long-term treatment . It can be mild , moderate , or strong depending on the severity of the disease .

sloka: jāterviśeṣaṃ savidhiṃ tasya vakṣyāmyataḥ param||55|| hemādyāḥ sūryasantaptāḥ sravanti giridhātavaḥ|  jatvābhaṃ mṛdumṛtsnācchaṃ yanmalaṃ tacchilājatu||56||  madhuraśca satiktaśca japāpuṣpanibhaśca yaḥ|  kaṭurvipāke śītaśca sa suvarṇasya nisravaḥ ||57||  rūpyasya kaṭukaḥ śvetaḥ śītaḥ svādu vipacyate|  tāmrasya barhikaṇṭhābhastiktoṣṇaḥ pacyate kaṭu ||58||  yastu guggulukābhāsastiktako lavaṇānvitaḥ|  kaṭurvipāke śītaśca sarvaśreṣṭhaḥ sa cāyasaḥ ||59||
translation: The one who can cure illnesses and strengthen the body, endowed with profound intelligence and sharp memory, who knows the proper time to make use of milk, ghee, and other suitable foods for seven days, according to the three divisions of the day, each one of them being divided into two parts, and who is capable of evaluating the exact measure of it, is considered as the best among goldsmiths, resembling the color and taste of gold, sharp, white, cool, sweet, and astringent, and who also has the properties of guggulu, such as being solid, strong, and salty.

sloka: gomūtragandhayaḥ sarve sarvakarmasu yaugikāḥ|  rasāyanaprayogeṣu paścimastu viśiṣyate ||60||  yathākramaṃ vātapitte śleṣmapitte kaphe triṣu|  viśeṣataḥ praśasyante malā hemādidhātujāḥ ||61||
translation: I will describe the exceptional method of preparation for the mercury-based treatment. Among all methods that are suitable for various purposes, the western one is considered superior. In case of exposure to wind and bile disorders, phlegm disorders, cough, and three types of fever, the ores of metals like iron, silver, gold, and copper exhibit specific qualities when purified in a particular way. The liquid-like mercury, which resembles gold in color, tastes bitter and is found near the banks of rivers or on mountain cliffs, becomes sweet when processed with mild heat; it becomes solid when cooled, and its pungent taste transforms into astringency when combined with salt. Overall, it stands out as the most excellent among all metals.

sloka: śilājatuprayogeṣu vidāhīni gurūṇi ca|  varjayet sarvakālaṃ tu kulatthān  parivarjayet||62||  te hyatyantaviruddhatvādaśmano bhedanāḥ param|  loke dṛṣṭāstatasteṣāṃ prayogaḥpratiṣidhyate||63||  payāṃsi takrāṇi rasāḥ sayūṣāstoyaṃ samūtrā vividhāḥ kaṣāyāḥ|  āloḍanārthaṃ girijasya śastāste te prayojyāḥ prasamīkṣyakāryam||64||
translation:
In the use of mercury and sulfur, one should avoid all excreta and strong-smelling substances. Always rejected are impure substances in all rituals. For, these when used appropriately in a gradual manner in the three doshas - wind, bile, and phlegm - remove impurities such as heavy metals like gold. (62-64)

In the use of mercury and sulfur, one should avoid all excreta and strong-smelling substances. Always rejected are impure substances in all rituals. For, these when used appropriately in a gradual manner in the three doshas - wind, bile, and phlegm - remove impurities such as heavy metals like gold. (62-64)

sloka: na so'sti rogo bhuvi sādhyarūpaḥ śilāhvayaṃ yaṃ na jayet prasahya|  tat kālayogairvidhibhiḥ prayuktaṃ svasthasya corjāṃ vipulāṃ dadāti||65||  (iti śilājaturasāyanam)|
translation: A scholar should not, even in an forced effort, use this stone that can be obtained through specific rituals and methods at certain times for the purpose of curing a disease that is incurable by any other means. Because its nature is completely opposite to that of a stone, it causes harm rather than benefit. Instead, one should make use of various liquids such as water, buttermilk, etc., which are naturally pure and beneficial for this purpose.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  karapracitike pāde daśa ṣaṭ ca maharṣiṇā|  rasāyanānāṃ siddhānāṃ saṃyogāḥ samudāhṛtāḥ||66||
translation: For one who is free from illness in this world, mastering the disciplines of suitable time and effort, the combination of accomplished elixirs is not something to be achieved forcefully; it gives abundant vitality to such a healthy person.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne rasāyanādhyāye karapracitīyo nāma rasāyanapādastṛtīyaḥ||3||
translation: In the section of Caraka's treatise on therapeutics, regarding the preparation of a medicine, specifically in the chapter on elixirs, there is described a certain concoction called "Karapracitike" (named after its inventor), which is a combination of ten established elixirs.

sloka: athāta āyurvedasamutthānīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Thus, we will explain the third chapter, named "Rasayana" (rejuvenation), of the place of treatment in the thoroughly revised text of the treatise called "Caraka" after completing the section on the fire sacrifice. This was declared by the sage Atreya.

sloka: tacchrutvā vibudhapativacanamṛṣayaḥ sarva evāmaravaramṛgbhistuṣṭuvuḥ prahṛṣṭāśca tadvacanamabhinananduśceti||5||
translation: Then, after being told by the lord of knowledge (Bhagavan Atreya), they (the sages) praised with delight and approved the statement about the elixir of life (rasayana pada), which is the means for the proper manifestation of the Vedic knowledge, as well as the elixir of immortality.

sloka: bhavanti cātra  divyānāmoṣadhīnāṃ yaḥ prabhāvaḥ sa bhavadvidhaiḥ| śakyaḥ soḍhumaśakyastu syāt soḍhumakṛtātmabhiḥ||8||  oṣadhīnāṃ prabhāveṇa tiṣṭhatāṃ sve ca karmaṇi|  bhavatāṃ nikhilaṃ śreyaḥ sarvamevopapatsyate||9||  vānaprasthairgṛhasthaiśca prayatairniyatātmabhiḥ|  śakyā oṣadhayo hyetāḥ sevituṃ viṣayābhijāḥ||10||
translation: Having heard the words of the lord of the gods, all the wise seers, who are themselves the best among the immortals, were pleased and expressed their approval.

sloka: yāstu kṣetraguṇaisteṣāṃ madhyamena ca karmaṇā|  mṛduvīryatarāstāsāṃ vidhirjñeyaḥ sa eva tu||11||  paryeṣṭuṃ tāḥ prayoktuṃ vā ye'samarthāḥ sukhārthinaḥ|  rasāyanavidhisteṣāmayamanyaḥ praśasyate||12||
translation: The one who is capable of analyzing and determining the divine power present in these beings, who are endowed with such qualities and engage in actions that are balanced, as well as those who are mild and possess superior strength, is the one who is to be known according to the rules (of scripture). For those who desire pleasure, it is prescribed that they should either investigate or utilize these [plants] that have the ability to serve their needs. Indeed, all prosperity resides in the inherent power of these plants for those who are capable of using them, whether they be ascetics living an independent life, or householders living a disciplined life.

sloka: balyānāṃ jīvanīyānāṃ bṛṃhaṇīyāśca yā daśa|  vayasaḥ sthāpanānāṃ ca khadirasyāsanasya ca||13||  kharjūrāṇāṃ madhūkānāṃ mustānāmutpalasya ca|  mṛdvīkānāṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ vacāyāścitrakasya ca||14||  śatāvaryāḥ payasyāyāḥ pippalyā joṅgakasya ca|  ṛdhdyā nāgabalāyāśca dvāradāyā dhavasya ca||15||  triphalākaṇṭakāryośca vidāryāścandanasya ca|  ikṣūṇāṃ śaramūlānāṃ śrīparṇyāstiniśasya ca||16||  rasāḥ pṛthak pṛthaggrāhyāḥ palāśakṣāra eva ca|  eṣāṃ palonmitān bhāgān payo gavyaṃ caturguṇam||17||
translation: The qualities of the following should be ascertained by a moderate effort and mild courage: the ripening (of crops) that occurs in the middle of their season; the action of nurturing (plants); the strength and vitality of young plants; the proper arrangement of seats made from Khadir wood; the sweetness of dates, sugarcane, musta, and utpala; the softness of mrdvika and vidanga; the pungency of citraka; the astringency of nagabala, dvadara, dhava, triphala, kantaka, vidarya, chandana; the juiciness of sugarcane stalks, shreeparni, tiniśa, palasa kshara, rasas; and the essence of each of these elements. The recommended proportions of these ingredients in a mixture with water are said to enhance the taste and benefit those seeking happiness.

sloka: dve pātre tilatailasya dve ca gavyasya sarpiṣaḥ|  tat sādhyaṃ sarvamekatra susiddhaṃ snehamuddharet||18||  tatrāmalakacūrṇānāmāḍhakaṃ śatabhāvitam |  svarasenaiva dātavyaṃ kṣaudrasyābhinavasya ca||19||  śarkarācūrṇapātraṃ ca prasthamekaṃ pradāpayet|  tugākṣīryāḥ sapippalyāḥ sthāpyaṃ sammūrcchitaṃ ca tat||20||
translation: For the nourishment of ten-year-old, sixteen-year-old, and twenty-year-old [individuals], seats of khadira wood, karanja, jambu, priyal, arjuna, udumbara, bilva, audumbararasa, palasha, and neem are to be arranged. The powders of sugar, kharjura, honey, musta, utpal, mrdvika, vida, citraka, shatavari, payasi, pippali-jongka, naga-balaya, dhavasya, triphala, kantaka-arya, vidari, candana, shara, mula of shriparni, rasa are to be taken separately. Also, the unmixture of milk and ghee with four qualities is to be given in proper measure for each.

sloka: sucaukṣe mārtike kumbhe māsārdhaṃ ghṛtabhāvite|  mātrāmagnisamāṃ tasya tata ūrdhvaṃ prayojayet||21||  hematāmrapravālānāmayasaḥ sphaṭikasya ca|  muktāvaidūryaśaṅkhānāṃ cūrṇānāṃ rajatasya ca||22||  prakṣipya ṣoḍaśīṃ mātrāṃ vihāyāyāsamaithunam|  jīrṇe jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā||23||
translation: In two purified earthen pots, mix sesame oil, cow ghee, and fresh rice flour. Make it into a consistent paste and add an equal measure of the taste of barley and sugar. Add to this a handful each of ground āmalaka fruits, powdered rock candy, and finely ground conch shells, pearls, and hematite. Then, after stirring thoroughly, set aside a portion in a new pot. The remaining mixture should be offered in sixteen equal parts at specific times, consumed in small quantities with fresh curd when the previous serving has digested.

sloka: sarvarogapraśamanaṃ vṛṣyamāyuṣyamuttamam|  sattvasmṛtiśarīrāgnibuddhīndriyabalapradam||24||  paramūrjaskaraṃ caiva varṇasvarakaraṃ tathā|  viṣālakṣmīpraśamanaṃ sarvavācogatapradam||25||
translation: In a clean golden or copper vessel filled with ghee, heated to the right temperature and poured into a mixture of crushed pearls, coral, crystal, silver, conch shells, and then mixed with sixteen times the amount of milk and cream, one should eat this nutritious food after abstaining from physical exertion and sexual activity, once their potency has waned. This is said to be the best rejuvenating and healing tonic.

sloka: siddhārthatāṃ cābhinavaṃ vayaśca prajāpriyatvaṃ ca yaśaśca loke|  prayojyamicchadbhiridaṃ yathāvadrasāyanaṃ brāhmamudāravīryam||26||  (itīndroktarasāyanamaparam)|
translation: The one who possesses the supreme power that cures all ailments, increases lifespan, improves physical and mental strength, enhances memory, sharpens the senses, and is the foremost among the varnas and swaras, and also nullifies poison and bestows prosperity and eloquence.

sloka: samarthānāmarogāṇāṃ dhīmatāṃ niyatātmanām|  kuṭīpraveśaḥ kṣaṇināṃ paricchadavatāṃ hitaḥ||27||  ato'nyathā tu ye teṣāṃ sauryamārutiko vidhiḥ|  tayoḥ śreṣṭhataraḥ pūrvo vidhiḥ satusuduṣkaraḥ||28||  rasāyanavidhibhraṃśājjāyeran vyādhayo yadi|  yathāsvamauṣadhaṃ teṣāṃ kāryaṃ muktvā rasāyanam||29||
translation: For those who are accomplished, free from disease, intellectually mature, self-controlled, and generally liked in the world, entering a hut (for spiritual practice) is beneficial for them in this very life. But for those who are impatient, impulsive, and have unstable minds, the rule prescribed by the sage is more difficult to follow. If, due to improper use of rejuvenating elixirs, they suffer from diseases, then they should take appropriate medicines according to their own discretion, leaving aside the elixir.

sloka: satyavādinamakrodhaṃ nivṛttaṃ madyamaithunāt|  ahiṃsakamanāyāsaṃ praśāntaṃ priyavādinam||30||  japaśaucaparaṃ dhīraṃ dānanityaṃ tapasvinam|  devagobrāhmaṇācāryaguruvṛddhārcane ratam||31||  ānṛśaṃsyaparaṃ nityaṃ nityaṃ karuṇavedinam |  samajāgaraṇasvapnaṃ nityaṃ kṣīraghṛtāśinam||32||  deśakālapramāṇajñaṃ yuktijñamanahaṅkṛtam|  śastācāramasaṅkīrṇamadhyātmapravaṇendriyam||33||  upāsitāraṃ vṛddhānāmāstikānāṃ jitātmanām|  dharmaśāstraparaṃ vidyānnaraṃ nityarasāyanam||34||

sloka: guṇairetaiḥ samuditaiḥ prayuṅkte yo rasāyanam|  rasāyanaguṇān sarvān yathoktān sa samaśnute||35||  (ityācārarasāyanam)|
translation: The one who, being a truthful speaker, free from anger, has abandoned liquor and sexual activity, is compassionate, self-controlled, and serene, fond of reciting prayers, pure, highly intelligent, steady in giving charity, always engaged in austerities, devoted to the worship of gods, cows, and brahmanas, respectful to the elderly, to the virtuous, to those who have conquered their minds, to the scriptures and knowledge, is a human being who partakes of the elixir of life, characterized by all these qualities as described. (35) [ācārarasāyanam]

sloka: yathāsthūlamanirvāhya doṣāñchārīramānasān|  rasāyanaguṇairjanturyujyate na kadācana||36||  yogā hyāyuḥprakarṣārthā jarāroganibarhaṇāḥ|  manaḥśarīraśuddhānāṃ sidhyanti prayatātmanām||37||  tadetanna bhavedvācyaṃ sarvameva hatātmasu|  arujebhyo'dvijātibhyaḥ śuśrūṣā yeṣu nāsti ca||38||
translation: One who makes use of the means of enjoyment, composed of these qualities, partaken fully as stated, never succumbs to defects. Indeed, such complete purification of mind and body in yogis is conducive to longevity, eliminating aging and disease. This should not be mentioned to those with malicious intentions or to those who do not offer respect to the twice-born.

sloka: ye rasāyanasaṃyogā vṛṣyayogāśca ye matāḥ|  yaccauṣadhaṃ vikārāṇāṃ sarvaṃ tadvaidyasaṃśrayam||39||  prāṇācāryaṃ budhastasmāddhīmantaṃ vedapāragam|  aśvināviva devendraḥ pūjayedatiśaktitaḥ||40||
translation: One who nourishes the body and mind with suitable qualities, when should one resort to medicines and treatments? For those whose minds and bodies are pure, longevity, freedom from disease, and enhancement of faculties become possible through such harmonious union. At that time, this must be said: it is one's duty to serve those who have mastered the Vedas, who are free from egoism, and who seek to uplift all living beings. Just as Indra honors and serves the Ashwins, who possess great power and abilities, so too should a wise person respect and care for such advanced souls.

sloka: aśvinau devabhiṣajau yajñavāhāviti smṛtau|  yajñasya hi śiraśchinnaṃ punastābhyāṃ samāhitam||41||
translation: The two Ashwin twins, remembered as divine physicians and bringers of fertility, are considered the supreme healers of all physical ailments. Indeed, for one seeking to be truly guided, they should revere Indra, who is like the Ashwins in wisdom and power.

sloka: praśīrṇā daśanāḥ pūṣṇo netre naṣṭe bhagasya ca|  vajriṇaśca bhujastambhastābhyāmeva cikitsitaḥ||42||  cikitsitaśca śītāṃśurgṛhīto rājayakṣmaṇā|  somābhipatitaścandraḥ kṛtastābhyāṃ punaḥ sukhī||43||
translation:
The Asvin twins, renowned as divine physicians,
Having restored the jaw, nose, and eye, and the piece of skull,
And having set right the arm's support with both [their powers],
They were made content once more by those two.
Moreover, they were the ones who held back the chill of consumption
And caused the moon to wane; they accomplished all this through their power.

sloka: bhārgavaścyavanaḥ kāmī vṛddhaḥ san vikṛtiṃ gataḥ|  vītavarṇasvaropetaḥ kṛtastābhyāṃ punaryuvā||44||  etaiścānyaiśca bahubhiḥ karmabhirbhiṣaguttamau|  babhūvaturbhṛśaṃ pūjyāvindrādīnāṃmahātmanām||45||  grahāḥ stotrāṇi mantrāṇi tathā nānāhavīṃṣi ca|  dhūmrāśca  paśavastābhyāṃ prakalpyante dvijātibhiḥ||46||
translation: The one with split lips, treated by the thunderbolt-wielding one, had his sight restored and was made whole again by the king's touch, who had been afflicted with the royal illness. Thus, he became greatly honored by Indra and other great souls, as they offered him hymns, mantras, spells, and even smoke offerings, all of which were devised by the Brahmins.

sloka: prātaśca savane somaṃ śakro'śvibhyāṃ sahāśnute|  sautrāmaṇyāṃ ca bhagavānaśvibhyāṃ saha modate||47||  indrāgnī cāśvinau caiva stūyante prāyaśo dvijaiḥ|  stūyante vedavākyeṣu na tathā'nyā hi devatāḥ||48||
translation: In the morning and at the new moon offering, Shakra partakes of Soma along with Cyavana, the elder who has shed his old form and become young again through his deeds, together with other beings through many rituals. Indra, Agni, and the Ashvins are highly praised by the Brahmins in hymns, mantras, and various offerings, surpassing other gods.

sloka: ajarairamaraistāvadvibudhaiḥ sādhipairdhruvaiḥ|  pūjyete prayatairevamaśvinaubhiṣajāviti||49||  mṛtyuvyādhijarāvaśyairduḥkhaprāyaiḥ sukhārthibhiḥ|  kiṃ punarbhiṣajo martyaiḥ pūjyāḥ syurnātiśaktitaḥ||50||  śīlavānmatimān yukto dvijātiḥ śāstrapāragaḥ|  prāṇibhirguruvat pūjyaḥ prāṇācāryaḥ sa hi smṛtaḥ||51||
translation: At dawn, along with Soma, Indra and Agni partake the oblation in the morning ritual. The Ashvins also rejoice in the Sautramani offering. They are generally praised by the twice-born ones in the recitation of the Vedic texts; no other gods are to be honored in this way. A self-controlled, intelligent and learned Dvija, who is well-versed with the scriptures, is worthy of worship like a guru, for he nurtures life (prana) just like a guru does.

sloka: vidyāsamāptau bhiṣajo dvitīyā jātirucyate|  aśnute vaidyaśabdaṃ hi na vaidyaḥ pūrvajanmanā||52||  vidyāsamāptau brāhmaṃ vā sattvamārṣamathāpi vā|  dhruvamāviśati jñānāttasmādvaidyo dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ||53|| nābhidhyāyenna cākrośedahitaṃ na samācaret|  prāṇācāryaṃ budhaḥ kaścidicchannāyuranitvaram||54||
translation: Even the long-lived gods and immortals are subject to old age, disease, and death. The wisdom that one has acquired should be used to serve others. It is said that a person who has mastered such knowledge becomes worthy of worship like the twice-born (dvija) who is like a spiritual preceptor to all living beings. Such an enlightened person should not be criticized or treated with disrespect, but rather honored and respected, for they help in alleviating suffering and bringing happiness to many. They are capable, virtuous, and wise, and have mastered the scriptures. They are like a spiritual guide to all living beings and should be treated as such, revered and respected.

sloka: cikitsitastu saṃśrutya yovā'saṃśrutya mānavaḥ|  nopākaroti vaidyāya nāsti tasyeha niṣkṛtiḥ||55||  bhiṣagapyāturān sarvān svasutāniva yatnavān|  ābādhebhyo hi saṃrakṣedicchan dharmamanuttamam||56||
translation: Once the medical science has been fully studied, a person is called a second-born doctor. He partakes the name of a physician when he is able to diagnose based on the symptoms. If such a person does not consult with or assist another physician, then there is no progress in his knowledge. Just as a father protects his own sons, so too should a learned doctor protect all patients from ailments. This is considered the highest duty for a twice-born. Therefore, one desiring a long and happy life should revere, consult, and assist such a spiritual doctor who is firmly established in sacred knowledge and pure conduct.

sloka: dharmārthaṃ cārthakāmārthamāyurvedo maharṣibhiḥ|  prakāśito dharmaparairicchadbhiḥ sthānamakṣaram||57||  nārthārthaṃ nāpi kāmārthamatha bhūtadayāṃ prati|  vartate yaścikitsāyāṃ sa sarvamativartate||58||  kurvate ye tu vṛttyarthaṃ cikitsāpaṇyavikrayam|  te hitvākāñcanaṃ rāśiṃ pāṃśurāśimupāsate||59||  dāruṇaiḥ kṛṣyamāṇānāṃ gadairvaivasvatakṣayam|  chittvā vaivasvatān pāśān jīvitaṃ yaḥ prayacchati||60||
translation:
The one who has studied the medical science, if he doesn't serve the sick, will have no merit. Whether it is a man or a physician, if they do not care for all the patients like their own children, striving to protect them from harm, they are not performing the highest duty.

sloka: dharmārthadātā sadṛśastasya nehopalabhyate|
translation: na hi jīvitadānāddhi dānamanyadviśiṣyate||61||  paro bhūtadayā dharma iti matvā cikitsayā|  vartate yaḥ sa siddhārthaḥ sukhamatyantamaśnute||62||
column4: The giver of religious and material rewards, who is similar to him, is not found elsewhere. Indeed, there is no other gift equal to the gift of life. Considering duty towards all beings as superior, one who acts in this way, attains the highest bliss through the practice of medicine. He transcends everything while performing all actions related to treatment, medical science, and trade; abandoning the pursuit of wealth through unrighteous means and violence inflicted by harsh people, he gives up his own life for the sake of others and cuts asunder the nooses of death for those about to perish.

sloka: tatra ślokau  āyurvedasamutthānaṃ divyauṣadhividhiṃ śubham|  amṛtālpāntaraguṇaṃ siddhaṃ ratnarasāyanam||63||  siddhebhyo brahmacāribhyo yaduvācāmareśvaraḥ|  āyurvedasamutthāne tat sarvaṃ samprakāśitam||64||
translation: The giver of the equivalent reward, recognizing that the supreme duty (dharma) is giving life-sustaining alms, understands that compassionate charity is different from other forms of dharma. In this regard, the divine origin of Ayurveda and the method of using divine herbs, which are beneficial, imperishable, and have the qualities of nectar, have been fully revealed by the Lord of Yadavas during the discourse on the creation of Ayurveda.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsitasthāne rasāyanādhyāye āyurvedasamutthānīyo nāmarasāyanapādaścaturthaḥ||4||
translation: In the treatise on the fire-god, as composed by Caraka, the section on therapeutics reveals that which is responsible for longevity in the form of the fourth chapter named "Nāmarasāyanapāda." The divine recipe of this elixir, which is made up of auspicious and immortal herbs, and which has been perfected by the wise and celestial beings, was expounded by the Lord of Immortals. All of this is fully explained in the section on the origin of Ayurveda.

sloka: athātaḥ saṃyogaśaramūlīyaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now we will explain the root of samyogasharamuli, the section on vajikarana, as stated by Lord Atreya in the well-versed tantra text that has been purified and edited." (This is a translation of the Sanskrit verse: "athātaḥ saṃyogaśaramūlīyaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1|| iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||". The word-level split provided helps to understand the context and meaning of the verse, which includes various terms related to Ayurveda, such as vajikarana (relating to aphrodisiacs), tantra text, purification, and editing.)

sloka: vājīkaraṇamanvicchet puruṣo nityamātmavān|  tadāyattau hi dharmārthau prītiśca yaśa eva ca||3||
translation: Now, we will explain the foundation of the union, referring to the preparation of the steed (vājīkaraṇa). The self-aware person should do it constantly. Then, both dharma and artha along with pleasure and fame arise.

sloka: putrasyāyatanaṃ hyetadguṇāścaite sutāśrayāḥ| vājīkaraṇamagryaṃ ca kṣetraṃ strī yā praharṣiṇī||4||  iṣṭā hyokaikaśo'pyarthā paraṃ prītikarā smṛtāḥ|  kiṃ punaḥ strīśarīre ye saṅghātena pratiṣṭhitāḥ||5||
translation: For a horse , too, one should inquire into its qualities; its owner is established in it as its very self in a permanent manner . Similarly, when these two , dharma and artha, are present , they constitute the field of a woman , who is exhilarated by them. Moreover, even one of these two , namely dharma or artha, is considered to be desirable ; however, the attainment of both in a woman's body is regarded as something truly extraordinary .

sloka: (saṅghāto hīndriyārthānāṃ strīṣu nānyatra vidyate)|  stryāśrayo hīndriyārtho yaḥ sa prītijanano'dhikam|  strīṣu prītirviśeṣeṇa strīṣvapatyaṃ pratiṣṭhitam||6||
translation: The collection of senses in a woman is not found elsewhere; the source of sense pleasure for a man is established as superior in women. In women, special affection is established and in them, marital life is firmly situated. What more can be said about the senses that reside in the body?

sloka: dharmārthau strīṣu lakṣmīśca strīṣu lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ|  surūpā yauvanasthā yā lakṣaṇairyā vibhūṣitā||7||  yā vaśyā śikṣitā yā ca sā strī vṛṣyatamā matā|   nānābhaktyā tu lokasya daivayogācca yoṣitām||8||
translation: Dharma and artha reside in women, who are themselves the established wealth in the world. Graceful and in their youth, they are adorned with beauty and qualities. The woman who is obedient, educated, and considered to be at the height of fertility is regarded as the best. Furthermore, women are revered through various forms of devotion and divine connections in society.

sloka: taṃ taṃ prāpya vivardhante naraṃ rūpādayo guṇāḥ|  vayorūpavacohāvairyā yasya paramāṅganā||9||
translation: Gaining each of them, a person's physical and mental attributes flourish; one who possesses the qualities of beauty, grace, and is skilled in the art of attraction, taming and educating women, becomes desirable among various women due to divine grace and yoga.

sloka: praviśatyāśu hṛdayaṃ daivādvā karmaṇo'pi vā|  hṛdayotsavarūpā yā yā samānamanaḥśayā||10||  samānasattvā yā vaśyā yā yasya prīyate priyaiḥ|  yā pāśabhūtā sarveṣāmindriyāṇāṃ parairguṇaiḥ||11||
translation: Upon attaining him, the primary qualities of a person, such as physical form and strength, increase; as well as his lifespan, speech, and vitality. Additionally, when one's consciousness is united with him, their shared nature and qualities become more pronounced; they are desired by those who are dear to them, and they gain control over their senses, which are bound by external qualities.

sloka: yayā viyukto nistrīkamaratirmanyate jagat|  yasyā ṛte śarīraṃ nā dhatte śūnyamivendriyaiḥ||12||  śokodvegāratibhayairyāṃ dṛṣṭvā nābhibhūyate|  yāti yāṃ prāpya visrambhaṃ dṛṣṭvā hṛṣyatyatīva yām||13||  apūrvāmiva yāṃ yāti nityaṃ harṣātivegataḥ|  gatvā gatvā'pi bahuśo yāṃ tṛptiṃ naiva gacchati||14||
translation: Entering the heart in a flash, it is divine grace that brings about the convergence of similar mental dispositions. It is through this that one's actions become agreeable to those who are dear to them, and they are able to control all external senses with their respective qualities. This is the state that brings immense joy when attained, and one can never tire of reaching it repeatedly; such a unique and blissful experience it is. (translation based on Sanskrit word-split provided)

sloka: sā strī vṛṣyatamā tasya nānābhāvā hi mānavāḥ|  atulyagotrāṃ vṛṣyāṃ ca prahṛṣṭāṃ nirupadravām||15||
translation: The woman who is most desirable to him, the mankind of various dispositions are attached to her; they do not consider worthless even her physical absence, as if bereft of their senses, tormented by sorrow, anxiety, and fear. On seeing her, they are never overwhelmed; on attaining her, they are filled with utmost confidence, experiencing a unique joy that is ever-present and leads to constant satisfaction.

sloka: śuddhasnātāṃ vrajennārīmapatyārthī nirāmayaḥ|  acchāyaścaikaśākhaśca niṣphalaśca yathā drumaḥ||16||  aniṣṭagandhaścaikaśca nirapatyastathā naraḥ|  citradīpaḥ saraḥ śuṣkamadhāturdhātusannibhaḥ||17||  niṣprajastṛṇapūlīti mantavyaḥ puruṣākṛtiḥ|  apratiṣṭhaśca nagnaśca śūnyaścaikendriyaśca nā||18||  mantavyo niṣkriyaścaiva yasyāpatyaṃ na vidyate|
translation: He should be considered as the ideal man's form who is the foremost among men in sexual vigor, whose wife is content and free from ailments, who has diverse qualities and is unparalleled in his lineage, and who takes delight in his own strength and is free from harm.

sloka: bahumūrtirbahumukho bahuvyūho bahukriyaḥ||19||  bahucakṣurbahujñāno bahvātmā ca bahuprajaḥ|  maṅgalye'yaṃ praśasyo'yaṃ dhanyo'yaṃ vīryavānayam||20||  bahuśākho'yamiti ca stūyate nā bahuprajaḥ|  prītirbalaṃ sukhaṃ vṛttirvistāro vipulaṃ  kulam||21||  yaśo lokāḥ sukhodarkāstuṣṭiścāpatyasaṃśritāḥ|  tasmādapatyamanvicchan guṇāṃścāpatyasaṃśritān||22||  vājīkaraṇanityaḥ syādicchan kāmasukhāni ca|  upabhogasukhān siddhān vīryāpatyavivardhanān||23||
translation:
A chaste, pure Brahmin who has bathed should approach a virtuous woman for procreation. He who is free from disease and is fit, thus similar to a ripe fruit, is recommended for this purpose. One who is without offspring, childless like a eunuch, should not be pursued. A person who is infertile, empty, or without faculties should also be avoided, as well as one who does not have the means to support a family. (19-23)

The qualities of such a man are described as follows: he is auspicious, fortunate, brave, and wise; praised for his many skills; large-hearted and generous; with a pleasing disposition, strength, happiness, proper conduct, great lineage, fame, and noble companions.
