He is also praised for being a giver of wealth, capable of producing offspring, and possessing abundant energy, vigor, and vitality. (19-23)

Translation by: Amelia Glasper

sloka: vājīkaraṇasaṃyogān pravakṣyāmyata uttaram| śaramūlekṣumūlāni kāṇḍekṣuḥ sekṣuvālikā||24||  śatāvarī payasyā ca vidārī kaṇṭakārikā|  jīvantī jīvako medā vīrā carṣabhako balā||25||  ṛddhirgokṣurakaṃ rāsnā sātmaguptā punarnavā|  eṣāṃ tripalikān bhāgān  māṣāṇāmāḍhakaṃ navam||26||
translation: I will expound further on the methods of impregnation and rearing. The roots of the plants such as śaramūka, kāṇḍekṣu, sekṣuvālikā, śatāvarī, payasyā, vidārī, kaṇṭakārikā, jīvantī, medā, vīrā, carṣabhaka, and balā; the substances that contribute to their growth, namely rddhirgokṣurakaṃ, rāsnā, sātmagupta, punarnavā; and the essential parts of these plants - tripalikān - which is the ninth part of a māṣa measurement, are all praiseworthy for their various qualities such as being bountiful, having multiple branches, being auspicious, fortunate, brave, having many offshoots, and bringing fame in the world. Therefore, one who desires to have progeny, who is endowed with knowledge of the methods of impregnation and rearing, should seek these plant qualities and strive for their enhancement in his offspring.

sloka: vipācayejjaladroṇe caturbhāgaṃ ca śeṣayet|  tatra peṣyāṇi madhukaṃ drākṣā phalgūni pippalī||27||  ātmaguptā madhukāni kharjūrāṇi śatāvarī|  vidāryāmalakekṣūṇāṃ rasasya ca pṛthak pṛthak||28||  sarpiṣaścāḍhakaṃ dadyāt kṣīradroṇaṃ ca tadbhiṣak|  sādhayedghṛtaśeṣaṃ ca supūtaṃ yojayet punaḥ||29||  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāścūrṇaiḥ prasthonmitaiḥ pṛthak|  palaiścaturbhirmāgadhyāḥ palena maricasya ca||30||  tvagelākeśarāṇāṃ ca cūrṇairardhapalonmitaiḥ|  madhunaḥ kuḍavābhyāṃ ca dvābhyāṃ tatkārayedbhiṣak||31||
translation: The charioteer should mix the four parts of sugarcane juice and set aside the rest. Then, he should extract separately the honey-like substance from madhuka, date palm, and śatāvarī. He should give ghee and cow's milk to the patient. After that, he should prepare a concoction with the remaining buttermilk and mix it well. He should then prepare separate powders of sugar, jaggery, crushed long pepper, black pepper, dried ginger, piper cubeba, rock salt, cardamom, costus, cinnamon, cloves, and maricha. He should also make separate pastes from the bark of vālikā and śatāvarī. The physician should use these ingredients in the treatment.

sloka: palikā gulikāstyānāstā  yathāgni prayojayet|  eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ yogo bṛṃhaṇo balavardhanaḥ||32||  anenāśva ivodīrṇo balī liṅgaṃ samarpayet|33| (iti bṛṃhaṇīguṭikā)
translation: "In the churning of buttermilk in the four stages, separate the liquid and solid parts. This is the alchemical process called 'vrshya', the supreme union, promoting strength and growth. With this, prepare a pill-sized portion of butter, mix it with sugar, clarified butter, and milk; then add a quarter palasa of honey and two kudava measures each of powdered māgadhi, licorice, and arrow- poison. Mix all these together thoroughly."

sloka: māṣāṇāmātmaguptāyā bījānāmāḍhakaṃ navam||33||  jīvakarṣabhakau vīrāṃ medāmṛddhiṃ śatāvarīm|  madhukaṃ cāśvagandhāṃ ca sādhyet kuḍavonmitām||34||  rase tasmin ghṛtaprasthaṃ gavyaṃ daśaguṇaṃ payaḥ|  vidārīṇāṃ rasaprasthaṃ prasthamikṣurasasya ca||35||
translation:
With regard to the seeds of the sesame plant, how should one properly prepare and activate them, so as to enhance their potency and growth? Similarly, for the sake of increasing the strength and vitality of the following: jujube fruits, medicinal herbs like jivakarasha, vira, meda, shatavari, madhuka, and ashvagandha; as well as vidari, grithaprashtha, gavya (cow's milk), and prasthikshurasa?

Note: In this translation, I have tried to maintain the context of the original verse while using terminology that is relevant in English. For example, the term "gulikā" has been translated as "seeds," and "prayojayet" has been translated as "prepare and activate." The phrase "eṣa vṛṣyaḥ param yogaḥ" in the original verse has been translated as "for the sake of increasing the strength and vitality" to better convey the intended meaning. Similarly, the term "bṛṃhaṇaḥ bala vardhanaḥ" has been translated as "enhance their potency and growth." I hope this meets your requirements.

sloka: dattvā mṛdvagninā sādhyaṃ siddhaṃ sarpirnidhāpayet|  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāḥ kṣaudrasya ca pṛthak pṛthak||36||  bhāgāṃścatuṣpalāṃstatra pippalyāścāvapet palam| palaṃ pūrvamato līḍhvā tato'nnamupayojayet||37||  ya icchedakṣayaṃ śukraṃ śephasaścottamaṃ balam|38| (iti vājīkaraṇaṃ ghṛtam)
translation: For the eighth component (of vājīkaraṇa), take nine grains such as wheat, barley, etc., and an āḍhaka measure of equal parts of shatāvarī, madhuka, medāmṛddhi, jīvakarṣabha, and bīja of ātmaguptāyāḥ māṣa; add to it a handful each of kuḍava, vonmita, vidārīṇām rasa, and the juice of sugarcane and payas; previously mix well, then incorporate ghee prastha of ten qualities into it.

sloka: śarkarā māṣavidalāstugākṣīrī payo ghṛtam||38||  godhūmacūrṇaṣaṣṭhāni sarpiṣyutkārikāṃ pacet|  tāṃ nātipakvāṃ mṛditāṃ kaukkuṭe madhure rase||39||  sugandhe prakṣipeduṣṇe yathā sāndrībhavedrasaḥ|  eṣa piṇḍaraso vṛṣyaḥ pauṣṭiko balavardhanaḥ||40||
translation: Having made the oblation with ghee into the heated fire , one should place separately the portions of salt, sugar, and clarified butter , each mixed with a fourth part of crushed pippali fruits. After reciting the previously mentioned mantra, one should mix the well-cooked rice with this. This meal , which is nourishing and strength-enhancing , should be consumed with relish .

sloka: anenāśva ivodīrṇo balī  liṅgaṃ samarpayet| śikhitittirihaṃsānāmevaṃ piṇḍaraso mataḥ|  balavarṇasvarakaraḥ pumāṃstena vṛṣāyate||41||  (iti vājīkaraṇapiṇḍarasāḥ [2] )
translation: "Just as sugar, rice, ghee, wheat, and curd are cooked together with milk and water to make a sacrificial offering for the horse, in the same way, this pinda made of balanced ingredients that include barley, masha , salt, and spices, is mixed with madhura rasa , sugandha , oshna , and bala -enhancing substances."

sloka: ghṛtaṃ māṣān sabastāṇḍān sādhayenmāhiṣe rase|  bharjayettaṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ phalāmlaṃ navasarpiṣi||42||  īṣatsalavaṇaṃ yuktaṃ dhānyajīrakanāgaraiḥ|  eṣa vṛṣyaśca balyaśca bṛṃhaṇaśca rasottamaḥ||43||  (iti vṛṣyamāhiṣarasaḥ)
translation: Treating the extracted liquid from sesame seeds and rice as a potent aphrodisiac (vṛṣya), one should offer it to a strong man, comparing its effectiveness to that of a horse. This potion, when prepared with appropriate ingredients like Dhanyaka and Nāgara, acquires superior quality and enhances strength, virility, and growth, just as the balanced sounds (svara) and syllables (karaḥ) give power to speech in a man. (iti vṛṣyamāhiṣarasaḥ)

sloka: caṭakāṃstittirirase tittirīn kaukkuṭe rase|  kukkuṭān bārhiṇarase hāṃse bārhiṇameva ca||44||  navasarpiṣi santaptān phalāmlān kārayedrasān|  madhurān vā yathāsātmyaṃ gandhāḍhyān balavardhanān||45||  (ityanye vṛṣyarasāḥ)
translation: Churn fresh ghee and sesame along with other grains in a bull; extract the best essence. Add a little salt and suitable grains such as jira and nagara to it. Similarly, prepare juices from fresh fruits and bitter foods, and mix them appropriately with sweet-smelling substances that promote strength and growth. (According to another view) This vrsya (aphrodisiac) is prepared thus.

sloka: tṛptiṃ caṭakamāṃsānāṃ gatvā yo'nupibet payaḥ|  na tasya liṅgaśaithilyaṃ syānna śukrakṣayo niśi||46||  (iti vṛṣyamāṃsam)
translation: One who makes the quenched **caṭaka** birds and other thirsty creatures drink water, even if it's just a drop, they will not suffer seminal discharge at night nor will they lose their vigor; furthermore, they can enhance the sweetness of juicy fruits as per their taste and nature. (from Vṛṣyamāṃsam)

sloka: māṣayūṣeṇa yo bhuktvā ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  payaḥ pibati rātriṃ sa kṛtsnāṃ jāgarti vegavān||47||  (iti vṛṣyamāṣayogaḥ)
translation: Having eaten only the amount of meat equivalent to a grain of mung bean and consuming ghee-cooked rice measured by sixty handfuls, one who drinks milk throughout the night will experience complete satisfaction, lack of sexual desire, and depletion of semen.

sloka: na nā svapiti rātriṣu nityastabdhena śephasā|  tṛptaḥ kukkuṭamāṃsānā bhṛṣṭānāṃ nakraretasi||48||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ kukkuṭamāṃsaprayogaḥ)
translation: Who, after eating a meal of grain soup with ghee and sixteenth-part measure of rice, along with curds, drinks the night through without ever sleeping, remaining ever vigilant.

sloka: niḥsrāvya matsyāṇḍarasaṃ bhṛṣṭaṃ sarpiṣi bhakṣayet|  haṃsabarhiṇadakṣāṇāmevamaṇḍāni bhakṣayet||49||  (iti vṛṣyo'ṇḍarasaḥ)
translation: A swan, always content and never satiated, should eat every night only the fatty portions of chicken, just as it breaks the surface of water after shaking off the drops; such is the diet of a swan.

sloka: bhavataścātra  srotaḥsu śuddheṣvamale śarīre vṛṣyaṃ yadā nā  mitamatti kāle|  vṛṣāyate tena paraṃ manuṣyastadbṛṃhaṇaṃ caiva balapradaṃ ca||50||  tasmāt purā śodhanameva kāryaṃ balānurūpaṃ na hi vṛṣyayogāḥ|  sidhyanti dehe maline prayuktāḥ kliṣṭe  yathā vāsasi rāgayogāḥ||51||
translation: When one, devoid of semen, consumes fish and mussels, rice and sesame seeds in the manner of a swan on a lotus leaf, then that increase in virility becomes paramount strength. Therefore, purification should be performed appropriately according to one's ability, for sexual vitality does not succeed in a polluted body, just as the union of a rag (cloth) with a dirty vasani (a type of plant).

sloka: tatra ślokau  vājīkaraṇasāmarthyaṃ kṣetraṃ strī yasya caiva yā|  ye doṣā nirapatyānāṃ guṇāḥ putravatāṃ ca ye||52||  daśa pañca ca saṃyogā vīryāpatyavivardhanāḥ|  uktāste śaramūlīye pāde puṣṭibalapradāḥ||53||
translation:
In this passage, regarding the topic of conception, it is said that at the time when a pure and unblemished body is ready for intercourse, the man who has the ability to make his seed fertile is the superior one. Therefore, purification before intercourse is recommended, and in a clean body, the yoga of virility is successful, just as a dirty garment does not allow dye to absorb properly. (52-53)

Here, "ślokau" refers to two verses or couplets, "vājīkaraṇasāmarthyaṃ" means the ability to make seed fertile, "kṣetram" refers to the field or body, "strī yasya caiva" refers to his wife, "nirapatyānām guṇāh" means the qualities of one who has no children, "putravatām ca ye" means and the qualities of one who has children, "daśa pañca ca saṃyogāḥ" means ten and five are the combinations, "vīryāpatyavivardhanāḥ" means increasing virility and progeny. In verse 53, "puṣṭibalapradāḥ" means giving strength and power, "śaramūlīye" means in the final or last resort, "pāde" means at the time of or when. The rest of the words give details about the conditions and importance of these qualities and actions.

sloka: athāta āsiktakṣīrikaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we will explain the means of making a steed (vajikarana) and its power (samarthyam) that is mentioned in this hymn (slokau), referring to the one who has the qualities (gunah) of a son (putravatama) such as strength (virtya), increase of offspring (apatya vivardhanah), nourishment (pusti), and power (bala), which are the ten (dasa) and five (pancha) combined samyogas of those who are free from defects (dosanirapatyamanam). Thus spoke the Lord Atreya.

sloka: āsiktakṣīramāpūrṇamaśuṣkaṃ śuddhaṣaṣṭikam|  udūkhale  samāpothya pīḍayet kṣīramarditam||3||  gṛhītvā taṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ gavyena payasā saha|  bījānāmātmaguptāyā dhānyamāṣarasena ca||4||  balāyāḥ śūrpaparṇyośca jīvantyā jīvakasya ca [2] |  ṛddhyarṣabhakakākolīśvadaṃṣṭrāmadhukasya ca||5||  śatāvaryā vidāryāśca drākṣākharjūrayorapi|  saṃyuktaṃ mātrayā vaidyaḥ sādhayettatra cāvapet||6||  tugākṣīryāḥ samāṣāṇāṃ śālīnāṃ ṣaṣṭikasya ca|  godhūmānāṃ ca cūrṇāni yaiḥ sa sāndrībhavedrasaḥ||7||
translation: Now, we will explain the preparation of the mixture of curd and butter milk, as instructed by Lord Atreya. The ingredients include buttermilk that is unsoured , thin , dry , pure , and has six parts . This should be churned in a pot and the butter that forms should be removed . Then, this purified butter should be mixed with cow's milk , as well as with the seeds of grains and legumes . Additionally, the chaff of barley and rice , the juice of sugarcane , the horn of a bull , the teeth of an elephant , and the milk of a cow should be added. The physician should combine all these ingredients with an equal measure of water . This is then used to treat various eye ailments, such as those affecting the cornea , eyelashes , and the grains of rice-sized growths .

sloka: sāndrībhūtaṃ ca kuryāt prabhūtamadhuśarkaram|  guli(ṭi)kā badaraistulyāstāśca sarpiṣi bharjayet||8||  tā yathāgni prayuñjānaḥ kṣīramāṃsarasāśanaḥ|  paśyatyapatyaṃ vipulaṃ vṛddho'pyātmajamakṣayam||9||  (ityapatyakarī ṣaṣṭikādiguṭikā)
translation: One should prepare rice pudding with a moderate amount of sugar, adding condiments such as raisins and coriander to the previously cooked and cooled rice, mixed with ghee and milk. Similarly, a physician skilled in the use of appropriate drugs and dosages can treat disorders caused by the imbalance of the three humors (vata, pitta, and kapha), using grains such as barley and lentils, along with various fruits and vegetables, all properly cooked and combined to create a harmonious rasa (taste).

sloka: caṭakānāṃ sahaṃsānāṃ dakṣāṇāṃ śikhināṃ tathā|  śiśumārasya nakrasya bhiṣak śukrāṇi saṃharet||10||  gavyaṃ sarpirvarāhasya kuliṅgasya vasāmapi|  ṣaṣṭikānāṃ ca cūrṇāni cūrṇaṃ godhūmakasya  ca||11||
translation: Just as Agni (the sacrificial fire) consumes the offerings of ghee and meat from cows, goats, and sheep, similarly, a mature and wise person perceives the offspring (of these animals) to be vast and imperishable.

sloka: ebhiḥ pūpalikāḥ kāryāḥ śaṣkulyo vartikāstathā|  pūpā dhānāśca vividhā bhakṣyāścānye pṛthagvidhāḥ||12||  eṣāṃ prayogādbhakṣyāṇāṃ stabdhenāpūrṇaretasā|  śephasā vājivadyāti yāvadicchaṃ striyo naraḥ||13||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikādiyogāḥ)
translation: Of partridges, swans, hawks, kites, and young eagles, as well as of serpents, doctors, and sons of Mārāsa and Nakra, the testicles, marrow, and fat of a boar and a rabbit, along with the powder of barley and wheat, should be consumed. A man or woman may consume these foods until satiated, so long as it is their desire. (Translation of the verse "ebhiḥ pūpalikāḥ kāryāḥ..." and its corresponding word-split.)

sloka: ātmaguptāphalaṃ māṣān kharjūrāṇi śatāvarīm|  śṛṅgāṭakāni mṛdvīkāṃ sādhayet prasṛtonmitam||14||  kṣīraprasthaṃ jalaprasthametat prasthāvaśeṣitam|  śuddhena vāsasā pūtaṃ yojayet prasṛtaistribhiḥ||15||
translation: With pure clothing and using three specialized tools (grinder, pestle, and mortar), one should prepare a mixture of various types of grains and fruits such as peas, dates, Indian sarsparilla, long pepper, different kinds of edible roots and vegetables. A person who desires to maintain their health should consume this nutritious meal until they are satisfied, neither overindulging nor remaining hungry.

sloka: śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāḥ sarpiṣo'bhinavasya ca|  tat pāyayeta sakṣaudraṃ ṣaṣṭikānnaṃ ca bhojayet||16||  jarāparīto'pyabalo yogenānena vindati|  naro'patyaṃ suvipulaṃ yuveva ca sa hṛṣyati||17||  (ityapatyakaraḥ svarasaḥ)
translation: Having carefully prepared a medicinal concoction of sugar, new sesame oil, and the juices of mango, belleric myrobalan, licorice, calamus, and asparagus, one should mix it with pure, remaining cow's milk and water from a freshly opened coconut. By partaking of this potion, even a feeble old man will regain strength, become as energetic as a young person, and find great joy.

sloka: kharjūrīmastakaṃ māṣān payasyāṃ ca śatāvarīm|  kharjūrāṇi madhūkāni mṛdvīkāmajaḍāphalam||18||  palonmitāni matimān [4] sādhayet salilāḍhake|  tena pādāvaśeṣeṇa kṣīraprasthaṃ vipācayet||19||  kṣīraśeṣeṇa tenādyād ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  saśarkareṇa saṃyoga eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ smṛtaḥ||20||  (iti vṛṣyakṣīram)
translation: A prudent person should churn fresh curd and sugar mixed with water, together with

sloka: jīvakarṣabhakau medāṃ jīvantīṃ śrāvaṇīdvayam|  kharjūraṃ madhukaṃ drākṣāṃ pippalīṃ viśvabheṣajam||21||  śṛṅgāṭakaṃ vidārīṃ ca navaṃ sarpiḥ payo jalam|  siddhaṃ ghṛtāvaśeṣaṃ taccharkarākṣaudrapādikam||22||  ṣaṣṭikānnena saṃyuktamupayojyaṃ yathābalam|  vṛṣyaṃ balyaṃ ca varṇyaṃ ca kaṇṭhyaṃ bṛṃhaṇamuttamam||23||  (iti vṛṣyaghṛtam)
translation: Consisting of sixfold barley, cow's milk, and sugar; root of masha, Shaileya, liquorice, patala, jivanti, and honey; country sugar, sugarcane juice, and the residue of ghee; mixed in proper proportion with ṣaṣṭika rice, this is famously known as vṛṣyaghṛta, promoting strength, nourishment, complexion, voice, and bulk.

sloka: dadhnaḥ saraṃ śaraccandrasannibhaṃ doṣavarjitam|  śarkarākṣaudramaricaistugākṣīryā ca buddhimān||24||  yuktyā yuktaṃ sasūkṣmailaṃ nave kumbhe [5] śucau paṭe|  mārjitaṃ prakṣipecchīte ghṛtāḍhye ṣaṣṭikaudane||25||  pibenmātrāṃ rasālāyāstaṃ bhuktvā ṣaṣṭikaudanam [6] |  varṇasvarabalopetaḥ pumāṃstena vṛṣāyate||26||  (vṛṣyo dadhisaraprayogaḥ)
translation: The wise man should churn the buttermilk with a churning stick made of wood that is devoid of defects, looking like the autumn moon. He should consider using a new, smooth pot that is clean and pure for this purpose. After milk has been added to it in proper proportion with curd and water, he should churn it skillfully with balanced force while keeping a steady pace. Once the butter has surfaced and been collected, he should consume a measure of it mixed with sugar and clarified butter, which will increase his strength, vigor, complexion, voice, and overall well-being. (The practice of churning buttermilk)

sloka: candrāṃśukalpaṃ payasā ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  śarkarāmadhusaṃyuktaṃ prayuñjāno vṛṣāyate||27||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ ṣaṣṭikaudanaprayogaḥ)
translation: A wise person churns with buttermilk, free from impurities, resembling the autumn moon, mixed with sugar and rock candy, a quantity of sixty measures (of ghee and buttermilk), and produces curds.

sloka: tapte sarpiṣi nakrāṇḍaṃ tāmracūḍāṇḍamiśritam|  yuktaṃ ṣaṣṭikacūrṇena sarpiṣā'bhinavena ca||28|| paktvā pūpalikāḥ khādedvāruṇīmaṇḍapo naraḥ|  ya icchedaśvavadgantuṃ prasektuṃ gajavacca yaḥ||29||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)
translation:
Using the word-split provided, the translation of the verse is:

Made with refined rice flour, mixed with ghee and sugar, sweetened with jaggery and honey, when offered in the altar of Vrishabha, the desire for riding a horse or elephant is fulfilled. (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)

The verse describes the preparation and offering of a ritualistic food item made from refined rice flour, ghee, sugar, jaggery, and honey, to the altar of Vrishabha, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu. The results of such an offering are also mentioned, which is the fulfillment of desires related to horse or elephant riding.

sloka: bhavataścātra  etaiḥ prayogairvidhivadvapuṣmān vīryopapanno [7] balavarṇayuktaḥ|  harṣānvito vājivadaṣṭavarṣo bhavet samarthaśca varāṅganāsu||30|| yadyacca kiñcinmanasaḥ priyaṃ syādramyā vanāntāḥ pulināni śailāḥ|  iṣṭāḥ striyo bhūṣaṇagandhamālyaṃ priyā vayasyāśca tadatra yogyam [8] ||31||
translation: With the application of ghee heated in an earthen pot, mixed with equal parts of copper sulfate and refined sugar, a person becomes strong and energetic, capable of lifting and carrying a barley-sized mustard seed in a cow's hoof imprint, drinking the water of the Ganges. They become worthy of the company of beautiful women, beloved by women of their own age, and desired by horses, elephants, and even cows.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  āsiktakṣīrike pāde ye yogāḥ parikīrtitāḥ|  aṣṭāvapatyakāmaiste prayojyāḥ pauruṣārthibhiḥ||32||  ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne vājīkaraṇādhyāye āsiktakṣīriko nāma vājīkaraṇapādo dvitīyaḥ||2||
translation: In the tantric text "Agnivesaka" composed by Caraka, within the section on aphrodisiacs (vajikarana), specifically in the second sub-section named "Asiktakshiri," those yogis who have been highly praised and should be utilized for the pursuit of personal success through eight specialized means.

sloka: athāto māṣaparṇabhṛtīyaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now we will explain the section of the treatise concerning the preparation of rice cooked with mung beans, as previously mentioned by the blessed Atreya in the chapter on elixirs, which is praised for its eightfold yoga-like application in producing offspring."

sloka: māṣaparṇabhṛtāṃ dhenuṃ gṛṣṭiṃ puṣṭāṃ catuḥstanīm|  samānavarṇavatsāṃ ca jīvadvatsāṃ ca buddhimān||3||  rohiṇīmathavā kṛṣṇāmūrdhvaśṛṅgīmadāruṇām|  ikṣvādāmarjunādāṃ vā sāndrakṣīrāṃ ca dhārayet||4||  kevalaṃ tu payastasyāḥ śṛtaṃ vā'śṛtameva vā|  śarkarākṣaudrasarpirbhiryuktaṃ tadvṛṣyamuttamam||5||
translation:
Now, we will explain the characteristics of a she-ass. Once upon a time, the sage Atreya said:

References:
māṣaparṇabhṛtāṃ dhenuṃ - pertains to a she-ass
gṛṣṭiṃ puṣṭāṃ catuḥstanīm - strong, well-built, and of medium size
samānavarṇavatsāṃ ca - with a uniform color
jīvadvatsāṃ ca buddhimān - intelligent and tameable like a cow

rohiṇīmathavā kṛṣṇāmūrdhvaśṛṅgīmadāruṇām - having a horn that is black at the base and white at the tip
ikṣvākṣudrasarpirbhiryuktaṃ - with a coat of hair resembling the color of sugarcane, grains, or serpentine scales
tadvṛṣyamuttamam - excellent in every way (applicable to this description)
kevalaṃ tu payastasyāḥ śṛtaṃ vā'śṛtameva vā - whether it is thin or fat, or of medium build

sloka: śukralairjīvanīyaiśca bṛṃhaṇairbalavardhanaiḥ|  kṣīrasañjananaiścaiva payaḥ siddhaṃ pṛthak pṛthak||6||  yuktaṃ godhūmacūrṇena saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram|  paryāyeṇa prayoktavyamicchatā śukramakṣayam||7||
translation: Using milk, mixed with the curds of four cows, of the best quality, nourishing and of uniform white color; adding sugar, salt, and sarpir (a type of rice), considered to be the best; Arjuna should keep only that [milk] which is the essence, either in the middle or at the end, for increasing his semen.

sloka: medāṃ payasyāṃ jīvantīṃ vidārīṃ kaṇṭakārikām|  śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ kṣīrikāṃ māṣān godhūmāñchāliṣaṣṭikān||8||  payasyardhodake paktvā  kārṣikānāḍhakonmite|  vivarjayet payaḥśeṣaṃ tat pūtaṃ kṣaudrasarpiṣā||9||  yuktaṃ saśarkaraṃ pītvā vṛddhaḥ saptatiko'pi vā|  vipulaṃ labhate'patyaṃ yuveva ca sa hṛṣyati||10||
translation: Consuming milk, which is full of life-giving properties, nourishment, and strength, along with rice flour mixed with a small amount of rock salt, one should reject the remaining liquid. By drinking this prepared mixture, even an elderly person of seventy years will gain vitality and feel as if they were young again.

sloka: maṇḍalairjātarūpasya tasyā eva payaḥ śṛtam|  apatyajananaṃ siddhaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram||11||
translation: Of the living cow, having shed (removed) from its milk the [tough] outer skin, the [fine] inner layer mixed with ghee, after cooking and filtering it, an elderly person of seventy years, or even a young one, becomes strong and joyful, acquiring wealth and progeny.

sloka: triṃśat supiṣṭāḥ pippalyaḥ prakuñce tailasarpiṣoḥ|  bhṛṣṭāḥ saśarkarākṣaudrāḥ kṣīradhārāvadohitāḥ||12||  pītvā yathābalaṃ cordhvaṃ ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā|  bhuktvā na rātrimastabdhaṃ liṅgaṃ paśyati nā kṣarat||13||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ pippalīyogaḥ) śvadaṃṣṭrāyā vidāryāśca rase kṣīracaturguṇe|  ghṛtāḍhyaḥ sādhito vṛṣyo māṣaṣaṣṭikapāyasaḥ||14|| (iti vṛṣyapāyasayogaḥ)
translation: Born from the bulbs with well-developed shapes, the milk of cow's offspring, when churned with sesame, salt, and sugar, becomes a drink that, when consumed in appropriate quantity, allows one to see the linga (symbol of Shiva) the next morning without any discharge (from the body). [Referring to a yoga practice] With the addition of ghee and turmeric, this drink made from milk, curd, and six measures of rice pudding becomes potent.

sloka: phalānāṃ jīvanīyānāṃ snigdhānāṃ rucikāriṇām|  kuḍavaścūrṇitānāṃ syāt svayaṅguptāphalasya ca||15||  kuḍavaścaiva māṣāṇāṃ dvau dvau ca tilamudgayoḥ|  godhūmaśālicūrṇānāṃ kuḍavaḥ kuḍavo bhavet||16||  sarpiṣaḥ kuḍavaścaikastat sarvaṃ kṣīramarditam [1] |  paktvā pūpalikāḥ khādedbahvyaḥ syuryasya yoṣitaḥ||17||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)
translation:
Of the ripened fruits, thirty types, well-ripened, of pippalya, freshly cut, anointed with oil and ghee, mixed with sugar and rock salt, when consumed in proper quantity, enhances one's strength and keeps it upwards; if eaten at night, for more than six quantities, it causes loss of semen. (15-16)

The same applies to the use of two measures each of black sesame and mudga, as well as to the use of husked barley grains. (17) When ghee is mixed with milk, it becomes easy to digest all types of food. (18) (Vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)

sloka: ghṛtaṃ śatāvarīgarbhaṃ kṣīre daśaguṇe pacet|  śarkarāpippalīkṣaudrayuktaṃ tadvṛṣyamuttamam||18||  (iti vṛṣyaṃ śatāvarīghṛtam)
translation:
The churned ghee of *Śatāvarī*'s womb, when cooked with ten times the amount of milk, mixed with sugar, long pepper, and rock salt becomes the best aphrodisiac. (Churned ghee of Śatāvarī is called Vṛṣya.)

The translation emphasizes on the ingredients and their quantity to be mixed with the churned ghee of *Śatāvarī*'s womb to prepare the best aphrodisiac. The term 'Vṛṣya' is translated as 'aphrodisiac' because it directly refers to the churned ghee of *Śatāvarī*'s womb, which when prepared as mentioned in the verse becomes an aphrodisiac.

sloka: karṣaṃ madhukacūrṇasya ghṛtakṣaudrasamāṃśikam [1] |  prayuṅkte yaḥ payaścānu [2] nityavegaḥ sa nā bhavet||19||  (iti vṛṣyamadhukayogaḥ)
translation: One who daily cooks the mixture of clarified butter, costus root extract, cow's cream, and jaggery with a pinch of black pepper and pippalí, will never become lazy. (vṛṣyamadhukayogaḥ)

sloka: ghṛtakṣīrāśano nirbhīrnirvyādhirnityago yuvā|  saṅkalpapravaṇo nityaṃ naraḥ strīṣu vṛṣāyate||20||
translation: A constant thinker, always youthful, free from ailments and fears, with a diet of only milk and ghee, such a man excites women.

sloka: kṛtaikakṛtyāḥ siddhārthā ye cānyo'nyānuvartinaḥ|  kalāsu kuśalāstulyāḥ sattvena vayasā ca ye||21||  kulamāhātmyadākṣiṇyaśīlaśaucasamanvitāḥ|  ye kāmanityā ye hṛṣṭā ye viśokā gatavyathāḥ||22||  ye tulyaśīlā ye bhaktā ye priyā ye priyaṃvadāḥ|  tairnaraḥ saha visrabdhaḥ suvayasyairvṛṣāyate||23||
translation: Consisting of eating ghee and milk, always free from fear and ailments, youthful, with controlled desires, and constantly engaged in virtuous deeds, such is the description of a man. He is endowed with equal conduct towards women and men, devoted, dear, and speaking pleasing words. With such individuals, Nara (Arjuna), filled with trust, rejoices.

sloka: abhyaṅgotsādanasnānagandhamālyavibhūṣaṇaiḥ|  gṛhaśayyāsanasukhairvāsobhirahataiḥ priyaiḥ||24||  vihaṅgānāṃ rutairiṣṭaiḥ strīṇāṃ cābharaṇasvanaiḥ|  saṃvāhanairvarastrīṇāmiṣṭānāṃ ca vṛṣāyate||25||
translation: Accomplished in a single duty, the end goals of which are fulfilled, those who are skilled and equally proficient in virtues such as character, lineage, generosity, and cleanliness; always filled with desire, free from afflictions, equal-minded, and devoted to the wise who are eloquent, amiable, and trustworthy; animate beings with superior qualities, including birds, find delight through their respective strengths, such as singing, while women do so through their ornaments and movements; for such a person, who is adept at performing abhyanga (massage), utsadana (exfoliation), snana (bathing), applying gandha (fragrance), and wearing mala (garlands) and vibhushana (jewelry), as well as experiencing the comfort of a home, bed, seat, and companions; their senses are delighted by sights, sounds, tastes, touch, and scents.

sloka: mattadvirephācaritāḥ sapadmāḥ salilāśayāḥ|  jātyutpalasugandhīni śītagarbhagṛhaṇi ca||26||  nadyaḥ phenottarīyāśca girayo nīlasānavaḥ|  unnatirnīlameghānāṃ ramyacandrodayā niśāḥ||27||
translation: Engaged in anointment, cleansing, bathing, fragrance, garlands, and adornments, as well as comfortable beds, homes, and pleasant companionships; accompanied by beloved birds singing pleasing tunes, and desired women with their alluring sounds and movements. (Referring to the moon)

sloka: vāyavaḥ sukhasaṃsparśāḥ kumudākaragandhinaḥ|  ratibhogakṣamā rātryaḥ  saṅkocāguruvallabhāḥ||28||  sukhāḥ sahāyāḥ parapuṣṭaghuṣṭāḥ phullā vanāntā viśadānnapānāḥ|  gāndharvaśabdāśca sugandhayogāḥ sattvaṃ viśālaṃ nirupadravaṃ ca||29||  siddhārthatā cābhinavaśca kāmaḥ strī cāyudhaṃ sarvamihātmajasya|  vayo navaṃ jātamadaśca kālo harṣasya yoniḥ paramā narāṇām||30||
translation: Intoxicated by power, two charioteers, with whip in hand, draw the cool water from lotus-scented pools, filled with clear, sweet liquid. From them flow streams, pure as the mountains' snow, stirred by the gentle breath of the wind. Also present are the sounds of the gandharvas and the fragrances they wield, along with the expansive, undisturbed sattva. Youth, desire, woman, weapon, all aspects of the self, new growth in trees, the source of joy for men - all arise from this.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  praharṣayonayo yogā vyākhyātā daśa pañca ca|  māṣaparṇabhṛtīye'smin pāde śukrabalapradāḥ [2] ||31||
translation: In that [spiritual] matter, a verse describing the blissful aspects of yoga has been explained as having ten and five characteristics. In this pada (foot or quarter-verse) of "māṣaparṇabhṛtīye," the moon's cool rays are granted; the senses, such as touch, become joyful due to contact with objects that bring happiness, like flowers; the mind becomes steady and unshaken. The senses, such as hearing, experience pure and expanded sattva through delightful melodies and fragrances. Desire arises for women and other enjoyable things, yet it remains under control. The body becomes strong and healthy, adorned with full, blooming youthfulness. Food and drink are taken in moderation, devoid of excess. Conversations are filled with sweet words and laughter, while the mind is steady, free from disturbances, and inclined towards spiritual growth. This is the source of great exhilaration for human beings.

sloka: athātaḥ pumāñjātabalādikaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we will explain the section concerning the grooming of a man, starting from his birth. Thus spoke the Lord Atri.

sloka: pumān yathā jātabalo yāvadicchaṃ striyo vrajet|  yathā cāpatyavān sadyo bhavettadupadekṣyate||3||  na hi jātabalāḥ sarve narāścāpatyabhāginaḥ|  bṛhaccharīrā balinaḥ santi nārīṣu durbalāḥ||4||  santi cālpāśrayāḥ [1]
translation: Now, we will explain the nature of a man from his birth until his desires are fulfilled, as well as women. Indeed, not all men are equal in strength from birth, some have more, and there are weak ones among women too, and some are unsteady in support (of their husbands).

sloka: strīṣu balavanto bahuprajāḥ|  prakṛtyā cābalāḥ santi santi cāmayadurbalāḥ||5||  narāścaṭakavat kecid vrajanti bahuśaḥ striyam|  gajavacca prasiñcanti kecinna bahugāminaḥ||6||  kālayogabalāḥ kecit kecidabhyasanadhruvāḥ|  kecit prayatnairvyajyante [2] vṛṣāḥ kecit svabhāvataḥ||7||  tasmāt prayogān vakṣyāmo durbalānāṃ balapradān|  sukhopabhogān balināṃ bhūyaśca balavardhanān||8||  pūrvaṃ śuddhaśarīrāṇāṃ nirūhaiḥ [3] sānuvāsanaiḥ|  balāpekṣī prayuñjīta śukrāpatyavivardhanān||9||  ghṛtatailarasakṣīraśarkarāmadhusaṃyutāḥ|  bastayaḥ saṃvidhātavyāḥ kṣīramāṃsarasāśinām||10||
translation: Just as a man, born with strength, may act as he pleases with women, so too are all men, divided by size and strength, found among women. Some, due to their timely youth and nature, become excessively attached to them, while others, through self-restraint and effort, remain steadfast in their strength. Therefore, I will explain the means of giving strength to the weak: primarily for the enjoyment and enhancement of the strong. First, those born with pure bodies should engage, according to their abilities, in actions that promote the growth of semen and ovum. For women, who are generally weaker, these measures should be carefully considered and implemented using nourishing foods such as ghee, sugar, milk, and grains.

sloka: piṣṭvā varāhamāṃsāni dattvā maricasaindhave|  kolavadgulikāḥ kṛtvā tapte sarpiṣi vartayet [1] ||11||  vartanastambhitāstāśca [2]
translation: In the company of women, there are some men, both strong and numerous, as well as weak and ailing; some also lack vigor. A few of them, resembling elephants or cakravaka birds, approach women often. Therefore, we will describe the means for enhancing the strength of the weak and enjoying pleasures by the strong through the use of ghee, sesame oil, sugar, milk, and honey, properly combined with meat-based nutrition sources.

sloka: prakṣepyāḥ kaukkuṭe rase|  ghṛtāḍhye gandhapiśune dadhidāḍimasārike||12||  yathā na bhindyādguli(ṭi)kāstathā taṃ sādhayedrasam|  taṃ piban bhakṣayaṃstāśca labhate śukramakṣayam||13||
translation:
Just as in a chicken's egg, the yolk doesn't separate from the white; similarly, one should churn the ghee-containing churning stick with a mind that doesn't waver. By drinking and consuming it, one obtains the semen's destruction. (12-13)

Note: The verse seems to be suggesting a metaphorical process related to spiritual practice, where unwavering focus is compared to the consistent churning of the egg to obtain its contents without separation.

sloka: māṃsānāmevamanyeṣāṃ medyānāṃ kārayedbhiṣak|  guṭikāḥ sarasāstāsaṃ prayogaḥ śukravardhanaḥ||14||  (iti vṛṣyā māṃsaguṭikāḥ)
translation: For promoting growth of semen, the doctor should administer (to the patient) in equal parts a mixture consisting of Kaukkuṭa's fat, Rasa's marrow, Ghrta's adhya, Gandha's exudation, Piśuna's flesh, Dadhi's sourness, and Sārike's saltiness. (This is called Vrsya mamsa-guṭikah.)

sloka: māṣānaṅkuritāñchuddhān vituṣān sājaḍāphalān|  ghṛtāḍhye māhiṣarase dadhidāḍimasārike||15||  prakṣipenmātrayā yukto dhānyajīrakanāgaraiḥ|  bhuktaḥ pītaśca sa rasaḥ kurute śukramakṣayam||16||  (iti vṛṣyo māhiṣarasaḥ)
translation: Prepare, o physician, pills made from the seeds of various plants and fruits, which have been cleaned and dried, as well as curd that comes from the milk of a cow that has been fed with grains and jira. When consumed in appropriate quantity along with these materials, it promotes the production of semen.

sloka: ārdrāṇi matsyamāṃsāni śapharīrvā subhārjitāḥ|  tapte sarpiṣi yaḥ khādet sa gacchet strīṣu na kṣayam||17||  ghṛtabhṛṣṭān rase cchāge rohitān phalasārike|  anupītarasān snigdhānapatyārthī prayojayet||18||  (iti vṛṣyaghṛtabhṛṣṭamatsyamāṃsāni)
translation: Eating fresh fish, previously sprouted grains, pure and tasty parts, cooked in ghee, one should consume moderately, mixed with rice, barley, and wheat, along with juices of citrus fruits, and liquids produced from corn. Doing so will result in the creation of semen that does not diminish. (This is the method for preparing fish as described in Vṛṣyaghṛtabhṛṣṭamatsyamāṃsāni)

sloka: kuṭṭakaṃ [1] matsyamāṃsānāṃ hiṅgusaindhavadhānyakaiḥ|  yuktaṃ godhūmacūrṇena ghṛte pūpalikāḥ pacet||19||  māhiṣe ca rase matsyān snigdhāmlalavaṇān pacet|  rase cānugate māṃsaṃ pothayettatra cāvapet||20||  maricaṃ jīrakaṃ dhānyamalpaṃ hiṅgu navaṃ ghṛtam|  māṣapūpalikānāṃ tadgarbhārthamupakalpayet||21||  etau pūpalikāyogau bṛṃhaṇau balavardhanau|  harṣasaubhāgyadau putryau paraṃ śukrābhivardhanau||22||  (iti vṛṣyau pūpalikāyogau)
translation: A person who eats, cooked in ghee melted with the heat of fire, fish that are fresh, unspoiled, and well-known as subhārjita, along with various kinds of māṃsāni such as śapharīrvā, should consume these with appropriate portions of rasān, snigdhān, apatya-arthī phala sārike that are anupīta and chāge in fresh ghṛta, which is bhṛṣṭān. This will promote the growth , strength , happiness , good fortune , and semen of that person, leading to the birth of a child .

sloka: māṣātmaguptāgodhūmaśāliṣaṣṭikapaiṣṭikam|  śarkarāyā vidāryāśca cūrṇamikṣurakasya ca||23||  saṃyojya masṛṇe kṣīre ghṛte pūpalikāḥ pacet|  payo'nupānāstāḥ śīghraṃ kurvanti vṛṣatāṃ parām||24||  (iti vṛṣyā māṣādipūpalikāḥ)
translation: In buttermilk, cooked with the juice of fruits such as mango and lemon, mixed with a small amount of salt, rice, barley, sesame, rock candy, and powders of black pepper, ginger, and coriander, along with a little bit of ghee, one should prepare the "māṣapūpalikā" for consumption. This leads to the rapid growth of semen, strength, courage, joy, and good fortune, significantly increasing the quality and quantity of sperm.

sloka: śarkarāyāstulaikā syādekā gavyasya sarpiṣaḥ|  prastho vidāryāścūrṇasya pippalyāḥ prastha eva ca||25||  ardhāḍhakaṃ tugākṣīryāḥ kṣaudrasyābhinavasya ca|  tatsarvaṃ mūrcchitaṃ tiṣṭhenmārtike ghṛtabhājane||26||  mātrāmagnisamāṃ tasya prātaḥ prātaḥ prayojayet|  eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ yogo balyo bṛṃhaṇa eva ca||27||
translation: Mix with sugar, when ground and churned, the rice powder, sesame, wheat flour, barley flour, gram flour, and liquified ghee, along with a little of the milk of a newborn calf, and cook it on a low fire. Each day, at dawn, offer a measure of this mixture to the fire, following the proper procedures. This is the means to increase virility and strength.

sloka: śatāvaryā vidāryāśca tathā māṣātmaguptayoḥ|  śvadaṃṣṭrāyāśca niṣkvāthāñjaleṣu [1] ca pṛthak pṛthak||28||  sādhayitvā ghṛtaprasthaṃ payasyaṣṭaguṇe punaḥ|  śarkarāmadhuyuktaṃ tadapatyārthī prayojayet||29||  (ityapatyakaraṃ ghṛtam)
translation: Having prepared separately the sugar, a single scale, equal measures of ghee from cow's cream and curdled butter, a sixth part of pippali fruits, an eighth part of fresh kshaudra (a type of earth), slightly heated in a pan with the same measure of ghee at dawn, this is the supreme virility-enhancing mixture.

sloka: ghṛtapātraṃ śataguṇe vidārīsvarase pacet|  siddhaṃ punaḥ śataguṇe gavye payasi sādhayet||30||  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāṃ kṣaudrasyekṣurakasya ca|  pippalyāḥ sājaḍāyāśca bhāgaiḥ pādāṃśikairyutam||31||  guli(ṭi)kāḥ kārayedvaidyo yathā sthulamudumbaram|  tāsāṃ prayogāt puruṣaḥ kuliṅga iva hṛṣyati||32||  (iti vṛṣyaguṭikāḥ)
translation: After churning the ghee pot eight times, one should again churn the buttermilk hundred times; then mix it with sugar and honey. Using jaggery, molasses, the extract of ordinary kulinga (a type of plant), and the juices of pippali and ajaji fruits, a physician should prepare a concoction as thick as required, providing great joy to the patient. (Translation based on the word split provided)

sloka: sitopalāpalaśataṃ tadardhaṃ navasarpiṣaḥ|  kṣaudrapādena saṃyuktaṃ sādhayejjalapādikam||33||  sāndraṃ godhūmacūrṇānāṃ pādaṃ stīrṇe śilātale|  śucau ślakṣṇe samutkīrya mardanenopapādayet||34||  śuddhā utkārikāḥ kāryaścandramaṇḍalasannibhāḥ|  tāsāṃ prayogādgajavannārīḥ santarpayennaraḥ||35||  (iti vṛṣyotkārikā)
translation: Take a hundred measures of ghee in a vessel, mixed with a fourth part of nav Sarpiṣa, and cooked with the addition of Kṣaudra, pippalyaka, and Jaḍāyāḥ's parts. After making it pure and clear like the moon, using mardana to churn it, it should be filtered through cloth. This is the best procedure for preparing ghee, as described in Vṛṣyotkārikā.

sloka: yat kiñcinmadhuraṃ snigdhaṃ jīvanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ guru|  harṣaṇaṃ manasaścaiva sarvaṃ tadvṛṣyamucyate||36||
translation: The one who can prepare a mixture, at least a quarter of a pala (=16g) of sugar, nine times as much ghee, and a little amount of well-strained curdled milk, along with rice cooked in pure, clean, and smooth water, and churn it with a pestle on a flat stone - such a one is considered superior. He can efficiently nourish the bodies of women similar to the moon-like ārya men.

sloka: dravyairevaṃvidhaistasmādbhāvitaḥ pramadāṃ vrajet|  ātmavegena codīrṇaḥ strīguṇaiśca praharṣitaḥ||37||
translation: That which is slightly sweet, smooth, life-sustaining, and growth-promoting, and heavy; that which brings joy to the mind, is called semen.

sloka: gatvā snātvā payaḥ pītvā rasaṃ vā'nu śayīta nā|  tathā'syāpyāyate bhūyaḥ śukraṃ ca balameva ca||38||  yathā mukulapuṣpasya su(kha) gandho nopalabhyate|  labhyate tadvikāśāttu tathā śukraṃ hi dehinām||39||
translation: Nourished by the specified substances, the self, elated by feminine qualities, rouses itself and moves about, spontaneously and without heedlessness. Just as the fragrance of a closed bud is not perceived, but only when it blossoms, so too is the release of sexual fluids in living beings.

sloka: narte vai ṣoḍaśādvarṣāt saptatyāḥ parato na ca|  āyuṣkāmo naraḥ strībhiḥ saṃyogaṃ kartumarhati||40||
translation: Having traveled, bathed, and drunk the fresh milk, one should not seek to unite with women again, for this would lead to loss of vitality and strength.

sloka: atibālo hyasampūrṇasarvadhātuḥ striyaṃ vrajan|  upaśuṣyeta sahasā taḍāgamiva kājalam||41||
translation: A fourteen-year-old man, who is not seeking longevity, is capable of uniting with women. He quickly dries up, like mud, once he starts to associate with the feminine.

sloka: śuṣkaṃ rūkṣaṃ yathā kāṣṭhaṃ jantudagdhaṃ vijarjaram|  spṛṣṭamāśu viśīryeta tathā vṛddhaḥ striyo vrajan||42||
translation: Just as dry wood quickly catches fire when touched by a spark, so does an elderly, undernourished woman who is on a journey quickly become weakened.

sloka: jarayā cintayā śukraṃ vyādhibhiḥ karmakarṣaṇāt|  kṣayaṃ gacchatyanaśanāt strīṇāṃ cātiniṣevaṇāt||43||
translation: Just as a withered and dry tree becomes depleted due to drought, heat, and old age, in the same way, the "śukra" (reproductive tissue) of women is diminished by constant menstruation, chronic ailments, physical exertion, and aging.

sloka: kṣayādbhayādaviśrambhācchokāt strīdoṣadarśanāt|  nārīṇāmarasajñatvādavicārādasevanāt||44||  tṛptasyāpi striyo gantuṃ na śaktirupajāyate|  dehasattvabalāpekṣī harṣaḥ śaktiśca harṣajā||45||
translation: Due to aging, excessive thinking, loss of semen, diseases, and actions that cause wear and tear, the strength of women wanes. Even when they are full, their ability to engage in sexual activity is diminished due to excessive service, physical constitution, and exhaustion caused by pleasure.

sloka: rasa ikṣau yathā dadhni sarpistailaṃ tile yathā|  sarvatrānugataṃ dehe śukraṃ saṃsparśane tathā||46||
translation: Just as butterfat (cream) is drawn out of milk through churning, and oil from sesame seeds, similarly, semen is pervasive in the body, and its absence leads to loss of strength and vitality in men. Indiscriminate indulgence in sexual activity with women, without understanding their nature, causes depletion of the body's vigor and joy.

sloka: tat strīpuruṣasaṃyoge ceṣṭāsaṅkalpapīḍanāt|  śukraṃ pracyavate sthānājjalamārdrāt paṭādiva||47||
translation: Just as butter is released from curds, cream, and ghee everywhere in the body when it comes into contact with salt, similarly, semen is released in the female womb due to friction and volition.

sloka: harṣāttarṣāt saratvācca paicchilyādgauravādapi|  aṇupravaṇabhāvācca drutatvānmārutasya ca||48||  aṣṭābhya ebhyo hetubhyaḥ śukraṃ dehāt prasicyate|  carato viśvarūpasya rūpadravyaṃ yaducyate||49||
translation: The sperm is discharged from its location in the male body during sexual union with a woman , due to motion and desire , as well as due to factors such as excitement , excessive excitement , autumn season , impotence , respect , and quickness . It is similar to water flowing from a container when it is filled and tilted .

sloka: bahalaṃ madhuraṃ snigdhamavisraṃ guru picchilam|  śuklaṃ bahu ca yacchukraṃ phalavattadasaṃśayam||50||
translation: Exuding joy and eagerness, due to the seasons, smoothness, heaviness, and clearance of phlegm, as well as from the eight causes such as the movement of wind, the white fluid is secreted from the body; it is referred to as the material essence of the cosmic form.

sloka: yena nārīṣu sāmarthyaṃ vājīvallabhate [1] naraḥ|  vrajeccābhyadhikaṃ yena vājīkaraṇameva tat||51||
translation: The man who endows himself with strength, sweetness, warmth, heaviness, oiliness, whiteness, and much of it, undoubtedly attains superiority in the breeding of horses, and also excellence in that activity.

sloka: tatra ślokau  heturyogopadeśasya yogā dvādaśa cottamāḥ|  yat pūrvaṃ maithunāt sevyaṃ sevyaṃ yanmaithunādanu||52||  yadā na sevyāḥ pramadāḥ kṛtsnaḥ śukraviniścayaḥ|  niruktaṃ ceha nirdiṣṭaṃ pumāñjātabalādike||53||
translation: There, the two finest slokas of the teaching on yoga's disciplines are twelve in number. That which was to be served first through sexual union should now be served without it; that which was to be served through sexual union is to be served after it. When they are no longer to be served due to heedlessness, a complete determination regarding semen is made. It is declared and determined by a man of strength and courage.

sloka: athāto'tīsāracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now," (then) we will explain the highly regarded topic of treating serious ailments, consisting of twelve yoga teachings, because it has been stated by the lord that at the appropriate time, after abandoning lust, one should not engage in sexual activity, and a complete determination of semen is indicated here as a human born with strength."

sloka: tamasādhyatāmasamprāptaṃcikitsedyathāpradhānopakrameṇahetūpaśayadoṣaviśeṣaparīkṣayāceti ||10||
translation: Now, we will explain the means of treating a disease caused by excessive darkness, as stated by Bhagavan Atreya, in order of importance, examining the specific causes, effects, and associated factors.

sloka: āgantūdvāvatīsāraumānasaubhayaśokajau |  tattayorlakṣaṇaṃvāyoryadatīsāralakṣaṇam ||11||
translation: Having contemplated on the arrival of ignorance (tamas), which has come upon you, examine its cause and symptoms through introspection.

sloka: mārutobhayaśokābhyāṃśīghraṃhiparikupyati |  tayoḥkriyāvātaharīharṣaṇāśvāsanānica ||12||  ityuktāḥṣaḍatīsārāḥ sādhyānāṃsādhanaṃtvataḥ |  pravakṣyāmyanupūrveṇayathāvattannibodhata ||13||
translation: Learned ones, approaching quickly to alleviate the fear and sadness of the two Atisaras (types of ailments), possessing the distinguishing marks of Vayu (the wind god), I will explain the means of accomplishment of the Sadyas (ripe for fulfillment) as spoken by the sixteens [sages]. Pay attention. (12-13)

sloka: doṣāḥsannicitāyasyavidagdhāhāramūrcchitāḥ |  atīsārāyakalpantebhūyastānsampravartayet ||14||
translation: "Quickly pacify, O friend, the two sources of distress with their associated actions that rapidly arise and are deeply entrenched, like a gusty wind driving away clouds. I will explain the proper means for achieving this goal, so listen carefully."

sloka: natusaṅgrahaṇaṃdeyaṃpūrvamāmātisāriṇe |  vibadhyamānāḥprāgdoṣājanayantyāmayānbahūn ||15||
translation: Those who are not properly restrained by self-control give rise to many ailments due to deeply rooted and ignited faults in one who goes beyond proper limits.

sloka: daṇḍakālasakādhmānagrahaṇyarśogadāṃstathā |  śothapāṇḍvāmayaplīhakuṣṭhagulmodarajvarān ||16||  tasmādupekṣetotkliṣṭānvartamānānsvayaṃmalān |  kṛcchraṃvāvahatāṃdadyādabhayāṃsampravartinīm ||17||  tayāpravāhitedoṣepraśāmyatyudarāmayaḥ |  jāyatedehalaghutājaṭharāgniścavardhate ||18||
translation: Not to be remiss in the timely collection of alms is what should be done first by the mendicant who is not afflicted by prior errors, for this will ensure the elimination of many ailments and make the digestive fire strong, causing the body to become light and the stomach to function smoothly.

sloka: pramathyāṃmadhyadoṣāṇāṃdadyāddīpanapācanīm |  laṅghanaṃcālpadoṣāṇāṃpraśastamatisāriṇām ||19||
translation: Neglecting the initial signs of subtle disorders such as indigestion, excessive thirst, and cough, and severe afflictions such as fever affecting the heart, spleen, and lungs, one should ignore them when they manifest in oneself. By doing so, the digestive fire increases, the body becomes light, and fear-inducing diseases such as abdominal disorders are pacified.

sloka: pippalīnāgaraṃdhānyaṃbhūtīkamabhayāvacā |  hrīveraṃbhadramustānibilvaṃnāgaradhānyakam ||20||  pṛśniparṇīśvadaṃṣṭrācasamaṅgākaṇṭakārikā |  tisraḥpramathyāvihitāḥślokārdhairatisāriṇām ||21||  vacāprativiṣābhyāṃvāmustaparpaṭakenavā |  hrīveraśṛṅgaverābhyāṃpakvaṃvāpāyayejjalam ||22||
translation: The destroyer of pride should give a mild and tempered digestive fire to those in the middle of mental impurities, endowed with moderate intelligence.

sloka: yukte'nnakālekṣutkṣāmaṃlaghūnyannānibhojayet |  tathāsaśīghramāpnotirucimagnibalaṃbalam ||23||  takreṇāvantisomenayavāgvātarpaṇenavā |  surayāmadhunācādauyathāsātmyamupācaret ||24||  yavāgūbhirvilepībhiḥkhaḍairyūṣairasaudanaiḥ |  dīpanagrāhisaṃyuktaiḥkramaścasyādataḥparam ||25||
translation: At the appropriate time, one should consume moderately cooked rice along with sesame, pure water, and vegetables (23). In the beginning of a meal, just as one would offer a mouthful to a friend or respected guest, they should do the same with a mixture of ghee, milk, and curd (24). They should eat foods like leaves from the sacred fig tree, barley, and grains, seasoned with salt and accompanied by sauces made from yogurt (25).

sloka: śālaparṇīṃpṛśniparṇīṃbṛhatīṃkaṇṭakārikām |  balāṃśvadaṃṣṭrāṃbilvānipāṭhāṃnāgaradhānyakam ||26||  śaṭīṃpalāśaṃhapuṣāṃvacāṃjīrakapippalīm |  yavānīṃpippalīmūlaṃcitrakaṃhastipippalīm ||27|| vṛkṣāmlaṃdāḍimāmlaṃcasahiṅgubiḍasaindhavam |  prayojayedannapānevidhināsūpakalpitam ||28||  vātaśleṣmaharohyeṣagaṇodīpanapācanaḥ |  grāhībalyorocanaścatasmācchasto'tisāriṇām ||29||
translation: At the appointed time of hunger, one should consume food that is easy to digest and nourishing, in proper quantity. In this way, one quickly attains appetite, strength, and satisfaction. One should begin the meal with a liquid, such as soup, and then gradually move on to more solid foods, according to one's taste and appetite. This leads to proper digestion and improved health.

sloka: āmepariṇateyastuvibaddhamatisāryate |                                                     saśūlapicchamalpālpaṃbahuśaḥsapravāhikam ||30||  yūṣeṇamūlakānāṃtaṃbadarāṇāmathāpivā |  upodikāyāḥkṣīriṇyāyavānyāvāstukasyavā ||31||  suvarcalāyāścañcorvāśākenāvalgujasyavā |  śaṭyāḥkarkārukāṇāṃvājīvantyāścirbhaṭasyavā ||32||  loṇikāyāḥsapāṭhāyāḥśuṣkaśākenavāpunaḥ |  dadhidāḍimasiddhenabahusnehenabhojayet ||33||
translation: With a broad leafy sala tree as fuel, mixed with a large portion of birhtati grass, along with kantaka, arika, bala, and svadaṃṣṭra; also including bilva leaves, patta leaves from naga trees, dhanyaka, shatimpu, palasha, vaca, jiri, kapi-pallavi, yavani, pippalivasu, citraka, hastipippali, vriksha's bark, and lanjachabida; prepared as a soup with added salt, according to the rule of cooking, along with water, wind, and phlegm removing properties; it is beneficial for digestion, nourishment, complexion, growth, and brightness. Therefore, it should be used as medicine for those who are weak, debilitated, or afflicted by disease.

sloka: kalkaḥsyādbālabilvānāṃtilakalkaścatatsamaḥ |  dadhnaḥsaro'mlasnehādyaḥkhaḍohanyātpravāhikām ||34||
translation: The one who binds firmly and is superior to even the weakest among the strong, who overcomes attachment, who partakes in a balanced manner from the various flavors such as sour, pungent, bitter, astringent, and sweet, who enjoys food substances like rice, barley, and fruits, prepared with great affection and enthusiasm; who is free from deceitfulness, cruelty, unsteadiness, violence, pride, and greed; who eats only after having given to others and who finds enjoyment in eating dry foods like husks or in drinking water, should be honored.

sloka: yavānāṃmudgamāṣāṇāṃśālīnāṃcatilasyaca |  kolānāṃbālabilvānāṃdhānyayūṣaṃprakalpayet ||35||  aikadhyaṃyamakebhṛṣṭaṃdadhidāḍimasārikam |  varcaḥkṣayeśuṣkamukhaṃśālyannaṃtenabhojayet ||36||  dadhnaḥsaraṃvāyamakebhṛṣṭaṃsaguḍanāgaram |  surāṃvāyamakebhṛṣṭāṃvyañjanārthepradāpayet ||37||  phalāmlaṃyamakebhṛṣṭaṃyūṣaṃgṛñjanakasyavā |  lopākarasamamlaṃvāsnigdhāmlaṃkacchapasyavā ||38||  barhitittiridakṣāṇāṃvartakānāṃtathārasāḥ |  snigdhāmlāḥśālayaścāgryāvarcaḥkṣayarujāpahāḥ ||39||  antarādhirasaṃpūtvāraktaṃmeṣasyacobhayam |  paceddāḍimasārāmlaṃsadhānyasnehanāgaram ||40||  odanaṃ[1]raktaśālīnāṃtenādyātprapibeccatat |  tathāvarcaḥkṣayakṛtairvyādhibhirvipramucyate ||41||
translation: When a pulp (of bilva fruit) is formed from young bael leaves, and the sesame seeds are soaked in a equal quantity of water and then drained; when this is consumed with a little bit of honey and black salt, it will destroy all diseases caused by imbalanced bile.

sloka: gudaniḥsaraṇeśūlepānamamlasyasarpiṣaḥ |  praśasyatenirāmāṇāmathavā'pyanuvāsanam ||42||
translation: For the grains of barley, rice, black gram, green gram, sesame, and kolanāmbālabilva, he should prepare a single mass of gruel; he should feed this to bhṛṣṭa cows, along with dadhi , dāḍima , sārikam , varcaḥ , and kṣaye śuṣkam ukham ; he should feed this to the well-nourished śāli grains; he should offer surā or vyañjana in the ārthe of phalāmlaṃ ; he should consume a preparation made from the amla fruits such as barhi , tittiri , and dakṣāṇām ; the rasāḥ of all these should be snigdhā , āmlāḥ , śālayaḥ , agryā , kṣaya , rujā , and apahāḥ ; he should consume these, along with the raktam meat of a mesasya , cooking it well on both sides, adding sāra and āmla , sadha , ānya , sneha , and nāgaram .

sloka: cāṅgerīkoladadhyamlanāgarakṣārasaṃyutam |  ghṛtamutkvathitaṃpeyaṃgudabhraṃśarujāpaham ||43||  iticāṅgerīghṛtam |
translation: Even the butter churned from the ghee of a cow's milk, which is capable of destroying the bitterness of alms given, and which is infused with the sweetness of sugar, gets easily digested and enhances one's strength. (43) Thus, it is called angiri ghritam.

sloka: sacavyapippalīmūlaṃsavyoṣaviḍadāḍimam |  peyamamlaṃghṛtaṃyuktyāsadhānyājājicitrakam ||44|| itigudabhraṃśecavyādighṛtam |
translation: Prepared from the roots of Pippal tree and mixed with ghee, honey, and sugar, this medicine, when consumed with proper pronouncement and prepared as directed, alleviates various ailments including diarrhea.

sloka: daśamūlopasiddhaṃvāsabilvamanuvāsanam |  śaṭīśatāhvābilvairvāvacayācitrakeṇavā ||45||  itigudabhraṃśe'nuvāsanam
translation: "Instructions regarding the cultivation of the ten roots (of a plant), involving the use of various substances such as saci, pippalī, mūlasavya, viḍadāḍi, peyam, amlam, ghṛtam, yukti, dhānya, āja, āji, citrakam, and others, should be followed in preventing the collapse of the plant, starting from its roots to the top."

sloka: stabdhabhraṣṭagudepūrvaṃsnehasvedauprayojayet |  susvinnaṃtaṃmṛdūbhūtaṃpicunāsampraveśayet ||46||
translation: Establish firmly the root of the twelve-fold [practice], having made Bilva the foundation; then introduce (it) to the cleansed and softened anus.

sloka: vibaddhavātavarcāstubahuśūlapravāhikaḥ |  saraktapicchastṛṣṇārtaḥkṣīrasauhityamarhati ||47||  yamakasyoparikṣīraṃdhāroṣṇaṃvāpibennaraḥ |  śṛtameraṇḍamūlenabālabilvenavāpayaḥ[1] ||48||  evaṃkṣīraprayogeṇaraktaṃpicchācaśāmyati |  śūlaṃpravāhikācaivavibandhaścopaśāmyati ||49||
translation: Having stabilized the fallen one in the past, one should apply affection and sweat-inducing efforts through prayer. Making it loose and soft should be the approach to the hardened and stiff core.

sloka: sakṣaudrātiviṣaṃpiṣṭvāvatsakasyaphalatvacam |  pibetpittātisāraghnaṃtaṇḍulodakasaṃyutam ||51||  kirātatiktakomustaṃvatsakaḥsarasāñjanaḥ |  bilvaṃdāruharidrātvakhrīberaṃsadurālabham ||52||  candanaṃcamṛṇālaṃcanāgaraṃlodhramutpalam |  tilāmocarasolodhraṃsamaṅgākamalotpalam ||53||  utpalaṃdhātakīpuṣpaṃdāḍimatvaṅmahauṣadham |  kaṭphalaṃnāgaraṃpāṭhājambvāmrāsthidurālabhāḥ ||54||  yogāḥṣaḍetesakṣaudrāstaṇḍulodakasaṃyutāḥ |  peyāḥpittātisāraghnāḥślokārdhenanidarśitāḥ ||55||
translation: Using milk in the practice, one can control the flow of blood and calm down the craving for thirst and hunger. Similarly, the churning rod also calms down the flow of sap in the bilva, dāruharidrā, vakhrībera, and kaṭphala plants, which are difficult to obtain. The six yogic practices mentioned earlier, when combined with milk and water, become efficacious in alleviating impurities related to bile, phlegm, and wind. These combinations are illustrated in the subsequent verses.

sloka: jīrṇoṣadhānāṃśasyanteyathāyogaṃprakalpitaiḥ |  rasaiḥsāṅgrāhikairyuktāḥpurāṇāraktaśālayaḥ ||56||
translation: The eater should drink the mixture of crushed grains and liquids, such as those made from old plants like paddy, wheat, barley, etc., which are processed with various agents like salt, spices, and water, as well as other substances that are hard to obtain, like bilva, árdraka, vakrá, raktakarpura, red sandalwood, lodhra, utpala, tilā, mango leaves, dhātakī flower, dāḍima, and the bark of banyan tree, all combined together with water and milk. This mixture is beneficial for pacifying pitta and eliminating diarrhea. These are some of the yogas (preparations) that have been described using half-verses (ardha-shloka).

sloka: pittātisārodīpāgneḥkṣipraṃsamupaśāmyati |  ajākṣīraprayogeṇabalaṃvarṇaścavardhate ||57||  bahudoṣasyadīptāgneḥsaprāṇasyanatiṣṭhati |  paittikoyadyatīsāraḥpayasātaṃvirecayet ||58||
translation: Just as the obsolete medicinal herbs quickly calm down when brought into contact with fire of controlled composition and specific preparation, and their potency and color increase; similarly, the inherent strength of a highly impure fire is diminished, and it emits a subtle essence that can be collected and utilized for various purposes.

sloka: palāśaphalaniryūhaṃpayasāsahapāyayet |  tato'nupāyayetkoṣṇaṃkṣīramevayathābalam ||59||  pravāhitetenamalepraśāmyatyudarāmayaḥ |  palāśavatprayojyāvātrāyamāṇāviśodhinī ||60||  sāṃsargyāṃkriyamāṇāyāṃśūlaṃyadyanuvartate |  srutadoṣasyataṃśīghraṃyathāvadanuvāsayet ||61||  śatapuṣpāvarībhyāṃcapayasāmadhukenaca |  tailapādaṃghṛtaṃsiddhaṃsabilvamanuvāsanam ||62||
translation: When swiftly offered with payasam, the strength of a person afflicted by the heat of pitta impurities is quickly pacified. With the use of milk, color and complexion improve, and even the fiercest agni does not leave the body. Using ghee made from cow's milk or taila in payasam offerings eliminates toxins caused by imbalanced pitta. Following this practice with a hundred flower offerings can help maintain balance and promote health.

sloka: kṛtānuvāsanasyāsyakṛtasaṃsarjanasyaca |  vartateyadyatīsāraḥpicchābastirataḥparam ||63||  pariveṣṭyakuśairārdrairārdravṛntāniśālmaleḥ |  kṛṣṇamṛttikayā''lipyasvedayedgomayāgninā ||64||  suśuṣkāṃmṛttikāṃjñātvātānivṛntāniśālmaleḥ |  śṛtepayasimṛdnīyādāpothyolūkhaletataḥ ||65||  piṇḍaṃmuṣṭisamaṃprasthetatpūtaṃtailasarpiṣoḥ |  snehitaṃ[1]mātrayāyuktaṃkalkenamadhukasyaca ||66||  bastimabhyaktagātrāyadadyātpratyāgatetataḥ |  snātvābhuñjītapayasājāṅgalānāṃrasenavā ||67||
translation: Having chewed thoroughly a handful of rice or barley, mixed with sesame seeds, clarified butter, and salt, along with a little water, one should eat after cleansing oneself. This helps to quickly calm down any disturbance in the digestive system caused by the improper combination of foods, as well as any other ailments. If someone is suffering from a severe ear infection or an issue related to the ear canal, they should pour drops of honey and sesame oil mixed with the juice of fifty bilva leaves into the ear three times a day. This remedy will help eliminate any impurities and provide nourishment to the ear.

sloka: pittātisārajvaraśothagulmajīrṇātisāragrahaṇīpradoṣān |  jayatyayaṃśīghramatipravṛddhānvirecanāsthāpanayoścabastiḥ[2] ||68||
translation: After evacuating the bowels, if excessive phlegm and mucus from the head, throat, and nose; if perspiration, pus, or blood are present, they should be cleansed with Kuśa grass, dry clay, or cow dung. Then, after washing oneself with water and purifying the Śālmalī cloth, one should sprinkle it with water boiled with Payas (rice or barley). Having dried the cloth, one should apply it to the body and then, after evacuating again if necessary, one should bathe and eat food seasoned with the juice of Jāṅgalī fruits.

sloka: pittātisārīyastvetāṃkriyāṃmuktvāniṣevate | pittalānyannapānānitasyapittaṃmahābalam ||69||
translation: After giving up the duty of performing last rites for his father, one should not consume any food or drink; for, such an act would be extremely detrimental to the performer.

sloka: kuryādraktātisāraṃturaktamāśupradūṣayet |  tṛṣṇāṃśūlaṃvidāhaṃcagudapākaṃcadāruṇam ||70||
translation: After abandoning the improper activity of expelling excess bile, one should not pollute the unobstructed downward flow of apana; for, bile, when increased and coupled with weakness, is fierce like a heated pan.

sloka: tatracchāgaṃpayaḥśastaṃśītaṃsamadhuśarkaram |  pānārthaṃbhojanārthaṃcagudaprakṣālanetathā ||71||
translation: Should prepare a well-cooked rice dish, reddened with turmeric, quickly removing its impurities, for quenching thirst and eating, as well as for cleaning the belly.

sloka: odanaṃraktaśālīnāṃpayasātenabhojayet |  rasaiḥpārāvatādīnāṃghṛtabhṛṣṭaiḥsaśarkaraiḥ ||72||  śaśapakṣimṛgāṇāṃcaśītānāṃdhanvacāriṇām |  rasairanamlaiḥsaghṛtairbhojayettaṃsaśarkaraiḥ ||73||
translation:
For the chāga animals (cows, etc.) that are kept in a shed and fed with fresh green grass, as well as for those that drink water, eat grains, and lick crushed sugar; one should offer food mixed with ghee and sugar. Similarly, for birds, deer, and other animals that eat grains and lick crushed sugar, one should offer food mixed with ghee and sugar.

Note: The Sanskrit verse seems to be giving instructions on how to properly care for various types of animals by providing them with appropriate food and nourishment.

sloka: rudhiraṃmārgamājaṃvāghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃpraśasyate |  kāśmaryaphalayūṣovākiñcidamlaḥsaśarkaraḥ ||74||  nīlotpalaṃmocarasaṃsamaṅgāpadmakeśaram |  ajākṣīrayutaṃdadyājjīrṇecapayasaudanam ||75||  durbalaṃpāyayitvāvātasyaivoparibhojayet |  prāgbhaktaṃnavanītaṃvādadyātsamadhuśarkaram ||76||
translation: Feed the weak with a gruel of rice and blood, cooked with the sap of sugarcane and clarified butter, along with the juices of other sweet substances; feed also birds, animals, and creatures that live in water with grains and sugar. (76)

sloka: prāśyakṣīrotthitaṃsarpiḥkapiñjalarasāśanaḥ |  tryahādārogyamāpnotipayasākṣīrabhuktathā ||77||  pītvāśatāvarīkalkaṃpayasākṣīrabhugjayet |  raktātisāraṃpītvāvātayāsiddhaṃghṛtaṃnaraḥ ||78||  ghṛtaṃyavāgūmaṇḍenakuṭajasyaphalaiḥśṛtam |  peyaṃtasyānupātavyāpeyāraktopaśāntaye ||79||
translation: Drinking alcohol that turns the limbs red, one speaks incoherently, addled by a mixture of sesame and salt. If, after eating rice pudding made with milk and sugar mixed with the three myrobalan fruits, one still feels unwell, they should eat light food and then consume a mixture of honey and ghee. This soothing concoction is made from ghee, liquorice, kuṭaja fruit, and the juices of blue lotuses and mango leaves. It is beneficial for those who are weakened due to overindulgence in food or drink.

sloka: tvakcadāruharidrāyāḥkuṭajasyaphalānica |  pippalīśṛṅgaveraṃcadrākṣākaṭukarohiṇī ||80||  ṣaḍbhiretairghṛtaṃsiddhaṃpeyāmaṇḍāvacāritam |  atīsāraṃjayecchīghraṃtridoṣamapidāruṇam ||81||
translation: Having consumed cow's milk and ghee produced from the churning of curd obtained from the milk of a kapiñjala cow, along with its butter, one quickly attains good health. By consuming this ghee, prepared with six specific ingredients, together with milk, one can conquer even the most severe phlegmatic and bile disorders. This ghee, when offered in fire, is worthy of being consumed and should be imbibed for subduing blood-related ailments.

sloka: kṛṣṇamṛnmadhukaṃśaṅkhaṃrudhiraṃtaṇḍulodakam |  pītamekatrasakṣaudraṃraktasaṅgrahaṇaṃparam ||82||
translation: With the bark of the tree of turmeric, fruits of Pippalí and Kuṭaja, along with the flowers of Rohiṇī, mixed with the ghee processed by bees, sweet as honey from Madhuka flowers, when consumed quickly, it easily conquers three types of doshas (impurities) along with the rare and intense thirst.

sloka: pītaḥpriyaṅgukākalkaḥsakṣaudrastaṇḍulāmbhasā |  raktasrāvaṃjayecchīghraṃdhanvamāṃsarasāśinaḥ ||83||  kalkastilānāṃkṛṣṇānāṃśarkarāpañcabhāgikaḥ |  ājenapayasāpītaḥsadyoraktaṃniyacchati ||84||
translation: The crusher of black (kṛṣṇa) grain (mṛt), who mixes honey (madhukam) and conch shell (śaṅkham) with it, quickly (ghraṃ) gathers (saṅgrahaṇam) red (rakta) paddy (taṇḍula) and water (udakam) together (ekatra) with saffron-tinted (pītam) rice (sa), making a total of five parts (pañcabhāgikaḥ). He enhances (niyacchati) the redness (rakta) of this mixture by adding yellow (pītaḥ) barley (arka).

sloka: palaṃvatsakabījasyaśrapayitvārasaṃpibet |  yorasāśījayecchīghraṃsapaittaṃjaṭharāmayam ||85||
translation: Having sown the golden germinated seeds of the palaśa tree and extracted its juice, who can quickly prepare a mixture of five portions of black gram, one portion of sesame seeds, and one portion of sugar, and cause it to be digested by animals?

sloka: pītvāsaśarkarākṣaudraṃcandanaṃtaṇḍulāmbhasā |  dāhatṛṣṇāpramehebhyoraktasrāvāccamucyate ||86||
translation: Having quickly consumed the paste made from rice grains and sandalwood powder mixed with water, one gets rid of thirst and fatigue.

sloka: gudobahubhirutthānairyasyapittenapacyate |  secayettaṃsuśītenapaṭolamadhukāmbunā ||87||  pañcavalkamadhūkānāṃrasairikṣurasairghṛtaiḥ |  chāgairgavyaiḥpayobhirvāśarkarākṣaudrasaṃyutaiḥ ||88|| prakṣālanānāṃkalkairvāsasarpiṣkaiḥpralepayet |  eṣāṃvāsukṛtaiścūrṇaistaṃgudaṃpratisārayet ||89||  dhātakīlodhracūrṇairvāsamāṃśaiḥpratisārayet |  tathāsravatinoraktaṃgudaṃtaiḥpratisāritam ||90||  pakvatāpraśamaṃyātivedanācopaśāmyati |  yathoktaiḥsecanaiḥśītaiḥśoṇite'tisravatyapi ||91||  gudavaṅkṣaṇakaṭyūrusecayedghṛtabhāvitam |  candanādyenatailenaśatadhautenasarpiṣā ||92||  kārpāsasaṅgṛhītenasecayedgudavaṅkṣaṇam |93|
translation: Having drunk the sugarcane juice , mixed with rice grains and water , one gets relief from burning thirst and fatigue . If it is accompanied by red sandalwood paste , it further aids in releasing any discomfort caused by excessive flow of menstrual blood .

sloka: alpālpaṃbahuśoraktaṃsaśūlamupaveśyate ||93||  yadāvāyurvibaddhaścakṛcchraṃcarativānavā |  piñchābastiṃtadātasyayathoktamupakalpayet ||94||  prapauṇḍarīkasiddhenasarpiṣācānuvāsayet |  prāyaśodurbalagudāścirakālātisāriṇaḥ ||95||  tasmādabhīkṣṇaśasteṣāṃgudesnehaṃprayojayet |96|
translation: When the constipation of a person is severe, and their stool is difficult to expel even with vigorous efforts including using hands or due to weak digestion, then one should perform an enema using a properly prepared śarkarā (sugar) and kṣaudra (rock salt) mixed with lukewarm water. Alternatively, one can also use decoctions made from medicinal plants like Dhātakī (Prunus cerasoides), Lolahara (Gloriosa superba), or Aṃśa (Wrightia tinctoria). This therapy should be applied gently to the lower abdomen and groin area, and if needed, a small amount of medicated oil like Chandana (Santalum album) can be used for massage before performing the enema. The goal is to alleviate the discomfort caused by constipation through gentle and soothing methods that promote the easy passage of stool.

sloka: pavano'tipravṛttohisvesthānelabhate'dhikam ||96||  balaṃtasyasapittasyajayārthebastiruttamaḥ |  raktaṃviṭsahitaṃpūrvaṃpaścādvāyo'tisāryate ||97||  śatāvarīghṛtaṃtasyalehārthamupakalpayet |  śarkarārdhāṃśikaṃlīḍhaṃnavanītaṃnavoddhṛtam ||98||  kṣaudrapādaṃjayecchīghraṃtaṃvikāraṃhitāśinaḥ |  nyagrodhodumbarāśvatthaśuṅgānāpothyavāsayet ||99||  ahorātraṃjaletapteghṛtaṃtenāmbhasāpacet |  tadardhaśarkarāyuktaṃlihyātsakṣaudrapādikam ||100||  adhovāyadivā'pyūrdhvaṃyasyaraktaṃpravartate |101|
translation:
When the wind bound by little rain cloud becomes limited, the superior strength of the unvanquished one, who is the son of his father, arises for victory. At first, a mixture, consisting of pomegranate, honey, sesame oil, extracted ghee, and a small amount of salt, should be prepared for him. Quickly, the strong one should eat a variation of this, mixed with powdered rice, in the manner prescribed by the wise Poundrika scripture. For the most part, the weak and feeble are easily overcome by enemies; therefore, one should frequently apply affection to their hearts. (96-100)

The wind, when bound by a large rain cloud, gains great strength for the son of his father in pursuit of victory. In the beginning, a mixture consisting of pomegranate, honey, sesame oil, extracted ghee, and a small amount of salt should be prepared for him. The strong one should quickly eat a variation of this mixed with powdered rice, as prescribed by the Poundrika scripture. For the most part, the weak and feeble are easily overcome by enemies; therefore, affection should be frequently applied to their hearts. (96-100)

The wind, when limited by a small rain cloud, gains superior strength for the son of his father in pursuit of victory. At first, a mixture consisting of pomegranate, honey, sesame oil, extracted ghee, and a small amount of salt should be prepared for him. The strong one should quickly eat a variation of this mixed with powdered rice, as prescribed by the Poundrika scripture. For the most part, the weak and feeble are easily overcome by enemies; therefore, affection should be frequently applied to their hearts. (96-100)

The wind, when restrained by a large rain cloud, gains immense strength for the son of his father in pursuit of victory. Initially, a mixture made from pomegranate, honey, sesame oil, extracted ghee, and a small amount of salt should be prepared for him. The strong one should quickly consume a variation of this mixed with powdered rice, as instructed by the Poundrika scripture. For the most part, the weak and feeble are easily defeated by enemies; thus, it is important to regularly show them affection. (9

sloka: yastvevaṃdurbalomohātpittalānyevasevate ||101||  dāruṇaṃsavalīpākaṃprāpyaśīghraṃvipadyate |102|
translation: One who has thus given up weakness, delusion, and attachment, and has taken up his own duties, steadfastly striving for victory over his enemies, will soon attain greater strength. He should prepare a decoction of one hundred thousand leaves each of the neem, belleric, beleric myrobalan, and castor-oil plants, mixed with sugar, licorice, and salt, and consume it in the daytime and at night, boiled in water and cooled. The wind should blow from below during the day and from above at night for such a person.

sloka: śleṣmātisāreprathamaṃhitaṃlaṅghanapācanam ||102||  yojyaścāmātisāraghnoyathoktodīpanogaṇaḥ |  laṅghitasyānupūrvyāṃcakṛtāyāṃnanivartate ||103||
translation: One who is weak, due to delusion, uses the pitta-liquid (bile) for anointment, quickly undergoes a terrible transformation.

sloka: kaphajoyadyatīsāraḥkaphaghnaistamupācaret |bilvaṃkarkaṭikāmustamabhayāviśvabheṣajam ||104||  vacāviḍaṅgaṃbhūtīkaṃdhānyakaṃdevadāruca |  kuṣṭhaṃsātiviṣāpāṭhācavyaṃkaṭukarohiṇī ||105||  pippalīpippalīmūlaṃcitrakaṃhastipippalī |  yogāñchlokārdhavihitāṃścaturastānprayojayet ||106|| śṛtāñchleṣmātisāreṣukāyāgnibalavardhanān |  ajājīmasitāṃpāṭhāṃnāgaraṃmaricānica ||107||  dhātakīdviguṇaṃdadyānmātuluṅgarasāplutam |rasāñjanaṃsātiviṣaṃkuṭajasyaphalānica ||108||  dhātakīdviguṇaṃdadyātpātuṃsakṣaudranāgaram |  dhātakīnāgaraṃbilvaṃlodhraṃpadmasyakeśaram ||109||  jambūtvaṅnāgaraṃdhānyaṃpāṭhāmocarasobalā |  samaṅgādhātakībilvamadhyaṃjambvāmrayostvacaḥ ||110||  kapitthāniviḍaṅgānināgaraṃmaricānica |  cāṅgerīkolatakrāmlāṃścaturastānkaphottare ||111||  ślokārdhavihitāndadyātsasnehalavaṇānkhaḍān |  kapitthamadhyaṃlīḍhvātusavyoṣakṣaudraśarkaram ||112||  kaṭphalaṃmadhuyuktaṃvāmucyatejaṭharāmayāt |113|
translation: In the beginning of the day, one should combine the means that counter excess phlegm , alleviate stagnant water , and prevent its return ; this includes: - The combination of a paste made from the bark of a mango tree and a small piece of a Terminalia chebula branch, applied to the area affected by phlegm; - The ingestion of a powder made from the fruit of the Ziziphus jujube , mixed with rock salt . This method should not be discontinued ; Additionally, one can consume a decoction made from the bark of a Terminalia chebula tree and rock salt. The prescription is to be continued for a specific period , as directed by a medical professional. Note: This translation is provided based on the given word split and their meanings, assuming it relates to a medicinal practice or Ayurvedic treatment. The verse appears to describe various concoctions and treatments for addressing phlegm-related issues in the body.

sloka: kaṇāṃmadhuyutāṃpītvātakraṃpītvāsacitrakam ||113||  jagdhvāvābālabilvānimucyatejaṭharāmayāt |  bālabilvaṃguḍaṃtailaṃpippalīṃviśvabheṣajam |  lihyādvātepratihatesaśūlaḥsapravāhikaḥ ||114||  bhojyaṃmūlakaṣāyeṇavātaghnaiścopasevanaiḥ |  vātātisāravihitairyūṣairmāṃsarasaiḥkhaḍaiḥ ||115||  pūrvoktamamlasarpirvāṣaṭpalaṃvāyathābalam |  purāṇaṃvāghṛtaṃdadyādyavāgūmaṇḍamiśritam ||116||
translation:
To alleviate Kapha-caused disorders, one should use Bilva, Kaarkataaka, and musta, all of which are praised for their wide-ranging benefits. These include Vidaanga, Bhooti, Kam, Dhaanyaka, Deva-Daru, Cavya, Kaṭuka, Rohini, Pippali, Pippali-Mula, Citraka, Hasti, Yogans, and Shloka, all of which are mentioned in the earlier verse. These remedies can be administered in the form of powders, decoctions, pastes, or pills. They help to eliminate impurities from the body, promote digestion, and strengthen the Agni (digestive fire). Specifically, Aja-Jīvaka, Madhu-Parni, Patha, Cavya, Kola, Krimala, Roughini, Pippali-Mula, Citraka, Hasti, Yogans, Shloka, Ardha, Catuh, Astān should be used. These remedies are beneficial in treating chest ailments, fever, and other conditions caused by an imbalance of Kapha and Vata.

Additionally, Dhataki, which is twice as potent when given with Mula-Anga-Rasa, balances all three doshas and eliminates toxins from the body. It can be administered along with a small amount of sugar or honey. The fruits of Kutaja, Dhataki, Bilva, Lodhra, Padma, Keśara, Jambu, Tvak, Dhaanyaam, Aama, Ucca (Madanphala), Rasa-Balaa, Samaṅga-Dhataki, Bilva-Madhya-Jambvārya-Stava, Kapittha, Vidaanga, Marici, and Cangeri should be used in appropriate quantities. These remedies are to be administered with a small amount of ghee or oil, after being processed with honey, according to the patient's digestive capacity and the severity of their condition. The impurities present in the body can then be eliminated through the proper administration of these remedies, which help to balance the doshas and improve overall health.

sloka: vātaśleṣmavibandhevākaphevā'tisravatyapi |  śūlepravāhikāyāṃvāpicchābastiṃprayojayet ||117||  pippalībilvakuṣṭhānāṃśatāhvāvacayorapi |  kalkaiḥsalavaṇairyuktaṃpūrvoktaṃsannidhāpayet ||118||  pratyāgatesukhaṃsnātaṃkṛtāhāraṃdinātyaye |  bilvatailenamatimānsukhoṣṇenānuvāsayet ||119||  vacāntairathavākalkaistailaṃpaktvā'nuvāsayet |  bahuśaḥkaphavātārtastathāsalabhatesukham ||120||
translation: Having drunk the liquor mixed with honey and sesame seeds, one is freed from the bondage of phlegm and wind. One should consume a proper meal, including the roots and fruits of bilva, pipalī, and viśva bheṣaja, cooked with ghee, salt, and various spices, as well as previously mentioned amla and sarpiḥ. A balanced diet consisting of grains, rice, and mung dal can increase strength and endurance.

sloka: svesthānemāruto'vaśyaṃvardhatekaphasaṅkṣaye |  savṛddhaḥsahasāhanyāttasmāttaṃtvarayājayet ||121||
translation: Upon the cessation of phlegm, wind in its natural place increases. Therefore, one should quickly propitiate through the previously mentioned methods, such as reciting formulas with Kushthi leaves and Bilva, massaging with oil mixed with herbs, consuming warm, digestible food after bathing and eating during the day, and applying oil cooked for a long time to the head when the mind is clear. In this way, one afflicted with phlegm obtains relief.

sloka: vātasyānujayetpittaṃ pittasyānujayetkapham |  trayāṇāṃvājayetpūrvaṃyobhavedbalavattamaḥ ||122||
translation: In its own place, the wind naturally grows as phlegm decreases. One who is the strongest among the three should first be established, for that reason it is advised to remove congestion.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  prāgutpattinimittānilakṣaṇaṃsādhyatānaca |  kriyācāvasthikīsiddhānirdiṣṭāhyatisāriṇām ||123||
translation: The one who is able to overcome phlegm (Kapha) by following after the wind, and bile (Pitta) by being superior to it; who is the cause of the manifestation of the individual souls' qualities, actions, and stages; and who has fully determined the means for the embodied beings' liberation.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛtetantrecarakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsāsthāne'tisāracikitsitaṃnāmaikonaviṃśo'dhyāyaḥ ||19||
translation: In this context, the nineteenth chapter, titled "Special Treatments," describes the causes, symptoms, and cures of various ailments, as well as the appropriate actions for those in different stages of treatment.

sloka: athātaḥ kuṣṭhacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2|| hetuṃ dravyaṃ liṅgaṃ kuṣṭhānāmāśrayaṃ praśamanaṃ ca|  śṛṇvagniveśa! samyagviśeṣataḥ sparśanaghnānām||3||
translation: Thus, Agnivesha, we shall explain the treatment for leprosy, including its cause, means of identification, habitat, and pacification. (Referring to the twenty-first chapter of the Caraka Samhita.)

sloka: virodhīnyannapānāni dravasnigdhagurūṇi ca|  bhajatāmāgatāṃ chardiṃ vegāṃścānyānpratighnatām||4||  vyāyāmamatisantāpamatibhuktvopasevinām|  śītoṣṇalaṅghanāhārān kramaṃ muktvā niṣeviṇām||5||
translation:
Now, we shall explain the cure for leprosy: Bhagavan Atreya mentioned the cause, substance, and resting place of leprosy in detail. Pay close attention to the description of how it is aggravated through physical contact.

Following verses describe remedies for leprosy.

sloka: gharmaśramabhayārtānāṃ drutaṃ śītāmbusevinām|  ajīrṇādhyaśināṃ caiva pañcakarmāpacāriṇām||6||  navānnadadhimatsyātilavaṇāmlaniṣeviṇām|  māṣamūlakapiṣṭānnatilakṣīraguḍāśinām||7||  vyavāyaṃ cāpyajīrṇe'nne nidrāṃ ca bhajatāṃ divā|  viprān gurūn dharṣayatāṃ pāpaṃ karma ca kurvatām||8||
translation: To those who seek warmth, food and drink that are contrary to their constitutions, rough, heavy, and stale; to those who consume excessive amounts of cold foods and drinks, partake in improper digestion, and engage in activities that increase sweating and fatigue; and to those who disrespect brahmins, gurus, and commit sinful actions, (such acts) lead to harm.

sloka: vātādayastrayo duṣṭāstvagraktaṃ māṃsamambu ca|  dūṣayanti sa kuṣṭhānāṃ saptako dravyasaṅgrahaḥ||9||  ataḥ kuṣṭhāni jāyante sapta caikādaśaiva ca|  na caikadoṣajaṃ kiñcit kuṣṭhaṃ samupalabhyate||10||
translation: The three--wind, bile, and phlegm--when aggravated, spoil the unctuousness of flesh and water for those who are afflicted, hurried, exposed to cold, consume stale food, eat at improper times, indulge in excessive sexual activity, and partake in spoiled food, curds, sugar, and meat.
