Furthermore, for those who engage in these activities, eat at improper times, disturb the sleep of brahmins and elders, and commit sins, seven or eleven types of skin diseases arise, and never does a disease-free type occur.

sloka: sparśājñatvamatisvedo na vā vaivarṇyamunnatiḥ|  koṭhānāṃ lomaharṣaśca kaṇḍūstodaḥ śramaḥ klamaḥ||11||  vraṇānāmadhikaṃ śūlaṃ śīghrotpattiścirasthitiḥ|  dāhaḥ [1] suptāṅgatā ceti kuṣṭhalakṣaṇamagrajam||12||
translation: The three types of wind, along with bile and phlegm, impurify the skin, blood, and flesh, as well as the combination of seven substances that constitute leprosy. Hence, the symptoms such as eruptions on the body, hair falling out, itching, discharge, and thinness arise; additionally, wounds, inflammation, and fever are also observed in this condition. However, not every instance of leprosy manifests all these symptoms at once.

sloka: kṛṣṇāruṇakapālābhaṃ yadrūkṣaṃ paruṣaṃ tanu|  kāpālaṃ todabahulaṃ tatkuṣṭhaṃ viṣamaṃ smṛtam||14||
translation: Known by the sense of touch, not made of iron, possibly variegated, rough, and with protruding knots; such is the skull, remembered as associated with fatigue and sweat from exertion.

sloka: dāhakaṇḍūrujārāgaparītaṃ lomapiñjaram|  udumbaraphalābhāsaṃ kuṣṭhamaudumbaraṃ viduḥ||15||
translation: They recognize it as a type of kuşṭha (skin disease) that is dark-colored, reddish-brown, has a rough and hard surface, is thin, brittle, irregularly shaped, and has many pustules on it; it resembles the outer covering of an udumbara fruit.

sloka: śvetaṃ raktaṃ sthiraṃ styānaṃ snigdhamutsannamaṇḍalam|  kṛcchramanyonyasaṃsaktaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ maṇḍalamucyate||16||
translation: A condition described as "kuşṭha" is characterized by symptoms such as redness , itching , inflammation , and discoloration of the skin, as well as roughness and hardening similar to the udumbara fruit. It is also associated with being tightly bound and having a circular shape . This condition is known as "kuşṭha."

sloka: karkaśaṃ raktaparyantamantaḥ śyāvaṃ savedanam|  yadṛṣyajihvāsaṃsthānamṛṣyajihvaṃ taducyate||17||
translation: That which is white up to the red portion, firm, smooth, unctuous, projecting, rounded, rough, and attached to another; this is called "rishyajihva" (a type of plant).

sloka: saśvetaṃ raktaparyantaṃ puṇḍarīkadalopamam|  sotsedhaṃ ca sadāhaṃ ca puṇḍarīkaṃ taducyate||18||
translation: The constantly flowing and reddish-tinged one is called Pundarika, a name that precisely describes the white lotus flower.

sloka: śvetaṃ tāmraṃ tanu ca yadrajo [1] ghṛṣṭaṃ vimuñcati|  alābūpuṣpavarṇaṃ tat sidhmaṃ prāyeṇa corasi||19||
translation: The one who discards a white and copper-red lotus with expanded petals that is comparable to a fully opened crown jewel , that one is usually a thief. And, I am known as the red lotus .

sloka: yat kākaṇantikāvarṇamapākaṃ tīvravedanam|  tridoṣaliṅgaṃ tat kuṣṭhaṃ kākaṇaṃ naiva sidhyati||20||
translation: A condition of leprosy that is marked by blackish discoloration, is hard to cure, causes intense pain, and affects the three doshas cannot be considered as a mere kākaṇa (small mark).

sloka: iti saptamahākuṣṭhāni
translation: That which is known as the seventh layer of the skin cannot be purified by any means if it has three types of defects, namely, extreme severity, coloration, and foul smell.

sloka: asvedanaṃ mahāvāstu yanmatsyaśakalopamam|  tadekakuṣṭha
translation: It is referred to as "asvedanaṃ", the great "kuṣṭhāni" (skin diseases), which is like the seventh.

sloka: carmākhyaṃ bahalaṃ hasticarmavat||21||
translation: That which is comparable to a big fish, the physical sensation (of inflammation or itching) that is great, called carmAkhyaM - such is its only equivalent, ekam.

sloka: śyāvaṃ kiṇakharasparśaṃ paruṣaṃ kiṭibhaṃ smṛtam|
translation: The skin is known as dark, rough, and elephant-like in texture. (Referring to the qualities of something/someone)

sloka: vaipādikaṃ pāṇipādasphuṭanaṃ tīvravedanam||22||
translation: With what kind of touch that is sharp, resembling the vaipādika fire, do you recognize it?

sloka: kaṇḍūmadbhiḥ sarāgaiśca gaṇḍairalasakaṃ citam|
translation: With intense itching and inflammation caused by the Kandu diseases.

sloka: sakaṇḍūrāgapiḍakaṃ dadrumaṇḍalamudgatam||23||
translation: Surrounded by groups of thorny bushes and affectionately loved by the residents (of the forest).

sloka: raktaṃ [1] sakaṇḍu sasphoṭaṃ sarugdalati cāpi yat|  taccarmadalamākhyātaṃ saṃsparśāsahamucyate||24||
translation: The red (rakta) inflammation (sasphoṭa) appearing like a kernel (sakaṇḍū) or grains (piḍaka) and spreading in a circular shape (māndalam) is known as a boil (armadala). This is also called a contact reaction (saṃsparśāsa-ha).

sloka: pāmāśvetāruṇaśyāvāḥ kaṇḍūlāḥ piḍakā bhṛśam|
translation:
The word split provided is: pāmā, āśu, etāruṇa, syā, vā, kaṇḍūlāḥ, piḍakā, bhṛśam

The enhanced translation would be: "Especially (bhṛśam) in these (etā) quickly reddening (āśu + īruṇa) places (vā + syā), there are (vā) pimples/blisters (kaṇḍūlāḥ) or abscesses (piḍakā)."

This translation is based on the individual meanings of each word from the word split, and the context provided. The use of 'etā' suggests a group of places, while 'āśu + īruṇa' means quickly reddening which can refer to an area becoming red due to inflammation or pimples/blisters (kaṇḍūlāḥ) or abscesses (piḍakā). The word 'bhṛśam' is used to indicate that it is especially true for those areas.

sloka: sphoṭāḥ śvetāruṇābhāso visphoṭāḥ syustanutvacaḥ||25||
translation: Sparks, both white and reddish in hue, intensely (bhṛśam) crackle (visphoṭāḥ) when rubbed (tanutvacaḥ).

sloka: raktaṃ śyāvaṃ sadāhārti śatāruḥ syādbahuvraṇam|
translation: With a bright flash, may there be both white and red hues on the body, manifesting as spots and streaks.

sloka: sakaṇḍūḥ piḍakā śyāvā bahusrāvā vicarcikā||26||
translation: Always becoming deeply colored red, and having many wounds, who might be such a sufferer?

sloka: ityekādaśa kṣudrakuṣṭhāni
translation: Itching, sneezing, and excessive hair whitening are thirteen minor ailments. (Assuming that sakaṇḍūḥ means itching, piḍakā means sneezing, śyāvā refers to excessive hair whitening, and bahusrāvā_vicarcikā refer to two more minor ailments.)

sloka: vāte'dhikatare kuṣṭhaṃ kāpālaṃ maṇḍalaṃ kaphe|  pitte tvaudumbaraṃ vidyāt kākaṇaṃ tu tradoṣajam||27|| vātapitte śleṣmapitte vātaśleṣmaṇi cādhike|  ṛṣyajihvaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ sidhmakuṣṭhaṃ ca jāyate||28||  carmākhyamekakuṣṭhaṃ ca kiṭimaṃ savipādikam|  kuṣṭhaṃ cālasakaṃ jñeyaṃ prāyo vātakaphādhikam||29||  pāmā śatārurvisphoṭaṃ dadruścarmadalaṃ tathā|  pittaśleṣmādhikaṃ prāyaḥ kaphaprāyā vicarcikā||30||
translation:
These are the eleven minor types of skin diseases: (27-30)
1. When air predominates, a severe type of kuṣṭha (skin disease) occurs.
2. When phlegm predominates, kāpāla (a type of skin disease) occurs.
3. When bile predominates, udumbara (a type of skin disease) is manifested.
4. When both air and phlegm are dominant, ṛṣyajihva (another type of skin disease) arises.
5. When both air and bile are excessive, a type called alasaka appears.
6. When all the three doshas (humors) are excessive, pāmā is produced.
7. A condition known as śatāru is commonly seen when phlegm is dominant.
8. Visphoṭa occurs when there is an excess of bile and phlegm.
9. Dadru is a type that manifests when phlegm is predominant, and
10. Carma is the general term for skin diseases, while 
11. Ekakuṣṭha is another specific type.
12-13. Kiṭi and savipādika are other names of kuṣṭha that one should be aware of; kuṣṭha is mostly caused by an imbalance of air and bile. (27-29)
The symptoms mentioned in the shlokas 30-31 (not provided here) describe further different characteristics of these skin diseases.

sloka: sarvaṃ tridoṣajaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ doṣāṇāṃ tu balābalam|  yathāsvairlakṣaṇairbuddhvā kuṣṭhānāṃ kriyate kriyā||31||  doṣasya yasya paśyet kuṣṭheṣu viśeṣaliṅgamadriktam|  tasyaiva śamaṃ kuryāttataḥ paraṃ cānubandhasya||32||
translation:
When pitta is in excess in the body, characterized by features like redness, inflammation, and burning sensation, treatment should be prescribed accordingly. Similarly, when a specific symptom is predominantly observed in kapha-related disorders, such as congestion, heaviness, and swelling, then that particular therapy should be administered. (31)

If one notices a distinguishing mark of a dosha in the form of a distinct sign in skin diseases, they should pacify that specific dosha first, followed by addressing the underlying cause. (32)

sloka: kuṣṭhaviśeṣairdoṣā doṣaviśeṣaiḥ punaśca kuṣṭhāni|  jñāyante tairheturhetustāṃśca [1] prakāśayati||33||
translation: Recognizing the distinct symptoms of all kinds of leprosy, as well as their opposite causes, one can identify leprosy. By understanding this, and perceiving the distinguishing signs of individual instances of leprosy, one should apply a cure to it. Moreover, once that is done, one should also address any further associations with the ailment.

sloka: raukṣyaṃ śoṣastodaḥ śūlaṃ saṅkocanaṃ tathā''yāmaḥ|  pāruṣyaṃ kharabhāvo harṣaḥ śyāvāruṇatvaṃ ca||34||  kuṣṭheṣu vātaliṅgaṃ dāho rāgaḥ parisravaḥ pākaḥ|  visro gandhaḥ kledastathā'ṅgapatanaṃ ca pittakṛtam||35||  śvaityaṃ śaityaṃ kaṇḍūḥ sthairyaṃ cotsedhagauravasnehāḥ|  kuṣṭheṣu tu kaphaliṅgaṃ jantubhirabhibhakṣaṇaṃ kledaḥ||36||
translation: In cases of disease, there is roughness, wasting away, sharp pain, contraction; also impatience, harsh speech, and excitement. There is blueness/blackness, redness, discharge, maturation, digestion, excretion in the form of pus in the affected areas. There is itching, burning, suppuration, firmness, heaviness, and phlegm-related swelling in cases of disease. Additionally, there is excessive appetite/thirst by the microbes present in the affected areas, and accumulation of bodily fluids. (34-36)

sloka: sarvairliṅgairyuktaṃ matimān vivarjayedabalam|  tṛṣṇādāhaparītaṃ śāntāgniṃ jantubhirjagdham||37||  vātakaphaprabalaṃ yadyadekadoṣolbaṇaṃ na tat kṛcchram|  kaphapittavātapittaprabalāni tu kṛcchrasādhyāni||38||
translation: A sagacious person should reject everything unctuous, sharp, astringent, and rough, as well as violent agitation caused by wind, bile, and phlegm. Only that which is not faulted with excessive wind can be easily accomplished without difficulty. However, the effects of an excess of bile, phlegm, and the combination of both are difficult to alleviate. Additionally, when consuming foods that cause phlegm in living beings, one should exercise caution.

sloka: vātottareṣu sarpirvamanaṃ śleṣmottareṣu kuṣṭheṣu|  pittottareṣu mokṣo raktasya virecanaṃ cāgre||39||
translation: A discerning person should reject, using all means, a weak individual afflicted by thirst and burning caused by imbalanced wind, phlegm, and bile in the northern direction; and difficult ailments and their severe symptoms caused by excessive pitta in the eastern direction.

sloka: vamanavirecanayogāḥ kalpoktāḥ kuṣṭhināṃ prayoktavyāḥ|  pracchanamalpe kuṣṭhe mahati ca śastaṃ sirāvyadhanam||40||
translation: In the northern Vata regions, for those afflicted with Kushta (skin diseases), the following has been recommended: an enema using a mixture of clarified butter and a decoction made from the fat of a tortoise, together with a purgative of salt and honey, should be administered in cases of severe Kushta as well as for eliminating phlegm and pitta from the body.

sloka: bahudoṣaḥ saṃśodhyaḥ kuṣṭhī bahuśo'nurakṣatā prāṇān|  doṣe hyatimātrahṛte vāyurhanyādabalamāśu||41||
translation: For psoriasis patients, the recommended treatments to be applied are purgation, emesis, and therapeutic practices, as well as ointment for minor skin lesions; for a severe case of the disease, bloodletting through cutting veins is advised.

sloka: snehasya pānamiṣṭaṃ śuddhe koṣṭhe pravāhite rakte|  vāyurhi śuddhakoṣṭhaṃ kuṣṭhinamabalaṃ viśati śīghram||42||
translation: Having purified the leprosy-patient of many flaws , one should protect them, for if the air enters the now pure body of a weakened patient whose vitality has been diminished , they will quickly be killed .

sloka: doṣotkliṣṭe hṛdaye vāmyaḥ kuṣṭheṣu cordhvabhāgeṣu|  kuṭajaphalamadanamadhukaiḥ sapaṭolairnimbarasayuktaiḥ||43|| śītarasaḥ pakvaraso madhūni madhukaṃ ca vamanāni|
translation: The nectar-like sap of the mistletoe, mixed with the bark of sacred trees like udumbara, is quickly absorbed into a pure heart free from impurities and residing in the upper part of a diseased body. It also alleviates the symptoms of the disease. Similarly, the honey and its bees are offered to the patient, which have a cooling effect and aid in digestion.

sloka: kuṣṭheṣu trivṛtā dantī triphalā ca virecane śastā||44||  sauvīrakaṃ tuṣodakamāloḍanamāsavāśca sīdhūni|  śaṃsantyadhoharāṇāṃ yathāvirekaṃ kramaśceṣṭaḥ||45||
translation: In cases of impure body parts, one who is proficient in identifying and uprooting the three types of dental ulcers and using triphala for purgation and cooling down with sweet, ripe fruits, combined with sugarcane, nimba, and patola - such a person, as they describe the actions and effects of these treatments, is praised by wise men.

sloka: dārvībṛhatīsevyaiḥ paṭolapicumardamadanakṛtamālaiḥ|  sasnehairāsthāpyaḥ kuṣṭhī sakaliṅgayavamustaiḥ||46||  vātolbaṇaṃ viriktaṃ nirūḍhamanuvāsanārhamālakṣya|  phalamadhukanimbakuṭajaiḥ sapaṭolaiḥ sādhayetsneham||47||
translation: For curing skin diseases like leprosy, one should apply a paste made of the three ingredients: Patala, Picumarda, and Mada, which are bitter, pungent, and sweet in taste, respectively. The paste should be applied all over the body, including the nails and hair, after being cooked with various substances such as Tusodaka, Asava, and Sesamum oil. After applying, one must then expose themselves to the rays of the sun, wind, and other natural elements, in a gradual and systematic manner. The desired result will be the elimination of the disease.

sloka: saindhavadantīmaricaṃ phaṇijjhakaḥ pippalī karañjaphalam|  nasyaṃ syātsaviḍaṅgaṃ krimikuṣṭhakaphaprakopaghnam [1] ||48||  vairecanikairdhūmaiḥ ślokasthāneritaiḥ praśāmyanti|  kṛmayaḥ kuṣṭhakilāsāḥ prayojitairuttamāṅgasthāḥ||49||
translation: The disease of the afflicted should be treated with a concoction made from bṛhatī and dārvī flowers, paṭola, pica, marda, madana fruits, and musta, yava, madhuka, nimba, kuṭaja, and sapatola herbs, all mixed together with ghee and applied warm. This powerful and soothing remedy alleviates the harmful effects of wind and eliminates skin disorders when used as directed.

sloka: sthirakaṭhinamaṇḍalānāṃ svinnānāṃ prastarapraṇāḍībhiḥ|  kūrcairvighaṭṭitānāṃ raktotkleśo'panetavyaḥ||50||
translation: The red inflammation caused by Krimi-born eruptions and other afflictions should be soothed using the smoke of Vairechana Nikai Dhuma, in stationary and stretched out body parts.

sloka: ānūpavārijānāṃ māṃsānāṃ poṭṭalaiḥ sukhoṣṇaiśca|  svinnotsannaṃ [1] vilikhet kuṣṭhaṃ tīkṣṇena śastreṇa||51||  rudhirāgamārthamathavā śṛṅgālābūni [2] yojayet kuṣṭhe|  pracchitamalpaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ virecayedvā jalaukobhiḥ||52||  ye lepāḥ kuṣṭhānāṃ yujyante nirhṛtāsradoṣāṇām|  saṃśodhitāśayānāṃ sadyaḥ siddhirbhavetteṣām||53||
translation: For purifying the hard and fixed pustules on the circular surface of well-developed, widely spread, and mobile mamsas, one should scrape them off with a sharp instrument, causing a flow of blood for the purpose of eliminating the red foulness. This is said to bring immediate success when such lepas are used on properly prepared, impurity-free patients.

sloka: yeṣu na śastraṃ kramate sparśendriyanāśanāni yāni syuḥ|  teṣu nipātyaḥ kṣāro raktaṃ doṣaṃ ca visrāvya||54||  pāṣāṇakaṭhinaparuṣe supte kuṣṭhe sthire purāṇe ca|  pītāgadasya kāryo viṣaiḥ pradeho'gadaiścānu||55||  stabdhāni suptasuptānyasvedanakaṇḍulāni kuṣṭhāni|  kūrcairdantītrivṛtākaravīrakarañjakuṭajānām||56||  jātyarkanimbajairvā patraiḥ śastraiḥ samudraphenairvā|  ghṛṣṭāni gomayairvā tataḥ pradehaiḥ pradehyāni||57||
translation: The impurities of chronic skin diseases are quickly cleansed and healed by the application of remedies that are suitable for them.

sloka: mārutakaphakuṣṭhaghnaṃ karmoktaṃ pittakuṣṭhināṃ kāryam|  kaphapittaraktaharaṇaṃ tiktakaṣāyaiḥ praśamanaṃ ca||58||  sarpīṃṣi tiktakāni ca yaccānyadraktapittanut [1] karma|  bāhyābhyantaramagryaṃ tat kāryaṃ pittakuṣṭheṣu||59||
translation: The action that harms the wind-like Kapha disorder and is carried out by sharp instruments causing physical touch should be applied to those bodily locations. Purifying the rakta dosha with astringent substances that remove it, making it thin and hard like a stone, is the treatment for the ancient, firmly established Pitta disorder. For other skin diseases such as blisters, pimples, and boils, use medicinal powders or pastes made from drugs like Kutaja, Arka, Nimba, mixed with water, ghee, or oil, applied externally; internally, give suitable drugs in appropriate doses.

sloka: doṣādhikyavibhāgādityetat karma kuṣṭhanut proktam|  vakṣyāmi kuṣṭhaśamanaṃ prāyastvagdoṣasāmānyāt||60||
translation: The distinguishing characteristic of a harmful action, due to an excess of bodily humors such as mucus, bile, and wind, is stated. I will speak of the means to alleviate this skin disease in general, due to the shared qualities of the aggravating factors like rakta (blood tissue), tikta (bitter taste), and kaṣāyaiḥ (phlegm).

sloka: dārvī rasāñjanaṃ vā gomūtreṇa prabādhate kuṣṭham|  abhayā prayojitā vā māsaṃ savyoṣaguḍatailā||61||
translation: "Eliminating the effects of bile through therapeutic use of clay or by using cow urine is recommended to alleviate leprosy . Generally, such a treatment , which is beneficial for the skin , should be practiced in most cases , as stated by scripture . However, it is also important to consider the specific nature of the ailment and seek guidance from a knowledgeable source."

sloka: mūlaṃ paṭolasya tathā gavākṣyāḥ pṛthak palāṃśaṃ triphalātvacaśca [1] |  syāttrāyamāṇā kaṭurohiṇī ca bhāgārdhikā nāgarapādayuktā||62||  palaṃ tathaiṣāṃ saha cūrṇitānāṃ jale śṛtaṃ doṣaharaṃ pibennā|  jīrṇe rasairdhanvamṛgadvijānāṃ purāṇaśālyodanamādadīta||63||  kuṣṭhāni śophaṃ grahaṇīpradoṣamarśāṃsi kṛcchrāṇi halīmakaṃ ca|  ṣaḍrātrayogena nihanti caiṣa hṛdbastiśūlaṃ viṣamajvaraṃ ca||64||
translation: With cow's urine and arsenic sulfide, along with sesame oil and brick powder, mixed together, this is used to treat leprosy; in the same way, for a month, every day during the waxing phase of the moon, one should drink a mixture of turmeric, iron rust, and salt in water, which helps eliminate skin diseases, heartburn, parasitic infections, diarrhea, and hemorrhoids, as well as irregular fevers and other severe ailments.

sloka: mustaṃ vyoṣaṃ triphalā mañjiṣṭhā dāru pañcamūlyau dve|  saptacchadanimbatvak saviśālaścitrako mūrvā||65||  cūrṇaṃ tarpaṇabhāgairnavabhiḥ saṃyojitaṃ samadhvājyam [1] |  siddhaṃ kuṣṭhanibarhaṇametat prāyogikaṃ bhakṣyam||66||  śvayathuṃ sapāṇḍurogaṃ śvitraṃ grahaṇīpradoṣamarśāṃsi|  braghnabhagandarapiḍakākaṇḍūkoṭhāṃśca vinihanti||67||  iti mustādicūrṇa
translation: "Drinking the filtered liquid mixed with the powder of

sloka: triphalāphalātiviṣākaṭukānimbakaliṅgakavacāpaṭolānām|  māgadhikārajanīdvayapadmakamūrvāviśālānām||68||  bhūnimbapalāśānāṃ dadyādvipalaṃ tatastrivṛddviguṇā|  tasyāśca punarbrāhmī taccūrṇaṃ suptinut paramam||69||
translation: Of the three types of fruits known as Triphala, if the

sloka: lelītakaprayogo [1] rasena jātyāḥ samākṣikaḥ paramaḥ|  saptadaśakuṣṭhaghātī mākṣikadhātuśca mūtreṇa||70||
translation: The supreme essence of the three-fruited creepers, the two-petaled jasmine and the mango tree, as well as that of bhu, nimba, and palasa, all combined through mantra recitation, becomes the powerful samakshika rasa, possessing extraordinary potency.

sloka: śreṣṭhaṃ [2] gandhakayogāt suvarṇamākṣikaprayogādvā|  sarvavyādhinibarhaṇamadyāt kuṣṭhī rasaṃ ca nigṛhītam||71||  vajraśilājatusahitaṃ sahitaṃ vā yogarājena|  sarvavyādhipraśamanamadyātkuṣṭhī nigṛhya nityaṃ ca||72||
translation: The best thing, obtained through the union of sandalwood and gold, has the power to heal all ailments and constantly keeps leprosy in check. Or, combined with the king of yogis, it constantly soothes all diseases and permanently keeps leprosy at bay.

sloka: khadirasuradārusāraṃ śrapayitvā tadrasena toyārthaḥ|  kṣaudraprasthe kāryaḥ kārye te cāṣṭapalike ca||73||  tatrāścūrṇānāmaṣṭapalaṃ prakṣipettathā'mūni|  triphalaile tvaṅmaricaṃ patraṃ kanakaṃ ca karṣāṃśam||74||  matsyaṇḍikā madhusamā tanmāsaṃ jātamāyase bhāṇḍe|  madhvāsavamācarataḥ kuṣṭhakilāse śamaṃ yātaḥ||75||  iti madhvāsavaḥ
translation: By consistently using a combination of vajra-silā (adamantine stone) and jatu (a type of grass), along with yoga (practice) of the rajena (kingly) method, all diseases can be pacified, including kuṣṭhī (leprosy).

sloka: khadirakaṣāyadroṇaṃ kumbhe ghṛtabhāvite samāvāpya|  dravyāṇi cūrṇitāni ca ṣaṭpalikānyatra deyāni||76||
translation: Having filled the pot with the extract of Khadira wood and ghee, one should also put in it six types of crushed spices such as turmeric, salt, and camphor, as well as gold, a fish's tongue, honey, and intoxicating drink made from sugar, all of which are conducive to health and alleviate skin diseases and itching.

sloka: triphalāvyoṣaviḍaṅgarajanīmustāṭarūṣakendrayavāḥ|  sauvarṇī ca tathā tvak chinnaruhā ceti tanmāsam||77||
translation: Made from a mixture of khadira and kaṣāya in a copper vessel, mixed with ghṛta that has been heated, along with samā, vāpya, and other dravyāṇi that have been ground into a powder; this is the recommended preparation for tanmāsam.

sloka: nidadhīta dhānyamadhye prātaḥ prātaḥ pibettato yuktyā|  māsena mahākuṣṭhaṃ hantyevālpaṃ tu pakṣeṇa||78||  arśaḥśvāsabhagandarakāsakilāsapramehaśoṣāṃśca|  nā bhavati kanakavarṇaḥ pītvā'riṣṭaṃ kanakabindum||79||
translation:
Consuming every morning, before the sun rises, sesame seeds that are cleaned and well-stored in a jar, will help to prevent or reduce diseases such as consumption, hiccups, cough, leprosy, and other Pitta-related disorders; but consuming a small quantity of it daily won't yield the same benefits as having it in large quantities once a month. (78-79)

Triphala, Ajwain, Vida, black salt, Rajanighantu, Musta, Ushira, Kendrayavah, Sauvarni, and chopped skin - all these when taken together with honey, will cure diseases caused by Vata, Kapha, and Rakta (blood), as well as itching and other Pitta-related disorders; but having a small quantity of just gold won't yield the same benefits. (80)

sloka: iti kanakabindvariṣṭam  kuṣṭheṣvanilakaphakṛteṣvevaṃ peyastathā'pi paitteṣu|  kṛtamālakvāthaścāpyeṣa viśeṣāt kaphakṛteṣu||80||
translation: Having established the rice crop in the middle at dawn, one should drink (water) according to due measure with a month; thus it (drinking water) eliminates a small amount of pithy disorder. However, even in the case of phthisis, cough, shortness of breath, diarrhea, vomiting, fever, and leprosy, this distinction is that (the drinking water) does not become golden-colored after drinking the medicine.

sloka: triphalāsavaśca gauḍaḥ sacitrakaḥ kuṣṭharogavinihantā|  kramukadaśamūladantīvarāṅgamadhuyogasaṃyuktaḥ||81||
translation: This is Gauda, specially made with triple-fermented phala, which eliminates kuṣṭha and other doshas such as kapha and anila. It is also infused with ingredients like peya, paitte, kṛtamāla, and aromatic ariṣṭam, and has a golden hue.

sloka: laghūni cānnāni hitāni vidyāt kuṣṭheṣu śākani ca tiktakāni|  bhallātakaiḥ satriphalaiḥ sanimbairyuktāni cānnāni ghṛtāni caiva||82||  purāṇadhānyānyatha jāṅgalāni māṃsāni mudgāśca paṭolayuktāḥ|  śastā na gurvamlapayodadhīni nānūpamatsyā na guḍastilāśca||83||
translation: Three types of fruit concoctions, namely Gauda and Sacitraka, which eliminate skin diseases, Kramuka, Dasamula, Dantimula, Vara, and Angamadhu, all combined with honey, are beneficial in treating leprosy. However, the consumption of coarse grains like Mudga and Patola, water from stale sources, unwholesome fish, and Guda-Stila is to be avoided.

sloka: elā kuṣṭhaṃ dārvī śatapuṣpā citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭhālepanamiṣṭaṃ rasāñjanaṃ cābhayā caiva||84||
translation: Lightly fried grains, beneficial to kuṣṭha, are the herbal plants such as śatapuṣpā and citraka, as well as viḍaṅga; also included are ointments made from kuṣṭha, rasāñjana, and abhayā. Additionally, there are ancient grains, jāṅgalas, various kinds of meat, mudgās with patola, light fruits, not heavy, nor sour, such as payas, dadhis, ānūpa-fish, guḍa, and tilas.

sloka: citrakamelāṃ bimbīṃ [1] vṛṣakaṃ trivṛdarkanāgarakam|  cūrṇīkṛtamaṣṭāhaṃ bhāvayitavyaṃ palāśasya||85||  kṣāreṇa gavāṃ mūtrasrutena tenāsya maṇḍalānyāśu|  bhidyante vilayanti ca liptānyarkābhitaptāni||86||
translation: The bilva fruit , mixed with costus , manjishtha , and one hundred flowers of utpala or blue water lily , should be carefully prepared and applied as a paste to the eight cardinal points on the bark . When smeared with the cow dung , it causes the circles to split open and disintegrate due to the power of the medicinal herbs, just as fear is dispelled by the mere sight of a protector .

sloka: māṃsī maricaṃ lavaṇaṃ rajanī tagaraṃ sudhā gṛhāddhūmaḥ|  mūtraṃ pittaṃ [2] kṣāraḥ pālāśaḥ kuṣṭhahā lepaḥ||87||
translation: With ghee from cows, salt, black pepper, tagara, honey, and smoke from the home, along with urine, bile, lime, and arka applied, split open (for medicinal purposes).

sloka: trapu sīsamayaścūrṇaṃ maṇḍalanut phalgucitrakau bṛhatī|  godhārasaḥ salavaṇo dāru ca mūtraṃ ca maṇḍalanut||88||
translation: Consisting of a small, flat, and fragmented piece, a circular design of moderate beauty, a large-sized one, a mixture of turmeric and flour, wood, and urine, all contained in a small circle. (Note: This translation is based on the interpretation that this verse describes some kind of seal or insignia, possibly used for ceremonial purposes.)

sloka: kadalīpalāśapāṭaliniculakṣārāmbhasā prasannena|  māṃseṣu toyakāryaṃ kāryaṃ piṣṭe ca kiṇve [3] ca||89||  tairmedakaḥ sujātaḥ kiṇvairjanitaṃ pralepanaṃ śastam|  maṇḍalakuṣṭhavināśanamātapasaṃsthaṃ kṛmighnaṃ ca||90||
translation: With refined rice flour and a mixture of coconut palm leaves, ripe bimbi fruit, hardened dough, and liquids such as water, one should anoint the sacrificial animal. This auspicious and pure mixture, which consists of turmeric, yellow myrobalan, and black myrobalan, and is destructive to mold and harmful insects, should be applied to the animal's body.

sloka: mustaṃ madanaṃ triphalā karañja āragvadhakaliṅgayavāḥ|  dārvī sasaptaparṇā snānaṃ siddhārthakaṃ nāma||91||  eṣa kaṣāyo vamanaṃ virecanaṃ varṇakastathodgharṣaḥ|  tvagdoṣakuṣṭhaśophaprabādhanaḥ pāṇḍurogaghnaḥ||92||
translation:
Rubbed with mustard, triphala, karañja, āragvadha, and kaliṅga, the well-prepared paste is named siddhārthaka. This application removes fat, impurities, skin disorders, intestinal worms, and bile-related ailments, and is beneficial for the complexion. (91)
The purgative and emetic therapies, devoid of kuṣṭha, alleviate ātapa-induced disorders, impurities, and itching caused by skin diseases, and destroy pāṇḍu ailments. (92)

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ karañjabījānyeḍagajaḥ kuṣṭhasūdano lepaḥ|  prapunnāḍabījasaindhavarasāñjanakapitthalodhrāśca||93||  śvetakaravīramūlaṃ kuṭajakarañjayoḥ phalaṃ tvaco dārvyāḥ|  sumanaḥpravālayukto lepaḥ kuṣṭhāpahaḥ siddhaḥ||94||
translation: A remedy for the disease kushtha is made from the fruits of madana, triphala, karañjabija, aragvadha, kalinga, yavah, dārvī, and sasaptaparṇā, which when used as a paste, applied in a bath, or taken as vamana (a type of medical emesis) or virechana (purgative), is successful in treating the condition, including its symptoms like whitening of the skin, and is also beneficial in treating pandu-roga.

sloka: lodhrasya dhātakīnāṃ vatsakabījasya naktamālasya|  kalkaśca mālatīnāṃ kuṣṭheṣūnmardanālepau||95||
translation: A paste made from the root of lodhraa tree and dhataki flower, night-flower's seeds, a cure for kushta disease in kutharaj fruits, and applied with gaja kushta - this is the proven remedy.

sloka: śairīṣī tvak puṣpaṃ kārpāsyā rājavṛkṣapatrāṇi|  piṣṭā ca kākamācī caturvidhaḥ kuṣṭhanullepaḥ||96||  iti lepāḥ
translation: Made from the powder of lodhra, dhātakī, vatsaka, naktam, ālasya, kalka, mālatī, and kuṣṭha, applied with the oil of īśū and marda, are the four kinds of therapeutic pastes.

sloka: dārvyā rasāñjanasya ca nimbapaṭolasya khadirasārasya|  āragvadhavṛkṣakayostriphalāyāḥ saptaparṇasya||97||  iti ṣaṭ kaṣāyayogāḥ kuṣṭhaghnāḥ saptamaśca tiniśasya|  snāne pāne ca hitāstathā'ṣṭamaścāśvamārasya||98||  ālepanaṃ pragharṣaṇamavacūrṇanameta eva ca kaṣāyāḥ|  tailaghṛtapākayoge ceṣyante kuṣṭhaśāntyartham||99||
translation: The ingredients for a paste include the bark of a tree known as śairī Shahar, the skin of a pomegranate, the flowers of a plant called kārpāsyā, the leaves of the rāja vṛkṣa tree, all pulverized and mixed together with the juice of kuṣṭha nut. This is the application for curing leprosy. Additionally, rubbing, scratching, and anointing the affected area with this paste is also beneficial for treating the ailment. The eighth remedy is to consume the decoction made from asvamāra herb.

sloka: triphalā nimbapaṭolaṃ mañjiṣṭhā rohiṇī vacā rajanī|  eṣa kaṣāyo'bhyasto nihanti kaphapittajaṃ kuṣṭham||100||  etaireva ca sarpiḥ siddhaṃ vātolbaṇaṃ jayati kuṣṭham|  eṣa ca kalpo diṣṭaḥ khadirāsanadārunimbānām||101||
translation: The three fruits of the

sloka: kuṣṭhārkatutthakaṭphalamūlakabījāni rohiṇī kaṭukā|  kuṭajaphalotpalamustaṃ bṛhatīkaravīrakāsīsam||102||  eḍagajanimbapāṭhā durālabhā citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  tiktālābukabījaṃ kampillakasarṣapau vacā dārvī||103||  etaistailaṃ siddhaṃ kuṣṭhaghnaṃ yoga eṣa cālepaḥ|  udvartanaṃ pragharṣaṇamavacūrṇanameṣa eveṣṭaḥ||104||
translation: This is a special concoction of

sloka: śvetakaravīrakaraso gomūtraṃ citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭheṣu tailayogaḥ siddho'yaṃ sammato bhiṣajām||105||  iti śvetakaravīrādyaṃ tailam
translation: Prepared from the roots of Rohini, Katukakutaja, Utphala, Musta, Brihati, Krsnasariva, Citraka, Vida, and Dhavanika, as well as the seeds of Tiktalabuka and Durarbhapata, mixed with sesame oil, this is a renowned medicinal oil for treating skin diseases.

sloka: śvetakaravīrapallavamūlatvagvatsako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭhārkamūlasarṣapaśigrutvagrohiṇī kaṭukā||106||  etaistailaṃ siddhaṃ kalkaiḥ pādāṃśikairgavāṃ mūtram|  dattvā tailacaturguṇamabhyaṅgāt kuṣṭhakaṇḍūghnam||107||  iti śvetakaravīrapallavādyaṃ tailam
translation: This is the anointment (taila), named "Śvetakaravīra", acknowledged by physicians, made from the root of the Śvetakaravīra plant and other ingredients. Its fourfold strength, when applied to affected areas after mixing with cow's urine, is said to cure skin diseases (kuṣṭhakaṇḍūghnam).

sloka: tiktālābukabījaṃ dve tutthe rocanā haridre dve|  bṛhatīphalameraṇḍaḥ saviśālaścitrako mūrvā||108||  kāsīsahiṅguśigrutryūṣaṇasuradārutumburuviḍaṅgam|  lāṅgālakaṃ kuṭajatvak kaṭukākhyā rohiṇī caiva||109|| sarṣapatailaṃ kalkairetairmūtre caturguṇe sādhyam|  kaṇḍūkuṣṭhavināśanamabhyaṅgānmārutakaphahantṛ||110|| iti tiktekṣvākvāditailam
translation: The root of white karaveerA leaves, viḍaṅga, and kuṣṭha, along with arka, sarṣapa, śigru, and the outer skin of Rohiṇī and Kaṭukā plants, when combined in equal parts with the expressed oil of sesame seeds, becomes a medicinal oil that is siddha after being cooked with the milk of cows. This is the first among the oils prepared from the roots mentioned. [Translation based on the word-split provided, original verse context may differ]

sloka: kanakakṣīrī śailā bhārgī dantyāḥ phalāni mūlaṃ ca|  jātīpravālasarṣapalaśunaviḍaṅgaṃ karañjatvak||111||  saptacchadārkapallavamūlatvaṅnimbacitrakāsphotāḥ|  guñjairaṇḍaṃ bṛhatīmūlakasurasārjakaphalāni||112||  kuṣṭhaṃ pāṭhā mustaṃ tumburumūrvāvacāḥ saṣaḍgranthāḥ [1] |  eḍagajakuṭajaśigrutryūṣaṇabhallātakakṣavakāḥ||113||  haritālamavākpuṣpī tutthaṃ kampillako'mṛtāsañjñaḥ|  saurāṣṭrī kāsīsaṃ dārvītvak sarjikālavaṇam||114||  kalkairetaistailaṃ karavīrakamūlapallavakaṣāye|  sārṣapamathavā tailaṃ gomūtracaturguṇaṃ sādhyam||115||
translation: The buds of the bitter ala (tiktala) plant, two tutthha type, with shining haridra color and bṛhatī size fruits, long eranda type, saviśālaścitraka having mūrvā, kāsīsa, hiṅgu, śuktri, yūṣaṇa, sura, dāru, tumburu, viḍaṅga components, with lāṅgala type skin, kuṭaja type, kaṭuka named, having ākhyā component, rohiṇī type, along with sarṣapa oil, extracted with kalkaiḥ, mixed with four-fold guṇas of gomūtra, is able to cure kuṣṭha, vinā kandū, and aśanam, beneficial in abhyaṅgān, pacifying māruta and kapha, hantṛ of tiktā and ikṣvāku type diseases.

sloka: sthāpyaṃ kaṭukālābuni tatsiddhaṃ tena maṇḍalānyāśu|  bhindyādbhiṣagabhyaṅgātkṛmīṃśca kaṇḍūṃ ca vinihanyāt||116||  iti kanakakṣīrītailam
translation: Prepare a concoction using the following:

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ tamālapatraṃ maricaṃ samanaḥśilaṃ sakāsīsam|  tailena yuktamuṣitaṃ saptāhaṃ bhājane tāmre||117||  tenāliptaṃ sidhmaṃ saptāhāhyeti [1] tiṣṭhato gharme|  māsānnavaṃ kilāsaṃ snānaṃ muktvā viśuddhatanoḥ||118||  iti sidhme lepaḥ
translation: Upon being applied with the therapeutic agent consisting of ingredients such as costus, black myrobalan, rock salt, powdered iron ore, and a suitable amount of clarified butter, massaged and fomented with heat for seven days, then washed off with a mixture of turmeric and golden-colored liquid butter, the affliction is cured; this treatment is known as "sidhma" and is used to alleviate skin conditions such as scabies and boils.

sloka: sarṣapakarañjakoṣātakīnāṃ tailānyatheṅgudīnāṃ ca|  kuṣṭheṣu hitānyāhustailaṃ yaccāpi khadirasārasya||119||
translation: For skin diseases, the oil extracted from sesame seeds and kodrava grass is recommended; also, the sap of the tamala tree, mixed with marica and salt, is beneficial. This has been established as a treatment for leprosy.

sloka: jīvantī mañjiṣṭhā dārvī kampillakaḥ payastuttham|  eṣa ghṛtatailapākaḥ siddhaḥ siddhe ca sarjarasaḥ||120||  deyaḥ samadhūcchiṣṭo vipādikā tena śāmyate'bhyaktā|  carmaikakuṣṭhakiṭimaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ śāmyatyalasakaṃ ca||121||  iti vipādikāharaghṛtataile
translation: The oils extracted from black gram, sesame, and castor beans, as well as the resin of trees like khadira, are considered beneficial for skin diseases. When applied with pure ghee, they alleviate various skin ailments, including eczema and psoriasis. This is known as the treatment of skin diseases with ghee-based concoctions.

sloka: kiṇvaṃ [1] varāharudhiraṃ pṛthvīkā saindhavaṃ ca lepaḥ syāt|  lepo yojyaḥ kustumburūṇi kuṣṭhaṃ ca maṇḍalanut||122||
translation: With a paste made from the juices of myrobalan, licorice, barley, and camphor, mixed with clarified butter and sesame oil, applied to the affected area, impure bodily humors are appeased. This is a tried and true remedy for leprosy.

sloka: pūtīkadārujaṭilāḥ pakvasurā kṣaudramudgaparṇyau ca|  lepaḥ sakākanāso maṇḍalakuṣṭhāpahaḥ siddhaḥ||123||
translation:
The dough made from pure flour, mixed with salt, sugar, and crushed peas, when properly prepared, becomes an excellent relish. (123)

Word level split:

sloka: citrakaśobhāñjanakau guḍūcyapāmārgadevadārūṇi|  khadiro dhavaśca lepaḥ śyāmā dantī dravantī ca||124||  lākṣārasāñjanailāḥ punarnavā ceti kuṣṭhino lepāḥ|  dadhimaṇḍayutāḥ sarve deyāḥ ṣaṇmārutakaphakuṣṭhaghnāḥ||125||
translation: The medicinal formulations made from wood apple, Indian gooseberry, black myrobalan, licorice, and belleric myrobalan, which are processed, matured, and mixed with pure sugar, clarified butter, and long pepper, are all excellent for treating various types of skin diseases, including those that are hard to cure.

sloka: eḍagajakuṣṭhasaindhavasauvīrakasarṣapaiḥ kṛmighnaiśca|  kṛmikuṣṭhamaṇḍalākhyaṃ dadrūkuṣṭhaṃ ca śamamupaiti||126||
translation: The creators of splendor, Citraka and Sobhana, along with the tree pastes made from Khadira, Dhava, and lemon, as well as ANjana, ela, and laksA, all applied together, are capable of eliminating the kuSTha condition characterized by the six humors (shat-mAruta), kapha, and kuSTha. Additionally, a paste made from all the ingredients mentioned, including yogurt and mud, is recommended for those afflicted with kuSTha-maNDala.

sloka: eḍagajaḥ sarjaraso mūlakabījaṃ ca sidhmakuṣṭhānām|  kāñjikayuktaṃ tu pṛthaṅmatamidamudvartanaṃ lepāḥ||127||
translation: The paste made of myrobalan, licked by an elephant, is the foremost treatment for boils and pustules.

sloka: vāsā triphalā pāne snāne codvartane pralepe ca|  bṛhatīsevyapaṭolāḥ sasārivā rohiṇī caiva||128||  khadirāvaghātakakubharohītakalodhrakuṭajadhavanimbāḥ|  saptacchadakaravīrāḥ śasyante snānapāneṣu||129||
translation: The triphala paste prepared from its fruits, when used in ablution, anointment, and friction, and when consumed as a beverage, is known to cure skin diseases like eczema and psoriasis; the khadira bark, when processed with various ingredients including birch bark, costs seven types of impurities during bathing and drinking water.

sloka: jalavāpyalohakeśarapatraplavacandanaṃ mṛṇālāni|  bhāgottarāṇi siddhaṃ pralepanaṃ pittakaphakuṣṭhe||130||
translation: In the use of water, earth, and plant substances such as sacred turmeric, red sandalwood, birch bark, and the bark of seven other trees for bathing, drinking, and anointment, there are three-fold benefits.

sloka: yaṣṭyāhvalodhrapadmakapaṭolapicumardacandanarasāśca|  snāne pāne ca hitāḥ suśītalāḥ pittakuṣṭhibhyaḥ||131||
translation: Cooling and beneficial for both Pitta and Kapha doshas, the paste made from sandalwood, picked from the upper petals of a lotus that grows in a clean water source, when applied during bathing and drinking, is properly prepared.

sloka: ālepanaṃ priyaṅgurhareṇukā vatsakasya ca phalāni|  sātiviṣā ca sasevyā sacandanā rohiṇī kaṭukā||132||
translation: Washings with the cool and soothing extracts of priyangu, usheer, padma, kapaalaa, marda, Chandan, and Rohini, as well as the fruit of Vatsaka, are beneficial for bathing and drinking, and alleviate pitta and kushthi.

sloka: tiktaghṛtairdhautaghṛtairabhyaṅgo dahyamānakuṣṭheṣu|  tailaiścandanamadhukaprapauṇḍarīkotpalayutaiśca||133||
translation: With a paste made from priyaṅgu, haridra, and vatsaka fruits, as well as ativiṣa, applied to the body that is anointed with sacandana paste and adorned with pauṇḍarīka and utpala flowers.

sloka: klede prapatati cāṅge dāhe visphoṭake sacarmadale|  śītāḥ pradehasekā vyadho vireko ghṛtaṃ tiktam||134||
translation: Consumed by heat, one seeks to cool down with clarified butter that has been properly cleansed; sesame oil and sandalwood, applied to the body, alleviate the itch of eczema.

sloka: khadiraghṛtaṃ nimbaghṛtaṃ dārvīghṛtamuttamaṃ paṭolaghṛtam|  kuṣṭheṣu raktapittaprabaleṣu bhiṣagjitaṃ siddham||135||
translation: In cases of bleeding, inflammation, and skin disorders like rakta pitta, the expert doctor should apply the best quality ghee made from khadira, nimba, patola, and dārvī, which have bitter, astringent tastes; this is proven to be effective.

sloka: triphalātvaco'rdhapalikāḥ paṭolapatraṃ ca kārṣikāḥ śeṣāḥ|  kaṭurohiṇī sanimbā yaṣṭyāhvā trāyamāṇā ca||136||  eṣa kaṣāyaḥ sādhyo dattvā dvipalaṃ masūravidalānām|  salilāḍhake'ṣṭabhāge śeṣe pūto raso grāhyaḥ||137||
translation: Consuming a mixture of the best quality ghee from cows, gruel made from barley and wheat, extract from nimba tree, and decoction of khadira bark, along with suitable additions of pitta-alleviating and rakta-purifying substances, administered by a learned physician, brings about a cure for the diseases caused by imbalance in katu and ushna components.

sloka: te ca [1] kaṣāye'ṣṭapale catuṣpalaṃ sarpiṣaśca paktavyam|  yāvatsyādaṣṭapalaṃ śeṣaṃ peyaṃ tataḥ koṣṇam||138||  tadvātapittakuṣṭhaṃ vīsarpaṃ vātaśoṇitaṃ prabalam|  jvaradāhagulmavidradhivibhramavisphoṭakān hanti||139||
translation: When [tri] fruits [phalah] are ripe [tvacah ardha], who [kaH] among you [pali] will prepare [karsi] the four-cornered [chatushpala] pancake [sarpishca paktavyam]? Eat [asaDyaH sadyah] up to [asta bhage] eight [asta] parts [bhage], leaving [sheshaM] a quarter [ashtapalam sheShaM]. Pure [pootah] juice [rasah] is to be consumed [grAhyaH] after straining [saliila adhake]. This eliminates [hanthi] the harmful effects [vata shonitam prabalam, jvara daha gulma vidradhi vibhrama visphotakan] of excessive heat [tapittakushtam], wind [vatah shonitam], and bile [pitta-kushtam].

sloka: nimbapaṭolaṃ dārvīṃ durālabhāṃ tiktarohiṇīṃ triphalām|  kuryādardhadalāṃśaṃ parpaṭakaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca||140||  salilāḍhakasiddhānāṃ rase'ṣṭabhāgasthite kṣipet pūte|  candanakirātatiktakamāgadhikāstrāyamāṇāṃ ca||141||  mustaṃ vatsakabījaṃ kalkīkṛtyārdhakārṣikān bhāgān|  navasarpiṣaśca ṣaṭpalametatsiddhaṃ [3] ghṛtaṃ peyam||142||  kuṣṭhajvaragulmārśograhaṇīpāṇḍvāmayaśvayathuhāri|  pāmāvisarpapiḍakākaṇḍūmadagaṇḍanutsiddham||143||  iti tiktaṣaṭpalakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: This ghee made from six equal parts of the pungent leaves of Tinduka, chosen carefully, difficult to obtain, and having bitter taste, and one part each of the drugs for wind, bile, leprosy, poison, blood, excessive strength, and symptoms like fever, shivering, etc., is capable of curing diseases like leprosy, consumption, edema, hemorrhoids, and various other ailments.

sloka: saptacchadaṃ prativiṣāṃ śampākaṃ tiktarohiṇīṃ pāṭhām|  mustamuśīraṃ triphalāṃ paṭolapicumardaparpaṭakam||144||  dhanvayavāsaṃ candanamupakulyāṃ padmakaṃ haridre dve|  ṣaḍgranthāṃ saviśālāṃ śatāvarīṃ sārive cobhe||145||  vatsakabījaṃ yāsaṃ [4] mūrvāmamṛtāṃ kirātatiktaṃ ca|  kalkān kuryānmatimānyaṣṭyāhvaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca||146||  kalkaścāturbhāgo [5] jalamaṣṭaguṇaṃ raso'mṛtaphalānām|  dviguṇo ghṛtātpradeyastatsarpiḥ pāyayetsiddham||147||  kuṣṭhāni raktapittaprabalānyarśāṃsi raktavāhīni|  vīsarpamamlapittaṃ [6] vātāsṛk pāṇḍurogaṃ ca||148|| visphoṭakānsapāmānunmādaṃ kāmalāṃ jvaraṃ kaṇḍūm|  hṛdrogagulmapiḍakā asṛgdaraṃ gaṇdamālāṃ ca||149||  hanyādetat sarpiḥ pītaṃ kāle yathābalaṃ sadyaḥ|  yogaśatairapyajitānmahāvikārānmahātiktam||150||  iti mahātiktakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Prepare the following mixture: a half-part of nimbapaṭolam and dārvīm, each being durālabhā and tikta; one triphalā, thoroughly crushed with ardha dala aṃśam parpaṭakam; trāyamāṇām salila āḍhaka of siddhānām rase, divided into eight parts; place kuṣṭhajvaragulmārśograhaṇīpāṇḍvāmayaśvayathuhāri in it, pūte with candana; further add kirāta tiktaka and māgadhi; stir until the mixture becomes free from all impurities like kāḥ pāmāvisarpapiḍakākaṇḍūmadagaṇḍanutsiddham; this is known as tiktaṣaṭpalakam ghṛtam. (144-150)

sloka: doṣe hṛte'panīte rakte bāhyāntare kṛte śamane [7] |  snehe ca kālayukte na kuṣṭhamanuvartate [8] sādhyam||151||
translation: In the seventh part of the treatment of a disease, when the toxin is removed, the blood is purified, and tridoshic equilibrium is restored; and in the eighth part, when ointments like usheer, sarpi , pittapapa, madhu, etc., are applied, no kustha can arise. This is sadyaha effective in counteracting major vikaras such as jvara , kandu , hrdrogagulmapidakaasrga , gandamala , etc. Its taste is tiktakam .

sloka: khadirasya tulāḥ pañca śiṃśapāsanayostule|  tulārdhāḥ sarva evaite karañjāriṣṭavetasāḥ||152||  parpaṭaḥ kuṭajaścaiva vṛṣaḥ kṛmiharastathā|  haridre kṛtamālaśca guḍūcī triphalā trivṛt||153||  saptaparṇaśca saṅkṣuṇṇā daśadroṇeṣu vāriṇaḥ|  aṣṭabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu kaṣāyamavatārayet||154||  dhātrīrasaṃ ca tulyāṃśaṃ sarpiṣaścāḍhakaṃ pacet|  mahātiktakakalkaistu yathoktaiḥ palasammitaiḥ||155||  nihanti sarvakuṣṭhāni pānābhyaṅganiṣevaṇāt|  mahākhadiramityetat paraṃ kuṣṭhavikāranut||156||  iti mahākhadiraṃ ghṛtam
translation: A five-unit scale made of Khadira wood, and a similar one made of Śimśapā wood; half of each of these scales, when combined, are equivalent to the weight of Karañja and Ariṣṭa fruits. The weight of a Parpaṭa fruit and that of a Kuṭaja fruit, along with the weight of a Vṛṣa fruit and that of a worm-infested grain, and the weight of a garland made from Haridrā, Guḍūcī, Triphalā fruits, all combined, equals the weight of a Saptaparṇa leaf when it is reduced to fragments and its weight is taken in ten equal parts. The remainder, after subtracting eight parts of this total from Kaṣāya, serves to purify it. The same quantity as that of Dhātrī rasa is used in cooking clarified butter, along with the measured weights of Mahātiktaka, Kakala, and other ingredients mentioned. Regular application of this Khadira ghee can help eliminate all types of skin diseases. This is known as the supreme remedy for chronic skin conditions.

sloka: prapatatsu lasīkāprasruteṣu gātreṣu jantujagdheṣu|  mūtraṃ nimbaviḍaṅge snānaṃ pānaṃ pradehaśca||157||
translation: Five silver pieces of Shimshapa wood, a pair of gold Tulap scales, equally weighing the bark of Khadira, Kutaja, Ariṣṭa, Vetas, Parpaṭa, Vṛṣa, Krimi, and Haridra, formed into a garland, three fruits of Guḍūcī, mixed with seven cleaned Parṇa leaves, crushed and reduced to ten portions, combined with the eight parts of water, leaving aside the impurities, should be cooked with the equalized juice of Dhātrī, ghee, and the measured quantity of Tiktaka Kalka as directed, to remove all types of skin disorders, consumed in the form of a drink or applied externally, this is considered the supreme remedy for skin diseases made from Khadira.

sloka: vṛṣakuṭajasaptaparṇāḥ karavīrakarañjanimbakhadirāśca|  snāne pāne lepe krimikuṣṭhanudaḥ sagomūtrāḥ||158||
translation: Upon touching the bodies of creatures in the act of bathing, drinking, and anointing themselves, the raindrops fall, becoming pure like the Nimba tree's sap.

sloka: pānāhāravidhāne prasecane dhūpane pradehe ca|  kṛmināśanaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ viśiṣyate kuṣṭhahā khadiraḥ||159||
translation: In the practice of drinking and eating, the use of seven types of leaves, including those of the male and female Kutaja trees, as well as those of Karañja and Nimba, is considered superior for eliminating worms and skin diseases such as scabies.

sloka: eḍagajaḥ saviḍaṅgo mūlānyāragvadhasya kuṣṭhānām|  uddālanaṃ śvadantā gośvavarāhoṣṭradantāśca||160||
translation: In the administration of emetics and purgatives for scraping away the roots of causes of leprosy, the use of Pāna (a medicinal decoction) and Āhāra (medicated diet), along with Dhūpana (fumigation), Pradeha (application of ointment), and elimination of Kṛmi (worms) with Viḍaṅga, is most effective; especially when enhanced with Kadira.

sloka: eḍagajaḥ saviḍaṅgo dve ca niśe rājavṛkṣamūlaṃ ca|  kuṣṭhoddālanamagryaṃ sapippalīpākalaṃ yojyam||161||
translation: The root of the madder plant, along with that of elephant, vit (a type of tree), two kinds of grasses, and the teeth of a dog, boar, and buffalo, is excellent for treating skin diseases.

sloka: śvitrāṇāṃ saviśeṣaṃ [1] yoktavyaṃ sarvato viśuddhānām|  śvitre sraṃsanamagryaṃ malapūrasa iṣyate saguḍaḥ||162||  taṃ pītvā susnigdho yathābalaṃ sūryapādasantāpam|  saṃseveta viriktastryahaṃ pipāsuḥ pibet peyām||163||
translation: For those who are completely pure, the foremost excellence is to adopt the practices of all white-colored (virtuous) beings. Just as a thirsty elephant, after drinking water, becomes refreshed and approaches the heat of the sun, one should similarly worship Me, having first cleaned oneself, and a thirsty person should drink water.

sloka: śvitre'ṅge ye sphoṭā jāyante kaṇṭakena tānbhindyāt|  sphoṭeṣu visruteṣu prātaḥ prātaḥ pibet pakṣam||164||  malapūmasanaṃ priyaṅguṃ śatapuṣpāṃ cāmbhasā samutkvāthya|  pālāśaṃ vā kṣāraṃ yathābalaṃ phāṇitopetam||165||
translation: Having consumed the clarified butter in the morning, one should sip (the soup) as warm as the foot of the sun, alleviating the heat of exhaustion. Just as a tree sheds its leaves, likewise, a man should let go of (his) semen, consuming as much as his strength allows, purified and contained.

sloka: yaccānyat kuṣṭhaghnaṃ śvitrāṇāṃ sarvameva tacchastam|  khadirodakasaṃyuktaṃ khadirodakapānagryaṃ vā||166||
translation: In the morning, one should drink water mixed with Khadira decoction, which eliminates all symptoms of leprosy in the bodies of those who are affected by it. Or, one may drink it as a preferred beverage, having extracted the essence of one hundred flowers of Priyangu and added it to water. Just as the strength of the body is restored by consuming nutritious food, similarly, the vitality lost due to the ailment can be regained by drinking this decoction.

sloka: samanaḥśilaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ kāsīsaṃ rocanāṃ kanakapuṣpīm|  śvitrāṇāṃ praśamārthaṃ sasaindhavaṃ lepanaṃ dadyāt||167||
translation: Use as a topical application for all types of leprosy, made from a mixture of powdered wood of Khadira tree, water, and the best kind of turmeric, which is coolingly fragrant and golden in color.

sloka: kadalīkṣārayutaṃ vā kharāsthi dagdhaṃ gavāṃ rudhirayuktam|  hastimadādhyuṣitaṃ vā mālatyāḥ korakakṣāram||168||  nīlotpalaṃ sakuṣṭhaṃ sasaindhavaṃ hastimūtrapiṣṭaṃ vā|  mūlakabījāvalgujalepaḥ piṣṭo gavāṃ mūtre||169||  kākodumbarikā vā sāvalgujacitrakā gavāṃ mūtre|  piṣṭā manaḥśilā vā saṃyuktā barhipittena||170||  lepaḥ kilāsahantā bījānyāvalgujāni lākṣā ca|  gopittamañjane dve pippalyaḥ kālaloharajaḥ||171||
translation: Offering equally a cooling paste made of mud from the Kasi region , adorned with saffron , yellow turmeric , and white camphor for pacification of the cows' temperament , one should give the salty lepa paste.

sloka: śuddhyā śoṇitamokṣairvirūkṣaṇairbhakṣaṇaiśca saktūnām|  śvitraṃ kasyacideva praṇaśyati kṣīṇapāpasya||172||
translation: The blemish of some roots such as kutaja, utpala, nila, and mallika disappears by being cooked with the powder of barley, mudgaraka, manahshila, kustha, pippali, kasha, loha, rajah, and mustard seeds, mixed with ghee, milk, curd, ksira, urine and excreta of cow, and taken along with kadali, phalgu, patala, draksha, dhavani, kapittha fruits, honey, and water.

sloka: dāruṇaṃ cāruṇaṃ [1] śvitraṃ kilāsaṃ nāmabhistribhiḥ|  vijñeyaṃ trividhaṃ tacca [2] tridoṣaṃ prāyaśaśca tat||173||  doṣe raktāśrite raktaṃ tāmraṃ māṃsasamāśrite|  śvetaṃ medaḥśrite śvitraṃ guru taccottarottaram||174||
translation: Through purification, blood-letting treatments, and avoidance of certain foods, a person may eliminate their blemishes; some quickly disappear when evil tendencies are diminished. The white sheen appears on the body when fat disappears, and becomes heavier as it further subsides.

sloka: yat parasparato'bhinnaṃ bahu yadraktalomavat|  yacca varṣagaṇotpannaṃ tacchvitraṃ naiva sidhyati||175||  araktaloma tanu yat pāṇḍu nāticirotthitam|  madhyāvakāśe cocchūnaṃ śvitraṃ tatsādhyamucyate||176||
translation: That which is distinguished by its own unique flaws and has many red appearances like iron, or that which is produced from the passing of multiple seasons, such a distinctly marked thing does not become auspicious. And that body which is not discolored by the flaw of impurity, nor is it inflamed, and which appears only slightly yellowish in the middle region, that is considered auspicious.

sloka: vacāṃsyatathyāni kṛtaghnabhāvo nindā surāṇāṃ [1] gurudharṣaṇaṃ ca|  pāpakriyā pūrvakṛtaṃ ca karma hetuḥ kilāsasya virodhi cānnam||177||
translation: The cause of one's agitation is the action, preceded by sinful behavior, that becomes an obstacle to the pure white brilliance, similar to a cloud, arising in the middle region of a body with fair complexion, neither too thin nor too bulky, resembling a combination of various colors and appearing simultaneously with other qualities.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  heturdravyaṃ liṅgaṃ vividhaṃ ye yeṣu cādhikā doṣāḥ|  kuṣṭheṣu doṣaliṅgaṃ samāsato doṣanirdeśaḥ||178||  sādhyamasādhyaṃ kṛcchraṃ kuṣṭhaṃ kuṣṭhāpahāśca ye yogāḥ|  siddhāḥ kilāsaheturliṅgaṃ gurulāghavaṃ tathā śāntiḥ||179||  iti saṅgrahaḥ praṇīto maharṣiṇā kuṣṭhanāśane'dhyāye|  smṛtibuddhivarghanārthaṃ śiṣyāya hutāśaveśāya||180||
translation: In that section, there are verses describing the various properties of drugs, as well as the specific faults associated with them. A summary of this is provided: the means for achieving success in treating skin diseases include the use of proper medicines, identifying distinguishing marks, and avoiding faults. Additionally, there are yogic practices that can aid in the treatment and elimination of skin diseases. This has been compiled by the sage for the benefit of those seeking to learn about the treatment of skin diseases. word level split: tatra, ślokāḥ, hetuḥ, dravyaṃ, liṅgaṃ, vividhaṃ, ye, yeṣu, cādhikā, doṣāḥ, |, kuṣṭheṣu, doṣaliṅgaṃ, samāsataḥ, doṣanirdeśaḥ, ||178||, sādhyam, asādhyaṃ, kṛcchraṃ, kuṣṭhaṃ, kuṣṭhāpahāśca, ye, yogāḥ, |, siddhāḥ, kilā, saha, eturliṅgaṃ, guru, lāghavaṃ, tathā, śāntiḥ, ||179||, iti, saṅgrahaḥ, praṇītaḥ, maharṣiṇā, kuṣṭhanāśane, adhyāye, |, smṛti, buddhi, varghanārthaṃ, śiṣyāya, hutāśaveśāya, ||180|| Enhaced translation: In this [adhyaye or section], there are verses describing the various properties of drugs , as well as the specific faults associated with them. A summary of this is provided: the means for achieving success in treating skin diseases include the use of proper medicines , identifying distinguishing marks , and avoiding faults . Additionally, there are yogic practices

sloka: athātaḥ śvayathucikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now, we shall explain the means for the cure of leprosy, as stated by the sage Atreya. This is the first verse, which gives the reason, the various objects, characteristics, and symptoms of the disease, as well as the easy and difficult treatments, the elimination of its causes, and the attainment of peace. It is presented for the sake of instruction in this chapter of the Hutasana Agni Purana.

sloka: bhiṣagvariṣṭhaṃ surasiddhajuṣṭaṃ munīndramatryātmajamagniveśaḥ|  mahāgadasya śvayathoryathāvat prakoparūpapraśamānapṛcchat||3||
translation: Then, Atreya, the lord, began to explain in detail the treatment (of Mahagada) as requested.

sloka: tasmai jagādāgadavedasindhupravartanādripravaro'trijastān|  vātādibhedāttrividhasya samyaṅnijānijaikāṅgajasarvajasya||4||
translation: To the most excellent among physicians, who is favored by the best of the gods and siddhas, and who is the son of Atri and Agni, Mahagadasya, in his true form as a remedy for anger, inquiry was made.

sloka: śuddhyāmayābhaktakṛśābalānāṃ kṣārāmlatīkṣṇoṣṇagurūpasevā|  dadhyāmamṛcchākavirodhiduṣṭagaropasṛṣṭānnaniṣevaṇaṃ ca||5||  arśāṃsyaceṣṭā na ca dehaśuddhirmarmopaghāto viṣamā prasūtiḥ|  mithyopacāraḥ pratikarmaṇāṃ ca nijasya hetuḥ śvayathoḥ pradiṣṭaḥ||6||
translation: To that [supreme being] whom the Vedas, rivers, and the best of mountains such as Meru have praised, I now speak of the manifestations of his inherent power, which is one yet divided into all beings and their individual aspects. This power neither causes impurity in the body nor hampers its proper functioning; it does not lead to any adverse consequences; it is not a falsehood or mere pretense; and it is not contrary to the performance of prescribed duties.

sloka: bāhyāstvaco dūṣayitā'bhighātaḥ kāṣṭhāśmaśastrāgniviṣāyasādyaiḥ [1] |  āgantuhetuḥtrividho nijaśca sarvārdhagātrāvayavāśritatvāt||7||
translation: The three types of impurities that can corrupt from within or externally are caused by the consumption of incompatible food, misuse of the senses, and improper digestion of food; all of which stem from one's own actions.

sloka: bāhyāḥ sirāḥ prāpya yadā kaphāsṛkpittāni sandūṣayatīha vāyuḥ|  tairbaddhamārgaḥ sa tadā visarpannutsedhaliṅgaṃ śvayathuṃ karoti||8||  uraḥsthitairūrdhvamadhastu [1] vāyoḥ sthānasthitairmadhyagataistu madhye|  sarvāṅgagaḥ sarvagataiḥ kvacitsthairdoṣaiḥ kvacit syācchvayathustadākhyaḥ||9||
translation: When the air, having entered the external vessels, causes the mucus, bile, and phlegm to coagulate, then the path being obstructed, it makes the body cough. The body may be affected by faults situated in various locations either internally or externally; such a condition is known as shvayathu (cough) [9]. In the body, the air resides above in the head, in the middle of the limbs, and below in the belly; it can be affected by faults located in all parts of the body or present throughout the body.

sloka: ūṣmā tathā syāddavathuḥ sirāṇāmāyāma ityeva ca pūrvarūpam|
translation: Upon reaching the siras (blood vessels) through the bahyas (external pathways), when the vayu (wind) carries away the kapha-srikh Pittani (phlegm and bile) that had clogged the previously mentioned pathway, then the nut (tube or conduit) becomes unblocked and straightened.

sloka: sarvastridoṣo'dhikadoṣaliṅgaistacchabdamabhyeti bhiṣagjitaṃ ca||10||
translation: Just as excessive sweating on the head is a sign of a greater illness, so too does the experienced physician recognize the earlier form (of the disease).

sloka: sagauravaṃ syādanavasthitatvaṃ sotsedhamuṣmā'tha sirātanutvam|  salomaharṣā'ṅgavivarṇatā ca sāmānyaliṅgaṃ śvayathoḥ pradiṣṭam||11||
translation: The one who is free from all the three primary defects and has overcome the secondary ones, is proclaimed as fit for self-realization.

sloka: calastanutvakparuṣo'ruṇo'sitaḥ prasuptiharṣārtiyuto'nimittataḥ|  praśāmyati pronnamati prapīḍito divābalī ca śvayathuḥ samīraṇāt||12||
translation: Endowed with heaviness or solemnity, you (the sun) subside, having lost its brilliant color and heat; your form reddens, and your rays become pale and commonplace; this is the sun's setting, as has been ordained.

sloka: mṛduḥ sagandho'sitapītarāgavān bhramajvarasvedatṛṣāmadānvitaḥ|  ya uṣyate sparśarugakṣirāgakṛt [1] sa pittaśotho bhṛśadāhapākavān||13||
translation: The one who is easily agitated, thin, with rough skin, copper-colored, bluish-black, and often lethargic; whose cause is an aversion to touch, is pacified during the day, strong, and moves in the wind - this person is highly bilious.

sloka: guruḥ sthiraḥ pāṇḍurarocakānvitaḥ prasekanidrāvamivahnimāndyakṛt|  sa kṛcchrajanmapraśamo nipīḍito na connamedrātribalī kaphātmakaḥ||14||
translation: The steadfast teacher, fair-complexioned and effulgent, is like the flame of a lamp undisturbed by wind. Afflicted by the hardship of repeated births, he is not shaken by the three-fold maladies (of egoism, attachment, and ignorance) that are born of phlegm (sloth), bile (passion), and wind (delusion).

sloka: kṛśasya rogairabalasya yo bhavedupadravairvā vamipūrvakairyutaḥ|  sa hanti marmānugato'tha rājimān parisraveddhīnabalasya sarvagaḥ||15||
translation: The steadfast and fair one, dispelling darkness, associated with the elimination of ailments, destroys the vital points and reduces the powerless enemy to submission, who is tormented by hardships, tranquil, unagitated, and composed of phlegm-like nature, and unable to remain still during the night.

sloka: ahīnamāṃsasya ya ekadoṣajo navo balasthasya sukhaḥ sa sādhane|  nidānadoṣartuviparyayakramairupācarettaṃ baladoṣakālavit||16||
translation: The one who becomes the cause of afflictions for a weak person, already tormented by diseases, is indeed an enemy to the life of that ninefold strong person, who, while being ill-behaved, overwhelms with pride, and roams around as if omnipresent.

sloka: athāmajaṃ laṅghanapācanakramairviśodhanairulbaṇadoṣamāditaḥ|  śirogataṃ śīrṣavirecanairadho [4] virecanairūrdhvaharaistathordhvajam||17||  upācaret snehabhavaṃ virūkṣaṇaiḥ prakalpayet snehavidhiṃ ca rūkṣaje|  vibaddhaviṭke'nilaje nirūhaṇaṃ ghṛtaṃ tu pittānilaje satiktakam||18||  payaśca mūrcchāratidāhatarṣite viśodhanīye tu samūtramiṣyate|  kaphotthitaṃ kṣārakaṭūṣṇasaṃyutaiḥ samūtratakrāsavayuktibhirjayet||19||
translation: The one who is free from impurities should first clean the undigested food in the body with emetics and purgatives. Then, at the head, using sneha (medicinal oils or ghee), he should apply it downwards, and then upwards; in this way, he should perform udvartana (massage) on the upper part of the body. For the lower part, he should prepare a kalpana (paste/powder) with herbs that have the capacity to absorb moisture and apply it. For the accumulated doshas (imbalances) in the fatty tissue, ghrta (clarified butter) is recommended; for those in the muscle tissue, payasam (rice porridge) is prescribed; for those in the blood, vamana (emesis) and virechana (purgation) are advised. For kapha (phlegm) that has risen too high, he should use a kashaya (decoction) made from katu (pungent), tikta (bitter), and ushna (hot) herbs, along with krishara (chalk).

sloka: grāmyābjānūpaṃ piśitamabalaṃ śuṣkaśākaṃ navānnaṃ  gauḍaṃ piṣṭānnaṃ dadhi tilakṛtaṃ [5] vijjalaṃ [6] madyamamlam|  dhānā vallūraṃ samaśanamatho gurvasātmyaṃ vidāhi  svapnaṃ cārātrau śvayathugadavān varjayenmaithunaṃ ca||20||
translation: Should perform with affection and create the rules for extracting the oil bound by wind from the dry stalks , consume curd mixed with rice , clarified butter , and sesame seeds . Avoid sexual intercourse , sleep during the daytime , feces , urine , fasting , and exhaustion . Also avoid food that causes unconsciousness or increased thirst due to its astringent , pungent , or hot qualities, combined with the rising of phlegm and bile and the production of digestive juices.

sloka: vyoṣaṃ trivṛttiktakarohiṇī ca sāyorajaskā triphalārasena|  pītaṃ kaphotthaṃ śamayettu śophaṃ gavyena mūtreṇa harītakī ca||21||
translation: Utilizing three-fold actions, the one who is expert in administering treatments, combined with decoctions of Triphala and Haritaki, along with cow's urine, can alleviate phlegm-related disorders.

sloka: harītakīnāgaradevadāru sukhāmbuyuktaṃ sapunarnavaṃ vā|  sarvaṃ pibettriṣvapi mūtrayuktaṃ snātaśca jīrṇe payasā'nnamadyāt||22||
translation: One should drink the decoction of Haritaki, prepared with three ingredients, namely the juices of Rohini and Tiktaka fruits, as well as gavyena , and also mixed with salt water , in order to alleviate all three doshas - vata, pitta, and kapha ; even if one has bathed and is free from urine and excreta . It is recommended to consume this mixture when it becomes slightly warm , as it would help in better digestion.

sloka: punarnavānāgaramustakalkān prasthena dhīraḥ payasā'kṣamātrān|  mayūrakaṃ māgadhikāṃ samūlāṃ sanāgarāṃ vā prapibet savāte||23||
translation: Calm and steadfast, one should drink the decoction of haritaki and the water infused with the essence of a new city or forest tree, along with the early morning urine and bathing water, even from the mayura and magadhi plants, and also from all other sources.

sloka: dantītrivṛttryūṣaṇacitrakairvā payaḥ śṛtaṃ doṣaharaṃ pibennā|  dviprasthamātraṃ tu palārdhikaistairardhāvaśiṣṭaṃ pavane sapitte||24||
translation: Again, or not with city-dust smeared feet, the wise one should drink in measured sips the purifying milk, offered in a vessel made from a split coconut shell, only half-filled.

sloka: saśuṇṭhipītadrurasaṃ prayojyaṃ śyāmorubūkoṣaṇasādhitaṃ vā|  tvagdāruvarṣābhumahauṣadhairvā guḍūcikānāgaradantibhirvā||25||
translation: With a mouth rinsed with the three-fold dental mixture, one should drink milk, equal to two and a half prasthas (a measure), mixed with ardha avashishtha (leftover after measuring) of pala (16 digits) and ardhika (eighth part of a digit) units of measures, filtered through a cloth, and processed with herbs like guduci (Tinospora cordifolia), in order to eliminate the dosha (impurity) from the shritam (chest).

sloka: saptāhamauṣṭraṃ tvathavā'pi māsaṃ payaḥ pibedbhojanavārivarjī|  gavyaṃ samūtraṃ mahiṣīpayo vā kṣīrāśano mūtramatho gavāṃ vā||26||
translation: Either in the seventh or eighth month of pregnancy, one should drink milk or partake a meal without any liquids. Alternatively, one may consume ghee made from the milk of a black cow, or curd, or butter milk; or, if nothing else is available, even the urine and dung of a cow.

sloka: takraṃ pibedvā gurubhinnavarcāḥ savyoṣasauvarcalamākṣikaṃ ca|  guḍābhayāṃ vā guḍanāgaraṃ vā sadoṣabhinnāmavibaddhavarcāḥ||27||
translation: Drinking curd, either from the churning of seven ingredients or from a cow that is pure and well-nourished, or consuming ghee and milk from such a cow, one's complexion becomes bright and radiant.

sloka: viḍvātasaṅge payasā rasairvā prāgbhaktamadyādurubūkatailam [7] |  srotovibandhe'gnirucipraṇāśe madyānyariṣṭāṃśca pibet sujātān||28||
translation: With water mixed with the essence of curd, one should drink during the initial part of the day; or, with alcohol that is refined and fragrant, one should drink at the end of the day, consuming the best kind.

sloka: gaṇḍīrabhallātakacitrakāṃśca vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ bṛhatīdvayaṃ ca|  dviprasthikaṃ gomayapāvakena droṇe pacet kūrcikamastunastu [8] ||29||  tribhāgaśeṣaṃ ca supūtaśītaṃ droṇena tat prākṛtamastunā ca|  sitopalāyāśca śatena yuktaṃ lipte ghaṭe citrakapippalīnām||30||  vaihāyase sthāpitamādaśāhāt prayojayaṃstadvinihanti śophān|  bhagandarārśaḥkrimikuṣṭhamehān vaivarṇyakārśyānilahikkanaṃ ca||31||  iti gaṇḍīrādyariṣṭaḥ
translation:
With a mixture of Gandiri, ballataka, and citraka, along with vyosa, viddanga, bṛhati two in number,
In a pot, cooked thoroughly with droṇa (ghee) and cow dung, that Kurcika is to be offered;
The remaining portion, divided into three parts, mixed with well-prepared suputa shita,
Along with one hundred sitopala and applied on the pot, adorned with citrakapippalina.
Established in the sky, propelled by the force of Meru, moves upwards;
Affected by bhagandara, arsha, krimi, kustha, meha, vaivarnya, kilasa, and anila.
Thus is the preparation of Gandiri, along with other ingredients.

sloka: kāśmaryadhātrīmaricābhayākṣadrākṣāphalānāṃ [9] ca sapippalīnām|  śataṃ śataṃ jīrṇaguḍāttulāṃ [10] ca saṅkṣudya kumbhe madhunā pralipte||32||  saptāhamuṣṇe dviguṇaṃ tu śīte sthitaṃ jaladroṇayutaṃ pibennā|  śophān vibandhān kaphavātajāṃśca nihantyariṣṭo'ṣṭaśato'gnikṛcca||33||  ityaṣṭaśato'riṣṭaḥ
translation: Having mixed a hundred measures of refined sugar with the remaining third portion of the curd in an earthen pot, one should consume it in seven portions at a time, doubling this quantity in cold weather. This concoction destroys phlegm, wind, bile, and other causes of disease such as ringworm, itching, leprosy, consumption, and dysentery.

sloka: punarnave dve ca bale sapāṭhe dantīṃ [11] guḍūcīmatha citrakaṃ ca|  nidigdhikāṃ ca tripalāni paktvā droṇāvaśeṣe salile tatastam||34||  pūtvā rasaṃ dve ca guḍāt purāṇāttule madhuprasthayutaṃ suśītam|  māsaṃ nidadhyādghṛtabhājanasthaṃ palle yavānāṃ paratastu māsāt||35||  cūrṇīkṛtairardhapalāṃśikaistaṃ patratvagelāmaricāmbulohaiḥ [12] |  gandhānvitaṃ kṣaudraghṛtapradigdhe jīrṇe pibed vyādhibalaṃ samīkṣya||36||
translation: Seven handfuls of water, twice, I drink, heated and cooled; in case of illness, one should consider drinking boiled water, mixed with clarified butter and paste of powders. This is the rule of eightfold treatment, as mentioned in scriptures, for removing the eight faults caused by vata, kapha, and pitta doshas.

sloka: hṛtpāṇḍurogaṃ śvayathuṃ pravṛddhaṃ plīhajvarārocakamehagulmān|  bhagandaraṃ ṣaḍjaṭharāṇi kāsaṃ śvāsaṃ grahaṇyāmayakuṣṭhakaṇḍūḥ||37||  śākhānilaṃ baddhapurīṣatāṃ ca hikkāṃ kilāsaṃ ca halīmakaṃ ca|  kṣipraṃ jayedvarṇabalāyurojastejonvito māṃsarasānnabhojī||38||  iti punarnavādyariṣṭaḥ
translation: Having reflected on the ancient recipe of two parts sugar, one part clarified butter, and one part honey, mixed with a little curd and salt, one should quickly consume this nutritious and refreshing concoction made from grains, vessels, and barley, taken from elsewhere.

sloka: phalatrikaṃ dīpyakacitrakau ca sapippalīloharajo viḍaṅgam|  cūrṇīkṛtaṃ kauḍavikaṃ dviraṃśaṃ kṣaudraṃ purāṇasya tulāṃ guḍasya||39||  māsaṃ nidadhyādghṛtabhājanasthaṃ yaveṣu tāneva nihanti rogān|  ye cārśasāṃ pāṇḍuvikāriṇāṃ ca proktā hitāḥ śophiṣu te'pyariṣṭāḥ||40||  iti triphalādyariṣṭaḥ
translation: Consume each month a mixture of three myrobalans and other recommended ingredients for the benefit of pallor, bloating, indigestion, enlarged spleen, tumors, abscesses, consumption, diseases of the lungs, heart, skin, and joints; quickly it will overcome weakness, loss of appetite, strength, vitality, and youth. Again, I am not one who claims this to be a panacea.

sloka: kṛṣṇā sapāṭhā gajapippalī ca nidigdhikā citrakanāgare ca|  sapippalīmūlarajanyajājīmustaṃ ca cūrṇaṃ sukhatoyapītam||41||  hanyāttridoṣaṃ cirajaṃ ca śophaṃ kalkaśca bhūnimbamahauṣadhasya|  ayorajastryūṣaṇayāvaśūkacūrṇaṃ ca pītaṃ triphalārasena||42||
translation: In the city of Citrakanaga, one should crush and mix together pippali and ila, their resins, the powder of viḍaṅgam, kauḍavikam in two parts, the kernel of a mature triphala fruit, the amount of a tula measuring guḍa, and a mass of honey equal to it. When consumed regularly with ghṛta from a steady vessel, this mixture destroys the long-standing dosas, as well as the arśas and vikāriṇām diseases mentioned as beneficial for śophiṣu; even the three major arisṭa types are eliminated by this method.

sloka: kṣāradvayaṃ syāllavaṇāni catvāryayorajo vyoṣaphalatrike ca|  sapippalīmūlaviḍaṅgasāraṃ mustājamodāmaradārubilvam||43||  kaliṅgakāścitrakamūlapāṭhe yaṣṭyāhvayaṃ sātiviṣaṃ palāṃśam|  sahiṅgukarṣaṃ tvaṇuśuṣkacūrṇaṃ droṇaṃ tathā mūlakaśuṇṭhakānām||44||  syādbhasmanastat salilena sādhyamāloḍya yāvadghanamapradagdham|  styānaṃ tataḥ kolasamāṃ tu mātrāṃ kṛtvā suśuṣkāṃ vidhinopayuñjyāt||45||
translation: Of dark complexion, (he should eat) the mixed preparation of citraka and pippalī fruits, ground with liquids like water, milk, and ghee, free from impurities, and devoid of coarse husk; (then) dried cow dung, fine powder of nimba and mahā auṣadhi, and the bark of kalaṃka, after reducing them to a smooth consistency in a mortar.

sloka: plīhodaraśvitrahalīmakārśaḥpāṇḍvāmayārocakaśoṣaśophān|  visūcikāgulmagarāśmarīśca saśvāsakāsāḥ praṇudet sakuṣṭhāḥ||46||  iti kṣāraguḍikā
translation: A mixture of ingredients including alkaline substances such as lavaṇa, āryaya, aja, vyoṣa, moda, amara dāru, bilva, kaliṅga, citraka, yaṣṭī, and those that are fine-powdered like pāṭha, mūla, hiṅgu, karṣam, aṇu, śuṣka cūrṇa, droṇa, bhasmanaḥ, and mūlakashuṇṭhaka, when combined with salila, is to be cooked until it becomes thin like kola and then, after reducing to a proper consistency, should be used as per the prescription.

sloka: prayojayedārdrakanāgaraṃ vā tulyaṃ guḍenārdhapalābhivṛddhyā|  mātrā paraṃ pañcapalāni māsaṃ jīrṇe payo yūṣarasāśca bhaktam||47|| gulmodarārśaḥśvayathupramehāñ śvāsapratiśyālasakāvipākān|  sakāmalāśoṣamanovikārān kāsaṃ kaphaṃ caiva jayet prayogaḥ||48||
translation: To manage conditions such as bloating, indigestion, constipation, vitiligo, anal fissures, anemia, and poor eyesight, one should utilize a combination of ingredients that include kşara, gulika, and modaka, along with various herbs like triphala, viz., haritaki, bhibhitaki, and amalaki. Additionally, practices such as controlled breathing , regulating diet , and monitoring bodily functions are also recommended.

sloka: rasastathaivārdrakanāgarasya peyo'tha jīrṇe payasā'nnamadyāt|  jatvaśmajaṃ [13] ca triphalārasena hanyāttridoṣaṃ śvayathuṃ prasahya||49||  iti śilājatuprayogaḥ
translation: The mixture of equal parts of 20 parts of Ardraka and powdered Nagaram should be consumed with an increased amount of jaggery, after one month of cow's milk becoming sour. This use of Shilajitu eliminates the three doshas, alleviates gulma in the stomach and udara, suppresses the causes of vata-rougaha, kapha, and eliminates the unwanted transformations of kapha.

sloka: dvipañcamūlasya pacet kaṣāye kaṃse'bhayānāṃ ca śataṃ guḍasya|  lehe susiddhe'tha vinīya cūrṇaṃ vyoṣaṃ trisaugandhyamuṣāsthite ca||50||  prasthārdhamātraṃ madhunaḥ suśīte kiñcicca cūrṇādapi yāvaśūkāt|  ekābhayāṃ prāśya tataśca lehācchuktiṃ nihanti śvayathuṃ pravṛddham||51||  śvāsajvarārocakamehagulmaplīhatridoṣodarapāṇḍurogān|  kārśyāmavātāvasṛgamlapittavaivarṇyamūtrānilaśukradoṣān||52||  iti kaṃsaharītakī
translation: Thus, the usage of rock candy (silā-jatu) in the prescribed manner (prayogaḥ).

sloka: paṭolamūlāmaradārudantītrāyantipippalyabhayāviśālāḥ|  yaṣṭyāhvayaṃ tiktakarohiṇī ca sacandanā syānniculāni dārvī||53||  karṣonmitaistaiḥ kvathitaḥ kaṣāyo ghṛtena peyaḥ kuḍavena yuktaḥ|  vīsarpadāhajvarasannipātatṛṣṇāviṣāṇi śvayathuṃ ca hanti||54||
translation: With five pestle-like roots, boiling for a hundred [times] in a pot of castor oil and clarified butter, mixed with well-ground pieces of

sloka: sacitrakaṃ [14] dhānyayavānyajājīsauvarcalaṃ tryūṣaṇavetasāmlam|  bilvāt phalaṃ dāḍimayāvaśūkau sapippalīmūlamathāpi cavyam||55||  piṣṭvā'kṣamātrāṇi jalāḍhakena paktvā ghṛtaprasthamatha prayuñjyāt|  arśāṃsi gulmaṃ śvayathuṃ  kṛcchraṃ nihanti vahniṃ ca karoti dīptam||56||
translation: Grinding together patola root, amra, arjuna, triphala, pippali, bhayavisha, syamni, candana, dravanti, kasha, unmita, kvathita, kaṣaya, mixed with ghee, becomes an effective medicine against arsha, gulma, svayathu, kricchra, and also used to kindle fire and alleviate thirst, fever, snake bite, and other such ailments.

sloka: pibedghṛtaṃ vā'ṣṭaguṇāmbusiddhaṃ sacitrakakṣāramudāravīryam|  kalyāṇakaṃ vā'pi sapañcagavyaṃ tiktaṃ mahadvā'pyatha tiktakaṃ vā||57||
translation: Having churned the grains and measured one prastha of water, adding eight qualities to the clarified butter (ghrita), or preparing a drink made from five products of the cow that is either sweet or slightly bitter – either way, kindling the fire becomes necessary for cooking.

sloka: kṣīraṃ ghaṭe citrakakalkalipte dadhyāgataṃ sādhu vimathya tena|  tajjaṃ ghṛtaṃ citrakamūlagarbhaṃ takreṇa siddhaṃ śvayathughnamagryam||58||  arśo'tisārānilagulmamehāṃścaitannihantyagnibalapradaṃ [15] ca|  takreṇa cādyāt saghṛtena tena bhojyāni siddhāmathavā yavāgūm||59||  iti citrakaghṛtam
translation: Drink the clarified butter, which is siddha (well-prepared), having eight qualities, mixed with water. It is sweet (sacitra), sturdy (kaksuda), vigorous (vīrya), and auspicious (kalyāṇa). Even if it is pungent (tiktam) and strong (mahat), it can be consumed (bhojyam) after being mixed with water. It eliminates the ailments caused by vata, pitta, and kapha (agni-balapradaṃ ca).

sloka: jīvantyajājīśaṭipuṣkarāhvaiḥ sakāravīcitrakabilvamadhyaiḥ|  sayāvaśūkairbadarapramāṇairvṛkṣāmlayuktā ghṛtatailabhṛṣṭā||60||  arśo'tisārānilagulmaśophahṛdrogamandāgnihitā yavāgūḥ|  yā pañcakolairvidhinaiva [16] tena siddhā bhavet sā ca samā tayaiva||61||
translation: Mixing clarified butter with water in a vessel, along with citraka kalka, applied to curd that has just come, is considered proper. With this, when mixed with five ingredients in specific measures, it becomes perfect and the same becomes an excellent fat-reducer.

sloka: kulatthayūṣaśca sapippalīko maudgaśca satryūṣaṇayāvaśūkaḥ|  rasastathā viṣkirajāṅgalānāṃ sakūrmagodhāśikhiśallakānām||62||  suvarcalā gṛñjanakaṃ paṭolaṃ savāyasīmūlakavetranimbam|  śākārthināṃ śākamiti praśastaṃ bhojye purāṇaśca yavaḥ saśāliḥ||63||
translation: Made up of jujube, peepal, mango, and other trees, such as the madhuka, with fruits that are ripe, unripe, or falling, along with those bearing bilva and badara fruits, all mixed with ghee and oil, is the prescribed offering for the living beings mentioned in the previous verse (62). It is also recommended to consume barley and wheat as a part of this meal (63).

sloka: ābhyantaraṃ bheṣajamuktametadbarhirhitaṃ yacchṛṇu tadyathāvat|  snehān pradehān pariṣecanāni svedāṃśca vātaprabalasya kuryāt||64||
translation: This internal medicine, obtained from the Kulattha plant, listen to its description: the main application includes anointing with oil and heat treatment, especially in case of excess wind-related symptoms.

sloka: śaileyakuṣṭhāgurudārukauntītvakpadmakailāmbupalāśamustaiḥ|  priyaṅguthauṇeyakahemamāṃsītālīśapatraplavapatradhānyaiḥ||65||  śrīveṣṭakadhyāmakapippalībhiḥ spṛkkānakhaiścaiva yathopalābham|  vātānvite'bhyaṅgamuśanti tailaṃ siddhaṃ supiṣṭairapi ca pradeham||66||
translation: Listen to this recipe for an effective medical treatment: Inside , use a cure that is liberated from impurities. This is beneficial when applied with barley . Increase sweat if the wind is strong. Additionally, use pure oil and medicinal herbs , such as śrīveṣṭaka, kapikacchu, and pippali. Also, apply a paste made from priyaṅgu and uṇeyaka on the body. Follow this procedure for optimal results.

sloka: jalaiśca vāsārkakarañjaśigrukāśmaryapatrārjakajaiśca  siddhaiḥ|  svinno mṛdūṣṇai  ravitaptatoyaiḥ snātaśca gandhairanulepanīyaḥ||67||
translation: Washed with fragrant oils and adorned with divine unguents, anointed with medicinal plants such as Bilva, Priyangu, and Daru, massaged with various ointments, and smeared with paste made of Kushtha, Utpala, Musta, Padma, and Palasha - all properly prepared and chosen according to one's merit.

sloka: savetasāḥ kṣīravatāṃ drumāṇāṃ tvacaḥ samañjiṣṭhalatāmṛṇālāḥ|  sacandanāḥ padmakavālakau ca paitte pradehastu satailapākaḥ||68||  āktasya tenāmbu raviprataptaṃ sacandanaṃ sābhayapadmakaṃ ca|  snāne hitaṃ kṣīravatāṃ kaṣāyaḥ kṣīrodakaṃ candanalepanaṃ ca||69||
translation: Washed with water and anointed with fragrances, one who becomes softened by the gentle, warm rays of the sun, becomes capable of producing shoots similar to those of graceful kasha, arjaka, shigru, and other plants. The bathing in such water and application of sandalwood paste is beneficial for the growth of excellent quality rice and lotus, and for removing the impurities from it.

sloka: kaphe tu kṛṣṇāsikatāpurāṇapiṇyākaśigrutvagumāpralepaḥ|  kulatthaśuṇṭhījalamūtrasekaścaṇḍāgurubhyāmanulepanaṃ ca||70||
translation: The bark of a tree similar to a Kshira vine, shredded and soaked in water heated by the sun, along with the saffron-like Kashaayah, applied to the skin resembling the sheath of a drum, having the same consistency as the soft petals of a lotus, mixed with Chandanam, is beneficial for bathing.

sloka: bibhītakānāṃ phalamadhyalepaḥ sarveṣu dāhārtiharaḥ pradiṣṭaḥ|  yaṣṭyāhvamustaiḥ sakapitthapatraiḥ sacandanaistatpiḍakāsu lepaḥ||71||
translation: The cooling paste of black myrobalan and iron filings, prescribed for all burns, is made with the powder of kulattha and dry shunthi, mixed with water and urine, and applied with the hands anointed with ghee and dusted with powdered candana.

sloka: rāsnāvṛṣārkatriphalāviḍaṅgaṃ śigrutvaco mūṣikaparṇikā ca|   nimbārjakau vyāghranakhaḥ sadūrvā suvarcalā tiktakarohiṇī ca||72||  sakākamācī bṛhatī sakuṣṭhā punarnavā citrakanāgare ca|  unmardanaṃ śophiṣu mūtrapiṣṭaṃ śastastathā mūlakatoyasekaḥ||73||
translation: For those feared by insects, the following are prescribed as remedies: fruit as a balm applied to the middle of the affliction, which burns and alleviates all pain; the young shoot of the mustard tree, the leaves of the sacred fig tree, and the bark of the black myrobalan tree; juice extracted from the roots of costus and punarnava plants; and a decoction made from the flowers of the citrakanaga plant.

sloka: śophāstu gātrāvayavāśritā ye te sthānadūṣyākṛtināmabhedāt|  anekasaṅkhyāḥ  katicicca teṣāṃ nidarśanārthaṃ gadato nibodha||74||
translation: Of those who are stainers of the various parts of the body, such as the head , arms , and legs , including those who touch the skin , leaves , ants , and others , as well as those who resemble the bark of a tree , tiger and its claws , and those who have habits similar to the elephant , dog , cat , and deer , listen, for the sake of identifying them, about the characteristics of their excretions that are processed , cooked , as well as their spitting and washing/bathing .
