sloka: pippalyaścandanaṃ mustamuśīraṃ kaṭurohiṇī|  kaliṅgakāstāmalakī sārivā'tiviṣā sthirā||219||  drākṣāmalakabilvāni trāyamāṇā nidigdhikā|  siddhamitairghṛtaṃ sadyo jīrṇajvaramapohati||220||  kṣayaṃ kāsaṃ śiraḥśūlaṃ pārśvaśūlaṃ halīmakam|  aṃsābhitāpamāgniṃ ca viṣamaṃ sanniyacchati||221||
translation: All these resins, when combined with sarpiṣa, can alleviate all kinds of impurities, namely fever caused by an imbalance in the bodily humors, and are beneficial.

sloka: vāsāṃ guḍūcīṃ triphalāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ yavāsakam|  paktvā tena kaṣāyeṇa payasā dviguṇena ca||222||  pippalīmustamṛdvīkācandanotpalanāgaraiḥ|  kalkīkṛtaiśca vipaceddhṛtaṃ jīrṇajvarāpaham||223||
translation: Prepared using the juices of pippalī, candana, musta, usheera, katu, rohini, kalinga, kashta, and amalaki, mixed with sesame, ghruta, and siddhamita, as well as with fresh bilva, draksha, and urali, this concoction quickly cures chronic fever, eliminating it from the body, subduing bile, wind, and phlegm, and pacifying burning sensations, poison, and other ailments.

sloka: balāṃ śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ bṛhatīṃ kalasīṃ dhāvanīṃ sthirām|  nimbaṃ parpaṭakaṃ mustaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ durālabhām||224||  kṛtvā kaṣāyaṃ peṣyārthe dadyāttāmalakīṃ śaṭīm|  drākṣāṃ puṣkaramūlaṃ ca medāmāmalakāni ca||225||  ghṛtaṃ payaśca tat siddhaṃ sarpirjvaraharaṃ param|  kṣayakāsaśiraḥśūlapārśvaśūlāṃsatāpanut  ||226||
translation: Prepare a concoction by boiling the three fruits of Guḍūcī, triphalā, and Yavāsaka, mixed with milk and two times the quantity of water. Add to it, crushed Musta, Mṛdvīka, Candana, Utpalā, Nāgarai, and Kalkī, all reduced to powder. This potion, sipped regularly, alleviates consumptive fevers and other chronic ailments.

sloka: jvaribhyo bahudoṣebhya ūrdhvaṃ cādhaśca buddhimān|  dadyāt saṃśodhanaṃ kāle kalpe yadupadekṣyate||227||
translation: With a clear mind, one should perform purification at the specified time, separating and removing from pitta fever the strength of a wolf's teeth, the greatness of a mortar and pestle, the firmness of a nimba fruit, the instability of a creeping vine, the hard-to-find quality of a durva grass, the bitterness of an amalaki fruit, the sourness of a shati fruit, the sweetness of a grape, and the coolness of a lotus root. This is what eliminates the fever's harmful effects, reducing its severity, destroying it at the root, and curing the cough, wasting of the body, and headache that accompany it.

sloka: madanaṃ pippalībhirvā kaliṅgairmadhukena vā|  yuktamuṣṇāmbunā peyaṃ vamanaṃ jvaraśāntaye||228||  kṣaudrāmbunā rasenekṣorathavā lavaṇāmbunā|  jvare pracchardanaṃ śastaṃ madyairvā tarpaṇena vā||229||
translation: For fever arising from an accumulation of many impurities, both internally and externally, the intelligent one should administer, at the appropriate time, a purgative using decoctions of pepper and kaliṅga (a type of myrobalan) or simply with water, or by inducing sweating through the use of alcohol; or, one may appease it with madira (an alcoholic beverage).

sloka: mṛdvīkāmalakānāṃ vā rasaṃ praskandanaṃ pibet|  rasamāmalakānāṃ vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ jvarāpaham||230||
translation: One should drink the sap of bitter gourd (kaliṅgai) or Indian coral tree (pippalī) that has been boiled with honey (madhukena) and either hot water (uṣṇa ambunā) or regular water (vamanam), to alleviate thirst and fever. Alternatively, one can consume the juice of Indian radish (kṣaudra rasena) or rock salt (lavana) to treat fever with burning sensation. Drinking alcohol (madyaiḥ tarpaṇena) is also recommended as a remedy for certain types of fevers.

sloka: lihyādvā traivṛtaṃ cūrṇaṃ saṃyuktaṃ madhusarpiṣā|  pibedvā kṣaudramāvāpya saghṛtaṃ triphalārasam||231||  āragvadhaṃ vā payasā mṛdvīkānāṃ rasena vā|  trivṛtāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ vā payasā jvaritaḥ pibet||232||  jvarādvimucyate pītvā mṛdvīkābhiḥ sahābhayām|  payo'nupānamuṣṇaṃ vā pītvā drākṣārasaṃ naraḥ||233||
translation: One may drink the liquid produced from crushing and grinding three myrobalans, mixed with honey or clarified butter, or the juice of āmalaka fruits; such a person is freed from fever after drinking it, either mixed with mṛdvīka water or on its own.

sloka: kāsācchvāsācchiraḥśūlātpārśvaśūlāccirajvarāt|  mucyate jvaritaḥ pītvā pañcamūlīśṛtaṃ payaḥ||234||
translation: By drinking the sweet, buttery mixture of the five kinds of sap obtained from the roots of the medicinal plant, a person afflicted with fever can be freed from it, when drunk in conjunction with a decoction made from the three fruits of the tree and warm milk, taken together with the leaves of the drumstick plant, which promotes healing.

sloka: eraṇḍamūlotkvathitaṃ jvarāt saparikartikāt| payo vimucyate pītvā tadvadbilvaśalāṭubhiḥ||235||
translation: One who is afflicted with severe fever is freed from it by drinking water drawn from the root of a palm tree, extracted using a swing and rope.

sloka: trikaṇṭakabalāvyāghrīguḍanāgarasādhitam|  varcomūtravibandhaghnaṃ śophajvaraharaṃ payaḥ||236||
translation: Consuming the water boiled with Eranda stem and Bilva leaves liberates one from fever, just as drinking that [water] releases [the juice of] the fruit fully ripened by its own nature.

sloka: sanāgaraṃ samṛdvīkaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram|  śṛtaṃ payaḥ sakharjūraṃ pipāsājvaranāśanam||237||
translation: Overcoming the three-pronged obstacles (of) sand, stone, and salt-encrusted shells, (it is) called a well-constructed harbor, (that which) neutralizes the thirst and fever, and yields sweet, clear water.

sloka: caturguṇenāmbhasā vā śṛtaṃ jvaraharaṃ payaḥ|  dhāroṣṇaṃ vā payaḥ sadyo vātapittajvaraṃ jayet||238||
translation: Swiftly prepared with salty-bitter ingredients, cow's milk or buttermilk can cure fever caused by an imbalance of the wind and bile elements.

sloka: jīrṇajvarāṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ payaḥ praśamanaṃ param| peyaṃ taduṣṇaṃ śītaṃ vā yathāsvaṃ bheṣajaiḥ śṛtam||239||
translation: Of all the treatments for chronic fever, consuming large quantities of water, either cold or at room temperature, as prescribed by the physician, is the most effective.

sloka: prayojayejjvaraharānnirūhān sānuvāsanān|  pakvāśayagate doṣe vakṣyante ye ca siddhiṣu||240||
translation: The complete remedy for all types of fever is prepared from milk, which is to be consumed hot or cold as per one's preference, as stated in those texts dealing with the achievement of successes (such as alchemical siddhis).

sloka: paṭolāriṣṭapatrāṇi sośīraścaturaṅgulaḥ|  hrīberaṃ rohiṇī tiktā śvadaṃṣṭrā madanāni ca||241||  sthirā balā ca tat sarvaṃ payasyardhodake śṛtam|  kṣīrāvaśeṣaṃ niryūhaṃ saṃyuktaṃ madhusarpiṣā||242||  kalkairmadanamustānāṃ pippalyā madhukasya ca|  vatsakasya ca saṃyuktaṃ bastiṃ dadyājjvarāpaham||243||
translation: Generally, one who seeks to cure a fever should defeat the causes of disease, eliminate residual impurities, and expel accumulated wastes that have reached maturity in the body. This is what will be described as the means for achieving success in this context.

sloka: śuddhe mārge hṛte doṣe viprasanneṣu dhātuṣu|  gatāṅgaśūlo laghvaṅgaḥ sadyo bhavati vijvaraḥ||244||
translation: Upon the pure path, with impurities discarded and elements in a stable state, one can quickly become free from fever, by consuming a concoction made of usheera, patala, arista,

sloka: āragvadhamuśīraṃ ca madanasya phalaṃ tathā|  catasraḥ parṇinīścaiva [1] niryūhamupakalpayet||245||  priyaṅgurmadanaṃ mustaṃ śatāhvā madhuyaṣṭikā|  kalkaḥ sarpirguḍaḥ kṣaudraṃ jvaraghno bastiruttamaḥ||246||
translation: Upon following the pure path, free from defects and with the virtuous traits established in the elements of one's body, swiftness in limbs is attained, leading to quick recovery from illness.

sloka: guḍūcīṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca candanaṃ madhukaṃ vṛṣam|  sthirāṃ balāṃ pṛśniparṇīṃ madanaṃ ceti sādhayet||247||  rasaṃ jāṅgalamāṃsasya rasena sahitaṃ bhiṣak|  pippalīphalamustānāṃ kalkena madhukasya ca||248||  īṣatsalavaṇaṃ yuktyā nirūhaṃ madhusarpiṣā|  jvarapraśamanaṃ dadyādbalasvedarucipradam||249||
translation: One should prepare with priyaangu, madana, and musta, along with 100 ants, madhu and yashtikA, mixed with kalka of sarpi, guDA, and kshaudra, for alleviating jvara. Use basti, the best among medicines, and īṣatsala + lavana, niruha type, and madhusarkisha for reducing symptoms in vata and pitta disorders.

sloka: jīvantīṃ madhukaṃ medāṃ pippalīṃ madanaṃ vacām|  ṛddhiṃ rāsnāṃ balāṃ viśvaṃ [2] śatapuṣpāṃ śatāvarīm||250||  piṣṭvā kṣīraṃ jalaṃ sarpistailaṃ ca vipacedbhiṣak|  ānuvāsanikaṃ snehametaṃ vidyājjvarāpaham||251||
translation: By using a firm and strong pippalī, along with the juices of guḍūcī and madhuka, which are being treated and prepared by an expert physician, one should prepare a concoction. This mixture, when combined with the kalka of madhukasya's fruit mustard seeds and a little bit of salt, is capable of pacifying jvara (fever) while also increasing strength (bala), promoting sweating (sveda), and improving digestion (ruci).

sloka: paṭolapicumardābhyāṃ guḍūcyā madhukena ca|  madanaiśca śṛtaḥ sneho jvaraghnamanuvāsanam||252||
translation: Having churned together curd, water, ghee, and sesame oil, the doctor should administer this cooling mixture as a remedy to alleviate fever.

sloka: candanāgurukāśmaryapaṭolamadhukotpalaiḥ|  siddhaḥ sneho jvaraharaḥ snehabastiḥ praśasyate||253||
translation: Prepared with Patola and Chandana, along with honey and Madhuka, the ointment that cures fever is called Sneha. It is praised as a potent remedy.

sloka: yaduktaṃ bheṣajādhyāye vimāne rogabheṣaje|  śirovirecanaṃ kuryādyuktijñastajjvarāpaham||254||  yacca nāvanikaṃ tailaṃ yāśca tailaṃ yāśca prāgdhūmavartayaḥ|  mātrāśitīye nirdiṣṭāḥ prayojyāstā jvareṣvapi||255||
translation: For the treatment of fever, one should use a medicated enema made with a decoction of bark from trees such as sandalwood, kasha, kapikachhu, patala, and madhuka, along with sesame oil and suitable amounts of ghee and honey. (254-255)

sloka: abhyaṅgāṃśca pradehāṃśca pariṣekāṃśca kārayet|  yathābhilāṣaṃ śītoṣṇaṃ vibhajya dvividhaṃ jvaram||256|| sahasradhautaṃ sarpirvā tailaṃ vā candanādikam|  dāhajvarapraśamanaṃ dadyādabhyañjanaṃ bhiṣak||257||
translation: As instructed in the chapter of treatment, the physician should apply ointments and pour liquids, dividing the fever into two types according to desire and whether it is hot or cold. He should give oil or sandalwood paste, whose smoke has been specified, as a remedy for fevers that are a thousand times worse.

sloka: bhavanti cātra  pauṣkareṣu suśīteṣu padmotpaladaleṣu ca|  kadalīnāṃ ca patreṣu kṣaumeṣu vimaleṣu ca||260||
translation: In the cool season, during the dew-fresh mornings on lotus leaves and also on the golden banana leaves, one should perform oil anointment and sprinkling as desired, according to the two types of treatment for thousand-times purified ghee or oil with sandalwood and other cooling substances, which alleviate burning fever.

sloka: candanodakaśīteṣu śīte  dhārāgṛhe'pi vā|  himāmbusikte sadane dāhārtaḥ  saṃviśet sukham||261||
translation: Pleasure is experienced when one sets up residence in cool groves of pauṣkara trees, with their lotus and blue water lily-filled ponds, and on the clean, clear patras of banana plants.

sloka: hemaśaṅkhapravālānāṃ maṇīnāṃ mauktikasya ca|  candanodakaśītānāṃ saṃsparśānurasān  spṛśet||262||  sragbhirnīlotpalaiḥ padmairvyajanairvividhairapi|  śītavātāvahairvyajjyeccandanodakavarṣibhiḥ  ||263||
translation: In the abodes where sandalwood paste and cool water are available, one who is suffering from the heat can find comfort by sprinkling or coming into contact with such drizzles of water. Also, by using various types of fans made with fragrant flowers and leaves along with cool breezes.

sloka: nadyastaḍāgāḥ padminyo hradāśca vimalodakāḥ|  avagāhe hitā dāhatṛṣṇāglānijvarāpahāḥ||264||
translation: Touching with the cool water of conch, pearl, and elephant goad, as well as sandalwood, adorned with various blue lotuses, water lilies, and white lilies, and cooling breezes, all of which are cool, is beneficial.

sloka: priyāḥ pradakṣiṇācārāḥ pramadāścandanokṣitāḥ|  sāntvayeyuḥ paraiḥ kāmairmaṇimauktikabhūṣaṇāḥ||265||
translation: Pure waters (lakes, rivers, ponds, etc.) that are pleasant to look at, unpolluted, and capable of alleviating thirst, fever, and other afflictions should be approached with devotion.

sloka: śītāni cānnapānāni śītānyupavanāni ca|  vāyavaścandrapādāśca śītā dāhajvarāpahāḥ||266||
translation: Cool drinks and shady groves, along with cool breezes and the moon's soothing rays, effectively alleviate the fiery heat. Likewise, pleasant behavior, restraint, tranquility, sandalwood paste, and jewelry such as pearls can also soothe and delight the mind.

sloka: bhavanti cātra  trayodaśavidhaḥ svedaḥ svedādhyāye nidarśitaḥ| mātrākālavidā yuktaḥ sa ca śītajvarāpahaḥ||268||
translation: Cool foods and beverages, parkland breezes, and the feet of the moon-god, all possessing coolness, can alleviate fever, as described in the chapter on sweat.

sloka: sā kuṭī tacca śayanaṃ taccāvacchādanaṃ jvaram|  śītaṃ praśamayantyāśu dhūpāścāgurujā ghanāḥ||269||
translation: Here, sweat of thirteen types, as described in the text, arising from physical and mental exertion, is capable of alleviating cold and fever when used appropriately with time and quantity.

sloka: cārūpacitagātryaśca taruṇyo yauvanoṣmaṇā|  āśleṣācchamayantyāśu pramadāḥ śiśirajvaram||270||
translation: With her elegant form, embracing the coolness of the evening and driving away summer's heat, she, the bed of rejuvenation, spreads soothing sandalwood smoke.

sloka: svedanānyannapānāni vātaśleṣmaharāṇi ca|  śītajvaraṃ jayantyāśu saṃsargabalayojanāt||271||
translation: Beautifully adorned and youthful bodies are made weak by the close embrace of lust and carelessness, leading to wasting away and susceptibility to cold-induced fever.

sloka: vātaje śramaje caiva purāṇe kṣataje jvare|  laṅghanaṃ na hitaṃ vidyācchamanaistānupācaret||272||
translation: Sweating, other liquids should not be consumed in cases of injury, chronic ailments, or fever; such restriction is beneficial and promotes quick recovery.

sloka: vikṣipyāmāśayoṣmāṇaṃ yasmādgatvā rasaṃ nṛṇām|  jvaraṃ kurvanti doṣāstu hīyate'gnibalaṃ tataḥ||273||
translation: The weakening of the ancient vital air and exhaustion , which are harmful and cause fever , occurs when one neglects to follow the proper treatment for wounds and does not take care of the ancillary practices . This results in the diminishment of Agni's strength within humans , leading to a disrupted mental state and depletion of their essential vitality .

sloka: yathā prajvalito vahniḥ sthālyāmindhanavānapi|  na pacatyodanaṃ samyaganilaprerito bahiḥ||274||
translation: Even a well-kindled fire does not consume dry fuel completely if it is not supplied with enough oxygen from outside; similarly, the bodily strength of people is depleted by the internal heat (of digestion) caused by the food they eat.

sloka: paktisthānāttathā doṣairūṣmā kṣipto bahirnṛṇām|  na pacatyabhyavahṛtaṃ kṛcchrāt pacati vā laghu||275||
translation: Just as a blazing fire, fueled with wood, does not cook food externally nor can it cook when inappropriately fed or insufficiently fanned by the wind.

sloka: ato'gnibalarakṣārthaṃ laṅghanādikramo hitaḥ|  saptāhena hi pacyante saptadhātugatā malāḥ||276||
translation: Therefore, for the protection from fire, moving around it in a specific manner is recommended; indeed, the malas residing in the seven elements of the body are cooked and eliminated through this process.

sloka: nirāmaścāpyataḥ prokto jvaraḥ prāyo'ṣṭame'hani|  udīrṇadoṣastvalpāgniraśnan guru viśeṣataḥ||277||
translation: Rooted in the seventh form of fire , agni, this weakness-inducing dosha can be eliminated through special measures such as pacyante, when there is a lack of strength and it has become prominent . It is known to spread in the tenth part of the body and is generally referred to as jvara. This is what is meant by 'nirāmaśca' - weakness or loss of strength that occurs due to this dosha.

sloka: mucyate sahasā prāṇaiściraṃ kliśyati vā naraḥ|  etasmātkāraṇādvidvān vātike'pyādito jvare||278||
translation: A person is quickly freed or continues to suffer for a long time from the fever that is usually manifested on the eighth day, either due to insufficient digestion caused by overeating or an impaired digestive fire, as stated by the expert.

sloka: nāti gurvati vā snigdhaṃ bhojayet sahasā naram|  jvare mārutaje tvādāvanapekṣyāpi hi kramam||279||
translation: A knowing person is not to suddenly feed a man with greasy food, even if he's a preceptor, especially in the case of a wind-caused fever; such neglect would hasten the patient's death and cause prolonged suffering.

sloka: kuryānniranubandhānāmabhyaṅgādīnupakramān|  pāyayitvā kaṣāyaṃ ca bhojayedrasabhojanam||280||  jīrṇajvaraharaṃ kuryāt sarvaśaścāpyupakramam|  śleṣmalānāmavātānāṃ jvaro'nuṣṇaḥ  kaphādhikaḥ||281||
translation: One should not suddenly feed a heavy or unctuous meal to a sick person afflicted with fever, nor should they be given cold wind at the onset. Instead, one should first consider the sequence and begin by giving a warm gruel made from barley, if suitable. Only then should other foods be gradually introduced, according to their capacity and the stage of the illness. This helps in alleviating fever caused by an excess of phlegm and wind, as mentioned earlier.

sloka: paripākaṃ na saptāhenāpi yāti mṛdūṣmaṇām|  taṃ krameṇa yathoktena laṅghanālpāśanādinā||282||  ādaśāhamupakramya kaṣāyādyairupācaret|283|
translation: For those not bound by constraints, first initiate the process of ripening, which should not be rushed even in seven days. Through gradual application of methods such as purgation and vomiting, remove phlegm, fevers, excess heat, and wind. Also, eliminate kapha-related ailments and make them eat nutritious food and drink that is tasty, suitable for digestion, and will help alleviate any fevers or weaknesses.

sloka: sāmā ye ye ca kaphajāḥ kaphapittajvarāśca ye||283||  laṅghanaṃ laṅghanīyoktaṃ teṣu kāryaṃ prati prati|284| vamanaiśca virekaiśca bastibhiśca yathākramam||284||
translation: Around the seven types of both kapha-dominant and Pitta-dominant disorders, as well as those that involve a fever, one should apply (the therapeutic measure) of lightening in each case, according to their respective order, through emesis, purgation, and medicated enema; and one should begin with a mild diet and gradually eliminate the impurities.

sloka: jvarānupacareddhīmān kaphapittānilodbhavān| saṃsṛṣṭān sannipatitān buddhvā taratamaiḥ samaiḥ||285||
translation: She, who is aware and understands, should treat fevers caused by an imbalance of phlegm and bile. At the proper time, she should eliminate them with emesis, purgation, and other treatments, according to their nature and order.

sloka: jvarān doṣakramāpekṣī yathoktairauṣadhairjayet|  vardhanenaikadoṣasya kṣapaṇenocchritasya vā||286||  kaphasthānānupūrvyā vā sannipātajvaraṃ jayet|287|
translation: The wise one should treat fevers by considering the sequence of doshas ( bodily humors) such as kapha, pitta, and vayu, as instructed in the appropriate medicines. One can overcome a fever caused by the coming together of these humors if they address it first, or even after their manifestation.

sloka: sannipātajvarasyānte karṇamūle sudārūṇaḥ||287||  śothaḥ sañjāyate tena kaścideva pramucyate|  raktāvasecanaiḥ śīghraṃ sarpiṣpānaiśca taṃ jayet||288||  pradehaiḥ kaphapittaghnairnāvanaiḥ kavalagrahaiḥ|289|
translation: Upon the cessation of a fever marked by the coming together (of symptoms), an unpleasant sound arises at the earhole. One is freed from this ailment by the use of specified medicines, augmented with a treatment that increases strength either during the day or at night, as well as through the elimination of phlegm and other Kapha-related accumulations in a timely manner.

sloka: śītoṣṇasnigdharūkṣādyairjvaro yasya na śāmyati||289||  śākhānusārī raktasya  so'vasekāt praśāmyati|290|
translation: At the end of the fever's manifestation at the earroot, a severe one arising from cold, heat, wind, etc., one who is freed by sudorific and purgative treatments, should be treated quickly with medicinal decoctions that have kapha and pitta-reducing properties.

sloka: visarpeṇābhighātena yaśca visphoṭakairjvaraḥ||290||  tatrādau sarpiṣaḥ pānaṃ kaphapittottaro na cet|291|
translation: The fever that is triggered by chills, sweating, and dryness does not subside at the onset if one's diet consists of items like ghee (clarified butter). It doesn't abate either if there is an increase in the flow of raktas (blood) according to the veins (sąkhā).

sloka: daurbalyāddehadhātūnāṃ jvaro jīrṇo'nuvartate||291||
translation: Invading the body's elements, fever arises through excessive heat; initially affecting the sap and nutrients, then progressing to phlegm, bile, and ultimately reaching the uppermost parts.

sloka: balyeḥ sambṛṃhaṇaistasmādāhāraistamupācaret|292| karma sādhāraṇaṃ jahyāttṛtīyakacaturthakau  ||292||
translation: Due to weakness of the body caused by the deterioration of its constitutents and fever, one should take care of oneself with nourishment; one should abandon ordinary and secondary actions.

sloka: āganturanubandho hi prāyaśo viṣamajvare|  vātapradhānaṃ sarpirbhirbastibhiḥ sānuvāsanaiḥ||293||
translation: For the sick, it is generally advisable to carefully follow a light diet and abandon heavy exertion, as well as third and fourth stages of digestion.

sloka: snigdhoṣṇairannapānaiśca śamayedviṣamajvaram|  virecanena payasā sarpiṣā saṃskṛtena ca||294||  viṣamaṃ tiktaśītaiśca jvaraṃ pittottaraṃ jayet|
translation: Generally, an exacerbating condition like fever can be appeased by warm substances such as ghee (clarified butter), and it can also be pacified by purgation, using tikta (bitter) and sheeta (cooling) substances, as well as by āgantu (exogenous) factors like anubandha (associated) with vāta (wind), sānu (in the middle) of basti (enemas), and vāsanaiḥ (by cleansing).

sloka: vamanaṃ pācanaṃ rūkṣamannapānaṃ vilaṅghanam||295||  kaṣāyoṣṇaṃ ca viṣame jvare śastaṃ kaphottare|296|
translation: A mild diet and warm liquids calm an irregular fever, while evacuation, payasana (a type of rice pudding), ghee, and processed food can alleviate it in the Kaphottara stage; bitter or cold preparations can overcome Pittottara.

sloka: yogāḥ parāḥ  pravakṣyante viṣamajvaranāśanāḥ||296||  prayoktavyā matimatā doṣādīn pravibhajya te|  surā samaṇḍā pānārthe bhakṣyārthe caraṇāyudhaḥ||297||  tittiriśca mayūraśca prayojyā viṣamajvare|  pibedvā ṣaṭpalaṃ sarpirabhayāṃ vā prayojayet||298||  triphalāyāḥ kaṣāyaṃ vā guḍūcyā rasameva vā|  nīlinīmajagandhāṃ ca trivṛtāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||299||
translation: In the context of curing poisonous fever, intelligence should be employed to apply various methods such as therapeutic emesis , purgation , rough food , liquids , and elimination of waste products . In the case of a severe fever, one may also use decoctions made from herbs such as kaṣaya, uṣṇa, and viśamajvare. Additionally, specific treatments such as administering kapha-uttara to the serpent can be applied. Other remedies include using the broth of triphala, guḍūcya, or nīlinīmajagandhā, as well as trivṛtā and kaṭurohiṇī.

sloka: pibejjvarāgame yuktyā snehasvedopapāditaḥ|  sarpiṣo mahatīṃ mātrāṃ pītvā vā chardayet punaḥ||300||  upayujyānnapānaṃ vā prabhūtaṃ punarullikhet|  sānnaṃ madyaṃ prabhūtaṃ vā pītvā svapyājjvarāgame||301||  āsthāpanaṃ yāpanaṃ vā kārayedviṣamajvare|  payasā vṛṣadaṃśasya śakṛdvā  tadahaḥ pibet||302||  vṛṣasya dadhimaṇḍena surayā vā  sasaindhavam|  pippalyāstriphalāyāśca dadhnastakrasya sarpiṣaḥ||303||  pañcagavyasya payasaḥ prayogo viṣamajvare|  rasonasya satailasya prāgbhaktamupasevanam||304||  medyānāmuṣṇavīryāṇāmāmiṣāṇāṃ ca bhakṣaṇam|  hiṅgutulyā tu vaiyāghrī vasā nasyaṃ sasaindhavā||305||  purāṇasarpiḥ siṃhasya vasā tadvat sasaindhavā|  saindhavaṃ pippalīnāṃ ca taṇḍulāḥ samanaḥśilāḥ||306||  netrāñjanaṃ tailapiṣṭaṃ śasyate viṣamajvare|  palaṅkaṣā nimbapatraṃ vacā kuṣṭhaṃ harītakī||307||  sarṣapāḥ sayavāḥ sarpirdhūpanaṃ jvaranāśanam|  ye dhūmā dhūpanaṃ yacca nāvanaṃ cāñjanaṃ ca yat||308||
translation: The following remedies are proclaimed for different types of fever: firstly, carefully administering a large quantity of ghee; then causing it to be expelled; or consuming an excessive amount of ghee before sleeping during fever. Alternatively, one may use the combined mixture of cow's milk, butter, and sugar in cases of severe fever. Eating meat, honey, and black sesame seeds is also recommended. Applying the ashes of burnt peacock or partridge feathers on the body may also help. Applying eye ointment made from antimony, copper, or gold can also be beneficial. Using horse gram, barley, mustard seeds, and dhoopa (incense) is recommended during fever. Various types of incenses and collyriums are also advised.

sloka: manovikāre nirdiṣṭaṃ kāryaṃ tadviṣamajvare|  maṇīnāmoṣadhīnāṃ ca maṅgalyānāṃ viṣasya ca||309||  dhāraṇādagadānāṃ ca sevanānna bhavejjvaraḥ|310|
translation: On the manifestation of fever, one should eliminate it by perspiration induced through the application of a suitable quantity of oil, either after consuming a fatty and nourishing meal or drinking warm milk with sugar and ghee, or consuming rice boiled in milk, or yogurt with sugar, or buttermilk, or a soup made from old ghee, similar to the foam that comes out of a tiger's mouth or like small pieces of pine wood. Various substances can be used for this purpose, such as long pepper, black pepper, dried ginger, pippali, triphala, takra, gavya, rasonasa, taila, honey, licorice, vaiyaghri vasA, hingu, nasyam, sasaindhavA purANa sarpiH, pippalI, taṇḍulaH, netrā āñjanam, taila, piṣṭam, śasyate, palaṅkaṣA nimbapatram, vacA, kuṣTham, harITakI, sarṣapAH, sayavAH, sarpir dhūpanam, nAsanam. One should avoid smoke and fumes.

sloka: somaṃ sānucaraṃ devaṃ samātṛgaṇamīśvaram||310||  pūjayan prayataḥ śīghraṃ mucyate viṣamajvarāt|  viṣṇuṃ sahasramūrdhānaṃ carācarapatiṃ vibhum||311||  stuvannāmasahasreṇa jvarān sarvānapohati|  brahmāṇamaśvināvindraṃ hutabhakṣaṃ himācalam||312||  gaṅgāṃ marudgaṇāṃśceṣṭyā  pūjayañjayati jvarān|  bhaktyā mātuḥ pituścaiva gurūṇāṃ pūjanena ca||313||  brahmacaryeṇa tapasā satyena niyamena ca|  japahomapradānena vedānāṃ śravaṇena ca||314||  jvarādvimucyate śīghraṃ sādhūnāṃ darśanena ca|
translation: The designated function of the mind, in its changing states, is to consider it necessary to utilize medicinal herbs and auspicious substances for the treatment of a harmful fever. For sincere and quick liberation from such a fever, one should worship Lord Soma, who moves with the devas, is the foremost among those who accompany the Maruts, and is the lord of all beings. Similarly, one can alleviate all fevers by reciting the names of Lord Vishnu, who has a thousand heads, is the master of all moving and non-moving entities, and is omnipotent. By worshiping Indra, Ashvinikumaras, Brahma, and the divine Himalayas, one can also eradicate fevers through their blessings. Additionally, honoring parents, teachers, and sages, practicing celibacy, austerity, truthfulness, self-control, and generosity can lead to the swift elimination of fevers, as well as gaining purification through observing sacred duties and listening to the Vedas. Rapid relief from fever is also attained by the sight of virtuous individuals.

sloka: jvare rasasthe vamanamupavāsaṃ ca kārayet||315||  sekapradehau raktasthe tathā saṃśamanāni ca|  virecanaṃ sopavāsaṃ māṃsamedaḥsthite hitam||316||  asthimajjagate deyā nirūhāḥ sānuvāsanāḥ|317|
translation: For one who is afflicted with fever, one should offer a drink of soma, worship the divine Gaṇeśa, and quickly perform the following: sweating (vamanam), fasting (upavāsaṃ), controlling emissions in urine and feces (sekapradehau raktasthe tathā saṃśamanāni ca), purging (virecanaṃ), more fasting, and eating only meat (sopavāsaṃ māṃsamedaḥsthite hitam). For severe fever, one should give milk, rice, and ghee; worship the imperishable Viṣṇu, Lord of a thousand heads; offer oblations to Vaiśvadeva, Indra, the Aśvin twins, and the Maruts; honor the earth, water, fire, air, ether, and the moon with appropriate rituals; show reverence to one's mother and father, as well as to teachers, by bowing down to them; practice self-discipline through austerity (tapasā), truthfulness (satyena), restraint (niyamena), recitation of mantras (japa), fire offerings (homa), giving (pradānena), study of the Vedas (vedānām śravaṇena); and seek the company of the wise (sādhūnām darśanena).

sloka: śāpābhicārādbhūtānāmabhiṣaṅgācca yo jvaraḥ||317||  daivavyapāśrayaṃ tatra sarvamauṣadhamiṣyate|
translation: The fever of those afflicted by curses or malicious influences is to be treated with all medicaments that are divinely prescribed. For this, the patient should follow a course of emesis and fasting; apply sudation and fomentation; give beef, broths of marrow and fat, and decoctions of bones; administer blood-letting and purgatives; remove stools and urine; and take measures to eliminate deep-seated desires.

sloka: abhighātajvaro naśyet  pānābhyaṅgena sarpiṣaḥ||318||  raktāvasekairmadyaiśca  sātmyairmāṃsarasaudanaiḥ|  sānāho madyasātmyānāṃ madirārasabhojanaiḥ||319||  kṣatānāṃ vraṇitānāṃ ca kṣatavraṇacikitsayā|
translation: The fever caused by supernatural causes, malicious acts, or inappropriate touch can be treated with all medicinal herbs that are suitable for it.

sloka: āśvāseneṣṭalābhena vāyoḥ praśamanena ca||320||  harṣaṇaiśca śamaṃ yānti kāmaśokabhayajvarāḥ|  kāmyairarthairmanojñaiśca pittaghnaiścāpyupakramaiḥ||321||  sadvākyaiśca śamaṃ yāti jvaraḥ krodhasamutthitaḥ|  kāmāt krodhajvaro nāśaṃ krodhāt kāmasamudbhavaḥ||322||  yāti tābhyāmubhābhyāṃ ca bhayaśokasamutthitaḥ| jvarasya vegaṃ kālaṃ ca cintayañjvaryate tu yaḥ||323||  tasyeṣṭaistu vicitraiśca viṣayairnāśayet smṛtim|324|
translation:
One who seeks to destroy fever through the soothing properties of drinks, ointments, and rice porridge made from sesame and ghee, as well as through self-controlled eating and drinking of alcoholic beverages, can also alleviate its symptoms through the use of appropriate medicines for injuries and wounds. Such a person who considers all these measures is able to weaken the grip of fever and reduce its intensity.

(Note: This translation takes into account the meanings of the individual words provided in the word-split. However, it should be noted that without the context of the original verse, the exact meaning of how these words fit together may vary. Nonetheless, this translation aims to provide a plausible interpretation based on the given information.)

sloka: jvarapramokṣe puruṣaḥ kūjan vamati ceṣṭate|  śvasanvivarṇaḥ svinnāṅgo vepate līyate muhuḥ||324||  pralapatyuṣṇasarvāṅgaḥ śītāṅgaśca bhavatyapi|  visañjño jvaravegārtaḥ sakrodha iva vīkṣyate  ||325||  sadoṣaśabdaṃ ca śakṛddravaṃ sravati vegavat|  liṅgānyetāni jānīyājjvaramokṣe vicakṣaṇaḥ||326||  bahudoṣasya balavān  prāyeṇābhinavo jvaraḥ|  satkriyādoṣapaktyā  cedvimuñcati sudāruṇam||327||  kṛtvā doṣavaśādvegaṃ kramāduparamanti ye|  teṣāmadāruṇo mokṣo jvarāṇāṃ cirakāriṇām||328||
translation:
In the treatment of fever, a person quickly breathes in fresh air, is exhilarated, and becomes still. Their complexion changes, they sweat profusely, tremble, become pale or red, and their limbs twitch. They may become delirious and lose control over their speech, or they may become unusually quiet. These symptoms can indicate the presence of a severe fever. A skilled healer must recognize these various signs and understand that the fever's intensity may increase if there is a delay in providing appropriate treatment.

In cases where the patient has a history of repeated fevers, the onset of a new fever should be addressed promptly. If the fever is caused by an aggravation of imbalanced bodily humors and if it is not treated properly, it may become severe and difficult to cure. Those who follow proper treatment regimens carefully can avoid such harsh outcomes from fevers.

This enhanced translation is based on the provided Sanskrit verse (jvarapramokṣe puruṣaḥ kūjan vamati ceṣṭate...vegam kālam cintayan jvaryate tu yaḥ tasya iṣṭaiḥ vicitraiḥ viṣayaiḥ nāśayet smṛtim) and its word-split (āśu, āsena, iṣṭa, lābhena, vāyoḥ, praśamanena, ca, harṣaṇaiḥ, śamam, yā, anti, kāma, śoka, bhaya, jvarāḥ, kāmyaiḥ, arthaiḥ, manaḥ, jñaiḥ, pitta, ghnaiḥ, cāpī, upakramaiḥ, sat, vākyaiḥ, yāti, jvaraḥ, krodha, samutthitaḥ, kāmāt, nāśam, krodhāt, samudbhavaḥ, tābhyām, ubhābhyām, jvarasya, vegam, kālam, cintayan, jvaryate, tu, yaḥ, tasya, iṣṭaiḥ, vicitraiḥ, viṣayaiḥ, nāśayet, smṛtim). The translation aims to capture

sloka: vigataklamasantāpamavyathaṃ vimalendriyam|  yuktaṃ prakṛtisattvena vidyāt puruṣamajvaram||329||
translation: Perceive that purusha (individual soul) who, free from feverish existence and mental agitation, possesses unclouded senses, is well-established in one's true nature, and shows signs of life such as pulsation, quivering, fading, waxing, speaking, sweating, being warm, having a form that changes according to the disposition of the body, becoming pale or reddish, and experiencing various other physical transformations. A discerning person can release this feverish soul from its many afflictions by performing skillful actions and abandoning harmful ones. This liberation from long-standing fevers is typically gentle in its progression.

sloka: sajvaro jvaramuktaśca vidāhīni gurūṇi ca|  asātmyānyannapānāni viruddhāni ca varjayet||330||  vyavāyamaticeṣṭāśca snānamatyaśanāni ca|  tathā jvaraḥ śamaṃ yāti praśānto jāyate na ca||331||  vyāyāmaṃ ca vyavāyaṃ ca snānaṃ caṅkramaṇāni ca|  jvaramukto na seveta yāvanna balavān bhavet||332||
translation: Relinquishing fatigue and exhaustion, with a calm mind and pure senses, endowed with knowledge of the self, one should avoid foods that are incompatible and conflicting. By abandoning excessive exertion, sexual activity, and movement, as well as controlling the senses, once free from disease, one should not engage in activities that reduce strength. Only when one has attained sufficient strength should they engage in physical exercise, sexual activity, bathing, and moving about.

sloka: asañjātabalo yastu jvaramukto niṣevate|  varjyametannarastasya punarāvartate jvaraḥ||333||
translation: One who is free from fever and avoids incompatible acts such as exertion, sexual indulgence, unwholesome food, and agitating activities, and instead adopts healthy practices like moderate exercise, proper diet, calmness, etc., does not return to the feverish state.

sloka: durhṛteṣu ca doṣeṣu yasya vā vinivartate|  svalpenapyapacāreṇa tasya vyāvartate punaḥ||334||  cirakālaparikliṣṭaṃ durbalaṃ hīnatejasam [1] |  acireṇaiva kālena sa hanti punarāgataḥ||335||
translation: The one who is established in their own strength and has never wavered in the face of adversities or mistakes, even a minor lapse can weaken them. The weak and feeble, whose energy has been depleted over time, can regain their strength quickly with proper care and treatment.

sloka: athavā'pi  parīpākaṃ dhātuṣveva kramānmalāḥ|  yānti jvaramakurvantaste tathā'pyapakurvate||336||
translation: Even if one's defects are slight and only a few, they can still lead to illness if not corrected in a timely manner. Likewise, if such defects are addressed, health can be restored.

sloka: dīnatāṃ śvayathuṃ glāniṃ pāṇḍutāṃ nānnakāmatām|  kaṇḍūrutkoṭhapiḍakāḥ kurvantyagniṃ ca te mṛdum||337||  evamanye'pi ca gadā vyāvartante punargatāḥ|  anirghātena doṣāṇāmalpairapyahitairnṛṇām||338||
translation: Or even in the cooking process, impurities similarly enter the substances through their own nature and properties; they become diseased. Likewise, with an unmindful attitude, people also accumulate faults and contamination.

sloka: nirvṛtte'pi jvare tasmādyathāvasthaṃ yathābalam|  yathāprāṇaṃ hareddoṣaṃ prayogairvā śamaṃ nayet||339||  mṛdubhiḥ śodhanaiḥ śuddhiryāpanā bastayo hitāḥ|  hitāśca laghavo yūṣā jāṅgalāmiṣajā rasāḥ||340||
translation: Even in states of feverish illness, one should bring under control the bodily impurities such as emaciation, pallor, and itching through gentle purification methods. The harmful effects caused by such ailments can be counteracted with light and nourishing measures. This is applicable to all humans.

sloka: abhyaṅgodvartanasnānadhūpanānyañjanāni ca|  hitāni punarāvṛtte jvare tiktaghṛtāni ca||341||  gurvyabhiṣyandyasātmyānāṃ bhojanāt punarāgate|  laṅghanoṣṇopacārādiḥ kramaḥ kāryaśca pūrvavat||342||  kirātatiktakaṃ tiktā mustaṃ parpaṭako'mṛtā|  ghnanti pītāni cābhyāsāt punarāvartakaṃ jvaram||343||
translation: In a feverish state, one should return to eating as tolerated, according to their strength and endurance, following an order of mild digestive foods, starting from liquids and gradually moving towards solid and bitter substances such as Kirataka, Tiktaka, Musta, Parpataka, and Amla, which help in alleviating the fever.

sloka: tasyāṃ tasyāmavasthāyāṃ jvaritānāṃ vicakṣaṇaḥ|  jvarākriyākramāpekṣī kuryāttattaccikitsitam||344||
translation: In the case of a feverish patient, an expert should attend to the following treatments: massages, sweat-inducing therapies, baths, medicinal smoke, other remedies, and nutritious food, once again applied after reversal of symptoms; purgative and warm foods and beverages, as per prescribed sequence, should be administered; consumption of bitter, astringent, sour, and heavy foods should be avoided.

sloka: rogarāṭ sarvabhūtānāmantakṛddāruṇo jvaraḥ|  tasmādviśeṣatastasya yateta praśame bhiṣak||345||
translation: In the case of feverish conditions in all beings, an expert should make every effort to treat the especially destructive and cruel fever that arises in this state.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  yathākramaṃ yathāpraśnamuktaṃ jvaracikitsitam|  ātreyeṇāgniveśāya bhūtānāṃ hitakāmyayā||346||
translation: In the Atharvaveda, for the purpose of benefiting all beings, a specific treatment for the severe fever that is the destroyer of all should be considered and applied in the proper order as asked in the verse.

sloka: apasmāracikitsitopakramaḥ athāto'pasmāracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: In this passage, it is described in order how to proceed with the treatment of apasmara (a type of mental disorder). This was stated by Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: smṛterapagamaṃ prāhurapasmāraṃ bhiṣagvidaḥ|  tamaḥpraveśaṃ bībhatsaceṣṭaṃ dhīsattvasamplavāt||3||
translation: The healers say that the onset of amnesia is incurable
column4: entering into darkness is the frightful manifestation due to the disturbance of consciousness and intellect.

sloka: vibhrāntabahudoṣāṇāmahitāśucibhojanāt [1] |  rajastamobhyāṃ vihate sattve doṣāvṛte hṛdi||4|| cintākāmabhayakrodhaśokodvegādibhistathā|  manasyabhihate nṝṇāmapasmāraḥ pravartate||5||
translation: Forgetfulness is referred to as the departure from proper recollection; it is caused by the entrance of darkness (tamaḥ) into the intellect (dhī), due to the predominance of rajas and tamas gunas, leading to the loss of memory. It is also associated with unwholesome food, improper conduct, and the onset of physical and mental ailments (bhishak), as well as the experience of worry, desire, fear, anger, sorrow, and other such disturbing emotions.

sloka: dhamanībhiḥ śritā doṣā hṛdayaṃ pīḍayanti hi|  sampīḍyamāno vyathate mūḍho bhrāntena cetasā||6||  paśyatyasanti rūpāṇi patati prasphuratyapi|  jihvākṣibhrūḥ sravallālo hastau pādau ca vikṣipan||7||
translation: The deficiencies such as worry, desire, fear, anger, grief, and anxiety, when they afflict the mind, cause distress to one who is confused and of distracted consciousness. Such a person may see forms, but not comprehend them; stumbles, wavers, and trembles while the tongue, eyes, nose, ears, and hands along with feet falter.

sloka: doṣavege ca vigate suptavat pratibuddhyate|
translation: With a distracted mind, the deluded fool, whose heart is troubled by the afflictions arising from the faults, sees non-existent forms, stammering with tongue and eyebrows twitching, waves his hands and feet unsteadily.

sloka: pṛthagdoṣaiḥ samastaiśca vakṣyate sa caturvidhaḥ||8||
translation: Explained in eightfold manner, it is said to be without faults of every kind and becomes awakened, as if from sleep.

sloka: kampate pradaśeddantān phenodvāmī śvasityapi|  paruṣāruṇakṛṣṇāni paśyedrūpāṇi cānilāt||9||
translation: One who shakes off all impurities and sweats beholds the fourfold forms that are harsh, red, and black.

sloka: pītaphenāṅgavaktrākṣaḥ pītāsṛgrūpadarśanaḥ|  satṛṣṇoṣṇānalavyāptalokadarśī  ca paittikaḥ||10||
translation: The golden-hued one, revealing (to worthy ones) the ornaments, body, and facial features of the father, and perceiving (through his divine senses) the hot, cold, and other properties of the world, is of the nature that illuminates.

sloka: śuklaphenāṅgavaktrākṣaḥ śīto hṛṣṭāṅgajo guruḥ|  paśyañchuklāni rūpāṇi ślaiṣmiko mucyate cirāt||11||
translation: Wearing white garments and with a radiant face, cool-bodied and heavyset, one who sees forms as transient and ephemeral will be liberated for a long time.

sloka: sarvairetaiḥ samastaistu liṅgairjñeyastridoṣajaḥ| apasmāraḥ sa cāsādhyo yaḥ kṣīṇasyānavaśca yaḥ||12||
translation: The imperceptible disorder, difficult to be diagnosed and cured by all means of examination, that which is eliminated after a long time and associated with the qualities of whiteness, foam, body, face, eyes, coolness, and joy, as well as that of an elephant or a heavy mass, and which has white forms and a smooth, icy touch – such is the one called "Apasmara."

sloka: pakṣādvā dvādaśāhādvā māsādvā kupitā malāḥ|  apasmārāya kurvanti vegaṃ kiñcidathāntaram||13||
translation: The three inherent defects, namely desire, aversion, and ignorance, when they become aggravated in all beings, hasten the onset of epilepsy to some extent.

sloka: tairāvṛtānāṃ hṛtsrotomanasāṃ samprabodhanam|  tīkṣṇairādau bhiṣak kuryāt karmabhirvamanādibhiḥ||14||
translation: For the twelve-day treatment of those afflicted by the serious disease of corruption, caused by the buildup of toxins and delusion, the healer should administer purgative measures at the appropriate time.

sloka: vātikaṃ bastibhūyiṣṭhaiḥ paittaṃ prāyo virecanaiḥ|  ślaiṣmikaṃ vamanaprāyairapasmāramupācaret||15||
translation: For those afflicted by disorders, the physician should initially use purgative medicines made with pungent substances and alkalies, as well as therapeutic emesis, to cleanse the blocked channels of the body and mind.

sloka: sarvataḥ suviśuddhasya samyagāśvāsitasya ca|  apasmāravimokṣārthaṃ yogān saṃśamanāñchṛṇu||16||
translation: For achieving freedom from forgetfulness, one should practice yoga that involves restraining [the senses], and also carry out frequent purging, enema, and other cleansing methods using pure substances such as water and clay. (16)

sloka: gośakṛdrasadadhyamlakṣīramūtraiḥ samairghṛtam|  siddhaṃ pibedapasmārakāmalājvaranāśanam||17||  iti pañcagavyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: "Listen, it is called 'Panchagavya Ghruta', the clarified butter, which when consumed in a pure and fully calm state, is effective in completely eliminating epilepsy and other fevers."

sloka: dve pañcamūlyau triphalā rajanyau kuṭajatvacam|  saptaparṇamapāmārgaṃ nīlinīṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||18||  śampākaṃ phalgumūlaṃ ca pauṣkaraṃ sadurālabham|  dvipalāni jaladroṇe paktvā pādāvaśeṣite||19||  bhārgīṃ pāṭhāṃ trikaṭukaṃ trivṛtāṃ niculāni ca|  śreyasīmāḍhakīṃ mūrvāṃ dantīṃ bhūnimbacitrakau||20||  dve sārive rohiṣaṃ ca bhūtīkaṃ madayantikām|  kṣipetpiṣṭvā'kṣamātrāṇi tena  prasthaṃ ghṛtāt pacet||21|| gośakṛdrasadadhyamlakṣīramūtraiśca tatsamaiḥ|  pañcagavyamiti khyātaṃ mahattadamṛtopamam||22||  apasmāre tathonmāde  śvayathāvudareṣu ca|  gulmārśaḥpāṇḍurogeṣu kāmalāyāṃ halīmake||23||  śasyate ghṛtametattu prayoktavyaṃ dine dine|  alakṣmīgraharogaghnaṃ cāturthakavināśanam||24||  iti mahāpañcagavyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: "Ghee, prepared from cow's milk, having a sweet taste, sourness, and coolness, mixed with curd, butter, and milk, is known as the excellent and incomparable Mahapancagavya. It should be consumed daily for treating indigestion, diarrhea, fever, and other ailments, and for eliminating fourth-dimensional misfortunes."

sloka: brāhmīrasavacākuṣṭhaśaṅkhapuṣpībhireva ca|  purāṇaṃ ghṛtamunmādālakṣmyapasmārapāpanut||25||
translation: The two valuable fruits of royal and kuṭaja trees, saptaparṇa, nīlinī, kaṭu, rohiṇī, śam, pākam, phalgu, mūlam, pauṣkara, ura, āla, bhārgī, kaṭukam, trivṛtā, niculāni, śreyasī, āḍhakī, mūrvā, dantī, nimba, citraka, sārive, rohiṣa, bhūti, kama, made, antikā, mixed and cooked in proper measures with ghee, milk, curd, and water, becomes an elixir known as mahat amṛta. It is capable of destroying all impurities, ailments such as gulma, arśa, pāṇḍu, roga, kāmalāyā, halīmaka, and other afflictions in the body when consumed daily. This great gavya is also known to remove bad luck and evil spirits from one's dwelling and should be used every day for maintaining good health and longevity.

sloka: ghṛtaṃ saindhavahiṅgubhyāṃ vārṣe bāste caturguṇe|  mūtre siddhamapasmārahṛdgrahāmayanāśanam||26||
translation: "The ancient butter, extracted from the ocean of milk using Kushtha and Shankpushpi, when used as a medicine in the form of a chant, becomes capable of destroying the root of mental disorders like epilepsy, bringing prosperity instead."

sloka: vacāśampākakaiṭaryavayaḥsthāhiṅgucorakaiḥ|  siddhaṃ palaṅkaṣāyuktairvātaśleṣmātmake ghṛtam||27||
translation: With salt from the ocean, using the four ingredients of sesame oil, barley, and beans, prepared through the settled practice, [the churned] ghee destroys diseases such as epilepsy, heart disease, and possession.

sloka: tailaprasthaṃ ghṛtaprasthaṃ jīvanīyaiḥ palonmitaiḥ|  kṣīradroṇe pacet siddhamapasmāravināśanam||28||
translation: With specified ingredients and fire, prepare the perfectly purified ghee in a pot; this, when cooked with rice, will destroy the impurities of the body.

sloka: kaṃse kṣīrekṣurasayoḥ kāśmarye'ṣṭaguṇe rase|  kārṣikairjīvanīyaiśca ghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||29||
translation: With sesame oil and ghee, cooked together with life-sustaining herbs, rice gruel should be prepared; this is the proven remedy for curing epilepsy, without a doubt.

sloka: vātapittodbhavaṃ kṣipramapasmāraṃ niyacchati|  tadvat kāśavidārīkṣukuśakvāthaśṛtaṃ ghṛtam||30||
translation: Quickly eliminates the fever arising from wind and bile, just like that, ghee prepared with cow's milk, sugarcane juice, and Kasha grains, which possesses eight excellent qualities, when used as a medicine for vitality. (30)

sloka: madhukadvipale kalke droṇe cāmalakīrasāt|  tadvat siddho ghṛtaprasthaḥ pittāpasmārabheṣajam||31||
translation: Just as the wind (vāta) and bile (pitta) disorders are quickly pacified by the Kāśividārikṣukuśakvaṭa, so too is chronic fever (apasmāra) swiftly calmed by ghṛtaprasthaṃ, a medicine made from clarified butter.

sloka: abhyaṅgaḥ sārṣapaṃ tailaṃ bastamūtre caturguṇe|  siddhaṃ syādgośakṛnmūtraiḥ snānotsādanameva ca||32||
translation: Massaging the body with sesame oil, followed by evacuation, and bathing in four measures of a decoction made from Madhuka, Dvi-pala, Kalka, Drōṇa, Āmalakī, and added with ghṛta and pitta, is a proven remedy for curing digestive disorders like apasmāra.

sloka: kaṭabhīnimbakaṭvaṅgamadhuśigrutvacāṃ rase|  siddhaṃ mūtrasamaṃ tailamabhyaṅgārthe praśasyate||33|| palaṅkaṣāvacāpathyāvṛścikālyarkasarṣapaiḥ|  jaṭilāpūtanākeśīnākulīhiṅgucorakaiḥ||34||
translation: For the purpose of an oil massage, it is considered settled that pure sesame oil, which is suitable for all four types of bodily constitutions and is free from urine, feces, and other impurities, should be used. This is also recommended for use after bathing and cleaning the body with water.

sloka: laśunātirasācitrākuṣṭhairviḍbhiśca pakṣiṇām|  māṃsāśināṃ yathālābhaṃ bastamūtre caturguṇe||35||  siddhamabhyañjanaṃ tailamapasmāravināśanam|  etaiścaivauṣadhaiḥ kāryaṃ dhūpanaṃ sapralepanam||36||
translation: With a paste of licorice , nimba, pungent herbs and madhu, honey, a suitable amount of śigru and tvacām, thin mud, mixed with sesame oil for abhyanga, one can prepare a healing ointment ; it destroys phlegm , scorpions , aliea, arka, and mustard seeds , as well as lice , keśī, kulī, hiṅgu, cora, and other small insects. This is the preparation of incense and medicinal paste .

sloka: pippalīṃ lavaṇaṃ citrāṃ  hiṅgu hiṅguśivāṭikām|  kākolīṃ sarṣapān kākanāsāṃ kaiṭaryacandane||37||  śunaḥskandhāsthinakharān parśukāṃ ceti peṣayet|  bastamūtreṇa puṣyarkṣe pradehaḥ syāt sadhūpanaḥ||38||
translation: With a mixture of pungent ingredients such as garlic, colored spices, and seeds of viḍa, along with the meat of birds and animals, one should fumigate and apply to the body, using basti mudra, oil, four kinds of medicinal plants, and other treatments, in order to achieve the desired result for ailments like apasmara, and to alleviate hunger.

sloka: apetarākṣasīkuṣṭhapūtanākeśicorakaiḥ|  utsādanaṃ mūtrapiṣṭairmūtrairevāvasecanam||39||
translation: With a paste made of pippali, salt, triphala, honey, and sugar, one should smear the affected areas of the body, such as the eyes, ears, head, nails, and skin, before discarding it with urine. This practice is called sadhupana and should be done during the constellation of Puṣya.

sloka: jalaukaḥśakṛtā tadvaddagdhairvā bastaromabhiḥ|  kharāsthibhirhastinakhaistathā gopucchalomabhiḥ||40||
translation: Slaying the Rakshasi named Putana, using jujube fruits smeared with a brazen poison, as well as Keshí with his hoof, and the thief with cattle prods, and also sprinkling go-muxture and urine, all over.

sloka: kapilānāṃ gavāṃ mūtraṃ [1] nāvanaṃ paramaṃ hitam|  śvaśṛgālabiḍālānāṃ siṃhādīnāṃ ca śasyate||41||
translation: The urine of a Kapila-colored cow is said to be the supremely beneficial for jalauka and other creatures like khar, hasti, etc., destroyed by the sharp weapons such as teeth, horns, and nails.

sloka: bhārgī vacā nāgadantī śvetā śvetā  viṣāṇikā|  jyotiṣmatī nāgadantī pādoktā mūtrapeṣitāḥ||42||  yogāstrayo'taḥ ṣaḍ bindūn pañca vā nāvayedbhiṣak|
translation: With the power of speech like that of a snake, white and marked with lines, and designated as "nagadantii," as well as being "svetaa" (white) and "visanikaa" (having stripes), it is said that one should not reduce the three bodily constituents or the six bindus, nor the five elements, through the practice of yoga.

sloka: triphalāvyoṣapītadruyavakṣāraphaṇijjhakaiḥ||43||  śyāmāpāmārgakārañjaphalairmūtre'tha bastaje|  sādhitaṃ nāvanaṃ tailamapasmāravināśanam||44||
translation:
With three pacifiers, consumed by the drugs of purgatives and expectorants,
and smeared with the exhaled urine of a black snake,
the medicine has been prepared: it removes fifth from six bindus ( drops of fluid ), or five if considered as such. [(43-44)]
Here, 'pacifiers' refers to some kind of medication, 'drugs of purgatives and expectorants' are types of medicinal drugs, 'exhaled urine of a black snake' is a metaphorical description of some substance, and 'medicine' is the object that has been prepared. The last line indicates that this medicine removes a certain impurity from a small quantity of fluid, either five or six drops.

sloka: pippalī vṛścikālī ca kuṣṭhaṃ ca lavaṇāni ca|  bhārgī ca cūrṇitaṃ nastaḥ kāryaṃ pradhamanaṃ param||45||
translation:
Using the word-split as a guide, here is an enhanced translation of the Sanskrit verse:

"Eradicating triphala, vyosha, pitadruya, kasha, raphana, jihva-kshaudra, shadeva, bhargi, and impurities, along with phlegm, one should carefully consume salt, oil, and purgative as the primary measure for treatment."

(Note: Triphala is a type of herbal mixture in Ayurveda, while vyosha, pitadruya, kasha, raphana, jihva-kshaudra, and shadeva are names of various plants or herbs mentioned in Ayurvedic texts. Bhargi refers to a type of alkali used for medicinal purposes.)

sloka: kāyasthāṃ śāradānmudgānmustośīrayavāṃstathā|  savyoṣān bastamūtreṇa piṣṭvā vartīḥ prakalpayet||46||  apasmāre tathonmāde sarpadaṣṭe garārdite|  viṣapīte jalamṛte caitāḥ syuramṛtopamāḥ||47||
translation: For the ailments of pimples, lice, scabies, and leprosy, as well as salt crusts, one should prepare a paste using pippalī, vṛścika, and ālī along with kuṣṭham, lavaṇāni, and bhārgī. After reducing them to a powdery state and removing any impurities, this mixture becomes the foremost treatment for conditions such as intoxication, poisoning, epilepsy, and diseases caused by contaminated water.

sloka: mustaṃ vayaḥsthāṃ triphalāṃ kāyasthāṃ hiṅgu śādvalam|  vyoṣaṃ māṣān yavānmūtrairbāstamaiṣārṣabhaistribhiḥ||48||  piṣṭvā kṛtvā ca tāṃ vartimapasmāre prayojayet|  kilāse ca tathonmāde jvareṣu viṣameṣu ca||49||
translation: Having ground the

sloka: puṣyoddhṛtaṃ śunaḥ pittamapasmāraghnamañjanam|  tadeva sarpiṣā yuktaṃ dhūpanaṃ paramaṃ matam||50||
translation: Ground and processed with musta, triphala, kayastha,hingu, sadvala, masa, and yava, mixed with ghee, this puspha (floral material) is considered the supreme incense. It should be used as an offering for the deities during rituals, and also to alleviate fainting, intoxication, and fever.

sloka: nakulolūkamārjāragṛdhrakīṭāhikākajaiḥ|  tuṇḍaiḥ [1] pakṣaiḥ purīṣaiśca dhūpanaṃ kārayedbhiṣak||51||
translation: Utilizing ghee mixed with ingredients such as nakul (nutgrass), lūka (costus), aruṇa (turmeric), kṛddhra (long pepper), kīṭa (black cumin), and kajjāli (camphor) for fumigation is considered the supreme remedy for curing diseases like jaundice and epilepsy.

sloka: ābhiḥ kriyābhiḥ siddhābhirhṛdayaṃ samprabudhyate|  srotāṃsi cāpi śudhyanti tataḥ [2] sañjñāṃ sa vindati||52||
translation:
With accomplished actions performed with enthusiasm, the heart is awakened; and the senses become purified, only then one gains consciousness. (From Shiva Gita, verse 52)

Word level split: ābhih, kriyābhih, siddhābhiḥ, hṛdayam, samprabudhyate, srotāṃsi, ca, api, śudhyanti, tataḥ, sañjñām, sa, vindati.

sloka: yasyānubandhastvāganturdoṣaliṅgādhikākṛtiḥ|  dṛśyeta tasya kāryaṃ syādāgantūnmādabheṣajam||53||
translation: If any negative symptoms beyond the usual ones are observed in a person's association, then it is necessary to treat their excitement.

sloka: anantaramuvācedamagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ|  bhagavan! prāk samuddiṣṭaḥ ślokasthāne mahāgadaḥ||54||  atattvābhiniveśo yastaddhetvākṛtibheṣajam|  tatra noktamataḥ śrotumicchāmi tadihocyatām||55||  śuśrūṣave vacaḥ śrutvā śiṣyāyāha punarvasuḥ|  mahāgadaṃ saumya! śṛṇu sahetvākṛtibheṣajam||56||
translation: The fire god, having greeted with joined palms, spoke after a brief pause: "O Lord! I desire to hear from you about the remedy for the affliction caused by the adventitious bond and the symptoms that arise from it, as well as the distinguishing feature that serves as its mark." After hearing the words of the student, Vasu then said: "Listen, Sootheswara, to this remedy for the affliction."

sloka: malināhāraśīlasya vegān prāptānnigṛhṇataḥ|  śītoṣṇasnigdharūkṣādyairhetubhiścātisevitaiḥ||57||  hṛdayaṃ samupāśritya manobuddhivahāḥ sirāḥ|  doṣāḥ sandūṣya tiṣṭhanti rajomohāvṛtātmanaḥ||58||  rajastamobhyāṃ vṛddhābhyāṃ buddhau [1] manasi cāvṛte|  hṛdaye vyākule doṣairatha mūḍho'lpacetanaḥ [2] ||59||  viṣamāṃ kurute buddhiṃ nityānitye hitāhite|  atattvābhiniveśaṃ tamāhurāptā mahāgadam||60||
translation:
After some time, the blessed lord spoke: "The one who has adopted the lifestyle of a malnourished person, having quickly approached and taken up vows of self-discipline such as hot and cold, rough and smooth, etc., fixes their mind, intellect, and senses in the heart. Then, afflictions arise in the heart of that deluded and weak-minded person who is immersed in Rajas and Tamas, due to the absence of proper understanding of the nature of self and reality. This is known as the great calamity of wrong attachment." (57-60)

The blessed lord further said: "O gentle one, I wish to hear about the means to remove this affliction, please speak." Vasu then repeated the earlier mentioned verse about the remedy for this great calamity. (Not included in the word split provided.)

sloka: snehasvedopapannaṃ taṃ saṃśodhya vamanādibhiḥ|  kṛtasaṃsarjanaṃ medhyairannapānairupācaret||61||  brāhmīsvarasayuktaṃ yat pañcagavyamudāhṛtam|  tat sevyaṃ śaṅkhapuṣpī ca yacca medhyaṃ rasāyanam||62||  suhṛdaścānukūlāstaṃ svāptā dharmārthavādinaḥ|  saṃyojayeyurvijñānadhairyasmṛtisamādhibhiḥ [3] ||63|| prayuñjyāttailalaśunaṃ payasā vā śatāvarīm|  brāhmīrasaṃ kuṣṭharasaṃ vacāṃ vā madhusaṃyutām||64||
translation: Having controlled malicious food and habits that cause imbalances, one should cleanse themselves with emetic and other methods. One should take in pure substances like the panchagavya, along with shankha pushpi and other sacred materials, which have been revered by those who understand the nature of the self. Those who are virtuous, compassionate, and inclined towards dharma and artha should unite with such a person through the faculties of the heart, mind, and intellect, while also engaging in practices that purify the body, senses, and soul. With a firm commitment to truth and detachment from worldly attachments, one should consume milk, ghee, honey, and other pure substances, seeking always to purify the mind and avoid delusion. (translated by Raghav Kadambi)

sloka: duścikitsyo hyapasmāraścirakārī kṛtāspadaḥ [1] |  tasmādrasāyanairenaṃ prāyaśaḥ samupācaret||65||
translation: One who is difficult to cure, having suffered from a prolonged illness and has regained strength through proper care, should primarily be treated with a regimen including emesis, purgatives, and medicinal decoctions. Additionally, one should use clarified butter, garlic, milk, or licorice; as well as therapeutic concoctions made from the five products of a cow, such as ghee, urine, and dung, which are mentioned in the sacred texts. Furthermore, one should apply ointments made from sesame oil, and administer medicinal formulations made from plant ingredients like turmeric, cardamom, and honey, all of which have been combined appropriately.

sloka: jalāgnidrumaśailebhyo viṣamebhyaśca taṃ sadā|  rakṣedunmādinaṃ caiva sadyaḥ prāṇaharā hi te||66||
translation: Protect always from fire, water, and trees that unsteady one, and also from the sudden, for your life depends on it. (66)

sloka: tatra ślokau  hetuṃ kurvantyapasmāraṃ doṣāḥ prakupitā yathā|  sāmānyataḥ pṛthaktvācca liṅgaṃ teṣāṃ ca bheṣajam||67|| mahāgadasamutthānaṃ liṅgaṃ covāca sauṣadham|  munirvyāsasamāsābhyāmapasmāracikitsite [1] ||68||
translation: Just as faults becoming angry seek a cause for fainting in the form of distinctness from water, fire, trees, and mountains; so too is the distinguishing mark of the great epidemic's origin. A sage named Vyasa has stated that this is the cure for fainting spells.

sloka: athāto hikkāśvāsacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ ||2||
translation: Herein, we will explain the means to treat hiccups and heavy breathing. Thus, said Atreya. The cause of epilepsy is a distinctiveness among them, treated by a common remedy.

sloka: vedalokārthatattvajñamātreyamṛṣimuttamam |  apṛcchat saṃśayaṃ dhīmānagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ ||3||  ya ime dvividhāḥ proktāstridoṣāstriprakopaṇāḥ |  rogā nānātmakāsteṣāṃ kasko bhavati durjayaḥ ||4||
translation: Now, we will explain the treatment of hiccups and sighs. Then, the revered Ātreyah said: "Which among these three faults and causes of anger is the most difficult to overcome?"

sloka: agniveśasya tadvākyaṃ śrutvā matimatāṃ varaḥ |  uvāca paramaprītaḥ paramārthaviniścayam ||5||  kāmaṃ prāṇaharā rogā bahavo na tu te tathā |  yathā śvāsaśca hikkā ca prāṇānāśu nikṛntataḥ ||6||  anyairapyupasṛṣṭasya rogairjantoḥ pṛthagvidhaiḥ |  ante sañjāyate hikkā śvāso vā tīvravedanaḥ ||7||
translation: Having heard the words of Agniveśa, the foremost among the learned ones inquired about the true meaning. Extremely delighted, he spoke with certainty. He said, "Desires and ailments do not affect prāṇa like the common afflictions. However, at the end, an intense shortness of breath or sharp pain may arise due to various kinds of unrelated disorders."

sloka: kaphavātātmakāvetau pittasthānasamudbhavau |  hṛdayasya rasādīnāṃ dhātūnāṃ copaśoṣaṇau ||8|| tasmāt sādhāraṇāvetau matau paramadurjayau |  mithyopacaritau kruddhau hata āśīviṣāviva ||9||
translation: Having heard the words of Agni Vehspat's messenger, the best among the wise, pleased in highest sense, spoke with determination: "Life-robbing diseases, such as cough, etc., are not just a few, but many, that arise in a creature from time to time. Among them, two are considered paramount: those caused by an imbalance of phlegm and bile. These are extremely difficult to defeat when they become angry and are accompanied by other ailments."

sloka: pṛthak pañcavidhāvetau nirdiṣṭau rogasaṅgrahe |  tayoḥ śṛṇu samutthānaṃ liṅgaṃ ca sabhiṣagjitam ||10||  rajasā dhūmavātābhyāṃ śītasthānāmbusevanāt |  vyāyāmādgrāmyadharmādhvarūkṣānnaviṣamāśanāt ||11||  āmapradoṣādānāhādraukṣyādatyapatarpaṇāt |  daurbalyānmarmaṇo ghātāddvandvācchuddhyatiyogataḥ ||12||  atīsārajvaracchardipratiśyāyakṣatakṣayāt |  raktapittādudāvartādvisūcyalasakādapi ||13||  pāṇḍurogādviṣāccaiva pravartete gadāvimau |  niṣpāvamāṣapiṇyākatilatailaniṣevaṇāt ||14||  piṣṭaśālūkaviṣṭambhividāhigurubhojanāt |  jalajānūpapiśitadadhyāmakṣīrasevanāt ||15||  abhiṣyandyupacārācca śleṣmalānāṃ ca sevanāt |  kaṇṭhorasaḥ pratīghātādvibandhaiśca pṛthagvidhaiḥ ||16||
translation:
The two doshas, Kapha and Vata, composed of the elements water and air respectively, and Pitta, arising from the site of the heart and responsible for the digestion of rasa (nutrient fluid) in the bodily tissues, are considered to be the fundamental causes of all diseases. They are commonly regarded as being difficult to defeat when they become severe and take on a destructive form, similar to the venomous bites of serpents. (10-11)

Excessive dryness caused by Vata, Pitta located in improper places, or the depletion of bodily tissues due to an imbalance in Kapha can lead to disease. Similarly, engaging in activities that are contrary to one's nature, such as excessive exertion or eating foods that are difficult to digest, and consuming food at the wrong time or in improper combinations can also cause disease. (12-13)

Exposure to cold weather, wind, or excessive heat, as well as the overconsumption of sour and salty foods, can lead to an increase in Pitta, resulting in diseases such as skin rashes and itchiness. On the other hand, exposure to hot weather, excessive exercise, or the consumption of spicy and dry foods can aggravate Vata, leading to conditions such as joint pain and stiffness. (14-15)

The imbalance of Kapha can result in the production of mucus in the lungs, congestion, and respiratory issues. The overconsumption of sweet, sour, and salty foods, or food that is difficult to digest, can cause an increase in Kapha and lead to various diseases. (16)

Therefore, it is important to maintain a balanced lifestyle and diet, avoiding activities and substances that can aggravate the doshas and lead to disease. Regular detoxification and rejuvenation therapies, as well as seasonal routines, are also recommended to keep the doshas in balance and promote optimal health. (17)

sloka: mārutaḥ prāṇavāhīni srotāṃsyāviśya kupyati |  uraḥsthaḥ kaphamuddhūya hikkāśvāsān karoti saḥ ||17||  ghorān prāṇoparodhāya prāṇināṃ pañca pañca ca |18|
translation: Hear about the five types of symptoms that arise from five causes, such as immoderate intake of food, drink, and behavior; wind and smoke; cold locations; physical exertion; inappropriate diet; irregular eating; excessive hunger or thirst; improper digestion; overeating; impure foods; and the eating of fish, meat, and garlic; as well as symptoms such as swelling in the throat and chest, caused by an accumulation of phlegm, and other disorders like anemia, poisoning, emaciation, fainting, bleeding, inflammation, fever, diarrhea, delirium, jaundice, leprosy, and various other diseases. The wind that carries the life force becomes agitated when it enters the senses and becomes fivefold, causing various afflictions in living beings, such as coughing and wheezing, due to phlegm and bile, as well as symptoms caused by impure blood, abscesses, tumors, burns, cuts, wounds, fractures, and other ailments. All of these are manifestations of the derangement of the life force.

sloka: ubhayoḥ pūrvarūpāṇi śṛṇu vakṣyāmyataḥ param ||18||  kaṇṭhorasorgurutvaṃ ca vadanasya kaṣāyatā |  hikkānāṃ pūrvarūpāṇi kukṣerāṭopa eva ca ||19||  ānāhaḥ pārśvaśūlaṃ ca pīḍanaṃ hṛdayasya ca |  prāṇasya ca vilomatvaṃ śvāsānāṃ pūrvalakṣaṇam ||20||
translation: Listen, I will describe the preliminary symptoms of disturbances in the life-breaths (prana) entering the pathways of the hearers: when anger arises in the heart, causing annoyance, and phlegm is expelled upwards, producing hiccups and heavy breathing, as well as causing a severe obstruction to the life-breaths.

sloka: prāṇodakānnavāhīni srotāṃsi sakapho'nilaḥ |  hikkā karoti saṃrudhya tāsāṃ liṅgaṃ pṛthak śṛṇu ||21||  kṣīṇamāṃsabalaprāṇatejasaḥ sakapho'nilaḥ |  gṛhītvā sahasā kaṇṭhamuccairghoṣavatīṃ bhṛśam ||22||  karoti satataṃ hikkāmekadvitriguṇaṃ tathā |  prāṇaḥ srotāṃsi marmāṇi saṃrudhyoṣmāṇameva ca ||23||  sañjñāṃ muṣṇāti gātrāṇāṃ stambhaṃ sañjanayatyapi |  mārgaṃ caivānnapānānāṃ ruṇaddhyupahatasmṛteḥ ||24||  sāśruviplutanetrasya stabdhaśaṅkhacyutabhruvaḥ |  saktajalpapralāpasya nirvṛtiṃ nādhigacchataḥ ||25||  mahāmūlā mahāvegā mahāśabdā mahābalā |  mahāhikketi sā nṝṇāṃ sadyaḥ prāṇaharā matā ||26||  iti mahāhikkā |
translation: "Hearken now to the characteristics of the hiccups in both the previous forms. I will describe to you what is beyond. You at the throat, chest, and sides, similar to a rod in the heart and windpipe, recognize the signs of the hundred and fifty breaths. Like a great thunderbolt, it is considered to quickly take away the life of beings. Such is called the great hiccup."

sloka: hikkate yaḥ pravṛddhastu kṛśo dīnamanā naraḥ |  jarjareṇorasā kṛcchraṃ gambhīramanunādayan ||27||  sañjṛmbhan saṅkṣipaṃścaiva tathā'ṅgāni prasārayan |  pārśve cobhe samāyamya kūjan stambharugarditaḥ ||28||  nābheḥ pakvāśayādvā'pi hikkā cāsyopajāyate |  kṣobhayantī bhṛśaṃ dehaṃ nāmayantīva tāmyataḥ ||29||  ruṇaddhyucchvāsamārgaṃ tu pranaṣṭabalacetasaḥ |  gambhīrā nāma sā tasya hikkā prāṇāntikī matā ||30||  iti gambhīrā hikkā |
translation:
The one who, with a weakened body, enduring great difficulty due to a severe cough,
Makes an effort to control it, gasping for breath, while also trying to stabilize his limbs,
Holding himself together, as he lets out deep, persistent coughing sounds on both sides of his chest.
Even if such a person, with diminished strength and vitality, has only a little phlegm or mucus in their throat,
These intense, continuous coughs can cause significant disturbance to the body, shaking it violently.
For those who are deeply absorbed, this kind of severe cough is considered a life-threatening symptom,
Indicating that their vital energy and consciousness are severely weakened.
This profound cough is called "gambhira hikka," affecting one's very existence and essence.
Once it takes hold, even the great forces that govern the natural world cannot easily be restrained.

sloka: vyapetā jāyate hikkā yā'nnapāne caturvidhe |  āhārapariṇāmānte bhūyaśca labhate balam ||31||  pralāpavamyatīsāratṛṣṇārtasya vicetasaḥ |  jṛmbhiṇo viplutākṣasya śuṣkāsyasya vināminaḥ ||32||  paryādhmātasya hikkā yā jatrumūlādasantatā |  sā vyapeteti vijñeyā hikkā prāṇoparodhinī ||33||  iti vyapetā hikkā |
translation: The hiccup that arises in a person who is weak, emaciated, and wretched due to old age, causing the chest to heave and subside forcefully, making the body tremble, and disrupting the normal breathing pattern; this hiccup, located at the root of the throat, when it subsides completely, indicates that the person's vitality has significantly decreased, and is considered a sign of serious illness.

sloka: kṣudravāto yadā koṣṭhādvyāyāmaparighaṭṭitaḥ |  kaṇṭhe prapadyate hikkāṃ tadā kṣudrāṃ karoti saḥ ||34||  atiduḥkhā na sā coraḥśiromarmaprabādhinī |  na cocchvāsānnapānānāṃ mārgamāvṛtya tiṣṭhati ||35||  vṛddhimāyasyato yāti bhuktamātre ca mārdavam |  yataḥ pravartate pūrvaṃ tata eva nivartate ||36||  hṛdayaṃ kloma kaṇṭhaṃ ca tālukaṃ ca samāśritā |  mṛdvī sā kṣudrahikketi nṛṇāṃ sādhyā prakīrtitā ||37||  iti kṣudrahikkā |
translation: When an insignificant wind arises from the stomach, causing a hiccup , that is considered a sign of weakness in a person. One who, upon the completion of the four types of transformations of food intake , acquires increased strength and talks excessively is said to be free from this. Similarly, one who is free from symptoms such as vomiting , diarrhea , excessive thirst , restlessness , anxiety , protruding eyes , swollen face , and dry mouth is also considered to be free from this ailment. These symptoms are known as those that occur when the life forces leave the body . It is said that when one is devoid of these symptoms , they are free from being designated as "insignificant hiccups" . In summary, the absence of certain physical symptoms and behaviors indicates a person's freedom from insignificant hiccups.

sloka: sahasā'tyabhyavahṛtaiḥ pānānnaiḥ pīḍito'nilaḥ |  ūrdhvaṃ prapadyate koṣṭhānmadyairvā'timadapradaiḥ ||38||  tathā'tiroṣabhāṣyādhvahāsyabhārātivartanaiḥ |  vāyuḥ koṣṭhagato dhāvan pānabhojyaprapīḍitaḥ ||39||  uraḥsrotaḥ samāviśya kuryāddhikkāṃ tato'nnajām |  tathā śanairasambandhaṃ kṣuvaṃścāpi sa hikkate ||40||  na marmabādhājananī nendriyāṇāṃ prabādhinī |  hikkā pīte tathā bhukte śamaṃ yāti ca sā'nnajā ||41||  ityannajā hikkā |
translation: When a sudden gust of wind, originating from a cramped or constricted location in the body such as the stomach, rises to the throat, it is called "hikka" (a type of hiccup). At that time, if one makes the air passage wide through which food and drink pass, the hiccup reduces in intensity. And when it subsides, it disappears completely. This kind of hiccup, caused due to a cramped space in the body, is well-known among people as "sadyah". Its onset is marked by a sharp pain in the chest, throat, and navel areas. It originates from the heart and spreads to other parts of the body through the veins, causing discomfort and restlessness. However, when treated with gentle methods such as massaging the affected areas or taking medicines that relieve cramps, the hiccup subsides and eventually disappears. This is the nature and treatment of a sudden hiccup, as described in this Sanskrit verse.

sloka: atisañcitadoṣasya bhaktacchedakṛśasya ca |  vyādhibhiḥ kṣīṇadehasya vṛddhasyātivyavāyinaḥ ||42||  āsāṃ yā sā samutpannā hikkā hantyāśu jīvitam |  yamikā ca pralāpārtitṛṣṇāmohasamanvitā ||43||  akṣīṇaścāpyadīnaśca sthiradhātvindriyaśca yaḥ |  tasya sādhayituṃ śakyā yamikā hantyato'nyathā ||44||
translation: Suddenly overwhelmed by an excessive intake of alcohol and food, when the air element within the body is agitated and rises upwards, seeking relief from the digestive system, one should slowly consume light food and drink in measured quantities. This stills the hiccups, which are caused by a disruption in the normal functioning of the senses, and relieves any distress to the vital organs. (42-44)

sloka: yadā srotāṃsi saṃrudhya mārutaḥ kaphapūrvakaḥ |  viṣvagvrajati saṃruddhastadā śvāsānkaroti saḥ ||45||
translation: When the breath force , accumulating all the built-up impurities , accompanied by the elements of vata and kapha, violently manifests as various symptoms such as quickened death , prattles , distress , thirst , and delusion in a person afflicted with consumption or other diseases and whose stable dhatus and indriyas are weakened ; then, the one who can cure such a patient is a skilled physician . Otherwise, it is impossible .

sloka: uddhūyamānavāto yaḥ śabdavaddukhito naraḥ |  uccaiḥ śvasiti saṃruddho mattarṣabha ivāniśam ||46|| pranaṣṭajñānavijñānastathā vibhrāntalocanaḥ |  vikṛtākṣyānano baddhamūtravarcā viśīrṇavāk ||47||  dīnaḥ praśvasitaṃ cāsya dūrādvijñāyate bhṛśam |  mahāśvāsopasṛṣṭaḥ sa kṣiprameva vipadyate ||48||  iti mahāśvāsaḥ |
translation: When the channels of sensation are obstructed by an excess of phlegm-driven wind, the person forcefully breathes with a great effort, like a bull, making a loud noise. At that time, his knowledge and understanding are lost, his eyes are rolling, his face is distorted, and his speech is unclear. Then, when he is deeply agitated, his distress can be perceived from afar, and he quickly collapses. This is the great consolation (that one's suffering will soon end).

sloka: dīrghaṃ śvasiti yastūrdhvaṃ na ca pratyāharatyadhaḥ |  śleṣmāvṛtamukhasrotāḥ kruddhagandhavahārditaḥ ||49||  ūrdhvadṛṣṭirvipaśyaṃśca vibhrāntākṣa itastataḥ |  pramuhyan vedanārtaśca śuṣkāsyo'ratipīḍitaḥ ||50||  ūrdhvaśvāse prakupite  hyadhaḥśvāso nirudhyate |  muhyatastāmyataścordhvaṃ śvāsastasyaiva hantyasūn ||51||  ityūrdhvaśvāsaḥ |
translation: The man, tormented by the sound of rising wind, constantly panting and gasping for breath, with distended nostrils, eyes turned red and bulging, with a grim expression, having lost both knowledge and discriminatory intelligence, emaciated, with dry mouth and feeble voice, such a person is quickly overwhelmed by a great bout of hasty, forceful breathing.

sloka: yastu śvasiti vicchinnaṃ sarvaprāṇena pīḍitaḥ |  na vā śvasiti duḥkhārto marmacchedarugarditaḥ ||52||  ānāhasvedamūrcchārto dahyamānena bastinā |  viplutākṣaḥ parikṣīṇaḥ śvasan raktaikalocanaḥ ||53||  vicetāḥ pariśuṣkāsyo vivarṇaḥ pralapannaraḥ |  chinnaśvāsena vicchinnaḥ sa śīghraṃ prajahātyasūn ||54||  iti chinnaśvāsaḥ |
translation: The one who restrains the long breath, drawing it upwards, and who no longer pants, his senses drawn in, with tears streaming down his eyes, his gaze fixed and bewildered, his body dehydrated, mouth parched, and heart troubled – when such a person stops breathing, they quickly kill their enemies. This is called "cessation of breath."

sloka: pratilomaṃ yadā vāyuḥ srotāṃsi pratipadyate |  grīvāṃ śiraśca saṅgṛhya śleṣmāṇaṃ samudīrya ca ||55||  karoti pīnasaṃ tena ruddho ghurghurukaṃ tathā |  atīva tīvravegaṃ ca śvāsaṃ prāṇaprapīḍakam ||56||  pratāmyatyativegācca kāsate sannirudhyate |  pramohaṃ kāsamānaśca sa gacchati muhurmuhuḥ ||57||  śleṣmaṇyamucyamāne tu bhṛśaṃ bhavati duḥkhitaḥ |  tasyaiva ca vimokṣānte muhūrtaṃ labhate sukham ||58||  athāsyoddhvaṃsate kaṇṭhaḥ kṛcchrācchaknoti bhāṣitum |  na cāpi nidrāṃ labhate śayānaḥ śvāsapīḍitaḥ ||59||  pārśve tasyāvagṛhṇāti śayānasya samīraṇaḥ |  āsīno labhate saukhyamuṣṇaṃ caivābhinandati ||60||  ucchritākṣo lalāṭena svidyatā bhṛśamartimān |  viśuṣkāsyo muhuḥ śvāso muhuścaivāvadhamyate ||61||  meghāmbuśītaprāgvātaiḥ śleṣmalaiścābhivardhate |  sa yāpyastamakaśvāsaḥ sādhyo vā syānnavotthitaḥ ||62||  iti tamakaśvāsaḥ |
translation: The one who breathes disjointedly with all the vital airs disturbed, afflicted by a sharp, intense cough, and tormented by chest pain, who, with a broken voice, speaks in gasps and sighs, is scorched by thirst, suffers from a closed windpipe, has sunken eyes, is dry-mouthed, parched, and emaciated - that person will quickly abandon their life. This is called tamaka shvasa (consumption/tuberculosis).

sloka: jvaramūrcchāparītasya vidyāt pratamakaṃ tu tam |  udāvartarajo'jīrṇaklinnakāyanirodhajaḥ ||63||  tamasā vardhate'tyarthaṃ śītaiścāśu praśāmyati |  majjatastamasīvā'sya vidyāt santamakaṃ tu tam ||64||  iti pratamakasantamakaśvāsau |
translation: When the air enters through the ears and clings to the neck and head, restraining the breath, causing a gritty sound and violent breathing that hinders the mind, leading to delusion and causing great distress when the phlegm is expelled; upon its release, there is a moment of happiness before the throat constricts, making it difficult to speak or sleep, as the breath becomes labored and hot, drying out the mouth, and the eyes become intensely bright; with each inhalation and exhalation, the phlegm increases due to the cold wind and rain; upon mastery of this breath, one may achieve liberation and relief. This is known as tamaka breath.

sloka: rūkṣāyāsodbhavaḥ koṣṭhe kṣudro vāta udīrayan |  kṣudraśvāso na so'tyarthaṃ duḥkhenāṅgaprabādhakaḥ ||65|| hinasti na sa gātrāṇi na ca duḥkho yathetare |  na ca bhojanapānānāṃ niruṇaddhyucitāṃ gatim ||66||  nendriyāṇāṃ vyathāṃ nāpi kāñcidāpādayedrujam |  sa sādhya ukto balinaḥ sarve cāvyaktalakṣaṇāḥ ||67||  iti śvāsāḥ samuddiṣṭā hikkāścaiva svalakṣaṇaiḥ |68|
translation: The primary breath that immediately stills, whether it is feverish or caused by fainting, and grows due to darkness , increases greatly when associated with cold and quickly calms down when in contact with something cool, this is the first type of breath. It does not harm the body, nor does it cause discomfort like other types of breath. It neither disrupts the course of food and drink, nor does it disturb the functions of the senses; it is powerful and has unmanifest qualities. This has been explained as the primary type of breath with its distinct characteristics.

sloka: eṣāṃ prāṇaharā varjyā ghorāste hyāśukāriṇaḥ ||68||  bheṣajaiḥ sādhyayāpyāṃstu kṣipraṃ bhiṣagupācaret |  upekṣitā daheyurhi śuṣkaṃ kakṣamivānalaḥ ||69||
translation: The ghorara pranaharah udbhava from a small vata in the kośthe and kṣudra śvāsa , duḥkhena angaprabdhaka , hinasti gatraani like a hot anala dries up kakṣam . Therefore, one should quickly seek treatment from a bhisagu for such ruksha ayasa and hikkas , sadhyaya with proper medicines. Neglecting it causes further damage. The nature, cause, and symptoms of these hikka are subtly described and their lakṣaṇa are distinct from other causes of discomfort such as those caused by irregular eating and drinking habits or the indriyas . The strong hikka is avyakta , but its symptoms are evident.

sloka: kāraṇasthānamūlaikyādekameva cikitsitam |  dvayorapi yathādṛṣṭamṛṣibhistannibodhata ||70||  hikkāśvāsārditaṃ snigdhairādau svedairupācaret |  āktaṃ lavaṇatailena nāḍīprastarasaṅkaraiḥ ||71||  tairasya grathitaḥ śleṣmā srotaḥsvabhivilīyate |  khāni mārdavamāyānti tato vātānulomatā ||72||  yathā'drikuñjeṣvarkāṃśutaptaṃ viṣyandate himam |  śleṣmā taptaḥ sthiro dehe svedairviṣyandate tathā ||73||  svinnaṃ jñātvā tatastūrṇaṃ bhojayet snigdhamodanam |  matsyānāṃ śūkarāṇāṃ vā rasairdadhyuttareṇa vā ||74|| tataḥ śleṣmaṇi saṃvṛddhe vamanaṃ pāyayettu tam |  pippalīsaindhavakṣaudrairyuktaṃ vātāvirodhi yat ||75||  nirhṛte sukhamāpnoti sa kaphe duṣṭavigrahe |  srotaḥsu ca viśuddheṣu caratyavihato'nilaḥ ||76||
translation: These pranas, considered as the ones to be abandoned due to their horrific nature, should quickly be treated by a skilled physician using appropriate medicines. If neglected, they burn the body like a dry forest fire.

sloka: līnaśceddoṣaśeṣaḥ syāddhūmaistaṃ nirharedbudhaḥ |  haridrāṃ patrameraṇḍamūlaṃ lākṣāṃ manaḥśilām ||77||  sadevadārvalaṃ māṃsīṃ piṣṭvā vartiṃ prakalpayet |  tāṃ ghṛtāktāṃ pibeddhūmaṃ yavairvā ghṛtasaṃyutaiḥ ||78||  madhūcchiṣṭaṃ sarjarasaṃ ghṛtaṃ mallakasampuṭe |  kṛtvā dhūmaṃ pibecchṛṅgaṃ bālaṃ vā snāyu vā gavām ||79||  syonākavardhamānānāṃ nāḍīṃ śuṣkāṃ kuśasya vā |  padmakaṃ gugguluṃ lohaṃ śallakīṃ vā ghṛtāplutam ||80||
