This is called Yogaraja, unequaled like amrita, the best among rejuvenators, beneficial in removing all diseases such as pandu-roga, poison, kasa, yakshman, visamajwaram, kushta, jirnaka meha, sosha, shwasa-marocakam, and others.

sloka: kauṭajatriphalānimbapaṭolaghananāgaraiḥ||87||  bhāvitāni daśāhāni rasairdvitriguṇāni vā|  śilājatupalānyaṣṭau tāvatī sitaśarkarā||88|| tvakkṣīrī pippalī dhātrī karkaṭākhyā palonmitā|  nidigdhyāḥ phalamūlābhyāṃ palaṃ yuktyā trigandhakam|  cūrṇitaṃ madhunaḥ kuryāt tripalenākṣikān guḍān|  dāḍimāmbupayaḥpakṣirasatoyasurāsavān||90||  tān bhakṣayitvā'nupibenniranno bhukta eva vā|  pāṇḍukuṣṭhajvaraplīhatamakārśobhagandarān||91||  pūtihṛcchukramūtrāgnidoṣaśoṣagarodarān [1] |  kāsāsṛgdarapittāsṛkśothagulmagalāmayān||92||  te ca sarvavraṇān hanyuḥ sarvarogaharāḥ śivāḥ|  iti śilājatuvaṭakāḥ|
translation: "The three parts of bitter gourd, citraka,

sloka: punarnavā trivṛdvyoṣaviḍaṅgaṃ dāru citrakam||93||  kuṣṭhaṃ haridre triphalā dantī cavyaṃ kaliṅgakāḥ|  pippalī [2] pippalīmūlaṃ mustaṃ ceti palonmitam||94||  maṇḍūraṃ dviguṇaṃ cūrṇādgomūtre dvyāḍhake pacet|  kolavadguṭikāḥ kṛtvā takreṇāloḍya nā pibet||95||  tāḥ pāṇḍurogān plīhānamarśāṃsi viṣamajvaram|  śvayathuṃ grahaṇīdoṣaṃ hanyuḥ kuṣṭhaṃ krimīṃstathā||96||  iti punarnavāmaṇḍūram|
translation: The herbal mixture known as "punarnava" is composed of the following ingredients in specified measures:

sloka: dārvītvak triphalā vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgamayaso rajaḥ|  madhusarpiryutaṃ lihyāt kāmalāpāṇḍurogavān||97||  tulyā ayorajaḥpathyāharidrāḥ kṣaudrasarpiṣā|  cūrṇitāḥ kāmalī lihyādguḍakṣaudreṇa vā'bhayāḥ||98||  triphalā dve haridre ca kaṭurohiṇyayorajaḥ|  cūrṇitaṃ kṣaudrasarpirbhyāṃ sa lehaḥ kāmalāpahaḥ||99||
translation: Again, let it not be that one should consume the powder of three types of vegetables , including triphala, along with black gram and wood , mixed together with a small amount of water . If one consumes this mixture, it will destroy diseases such as leprosy , worms , and other physical ailments . Moreover, the powder of two varieties of haridra and four types of spices , when combined with triphala , will act as a remedy for eliminating desires . For those who are afflicted by impurities of the mind and body , consuming this mixture is recommended . However, one should not drink large amounts of water after ingesting it.

sloka: dvipalāṃśāṃ tugākṣīrīṃ nāgaraṃ madhuyaṣṭikām|  prāsthikīṃ pippalīṃ drākṣāṃ śarkarārdhatulāṃ śubhām||100||  dhātrīphalarasadroṇe cūrṇitaṃ lehavat pacet|  śītaṃ madhuprasthayutaṃ lihyāt pāṇitalaṃ tataḥ||101||  hantyeṣa kāmalāṃ pittaṃ pāṇḍuṃ kāsaṃ halīmakam|  iti dhātryavalehaḥ|
translation: Prepared from the bark of tree, triplephala, vidanga, iron, salt, honey, ghee, and sesame, mixed with equal parts of clarified butter and powdered haridra, this medicinal paste also containing kashmarya, kasha, and halimaka is beneficial for treating skin diseases, Pitta, and Kapha. It also alleviates the symptoms caused by poison. This is called Dhatryavaleha.

sloka: tryūṣaṇaṃ triphalā cavyaṃ citrako devadāru ca||102||  viḍaṅgānyatha mustaṃ ca vatsakaṃ ceti cūrṇayet|  maṇḍūratulyaṃ taccūrṇaṃ gomūtre'ṣṭaguṇe pacet||103||  śanaiḥ siddhāstathā śītāḥ kāryāḥ karṣasamā guḍāḥ|  yathāgni bhakṣaṇīyāste plīhapāṇḍvāmayāpahāḥ||104|| grahaṇyarśonudaścaiva takravāṭyāśinaḥ smṛtāḥ|  iti maṇḍūravaṭakāḥ|
translation: Take two parts each of

sloka: mañjiṣṭhā rajanī drākṣā balāmūlānyayorajaḥ||105||  lodhraṃ caiteṣu gauḍaḥ syādariṣṭaḥ pāṇḍurogiṇām|  iti gauḍo'riṣṭaḥ|
translation: "In the ripe three fruits of Cavya, Citraka and Devadaru trees, along with the mustard seed and Vatsaka plant, grind equal parts of Lodhrā, red sandalwood, and the powdered karkatasringi. Mix this with cow's urine and milk, and prepare a paste by gradually adding eight portions of water. Let it settle and become cool. This is recommended for consumption during the night of the new moon (Mañjiṣṭhā rajanī), as it helps in eliminating poison, bile disorders, and diseases caused by graha (planetary influences) and seasonal changes. It also acts as a cure for arśa (piles) and udara (obesity). Those who consume this regularly are said to reap benefits similar to consuming agni (fire), in terms of digestion and metabolism."

sloka: bījakātṣoḍaśapalaṃ triphalāyāśca viṃśatiḥ||106||  drākṣāyāḥ pañca lākṣāyāḥ sapta droṇe jalasya tat|  sādhyaṃ pādāvaśeṣe tu pūtaśeṣe samāvapet||107||  śarkarāyāstulāṃ prasthaṃ mākṣikasya ca kārṣikam|  vyoṣaṃ vyāghranakhośīraṃ kramukaṃ sailavālukam||108||  madhukaṃ kuṣṭhamityetaccūrṇitaṃ ghṛtabhājane|  yaveṣu daśarātraṃ tadgrīṣme dviḥ śiśire sthitam||109||  pibettadgrahaṇīpāṇḍurogārśaḥśothagulmanut|  mūtrakṛcchrāśmarīmehakāmalāsannipātajit||110||  bījakāriṣṭa ityeṣa ātreyeṇa prakīrtitaḥ|  iti bījakāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: In the "Ātreyabrahmavaiptara-brāhmaṇa" of the Atharvaveda, this is called "bījakāriṣṭa": a decoction made from manjishtha (Rubia cordifolia) and draksha (Vitis vinifera), useful for treating various diseases in a patient named pāṇḍu, including consumption, wasting, jaundice, and skin diseases.

sloka: dhātrīphalasahasre dve pīḍayitvā rasaṃ tu tam||111||  kṣaudrāṣṭāṃśena saṃyuktaṃ kṛṣṇārdhakuḍavena ca|  śarkarārdhatulonmiśraṃ pakṣaṃ snigdhaghaṭe sthitam||112||  prapibenmātrayā prātarjīrṇe hitamitāśanaḥ|  kāmalāpāṇḍuhṛdrogavātāsṛgviṣamajvarān||113|| kāsahikkāruciśvāsāṃścaiṣo'riṣṭaḥ praṇāśayet|  iti dhātryariṣṭaḥ
translation:
By crushing in a mortar sixteen arghya-worthy *dhātrī* fruits, two each of *triphalā*, *drākṣā*, *lākṣā*, and seven *droṇas* of jala's sādhyapada remainder, after purifying, mix with an equal amount of sugar, a quarter of a *tulā* of rock salt, a measure of usīra, vyāghranakha, kramukam, elavālu, kam, madhukam, and kuṣṭhamiti; kept in a ghṛta-bhājana for ten nights during grīṣma and dviḥ sthitam during śiśira; consumed in the morning after being strained, along with pibetta (a drink) made from the urine of a cow that has overcome the bījaka-ariṣṭa, this is called the ātreyena-prakīrtita dhātryariṣṭa, which destroys kāmalā-sannipāta, jit, and other afflictions such as aśmarī, meha, kṛcchra, and mūtra.

*Note: This translation was made possible by the word split and additional context that it provides, without which a complete and accurate translation would have been difficult.*

sloka: sthirādibhiḥ śṛtaṃ toyaṃ pānāhāre praśasyate||114||  pāṇḍūnāṃ kāmalārtānāṃ mṛdvīkāmalakīrasaḥ|115|
translation: Consuming in the morning, with a moderate amount, the mixture of sugarcane juice and jaggery, combined in equal parts, sweetened with the extract from two thousand Sahasra fruits of the Dhatri tree, and strained through a cloth, will alleviate the afflictions of thirst, dysuria, cough, loss of appetite, irregular fever, hiccups, and other disorders for the Pandu-stricken.

sloka: pāṇḍurogapraśāntyarthamiti proktaṃ maharṣiṇā||115||  vikalpyametadbhiṣajā pṛthagdoṣabalaṃ prati|  vātike snehabhūyiṣṭhaṃ paittike tiktaśītalam||116||  ślaiṣmike kaṭutiktoṣṇaṃ [1]  vimiśraṃ sānnipātike|117|
translation: For the benefit of fair-skinned ones afflicted by various ailments, it has been said by the Maharishi: "Stable herbs such as śṛtam and toyam, when used in food, gladden the hearts of those suffering from kāmala and other diseases, being mild, cool, and delicious like āmalakī."

sloka: nipātayeccharīrāttu mṛttikāṃ bhakṣitāṃ bhiṣak||117||  yuktijñaḥ śodhanaistīkṣṇaiḥ prasamīkṣya balābalam|  śuddhakāyasya sarpīṃṣi balādhānāni yojayet||118||  vyoṣaṃ bilvaṃ haridre dve triphalā dve punarnave|  mustānyayorajaḥ pāṭhā viḍaṅgaṃ devadāru ca||119||  vṛścikālī ca bhārgī ca sakṣīraistaiḥ [1] samairghṛtam|  sādhayitvā pibedyuktyā naro mṛddoṣapīḍitaḥ||120||  tadvat keśarayaṣṭyāhvapippalīkṣāraśādvalaiḥ|  mṛdbhakṣaṇādāturasya laulyādavinivartinaḥ||121||  dveṣyārthaṃ bhāvitāṃ kāmaṃ dadyāttaddoṣanāśanaiḥ|  viṅgailātiviṣayā nimbapatreṇa pāṭhayā||122||  vārtākaiḥ kaṭurohiṇyā kauṭajairmūrvayā'pi vā|123|
translation: For the pacification of white-colored bodily ailments, it has been said by the great sage that this should be considered separately as the doctor's specific duty. Examining the strength and weakness of each dosha (Vata, Pitta, Kapha) with keen insight, sharpened through skillful means, one should administer purifying treatments to the pure bodied person. Using barley, bilva, haritaki, two types of triphala, purnarnava, musta, kasha, vinegar, patha, vidinga, devadaru, vrischikaali, bhargi, and sakshiri, along with ghee, the ailment can be treated when one drinks it after preparing it through the stated method. Similarly, using kesharaja, arista, hvapippali, ksheera, sharkara, vala, and madhurika, one should treat the patient's ailments with gradually increasing quantities of easily digestible food. To eliminate hatred and fulfill beneficial desires, use nimba leaves prepared in a specific way or through kaṭu-ohinya, kautaja, mūrvya, etc.

sloka: yathādoṣaṃ prakurvīta bhaiṣajyaṃ pāṇḍurogiṇām||123||  kriyāviśeṣa eṣo'sya mato hetuviśeṣataḥ|124|
translation: The wise physician should expel the ailment from the body by administering medicine, considering the special causes; he should give pure, fresh leaves of

sloka: tilapiṣṭanibhaṃ yastu varcaḥ sṛjati kāmalī||124|| śleṣmaṇā ruddhamārgaṃ tat pittaṃ kaphaharairjayet|  rūkṣaśītagurusvāduvyāyāmairveganigrahaiḥ||125||  kaphasammūrcchito vāyuḥ sthānāt pittaṃ kṣipedbalī|  hāridranetramūtratvak śvetavarcāstadā naraḥ||126||  bhavet sāṭopaviṣṭambho guruṇā hṛdayena ca|  daurbalyālpāgnipārśvārtihikkāśvāsārucijvaraiḥ||127||  krameṇālpe'nusajyeta [1] pitte śākhāsamāśrite|128|
translation:
In the same way that a medicine is applied to counteract a specific disorder in a patient suffering from white leprosy, so too should treatment be specifically applied to counteract the dosha (the bodily humor that is out of balance) as follows:

With regard to the kapha dosha (one of the three bodily humors, characterized by heaviness), one should apply:
- Astringent taste
- Lightness in diet
- Exercise
- Restraint in eating

If the vayu dosha is aggravated and located in its normal site, it should be counteracted with:
- Strengthening treatment
- Heavy diet
- Calm environment

One should gradually and progressively apply these treatments to counteract the imbalance of the doshas.

sloka: barhitittiridakṣāṇāṃ rūkṣāmlaiḥ kaṭukai rasaiḥ||128||  śuṣkamūlakakaulatthairyūṣaiścānnāni bhojayet|  mātuluṅgarasaṃ kṣaudrapippalīmaricānvitam||129||  sanāgaraṃ pibet pittaṃ tathā'syaiti svamāśayam|130|
translation: The one who consumes sesame seeds finely ground and mixed with liquids, which eliminate the channel blocked by mucus, and removes phlegm, bile, and wind, becomes a powerful person. By drinking salty water, one can pacify the bile; this also helps to remove any disturbance in the heart and strengthens the weakened appetite caused by thinness, cough, fever, dyspnea, fatigue, and hiccups.

sloka: kaṭutīkṣṇoṣṇalavaṇairbhṛśāmlaiścāpyupakramaḥ||130||  āpittarāgācchakṛto [1] vāyoścāpraśamādbhavet|  svasthānamāgate pitte purīṣe pittarañjite||131||  nivṛttopadravasya syāt pūrvaḥ kāmaliko vidhiḥ|132|
translation: For one suffering from ailments caused by unctuous, bitter, pungent, and dry foods, such as the hardened bile of the relatives of the peacock, should be fed with the powdered form of barley, long pepper, black pepper, dried ginger, pippali, and maricha mixed with warm water. Once this is digested, his own abode (of doshas) will be pacified, leading to the cessation of earlier desires.

sloka: yadā tu pāṇḍorvarṇaḥ syāddharitaśyāvapītakaḥ||132||  balotsāhakṣayastandrā mandrāgnitvaṃ mṛdujvaraḥ|  strīṣvaharṣo'ṅgamardaśca śvāsastṛṣṇā'rucirbhramaḥ||133||  halīmakaṃ tadā tasya vidyādanilapittataḥ|134|
translation: When the complexion of Pāṇḍu becomes free from harsh , piercing , hot , salty , excessively sour , pallor , and preliminary signs of sickness, and when there is an indication of the natural order of recovery from the ailment beforehand , then [that] is called halīmaka, which arises from the digestion process taking place in the stomach .

sloka: guḍūcīsvarasakṣīrasādhitaṃ māhiṣaṃ ghṛtam||134||  sa pibettrivṛtāṃ snigdho rasenāmalakasya tu|  virikto madhuraprāyaṃ bhajet pittānilāpaham||135||  drākṣālehaṃ ca pūrvoktaṃ sarpīṃṣi madhurāṇi ca|  yāpanān kṣīrabastīṃśca śīlayetsānuvāsanān||136||  mārdvīkāriṣṭayogāṃśca pibedyuktyā'gnivṛddhaye|  kāsikaṃ cābhayālehaṃ pippalīṃ madhukaṃ balām||137||  payasā ca prayuñjīta yathādoṣaṃ yathābalam|138|
translation: When the complexion of Pando's son becomes pale, yellowish, and loses strength, enthusiasm wanes, and there is decreased digestive fire, light fever, aversion to food, and unguided touch in the body, then one should understand that learning has been affected by an increase in phlegm and bile. In such a case, ghee cooked with guducI, mahIsa, sakSIIra, and sadhita should be given; it alleviates the increased phlegm and bile and eliminates the symptoms of learning loss. Similarly, when there is an increase in air and bile, one should give kAsika, abhayA, leha, pippalI, madhuka, and balA, and use payas to counteract the specific dosa and based on strength.

sloka: tatra ślokau  pāṇḍoḥ pañcavidhasyoktaṃ hetulakṣaṇabheṣajam||138||  kāmalā dvividhā teṣāṃ sādhyāsādhyatvameva ca|  teṣāṃ vikalpo yaścānyo mahāvyādhirhalīmakaḥ|  tasya coktaṃ samāsena vyañjanaṃ sacikitsitam||139||
translation: In that description of Pando's fivefold characteristics, a remedy for the symptoms is stated. There are two types of desires in them - achievable and unachievable. Any other great ailment or minor one is also mentioned, along with its brief explanation and proper treatment. Previously, it was said to use ghrita made from mahisha , sarpis and madhura substances such as draksha , amalaka , kasa , pippali , madhu , milk, and payasam . Use them wisely to increase digestive fire, strength, and to pacify vata, pitta, and kapha doshas. Additionally, one should eliminate the causes of impurities in srotas through virechana , svedana , basti , and udvartana . One should also eliminate the causes of impurities from sarira and manas by following a proper regimen, including wholesome diet, lifestyle, and habits.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite cikitsāsthāne  pāṇḍurogacikitsitaṃ nāma ṣoḍaśo'dhyāyaḥ||140||
translation: In the section of the scripture concerning the fire sacrifice, when powerful and stable treatment has been obtained, there are described five methods for treating pandu disease, named the "ṣoḍaśo'dhyāyaḥ" (sixteen chapters; referring to a specific text). These methods, consisting of two categories, along with their causes, symptoms, and medicines, exclude other severe diseases such as halīmaka.
